=encoding utf8

=head1 NAME

gcc - GNU project C and C++ compiler

=head1 SYNOPSIS

gcc [B<-c>|B<-S>|B<-E>] [B<-std=>I<standard>]
    [B<-g>] [B<-pg>] [B<-O>I<level>]
    [B<-W>I<warn>...] [B<-Wpedantic>]
    [B<-I>I<dir>...] [B<-L>I<dir>...]
    [B<-D>I<macro>[=I<defn>]...] [B<-U>I<macro>]
    [B<-f>I<option>...] [B<-m>I<machine-option>...]
    [B<-o> I<outfile>] [@I<file>] I<infile>...

ここに羅列されているのは最も重要なオプションのみです。他は下記を御覧ください。
B<g++> は概ね B<gcc> と同じオプションを受け付けます。

=head1 DESCRIPTION

GCC が呼び出されると、通常はプリプロセス、コンパイル、アセンブル、およびリンクが行われます。
「全体オプション」によって、この過程をある中間状態で止めることができます。
例えば、B<-c> オプションはリンカを走らせないように指示します。
この場合、出力はアセンブラにより出力されたオブジェクトファイルから成ります。


その他のオプションは処理過程の段階のうちのひとつかそれ以上に対して渡されます。
あるオプションはプリプロセッサを制御し、別のあるオプションはコンパイラ自体を制御します。
そしてまたあるオプションはアセンブラとリンカを制御しますが、それらの多くはここでは解説されていません。
なぜなら、それらのオプションが必要になることは滅多にないからです。

GCC で使えるコマンドラインオプションの多くは C プログラムに対して有用なものです。
あるオプションがその他の言語（多くの場合 C++）に対してのみ有用な場合は、そうであることを解説で明示します。
もしある特定のオプションについての解説がソース言語について触れていない場合、
そのオプションはすべてのサポートされた言語で用いることができます。

GCCを起動する通常の方法は、 B<gcc> という実行ファイルを起動することです。
但し、実行ファイル名はクロスコンパイルの際は I<machine>B<-gcc>、
特定のバージョンの GCC を起動したい場合は I<machine>B<-gcc->I<version> としてください。
C++ プログラムをコンパイルしたい場合は、代わりに B<g++> として呼び出してください。
C++ プログラムをコンパイルする際の B<gcc> と C<g++> の挙動の違いについては、
@xref{Invoking G++,,Compiling C++ Programs} を参照してください。

B<gcc> プログラムはオペランドとしてオプションとファイル名を受け付けます。
多くのオプションは複数文字から成ります。
故に、複数の一文字オプションをまとめてはI<いけません>。
B<-dv> は S<B<-d -v>> と全く違うものです。

オプションとその他の引数は混ぜることができます。
ほとんどの場合、順序は関係ありません。
順序が関係するのは、同種のオプションがいくつか使われたときです。
例えば、B<-L> を二度以上指定した場合、ディレクトリは指定された順に探索されます。
同様に、B<-l> オプションの位置も重要です。

多くのオプションが B<-f> や B<-W> から始まる名前を持っています。
例えば、B<-fmove-loop-invariants> や B<-Wformat> といったものです。
これらの多くには肯定形と否定形の両方があります。
B<-ffoo> の否定形は B<-fno-foo> です。
このマニュアルはこれら二つのうちの一つ、既定値でない方のみを解説します。

オプションによっては、一つまたは複数の引数を取ります。
これら引数は、典型的にはスペースか等号(B<=>)のどちらかによってオプション名と区切られます。
そうでないと書かれていない限り、引数は数値か文字列かのどちらかになり得ます。
数値引数は、典型的には十進または十六進の小さな符号無し整数でなくてはなりません。
十六進数の引数は B<0x> という接頭辞を付さなくてはなりません。
オプションへの引数の中でも何らかの大きさの閾値を指定するものには、
バイトサイズ接尾辞がついた任意に大きな十進または十六進の数値が許されます。
バイトサイズ接尾辞とはバイトの倍量を示すものであり、例えば
C<kB> と C<KiB> はそれぞれキロバイトとキビバイト、
C<MB> と C<MiB> はメガバイトとメビバイト、
C<GB> と C<GiB> はギガバイトとギビバイトを表します。
このような引数は以下の文章の中で I<byte-size> と示されます。
二進及び十進のバイトサイズ接尾辞の完全な表と説明は、米国国立標準技術研究所(NIST)、
国際電気標準会議(IEC)、及びその他の関係する国家規格と国際規格を参照してください。

=head2 出力の種類を制御するオプション


コンパイルは最高で4つの段階をもちます。
プリプロセス、厳密な意味でのコンパイル、アセンブル、リンクです。
これらは常にこの順序で行われます。
GCC はいくつかのファイルをファイルをプリプロセス、コンパイルした結果を
一つのアセンブラ入力ファイルとすることも、いくつかのアセンブラ入力ファイルとすることもできます。
その後、それぞれのアセンブラ入力ファイルはそれぞれ一つのオブジェクトファイルとなり、
リンクによってすべてのオブジェクトファイル（新たにコンパイルされたもの及び入力と指定されたもの）
が結合され、一つの実行ファイルとなります。

与えられたすべての入力ファイルについて、
ファイル名の接尾辞によってどのような種類のコンパイルを行うかが決定されます：


=over 4


=item I<file>B<.c>

プリプロセスされなければならない C のソースコード。


=item I<file>B<.i>

プリプロセスされてはならない C のソースコード。


=item I<file>B<.ii>

プリプロセスされてはならない C++ のソースコード。


=item I<file>B<.m>

Objective-C source code.  Note that you must link with the F<libobjc>
library to make an Objective-C program work.


=item I<file>B<.mi>

Objective-C source code that should not be preprocessed.


=item I<file>B<.mm>


=item I<file>B<.M>

Objective-C++ source code.  Note that you must link with the F<libobjc>
library to make an Objective-C++ program work.  Note that B<.M> refers
to a literal capital M.


=item I<file>B<.mii>

Objective-C++ source code that should not be preprocessed.


=item I<file>B<.h>

C, C++, Objective-C, ObjectiveC++ のヘッダファイルで、プリコンパイル済みヘッダに変換されるもの（既定値）。
または、C, C++ のヘッダファイルで、Ada spec に変換されるもの（B<-fdump-ada-spec> が指定されたとき）。


=item I<file>B<.cc>


=item I<file>B<.cp>


=item I<file>B<.cxx>


=item I<file>B<.cpp>

B<.cxx> の後ろ2文字は文字通り B<x> でなければならないことに注意。
同様に B<.C> は文字通り大文字の C であることを意味する。


=item I<file>B<.mm>

Objective-C++ source code that must be preprocessed.

Objective-C++ source code that should not be preprocessed.

プリコンパイル済みヘッダまたは Ada spec に変換される C++ ヘッダファイル。

Fixed form Fortran source code that should not be preprocessed.

Free form Fortran source code that should not be preprocessed.

You can specify the input language explicitly with the B<-x> option:


=over 4


=item B<-x> I<language>

Specify explicitly the I<language> for the following input files
(rather than letting the compiler choose a default based on the file
name suffix).  This option applies to all following input files until
the next B<-x> option.  Possible values for I<language> are:
	
	c  c-header  cpp-output
	c++  c++-header  c++-cpp-output
	objective-c  objective-c-header  objective-c-cpp-output
	objective-c++ objective-c++-header objective-c++-cpp-output
	assembler  assembler-with-cpp
	ada
	d
	f77  f77-cpp-input f95  f95-cpp-input
	go
	brig



=item B<-x none>

Turn off any specification of a language, so that subsequent files are
handled according to their file name suffixes (as they are if B<-x>
has not been used at all).

=back


If you only want some of the stages of compilation, you can use
B<-x> (or filename suffixes) to tell B<gcc> where to start, and
one of the options B<-c>, B<-S>, or B<-E> to say where
B<gcc> is to stop.  Note that some combinations (for example,
B<-x cpp-output -E>) instruct B<gcc> to do nothing at all.


=over 4


=item B<-c>

Compile or assemble the source files, but do not link.  The linking
stage simply is not done.  The ultimate output is in the form of an
object file for each source file.

By default, the object file name for a source file is made by replacing
the suffix B<.c>, B<.i>, B<.s>, etc., with B<.o>.

Unrecognized input files, not requiring compilation or assembly, are
ignored.


=item B<-S>

Stop after the stage of compilation proper; do not assemble.  The output
is in the form of an assembler code file for each non-assembler input
file specified.

By default, the assembler file name for a source file is made by
replacing the suffix B<.c>, B<.i>, etc., with B<.s>.

Input files that don't require compilation are ignored.


=item B<-E>

Stop after the preprocessing stage; do not run the compiler proper.  The
output is in the form of preprocessed source code, which is sent to the
standard output.

Input files that don't require preprocessing are ignored.


=item B<-o> I<file>

Place output in file I<file>.  This applies to whatever
sort of output is being produced, whether it be an executable file,
an object file, an assembler file or preprocessed C code.

If B<-o> is not specified, the default is to put an executable
file in F<a.out>, the object file for
F<I<source>.I<suffix>> in F<I<source>.o>, its
assembler file in F<I<source>.s>, a precompiled header file in
F<I<source>.I<suffix>.gch>, and all preprocessed C source on
standard output.


=item B<-v>

Print (on standard error output) the commands executed to run the stages
of compilation.  Also print the version number of the compiler driver
program and of the preprocessor and the compiler proper.


=item B<-###>

Like B<-v> except the commands are not executed and arguments
are quoted unless they contain only alphanumeric characters or C<./-_>.
This is useful for shell scripts to capture the driver-generated command lines.


=item B<--help>

Print (on the standard output) a description of the command-line options
understood by B<gcc>.  If the B<-v> option is also specified
then B<--help> is also passed on to the various processes
invoked by B<gcc>, so that they can display the command-line options
they accept.  If the B<-Wextra> option has also been specified
(prior to the B<--help> option), then command-line options that
have no documentation associated with them are also displayed.


=item B<--target-help>

Print (on the standard output) a description of target-specific command-line
options for each tool.  For some targets extra target-specific
information may also be printed.


=item B<--help={>I<class>|[B<^>]I<qualifier>B<}>[B<,...>]

Print (on the standard output) a description of the command-line
options understood by the compiler that fit into all specified classes
and qualifiers.  These are the supported classes:


=over 4


=item B<optimizers>

Display all of the optimization options supported by the
compiler.


=item B<warnings>

Display all of the options controlling warning messages
produced by the compiler.


=item B<target>

Display target-specific options.  Unlike the
B<--target-help> option however, target-specific options of the
linker and assembler are not displayed.  This is because those
tools do not currently support the extended B<--help=> syntax.


=item B<params>

Display the values recognized by the B<--param>
option.


=item I<language>

Display the options supported for I<language>, where
I<language> is the name of one of the languages supported in this
version of GCC.


=item B<common>

Display the options that are common to all languages.

=back


These are the supported qualifiers:


=over 4


=item B<undocumented>

Display only those options that are undocumented.


=item B<joined>

Display options taking an argument that appears after an equal
sign in the same continuous piece of text, such as:
B<--help=target>.


=item B<separate>

Display options taking an argument that appears as a separate word
following the original option, such as: B<-o output-file>.

=back


Thus for example to display all the undocumented target-specific
switches supported by the compiler, use:

	
	--help=target,undocumented


The sense of a qualifier can be inverted by prefixing it with the
B<^> character, so for example to display all binary warning
options (i.e., ones that are either on or off and that do not take an
argument) that have a description, use:

	
	--help=warnings,^joined,^undocumented


The argument to B<--help=> should not consist solely of inverted
qualifiers.

Combining several classes is possible, although this usually
restricts the output so much that there is nothing to display.  One
case where it does work, however, is when one of the classes is
I<target>.  For example, to display all the target-specific
optimization options, use:

	
	--help=target,optimizers


The B<--help=> option can be repeated on the command line.  Each
successive use displays its requested class of options, skipping
those that have already been displayed.  If B<--help> is also
specified anywhere on the command line then this takes precedence
over any B<--help=> option.

If the B<-Q> option appears on the command line before the
B<--help=> option, then the descriptive text displayed by
B<--help=> is changed.  Instead of describing the displayed
options, an indication is given as to whether the option is enabled,
disabled or set to a specific value (assuming that the compiler
knows this at the point where the B<--help=> option is used).

Here is a truncated example from the ARM port of B<gcc>:

	
	  % gcc -Q -mabi=2 --help=target -c
	  The following options are target specific:
	  -mabi=                                2
	  -mabort-on-noreturn                   [disabled]
	  -mapcs                                [disabled]


The output is sensitive to the effects of previous command-line
options, so for example it is possible to find out which optimizations
are enabled at B<-O2> by using:

	
	-Q -O2 --help=optimizers


Alternatively you can discover which binary optimizations are enabled
by B<-O3> by using:

	
	gcc -c -Q -O3 --help=optimizers > /tmp/O3-opts
	gcc -c -Q -O2 --help=optimizers > /tmp/O2-opts
	diff /tmp/O2-opts /tmp/O3-opts | grep enabled



=item B<--version>

Display the version number and copyrights of the invoked GCC.


=item B<-pass-exit-codes>

Normally the B<gcc> program exits with the code of 1 if any
phase of the compiler returns a non-success return code.  If you specify
B<-pass-exit-codes>, the B<gcc> program instead returns with
the numerically highest error produced by any phase returning an error
indication.  The C, C++, and Fortran front ends return 4 if an internal
compiler error is encountered.


=item B<-pipe>

Use pipes rather than temporary files for communication between the
various stages of compilation.  This fails to work on some systems where
the assembler is unable to read from a pipe; but the GNU assembler has
no trouble.


=item B<-specs=>I<file>

Process I<file> after the compiler reads in the standard F<specs>
file, in order to override the defaults which the B<gcc> driver
program uses when determining what switches to pass to B<cc1>,
B<cc1plus>, B<as>, B<ld>, etc.  More than one
B<-specs=>I<file> can be specified on the command line, and they
are processed in order, from left to right.  


=item B<-wrapper>

Invoke all subcommands under a wrapper program.  The name of the
wrapper program and its parameters are passed as a comma separated
list.

	
	gcc -c t.c -wrapper gdb,--args


This invokes all subprograms of B<gcc> under
B<gdb --args>, thus the invocation of B<cc1> is
B<gdb --args cc1 ...>.


=item B<-ffile-prefix-map=>I<old>B<=>I<new>

When compiling files residing in directory F<I<old>>, record
any references to them in the result of the compilation as if the
files resided in directory F<I<new>> instead.  Specifying this
option is equivalent to specifying all the individual
B<-f*-prefix-map> options.  This can be used to make reproducible
builds that are location independent.  See also
B<-fmacro-prefix-map> and B<-fdebug-prefix-map>.


=item B<-fplugin=>I<name>B<.so>

Load the plugin code in file I<name>.so, assumed to be a
shared object to be dlopen'd by the compiler.  The base name of
the shared object file is used to identify the plugin for the
purposes of argument parsing (See
B<-fplugin-arg->I<name>B<->I<key>B<=>I<value> below).
Each plugin should define the callback functions specified in the
Plugins API.


=item B<-fplugin-arg->I<name>B<->I<key>B<=>I<value>

Define an argument called I<key> with a value of I<value>
for the plugin called I<name>.


=item B<-fdump-ada-spec>[B<-slim>]

For C and C++ source and include files, generate corresponding Ada specs.



=item B<-fada-spec-parent=>I<unit>

In conjunction with B<-fdump-ada-spec>[B<-slim>] above, generate
Ada specs as child units of parent I<unit>.


=item B<-fdump-go-spec=>I<file>

For input files in any language, generate corresponding Go
declarations in I<file>.  This generates Go C<const>,
C<type>, C<var>, and C<func> declarations which may be a
useful way to start writing a Go interface to code written in some
other language.



=item B<@>I<file>

Read command-line options from I<file>.  The options read are
inserted in place of the original @I<file> option.  If I<file>
does not exist, or cannot be read, then the option will be treated
literally, and not removed.  

Options in I<file> are separated by whitespace.  A whitespace
character may be included in an option by surrounding the entire
option in either single or double quotes.  Any character (including a
backslash) may be included by prefixing the character to be included
with a backslash.  The I<file> may itself contain additional
@I<file> options; any such options will be processed recursively.

=back



=head2 Compiling C++ Programs


C++ source files conventionally use one of the suffixes B<.C>,
B<.cc>, B<.cpp>, B<.CPP>, B<.c++>, B<.cp>, or
B<.cxx>; C++ header files often use B<.hh>, B<.hpp>,
B<.H>, or (for shared template code) B<.tcc>; and
preprocessed C++ files use the suffix B<.ii>.  GCC recognizes
files with these names and compiles them as C++ programs even if you
call the compiler the same way as for compiling C programs (usually
with the name B<gcc>).

However, the use of B<gcc> does not add the C++ library.
B<g++> is a program that calls GCC and automatically specifies linking
against the C++ library.  It treats B<.c>,
B<.h> and B<.i> files as C++ source files instead of C source
files unless B<-x> is used.  This program is also useful when
precompiling a C header file with a B<.h> extension for use in C++
compilations.  On many systems, B<g++> is also installed with
the name B<c++>.

When you compile C++ programs, you may specify many of the same
command-line options that you use for compiling programs in any
language; or command-line options meaningful for C and related
languages; or options that are meaningful only for C++ programs.




=head2 Options Controlling C Dialect


The following options control the dialect of C (or languages derived
from C, such as C++, Objective-C and Objective-C++) that the compiler
accepts:


=over 4


=item B<-ansi>

In C mode, this is equivalent to B<-std=c90>. In C++ mode, it is
equivalent to B<-std=c++98>.

This turns off certain features of GCC that are incompatible with ISO
C90 (when compiling C code), or of standard C++ (when compiling C++ code),
such as the C<asm> and C<typeof> keywords, and
predefined macros such as C<unix> and C<vax> that identify the
type of system you are using.  It also enables the undesirable and
rarely used ISO trigraph feature.  For the C compiler,
it disables recognition of C++ style B<//> comments as well as
the C<inline> keyword.

The alternate keywords C<__asm__>, C<__extension__>,
C<__inline__> and C<__typeof__> continue to work despite
B<-ansi>.  You would not want to use them in an ISO C program, of
course, but it is useful to put them in header files that might be included
in compilations done with B<-ansi>.  Alternate predefined macros
such as C<__unix__> and C<__vax__> are also available, with or
without B<-ansi>.

The B<-ansi> option does not cause non-ISO programs to be
rejected gratuitously.  For that, B<-Wpedantic> is required in
addition to B<-ansi>.  

The macro C<__STRICT_ANSI__> is predefined when the B<-ansi>
option is used.  Some header files may notice this macro and refrain
from declaring certain functions or defining certain macros that the
ISO standard doesn't call for; this is to avoid interfering with any
programs that might use these names for other things.

Functions that are normally built in but do not have semantics
defined by ISO C (such as C<alloca> and C<ffs>) are not built-in
functions when B<-ansi> is used.  


=item B<-std=>

Determine the language standard.   This option
is currently only supported when compiling C or C++.

The compiler can accept several base standards, such as B<c90> or
B<c++98>, and GNU dialects of those standards, such as
B<gnu90> or B<gnu++98>.  When a base standard is specified, the
compiler accepts all programs following that standard plus those
using GNU extensions that do not contradict it.  For example,
B<-std=c90> turns off certain features of GCC that are
incompatible with ISO C90, such as the C<asm> and C<typeof>
keywords, but not other GNU extensions that do not have a meaning in
ISO C90, such as omitting the middle term of a C<?:>
expression. On the other hand, when a GNU dialect of a standard is
specified, all features supported by the compiler are enabled, even when
those features change the meaning of the base standard.  As a result, some
strict-conforming programs may be rejected.  The particular standard
is used by B<-Wpedantic> to identify which features are GNU
extensions given that version of the standard. For example
B<-std=gnu90 -Wpedantic> warns about C++ style B<//>
comments, while B<-std=gnu99 -Wpedantic> does not.

A value for this option must be provided; possible values are


=over 4


=item B<c90>


=item B<c89>


=item B<iso9899:1990>

Support all ISO C90 programs (certain GNU extensions that conflict
with ISO C90 are disabled). Same as B<-ansi> for C code.


=item B<iso9899:199409>

ISO C90 as modified in amendment 1.


=item B<c99>


=item B<c9x>


=item B<iso9899:1999>


=item B<iso9899:199x>

ISO C99.  This standard is substantially completely supported, modulo
bugs and floating-point issues
(mainly but not entirely relating to optional C99 features from
Annexes F and G).  See
S<E<lt>B<http://gcc.gnu.org/c99status.html>>E<gt> for more information.  The
names B<c9x> and B<iso9899:199x> are deprecated.


=item B<c11>


=item B<c1x>


=item B<iso9899:2011>

ISO C11, the 2011 revision of the ISO C standard.  This standard is
substantially completely supported, modulo bugs, floating-point issues
(mainly but not entirely relating to optional C11 features from
Annexes F and G) and the optional Annexes K (Bounds-checking
interfaces) and L (Analyzability).  The name B<c1x> is deprecated.


=item B<c17>


=item B<c18>


=item B<iso9899:2017>


=item B<iso9899:2018>

ISO C17, the 2017 revision of the ISO C standard
(published in 2018).  This standard is
same as C11 except for corrections of defects (all of which are also
applied with B<-std=c11>) and a new value of
C<__STDC_VERSION__>, and so is supported to the same extent as C11.


=item B<c2x>

The next version of the ISO C standard, still under development.  The
support for this version is experimental and incomplete.


=item B<gnu90>


=item B<gnu89>

GNU dialect of ISO C90 (including some C99 features).


=item B<gnu99>


=item B<gnu9x>

GNU dialect of ISO C99.  The name B<gnu9x> is deprecated.


=item B<gnu11>


=item B<gnu1x>

GNU dialect of ISO C11.
The name B<gnu1x> is deprecated.


=item B<gnu17>


=item B<gnu18>

GNU dialect of ISO C17.  This is the default for C code.


=item B<gnu2x>

The next version of the ISO C standard, still under development, plus
GNU extensions.  The support for this version is experimental and
incomplete.


=item B<c++98>


=item B<c++03>

The 1998 ISO C++ standard plus the 2003 technical corrigendum and some
additional defect reports. Same as B<-ansi> for C++ code.


=item B<gnu++98>


=item B<gnu++03>

GNU dialect of B<-std=c++98>.


=item B<c++11>


=item B<c++0x>

The 2011 ISO C++ standard plus amendments.
The name B<c++0x> is deprecated.


=item B<gnu++11>


=item B<gnu++0x>

GNU dialect of B<-std=c++11>.
The name B<gnu++0x> is deprecated.


=item B<c++14>


=item B<c++1y>

The 2014 ISO C++ standard plus amendments.
The name B<c++1y> is deprecated.


=item B<gnu++14>


=item B<gnu++1y>

GNU dialect of B<-std=c++14>.
This is the default for C++ code.
The name B<gnu++1y> is deprecated.


=item B<c++17>


=item B<c++1z>

The 2017 ISO C++ standard plus amendments.
The name B<c++1z> is deprecated.


=item B<gnu++17>


=item B<gnu++1z>

GNU dialect of B<-std=c++17>.
The name B<gnu++1z> is deprecated.


=item B<c++2a>

The next revision of the ISO C++ standard, tentatively planned for
2020.  Support is highly experimental, and will almost certainly
change in incompatible ways in future releases.


=item B<gnu++2a>

GNU dialect of B<-std=c++2a>.  Support is highly experimental,
and will almost certainly change in incompatible ways in future
releases.

=back



=item B<-fgnu89-inline>

The option B<-fgnu89-inline> tells GCC to use the traditional
GNU semantics for C<inline> functions when in C99 mode.

Using this option is roughly equivalent to adding the
C<gnu_inline> function attribute to all inline functions.

The option B<-fno-gnu89-inline> explicitly tells GCC to use the
C99 semantics for C<inline> when in C99 or gnu99 mode (i.e., it
specifies the default behavior).
This option is not supported in B<-std=c90> or
B<-std=gnu90> mode.

The preprocessor macros C<__GNUC_GNU_INLINE__> and
C<__GNUC_STDC_INLINE__> may be used to check which semantics are
in effect for C<inline> functions.  


=item B<-fpermitted-flt-eval-methods=>I<style>

ISO/IEC TS 18661-3 defines new permissible values for
C<FLT_EVAL_METHOD> that indicate that operations and constants with
a semantic type that is an interchange or extended format should be
evaluated to the precision and range of that type.  These new values are
a superset of those permitted under C99/C11, which does not specify the
meaning of other positive values of C<FLT_EVAL_METHOD>.  As such, code
conforming to C11 may not have been written expecting the possibility of
the new values.

B<-fpermitted-flt-eval-methods> specifies whether the compiler
should allow only the values of C<FLT_EVAL_METHOD> specified in C99/C11,
or the extended set of values specified in ISO/IEC TS 18661-3.

I<style> is either C<c11> or C<ts-18661-3> as appropriate.

The default when in a standards compliant mode (B<-std=c11> or similar)
is B<-fpermitted-flt-eval-methods=c11>.  The default when in a GNU
dialect (B<-std=gnu11> or similar) is
B<-fpermitted-flt-eval-methods=ts-18661-3>.


=item B<-aux-info> I<filename>

Output to the given filename prototyped declarations for all functions
declared and/or defined in a translation unit, including those in header
files.  This option is silently ignored in any language other than C.

Besides declarations, the file indicates, in comments, the origin of
each declaration (source file and line), whether the declaration was
implicit, prototyped or unprototyped (B<I>, B<N> for new or
B<O> for old, respectively, in the first character after the line
number and the colon), and whether it came from a declaration or a
definition (B<C> or B<F>, respectively, in the following
character).  In the case of function definitions, a K&R-style list of
arguments followed by their declarations is also provided, inside
comments, after the declaration.


=item B<-fallow-parameterless-variadic-functions>

Accept variadic functions without named parameters.

Although it is possible to define such a function, this is not very
useful as it is not possible to read the arguments.  This is only
supported for C as this construct is allowed by C++.


=item B<-fno-asm>

Do not recognize C<asm>, C<inline> or C<typeof> as a
keyword, so that code can use these words as identifiers.  You can use
the keywords C<__asm__>, C<__inline__> and C<__typeof__>
instead.  B<-ansi> implies B<-fno-asm>.

In C++, this switch only affects the C<typeof> keyword, since
C<asm> and C<inline> are standard keywords.  You may want to
use the B<-fno-gnu-keywords> flag instead, which has the same
effect.  In C99 mode (B<-std=c99> or B<-std=gnu99>), this
switch only affects the C<asm> and C<typeof> keywords, since
C<inline> is a standard keyword in ISO C99.


=item B<-fno-builtin>


=item B<-fno-builtin->I<function>

Don't recognize built-in functions that do not begin with
B<__builtin_> as prefix.  

GCC normally generates special code to handle certain built-in functions
more efficiently; for instance, calls to C<alloca> may become single
instructions which adjust the stack directly, and calls to C<memcpy>
may become inline copy loops.  The resulting code is often both smaller
and faster, but since the function calls no longer appear as such, you
cannot set a breakpoint on those calls, nor can you change the behavior
of the functions by linking with a different library.  In addition,
when a function is recognized as a built-in function, GCC may use
information about that function to warn about problems with calls to
that function, or to generate more efficient code, even if the
resulting code still contains calls to that function.  For example,
warnings are given with B<-Wformat> for bad calls to
C<printf> when C<printf> is built in and C<strlen> is
known not to modify global memory.

With the B<-fno-builtin->I<function> option
only the built-in function I<function> is
disabled.  I<function> must not begin with B<__builtin_>.  If a
function is named that is not built-in in this version of GCC, this
option is ignored.  There is no corresponding
B<-fbuiltin->I<function> option; if you wish to enable
built-in functions selectively when using B<-fno-builtin> or
B<-ffreestanding>, you may define macros such as:

	
	#define abs(n)          __builtin_abs ((n))
	#define strcpy(d, s)    __builtin_strcpy ((d), (s))



=item B<-fgimple>


Enable parsing of function definitions marked with C<__GIMPLE>.
This is an experimental feature that allows unit testing of GIMPLE
passes.


=item B<-fhosted>


Assert that compilation targets a hosted environment.  This implies
B<-fbuiltin>.  A hosted environment is one in which the
entire standard library is available, and in which C<main> has a return
type of C<int>.  Examples are nearly everything except a kernel.
This is equivalent to B<-fno-freestanding>.


=item B<-ffreestanding>


Assert that compilation targets a freestanding environment.  This
implies B<-fno-builtin>.  A freestanding environment
is one in which the standard library may not exist, and program startup may
not necessarily be at C<main>.  The most obvious example is an OS kernel.
This is equivalent to B<-fno-hosted>.




=item B<-fopenacc>

Enable handling of OpenACC directives C<#pragma acc> in C/C++ and
C<!$acc> in Fortran.  When B<-fopenacc> is specified, the
compiler generates accelerated code according to the OpenACC Application
Programming Interface v2.0 S<E<lt>B<https://www.openacc.org>>E<gt>.  This option
implies B<-pthread>, and thus is only supported on targets that
have support for B<-pthread>.


=item B<-fopenacc-dim=>I<geom>

Specify default compute dimensions for parallel offload regions that do
not explicitly specify.  The I<geom> value is a triple of
':'-separated sizes, in order 'gang', 'worker' and, 'vector'.  A size
can be omitted, to use a target-specific default value.


=item B<-fopenmp>

Enable handling of OpenMP directives C<#pragma omp> in C/C++ and
C<!$omp> in Fortran.  When B<-fopenmp> is specified, the
compiler generates parallel code according to the OpenMP Application
Program Interface v4.5 S<E<lt>B<https://www.openmp.org>>E<gt>.  This option
implies B<-pthread>, and thus is only supported on targets that
have support for B<-pthread>. B<-fopenmp> implies
B<-fopenmp-simd>.


=item B<-fopenmp-simd>

Enable handling of OpenMP's SIMD directives with C<#pragma omp>
in C/C++ and C<!$omp> in Fortran. Other OpenMP directives
are ignored.


=item B<-fgnu-tm>

When the option B<-fgnu-tm> is specified, the compiler
generates code for the Linux variant of Intel's current Transactional
Memory ABI specification document (Revision 1.1, May 6 2009).  This is
an experimental feature whose interface may change in future versions
of GCC, as the official specification changes.  Please note that not
all architectures are supported for this feature.

For more information on GCC's support for transactional memory,


Note that the transactional memory feature is not supported with
non-call exceptions (B<-fnon-call-exceptions>).


=item B<-fms-extensions>

Accept some non-standard constructs used in Microsoft header files.

In C++ code, this allows member names in structures to be similar
to previous types declarations.

	
	typedef int UOW;
	struct ABC {
	  UOW UOW;
	};


Some cases of unnamed fields in structures and unions are only
accepted with this option.  

Note that this option is off for all targets but x86 
targets using ms-abi.


=item B<-fplan9-extensions>

Accept some non-standard constructs used in Plan 9 code.

This enables B<-fms-extensions>, permits passing pointers to
structures with anonymous fields to functions that expect pointers to
elements of the type of the field, and permits referring to anonymous
fields declared using a typedef.    This is only
supported for C, not C++.


=item B<-fcond-mismatch>

Allow conditional expressions with mismatched types in the second and
third arguments.  The value of such an expression is void.  This option
is not supported for C++.


=item B<-flax-vector-conversions>

Allow implicit conversions between vectors with differing numbers of
elements and/or incompatible element types.  This option should not be
used for new code.


=item B<-funsigned-char>

Let the type C<char> be unsigned, like C<unsigned char>.

Each kind of machine has a default for what C<char> should
be.  It is either like C<unsigned char> by default or like
C<signed char> by default.

Ideally, a portable program should always use C<signed char> or
C<unsigned char> when it depends on the signedness of an object.
But many programs have been written to use plain C<char> and
expect it to be signed, or expect it to be unsigned, depending on the
machines they were written for.  This option, and its inverse, let you
make such a program work with the opposite default.

The type C<char> is always a distinct type from each of
C<signed char> or C<unsigned char>, even though its behavior
is always just like one of those two.


=item B<-fsigned-char>

Let the type C<char> be signed, like C<signed char>.

Note that this is equivalent to B<-fno-unsigned-char>, which is
the negative form of B<-funsigned-char>.  Likewise, the option
B<-fno-signed-char> is equivalent to B<-funsigned-char>.


=item B<-fsigned-bitfields>


=item B<-funsigned-bitfields>


=item B<-fno-signed-bitfields>


=item B<-fno-unsigned-bitfields>

These options control whether a bit-field is signed or unsigned, when the
declaration does not use either C<signed> or C<unsigned>.  By
default, such a bit-field is signed, because this is consistent: the
basic integer types such as C<int> are signed types.


=item B<-fsso-struct=>I<endianness>

Set the default scalar storage order of structures and unions to the
specified endianness.  The accepted values are B<big-endian>,
B<little-endian> and B<native> for the native endianness of
the target (the default).  This option is not supported for C++.

B<Warning:> the B<-fsso-struct> switch causes GCC to generate
code that is not binary compatible with code generated without it if the
specified endianness is not the native endianness of the target.

=back



=head2 Options Controlling C++ Dialect


This section describes the command-line options that are only meaningful
for C++ programs.  You can also use most of the GNU compiler options
regardless of what language your program is in.  For example, you
might compile a file F<firstClass.C> like this:

	
	g++ -g -fstrict-enums -O -c firstClass.C


In this example, only B<-fstrict-enums> is an option meant
only for C++ programs; you can use the other options with any
language supported by GCC.

Some options for compiling C programs, such as B<-std>, are also
relevant for C++ programs.


Here is a list of options that are I<only> for compiling C++ programs:


=over 4



=item B<-fabi-version=>I<n>

Use version I<n> of the C++ ABI.  The default is version 0.

Version 0 refers to the version conforming most closely to
the C++ ABI specification.  Therefore, the ABI obtained using version 0
will change in different versions of G++ as ABI bugs are fixed.

Version 1 is the version of the C++ ABI that first appeared in G++ 3.2.

Version 2 is the version of the C++ ABI that first appeared in G++
3.4, and was the default through G++ 4.9.

Version 3 corrects an error in mangling a constant address as a
template argument.

Version 4, which first appeared in G++ 4.5, implements a standard
mangling for vector types.

Version 5, which first appeared in G++ 4.6, corrects the mangling of
attribute const/volatile on function pointer types, decltype of a
plain decl, and use of a function parameter in the declaration of
another parameter.

Version 6, which first appeared in G++ 4.7, corrects the promotion
behavior of C++11 scoped enums and the mangling of template argument
packs, const/static_cast, prefix ++ and --, and a class scope function
used as a template argument.

Version 7, which first appeared in G++ 4.8, that treats nullptr_t as a
builtin type and corrects the mangling of lambdas in default argument
scope.

Version 8, which first appeared in G++ 4.9, corrects the substitution
behavior of function types with function-cv-qualifiers.

Version 9, which first appeared in G++ 5.2, corrects the alignment of
C<nullptr_t>.

Version 10, which first appeared in G++ 6.1, adds mangling of
attributes that affect type identity, such as ia32 calling convention
attributes (e.g. B<stdcall>).

Version 11, which first appeared in G++ 7, corrects the mangling of
sizeof... expressions and operator names.  For multiple entities with
the same name within a function, that are declared in different scopes,
the mangling now changes starting with the twelfth occurrence.  It also
implies B<-fnew-inheriting-ctors>.

Version 12, which first appeared in G++ 8, corrects the calling
conventions for empty classes on the x86_64 target and for classes
with only deleted copy/move constructors.  It accidentally changes the
calling convention for classes with a deleted copy constructor and a
trivial move constructor.

Version 13, which first appeared in G++ 8.2, fixes the accidental
change in version 12.

See also B<-Wabi>.


=item B<-fabi-compat-version=>I<n>

On targets that support strong aliases, G++
works around mangling changes by creating an alias with the correct
mangled name when defining a symbol with an incorrect mangled name.
This switch specifies which ABI version to use for the alias.

With B<-fabi-version=0> (the default), this defaults to 11 (GCC 7
compatibility).  If another ABI version is explicitly selected, this
defaults to 0.  For compatibility with GCC versions 3.2 through 4.9,
use B<-fabi-compat-version=2>.

If this option is not provided but B<-Wabi=>I<n> is, that
version is used for compatibility aliases.  If this option is provided
along with B<-Wabi> (without the version), the version from this
option is used for the warning.


=item B<-fno-access-control>

Turn off all access checking.  This switch is mainly useful for working
around bugs in the access control code.


=item B<-faligned-new>

Enable support for C++17 C<new> of types that require more
alignment than C<void* ::operator new(std::size_t)> provides.  A
numeric argument such as C<-faligned-new=32> can be used to
specify how much alignment (in bytes) is provided by that function,
but few users will need to override the default of
C<alignof(std::max_align_t)>.

This flag is enabled by default for B<-std=c++17>.


=item B<-fchar8_t>


=item B<-fno-char8_t>

Enable support for C<char8_t> as adopted for C++2a.  This includes
the addition of a new C<char8_t> fundamental type, changes to the
types of UTF-8 string and character literals, new signatures for
user-defined literals, associated standard library updates, and new
C<__cpp_char8_t> and C<__cpp_lib_char8_t> feature test macros.

This option enables functions to be overloaded for ordinary and UTF-8
strings:

	
	int f(const char *);    // #1
	int f(const char8_t *); // #2
	int v1 = f("text");     // Calls #1
	int v2 = f(u8"text");   // Calls #2


and introduces new signatures for user-defined literals:

	
	int operator""_udl1(char8_t);
	int v3 = u8'x'_udl1;
	int operator""_udl2(const char8_t*, std::size_t);
	int v4 = u8"text"_udl2;
	template<typename T, T...> int operator""_udl3();
	int v5 = u8"text"_udl3;


The change to the types of UTF-8 string and character literals introduces
incompatibilities with ISO C++11 and later standards.  For example, the
following code is well-formed under ISO C++11, but is ill-formed when
B<-fchar8_t> is specified.

	
	char ca[] = u8"xx";     // error: char-array initialized from wide
	                        //        string
	const char *cp = u8"xx";// error: invalid conversion from
	                        //        `const char8_t*' to `const char*'
	int f(const char*);
	auto v = f(u8"xx");     // error: invalid conversion from
	                        //        `const char8_t*' to `const char*'
	std::string s{u8"xx"};  // error: no matching function for call to
	                        //        `std::basic_string<char>::basic_string()'
	using namespace std::literals;
	s = u8"xx"s;            // error: conversion from
	                        //        `basic_string<char8_t>' to non-scalar
	                        //        type `basic_string<char>' requested



=item B<-fcheck-new>

Check that the pointer returned by C<operator new> is non-null
before attempting to modify the storage allocated.  This check is
normally unnecessary because the C++ standard specifies that
C<operator new> only returns C<0> if it is declared
C<throw()>, in which case the compiler always checks the
return value even without this option.  In all other cases, when
C<operator new> has a non-empty exception specification, memory
exhaustion is signalled by throwing C<std::bad_alloc>.  See also
B<new (nothrow)>.


=item B<-fconcepts>

Enable support for the C++ Extensions for Concepts Technical
Specification, ISO 19217 (2015), which allows code like

	
	template <class T> concept bool Addable = requires (T t) { t + t; };
	template <Addable T> T add (T a, T b) { return a + b; }



=item B<-fconstexpr-depth=>I<n>

Set the maximum nested evaluation depth for C++11 constexpr functions
to I<n>.  A limit is needed to detect endless recursion during
constant expression evaluation.  The minimum specified by the standard
is 512.


=item B<-fconstexpr-loop-limit=>I<n>

Set the maximum number of iterations for a loop in C++14 constexpr functions
to I<n>.  A limit is needed to detect infinite loops during
constant expression evaluation.  The default is 262144 (1E<lt>E<lt>18).


=item B<-fconstexpr-ops-limit=>I<n>

Set the maximum number of operations during a single constexpr evaluation.
Even when number of iterations of a single loop is limited with the above limit,
if there are several nested loops and each of them has many iterations but still
smaller than the above limit, or if in a body of some loop or even outside
of a loop too many expressions need to be evaluated, the resulting constexpr
evaluation might take too long.
The default is 33554432 (1E<lt>E<lt>25).


=item B<-fdeduce-init-list>

Enable deduction of a template type parameter as
C<std::initializer_list> from a brace-enclosed initializer list, i.e.

	
	template <class T> auto forward(T t) -> decltype (realfn (t))
	{
	  return realfn (t);
	}
	
	void f()
	{
	  forward({1,2}); // call forward<std::initializer_list<int>>
	}


This deduction was implemented as a possible extension to the
originally proposed semantics for the C++11 standard, but was not part
of the final standard, so it is disabled by default.  This option is
deprecated, and may be removed in a future version of G++.


=item B<-fno-elide-constructors>

The C++ standard allows an implementation to omit creating a temporary
that is only used to initialize another object of the same type.
Specifying this option disables that optimization, and forces G++ to
call the copy constructor in all cases.  This option also causes G++
to call trivial member functions which otherwise would be expanded inline.

In C++17, the compiler is required to omit these temporaries, but this
option still affects trivial member functions.


=item B<-fno-enforce-eh-specs>

Don't generate code to check for violation of exception specifications
at run time.  This option violates the C++ standard, but may be useful
for reducing code size in production builds, much like defining
C<NDEBUG>.  This does not give user code permission to throw
exceptions in violation of the exception specifications; the compiler
still optimizes based on the specifications, so throwing an
unexpected exception results in undefined behavior at run time.


=item B<-fextern-tls-init>


=item B<-fno-extern-tls-init>

The C++11 and OpenMP standards allow C<thread_local> and
C<threadprivate> variables to have dynamic (runtime)
initialization.  To support this, any use of such a variable goes
through a wrapper function that performs any necessary initialization.
When the use and definition of the variable are in the same
translation unit, this overhead can be optimized away, but when the
use is in a different translation unit there is significant overhead
even if the variable doesn't actually need dynamic initialization.  If
the programmer can be sure that no use of the variable in a
non-defining TU needs to trigger dynamic initialization (either
because the variable is statically initialized, or a use of the
variable in the defining TU will be executed before any uses in
another TU), they can avoid this overhead with the
B<-fno-extern-tls-init> option.

On targets that support symbol aliases, the default is
B<-fextern-tls-init>.  On targets that do not support symbol
aliases, the default is B<-fno-extern-tls-init>.


=item B<-fno-gnu-keywords>

Do not recognize C<typeof> as a keyword, so that code can use this
word as an identifier.  You can use the keyword C<__typeof__> instead.
This option is implied by the strict ISO C++ dialects: B<-ansi>,
B<-std=c++98>, B<-std=c++11>, etc.


=item B<-fno-implicit-templates>

Never emit code for non-inline templates that are instantiated
implicitly (i.e. by use); only emit code for explicit instantiations.
If you use this option, you must take care to structure your code to
include all the necessary explicit instantiations to avoid getting
undefined symbols at link time.



=item B<-fno-implicit-inline-templates>

Don't emit code for implicit instantiations of inline templates, either.
The default is to handle inlines differently so that compiles with and
without optimization need the same set of explicit instantiations.


=item B<-fno-implement-inlines>

To save space, do not emit out-of-line copies of inline functions
controlled by C<#pragma implementation>.  This causes linker
errors if these functions are not inlined everywhere they are called.


=item B<-fms-extensions>

Disable Wpedantic warnings about constructs used in MFC, such as implicit
int and getting a pointer to member function via non-standard syntax.


=item B<-fnew-inheriting-ctors>

Enable the P0136 adjustment to the semantics of C++11 constructor
inheritance.  This is part of C++17 but also considered to be a Defect
Report against C++11 and C++14.  This flag is enabled by default
unless B<-fabi-version=10> or lower is specified.


=item B<-fnew-ttp-matching>

Enable the P0522 resolution to Core issue 150, template template
parameters and default arguments: this allows a template with default
template arguments as an argument for a template template parameter
with fewer template parameters.  This flag is enabled by default for
B<-std=c++17>.


=item B<-fno-nonansi-builtins>

Disable built-in declarations of functions that are not mandated by
ANSI/ISO C.  These include C<ffs>, C<alloca>, C<_exit>,
C<index>, C<bzero>, C<conjf>, and other related functions.


=item B<-fnothrow-opt>

Treat a C<throw()> exception specification as if it were a
C<noexcept> specification to reduce or eliminate the text size
overhead relative to a function with no exception specification.  If
the function has local variables of types with non-trivial
destructors, the exception specification actually makes the
function smaller because the EH cleanups for those variables can be
optimized away.  The semantic effect is that an exception thrown out of
a function with such an exception specification results in a call
to C<terminate> rather than C<unexpected>.


=item B<-fno-operator-names>

Do not treat the operator name keywords C<and>, C<bitand>,
C<bitor>, C<compl>, C<not>, C<or> and C<xor> as
synonyms as keywords.


=item B<-fno-optional-diags>

Disable diagnostics that the standard says a compiler does not need to
issue.  Currently, the only such diagnostic issued by G++ is the one for
a name having multiple meanings within a class.


=item B<-fpermissive>

Downgrade some diagnostics about nonconformant code from errors to
warnings.  Thus, using B<-fpermissive> allows some
nonconforming code to compile.


=item B<-fno-pretty-templates>

When an error message refers to a specialization of a function
template, the compiler normally prints the signature of the
template followed by the template arguments and any typedefs or
typenames in the signature (e.g. C<void f(T) [with T = int]>
rather than C<void f(int)>) so that it's clear which template is
involved.  When an error message refers to a specialization of a class
template, the compiler omits any template arguments that match
the default template arguments for that template.  If either of these
behaviors make it harder to understand the error message rather than
easier, you can use B<-fno-pretty-templates> to disable them.


=item B<-frepo>

Enable automatic template instantiation at link time.  This option also
implies B<-fno-implicit-templates>.  


=item B<-fno-rtti>

Disable generation of information about every class with virtual
functions for use by the C++ run-time type identification features
(C<dynamic_cast> and C<typeid>).  If you don't use those parts
of the language, you can save some space by using this flag.  Note that
exception handling uses the same information, but G++ generates it as
needed. The C<dynamic_cast> operator can still be used for casts that
do not require run-time type information, i.e. casts to C<void *> or to
unambiguous base classes.

Mixing code compiled with B<-frtti> with that compiled with
B<-fno-rtti> may not work.  For example, programs may
fail to link if a class compiled with B<-fno-rtti> is used as a base 
for a class compiled with B<-frtti>.  


=item B<-fsized-deallocation>

Enable the built-in global declarations
	
	void operator delete (void *, std::size_t) noexcept;
	void operator delete[] (void *, std::size_t) noexcept;

as introduced in C++14.  This is useful for user-defined replacement
deallocation functions that, for example, use the size of the object
to make deallocation faster.  Enabled by default under
B<-std=c++14> and above.  The flag B<-Wsized-deallocation>
warns about places that might want to add a definition.


=item B<-fstrict-enums>

Allow the compiler to optimize using the assumption that a value of
enumerated type can only be one of the values of the enumeration (as
defined in the C++ standard; basically, a value that can be
represented in the minimum number of bits needed to represent all the
enumerators).  This assumption may not be valid if the program uses a
cast to convert an arbitrary integer value to the enumerated type.


=item B<-fstrong-eval-order>

Evaluate member access, array subscripting, and shift expressions in
left-to-right order, and evaluate assignment in right-to-left order,
as adopted for C++17.  Enabled by default with B<-std=c++17>.
B<-fstrong-eval-order=some> enables just the ordering of member
access and shift expressions, and is the default without
B<-std=c++17>.


=item B<-ftemplate-backtrace-limit=>I<n>

Set the maximum number of template instantiation notes for a single
warning or error to I<n>.  The default value is 10.


=item B<-ftemplate-depth=>I<n>

Set the maximum instantiation depth for template classes to I<n>.
A limit on the template instantiation depth is needed to detect
endless recursions during template class instantiation.  ANSI/ISO C++
conforming programs must not rely on a maximum depth greater than 17
(changed to 1024 in C++11).  The default value is 900, as the compiler
can run out of stack space before hitting 1024 in some situations.


=item B<-fno-threadsafe-statics>

Do not emit the extra code to use the routines specified in the C++
ABI for thread-safe initialization of local statics.  You can use this
option to reduce code size slightly in code that doesn't need to be
thread-safe.


=item B<-fuse-cxa-atexit>

Register destructors for objects with static storage duration with the
C<__cxa_atexit> function rather than the C<atexit> function.
This option is required for fully standards-compliant handling of static
destructors, but only works if your C library supports
C<__cxa_atexit>.


=item B<-fno-use-cxa-get-exception-ptr>

Don't use the C<__cxa_get_exception_ptr> runtime routine.  This
causes C<std::uncaught_exception> to be incorrect, but is necessary
if the runtime routine is not available.


=item B<-fvisibility-inlines-hidden>

This switch declares that the user does not attempt to compare
pointers to inline functions or methods where the addresses of the two functions
are taken in different shared objects.

The effect of this is that GCC may, effectively, mark inline methods with
C<__attribute__ ((visibility ("hidden")))> so that they do not
appear in the export table of a DSO and do not require a PLT indirection
when used within the DSO.  Enabling this option can have a dramatic effect
on load and link times of a DSO as it massively reduces the size of the
dynamic export table when the library makes heavy use of templates.

The behavior of this switch is not quite the same as marking the
methods as hidden directly, because it does not affect static variables
local to the function or cause the compiler to deduce that
the function is defined in only one shared object.

You may mark a method as having a visibility explicitly to negate the
effect of the switch for that method.  For example, if you do want to
compare pointers to a particular inline method, you might mark it as
having default visibility.  Marking the enclosing class with explicit
visibility has no effect.

Explicitly instantiated inline methods are unaffected by this option
as their linkage might otherwise cross a shared library boundary.



=item B<-fvisibility-ms-compat>

This flag attempts to use visibility settings to make GCC's C++
linkage model compatible with that of Microsoft Visual Studio.

The flag makes these changes to GCC's linkage model:


=over 4


=item Z<>1.

It sets the default visibility to C<hidden>, like
B<-fvisibility=hidden>.


=item Z<>2.

Types, but not their members, are not hidden by default.


=item Z<>3.

The One Definition Rule is relaxed for types without explicit
visibility specifications that are defined in more than one
shared object: those declarations are permitted if they are
permitted when this option is not used.

=back


In new code it is better to use B<-fvisibility=hidden> and
export those classes that are intended to be externally visible.
Unfortunately it is possible for code to rely, perhaps accidentally,
on the Visual Studio behavior.

Among the consequences of these changes are that static data members
of the same type with the same name but defined in different shared
objects are different, so changing one does not change the other;
and that pointers to function members defined in different shared
objects may not compare equal.  When this flag is given, it is a
violation of the ODR to define types with the same name differently.


=item B<-fno-weak>

Do not use weak symbol support, even if it is provided by the linker.
By default, G++ uses weak symbols if they are available.  This
option exists only for testing, and should not be used by end-users;
it results in inferior code and has no benefits.  This option may
be removed in a future release of G++.


=item B<-nostdinc++>

Do not search for header files in the standard directories specific to
C++, but do still search the other standard directories.  (This option
is used when building the C++ library.)

=back


In addition, these optimization, warning, and code generation options
have meanings only for C++ programs:


=over 4


=item B<-Wabi> (C, Objective-C, C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when G++ it generates code that is probably not compatible with
the vendor-neutral C++ ABI.  Since G++ now defaults to updating the
ABI with each major release, normally B<-Wabi> will warn only if
there is a check added later in a release series for an ABI issue
discovered since the initial release.  B<-Wabi> will warn about
more things if an older ABI version is selected (with
B<-fabi-version=>I<n>).

B<-Wabi> can also be used with an explicit version number to
warn about compatibility with a particular B<-fabi-version>
level, e.g. B<-Wabi=2> to warn about changes relative to
B<-fabi-version=2>.

If an explicit version number is provided and
B<-fabi-compat-version> is not specified, the version number
from this option is used for compatibility aliases.  If no explicit
version number is provided with this option, but
B<-fabi-compat-version> is specified, that version number is
used for ABI warnings.

Although an effort has been made to warn about
all such cases, there are probably some cases that are not warned about,
even though G++ is generating incompatible code.  There may also be
cases where warnings are emitted even though the code that is generated
is compatible.

You should rewrite your code to avoid these warnings if you are
concerned about the fact that code generated by G++ may not be binary
compatible with code generated by other compilers.

Known incompatibilities in B<-fabi-version=2> (which was the
default from GCC 3.4 to 4.9) include:


=over 4



=item Z<>*

A template with a non-type template parameter of reference type was
mangled incorrectly:
	
	extern int N;
	template <int &> struct S {};
	void n (S<N>) {2}


This was fixed in B<-fabi-version=3>.


=item Z<>*

SIMD vector types declared using C<__attribute ((vector_size))> were
mangled in a non-standard way that does not allow for overloading of
functions taking vectors of different sizes.

The mangling was changed in B<-fabi-version=4>.


=item Z<>*

C<__attribute ((const))> and C<noreturn> were mangled as type
qualifiers, and C<decltype> of a plain declaration was folded away.

These mangling issues were fixed in B<-fabi-version=5>.


=item Z<>*

Scoped enumerators passed as arguments to a variadic function are
promoted like unscoped enumerators, causing C<va_arg> to complain.
On most targets this does not actually affect the parameter passing
ABI, as there is no way to pass an argument smaller than C<int>.

Also, the ABI changed the mangling of template argument packs,
C<const_cast>, C<static_cast>, prefix increment/decrement, and
a class scope function used as a template argument.

These issues were corrected in B<-fabi-version=6>.


=item Z<>*

Lambdas in default argument scope were mangled incorrectly, and the
ABI changed the mangling of C<nullptr_t>.

These issues were corrected in B<-fabi-version=7>.


=item Z<>*

When mangling a function type with function-cv-qualifiers, the
un-qualified function type was incorrectly treated as a substitution
candidate.

This was fixed in B<-fabi-version=8>, the default for GCC 5.1.


=item Z<>*

C<decltype(nullptr)> incorrectly had an alignment of 1, leading to
unaligned accesses.  Note that this did not affect the ABI of a
function with a C<nullptr_t> parameter, as parameters have a
minimum alignment.

This was fixed in B<-fabi-version=9>, the default for GCC 5.2.


=item Z<>*

Target-specific attributes that affect the identity of a type, such as
ia32 calling conventions on a function type (stdcall, regparm, etc.),
did not affect the mangled name, leading to name collisions when
function pointers were used as template arguments.

This was fixed in B<-fabi-version=10>, the default for GCC 6.1.


=back


It also warns about psABI-related changes.  The known psABI changes at this
point include:


=over 4



=item Z<>*

For SysV/x86-64, unions with C<long double> members are 
passed in memory as specified in psABI.  For example:

	
	union U {
	  long double ld;
	  int i;
	};


C<union U> is always passed in memory.


=back



=item B<-Wabi-tag> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a type with an ABI tag is used in a context that does not
have that ABI tag.  See B<C++ Attributes> for more information
about ABI tags.


=item B<-Wctor-dtor-privacy> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a class seems unusable because all the constructors or
destructors in that class are private, and it has neither friends nor
public static member functions.  Also warn if there are no non-private
methods, and there's at least one private member function that isn't
a constructor or destructor.


=item B<-Wdelete-non-virtual-dtor> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when C<delete> is used to destroy an instance of a class that
has virtual functions and non-virtual destructor. It is unsafe to delete
an instance of a derived class through a pointer to a base class if the
base class does not have a virtual destructor.  This warning is enabled
by B<-Wall>.


=item B<-Wdeprecated-copy> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn that the implicit declaration of a copy constructor or copy
assignment operator is deprecated if the class has a user-provided
copy constructor or copy assignment operator, in C++11 and up.  This
warning is enabled by B<-Wextra>.  With
B<-Wdeprecated-copy-dtor>, also deprecate if the class has a
user-provided destructor.


=item B<-Wno-init-list-lifetime> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Do not warn about uses of C<std::initializer_list> that are likely
to result in dangling pointers.  Since the underlying array for an
C<initializer_list> is handled like a normal C++ temporary object,
it is easy to inadvertently keep a pointer to the array past the end
of the array's lifetime.  For example:


=over 4


=item Z<>*

If a function returns a temporary C<initializer_list>, or a local
C<initializer_list> variable, the array's lifetime ends at the end
of the return statement, so the value returned has a dangling pointer.


=item Z<>*

If a new-expression creates an C<initializer_list>, the array only
lives until the end of the enclosing full-expression, so the
C<initializer_list> in the heap has a dangling pointer.


=item Z<>*

When an C<initializer_list> variable is assigned from a
brace-enclosed initializer list, the temporary array created for the
right side of the assignment only lives until the end of the
full-expression, so at the next statement the C<initializer_list>
variable has a dangling pointer.

	
	// li's initial underlying array lives as long as li
	std::initializer_list<int> li = { 1,2,3 };
	// assignment changes li to point to a temporary array
	li = { 4, 5 };
	// now the temporary is gone and li has a dangling pointer
	int i = li.begin()[0] // undefined behavior



=item Z<>*

When a list constructor stores the C<begin> pointer from the
C<initializer_list> argument, this doesn't extend the lifetime of
the array, so if a class variable is constructed from a temporary
C<initializer_list>, the pointer is left dangling by the end of
the variable declaration statement.


=back



=item B<-Wliteral-suffix> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a string or character literal is followed by a ud-suffix which does
not begin with an underscore.  As a conforming extension, GCC treats such
suffixes as separate preprocessing tokens in order to maintain backwards
compatibility with code that uses formatting macros from C<E<lt>inttypes.hE<gt>>.
For example:

	
	#define __STDC_FORMAT_MACROS
	#include <inttypes.h>
	#include <stdio.h>
	
	int main() {
	  int64_t i64 = 123;
	  printf("My int64: %" PRId64"\n", i64);
	}


In this case, C<PRId64> is treated as a separate preprocessing token.

Additionally, warn when a user-defined literal operator is declared with
a literal suffix identifier that doesn't begin with an underscore. Literal
suffix identifiers that don't begin with an underscore are reserved for
future standardization.

This warning is enabled by default.


=item B<-Wlto-type-mismatch>


During the link-time optimization warn about type mismatches in
global declarations from different compilation units.
Requires B<-flto> to be enabled.  Enabled by default.


=item B<-Wno-narrowing> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

For C++11 and later standards, narrowing conversions are diagnosed by default,
as required by the standard.  A narrowing conversion from a constant produces
an error, and a narrowing conversion from a non-constant produces a warning,
but B<-Wno-narrowing> suppresses the diagnostic.
Note that this does not affect the meaning of well-formed code;
narrowing conversions are still considered ill-formed in SFINAE contexts.

With B<-Wnarrowing> in C++98, warn when a narrowing
conversion prohibited by C++11 occurs within
B<{ }>, e.g.

	
	int i = { 2.2 }; // error: narrowing from double to int


This flag is included in B<-Wall> and B<-Wc++11-compat>.


=item B<-Wnoexcept> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a noexcept-expression evaluates to false because of a call
to a function that does not have a non-throwing exception
specification (i.e. C<throw()> or C<noexcept>) but is known by
the compiler to never throw an exception.


=item B<-Wnoexcept-type> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn if the C++17 feature making C<noexcept> part of a function
type changes the mangled name of a symbol relative to C++14.  Enabled
by B<-Wabi> and B<-Wc++17-compat>.

As an example:

	
	template <class T> void f(T t) { t(); };
	void g() noexcept;
	void h() { f(g); } 


In C++14, C<f> calls C<fE<lt>void(*)()E<gt>>, but in
C++17 it calls C<fE<lt>void(*)()noexceptE<gt>>.


=item B<-Wclass-memaccess> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when the destination of a call to a raw memory function such as
C<memset> or C<memcpy> is an object of class type, and when writing
into such an object might bypass the class non-trivial or deleted constructor
or copy assignment, violate const-correctness or encapsulation, or corrupt
virtual table pointers.  Modifying the representation of such objects may
violate invariants maintained by member functions of the class.  For example,
the call to C<memset> below is undefined because it modifies a non-trivial
class object and is, therefore, diagnosed.  The safe way to either initialize
or clear the storage of objects of such types is by using the appropriate
constructor or assignment operator, if one is available.
	
	std::string str = "abc";
	memset (&str, 0, sizeof str);

The B<-Wclass-memaccess> option is enabled by B<-Wall>.
Explicitly casting the pointer to the class object to C<void *> or
to a type that can be safely accessed by the raw memory function suppresses
the warning.


=item B<-Wnon-virtual-dtor> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a class has virtual functions and an accessible non-virtual
destructor itself or in an accessible polymorphic base class, in which
case it is possible but unsafe to delete an instance of a derived
class through a pointer to the class itself or base class.  This
warning is automatically enabled if B<-Weffc++> is specified.


=item B<-Wregister> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn on uses of the C<register> storage class specifier, except
when it is part of the GNU B<Explicit Register Variables> extension.
The use of the C<register> keyword as storage class specifier has
been deprecated in C++11 and removed in C++17.
Enabled by default with B<-std=c++17>.


=item B<-Wreorder> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when the order of member initializers given in the code does not
match the order in which they must be executed.  For instance:

	
	struct A {
	  int i;
	  int j;
	  A(): j (0), i (1) { }
	};


The compiler rearranges the member initializers for C<i>
and C<j> to match the declaration order of the members, emitting
a warning to that effect.  This warning is enabled by B<-Wall>.


=item B<-Wno-pessimizing-move> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

This warning warns when a call to C<std::move> prevents copy
elision.  A typical scenario when copy elision can occur is when returning in
a function with a class return type, when the expression being returned is the
name of a non-volatile automatic object, and is not a function parameter, and
has the same type as the function return type.

	
	struct T {
	...
	};
	T fn()
	{
	  T t;
	  ...
	  return std::move (t);
	}


But in this example, the C<std::move> call prevents copy elision.

This warning is enabled by B<-Wall>.


=item B<-Wno-redundant-move> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

This warning warns about redundant calls to C<std::move>; that is, when
a move operation would have been performed even without the C<std::move>
call.  This happens because the compiler is forced to treat the object as if
it were an rvalue in certain situations such as returning a local variable,
where copy elision isn't applicable.  Consider:

	
	struct T {
	...
	};
	T fn(T t)
	{
	  ...
	  return std::move (t);
	}


Here, the C<std::move> call is redundant.  Because G++ implements Core
Issue 1579, another example is:

	
	struct T { // convertible to U
	...
	};
	struct U {
	...
	};
	U fn()
	{
	  T t;
	  ...
	  return std::move (t);
	}

In this example, copy elision isn't applicable because the type of the
expression being returned and the function return type differ, yet G++
treats the return value as if it were designated by an rvalue.

This warning is enabled by B<-Wextra>.


=item B<-fext-numeric-literals> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Accept imaginary, fixed-point, or machine-defined
literal number suffixes as GNU extensions.
When this option is turned off these suffixes are treated
as C++11 user-defined literal numeric suffixes.
This is on by default for all pre-C++11 dialects and all GNU dialects:
B<-std=c++98>, B<-std=gnu++98>, B<-std=gnu++11>,
B<-std=gnu++14>.
This option is off by default
for ISO C++11 onwards (B<-std=c++11>, ...).

=back


The following B<-W...> options are not affected by B<-Wall>.


=over 4


=item B<-Weffc++> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn about violations of the following style guidelines from Scott Meyers'
I<Effective C++> series of books:


=over 4


=item Z<>*

Define a copy constructor and an assignment operator for classes
with dynamically-allocated memory.


=item Z<>*

Prefer initialization to assignment in constructors.


=item Z<>*

Have C<operator=> return a reference to C<*this>.


=item Z<>*

Don't try to return a reference when you must return an object.


=item Z<>*

Distinguish between prefix and postfix forms of increment and
decrement operators.


=item Z<>*

Never overload C<&&>, C<||>, or C<,>.


=back


This option also enables B<-Wnon-virtual-dtor>, which is also
one of the effective C++ recommendations.  However, the check is
extended to warn about the lack of virtual destructor in accessible
non-polymorphic bases classes too.

When selecting this option, be aware that the standard library
headers do not obey all of these guidelines; use B<grep -v>
to filter out those warnings.


=item B<-Wstrict-null-sentinel> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn about the use of an uncasted C<NULL> as sentinel.  When
compiling only with GCC this is a valid sentinel, as C<NULL> is defined
to C<__null>.  Although it is a null pointer constant rather than a
null pointer, it is guaranteed to be of the same size as a pointer.
But this use is not portable across different compilers.


=item B<-Wno-non-template-friend> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Disable warnings when non-template friend functions are declared
within a template.  In very old versions of GCC that predate implementation
of the ISO standard, declarations such as 
B<friend int foo(int)>, where the name of the friend is an unqualified-id,
could be interpreted as a particular specialization of a template
function; the warning exists to diagnose compatibility problems, 
and is enabled by default.


=item B<-Wold-style-cast> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn if an old-style (C-style) cast to a non-void type is used within
a C++ program.  The new-style casts (C<dynamic_cast>,
C<static_cast>, C<reinterpret_cast>, and C<const_cast>) are
less vulnerable to unintended effects and much easier to search for.


=item B<-Woverloaded-virtual> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a function declaration hides virtual functions from a
base class.  For example, in:

	
	struct A {
	  virtual void f();
	};
	
	struct B: public A {
	  void f(int);
	};


the C<A> class version of C<f> is hidden in C<B>, and code
like:

	
	B* b;
	b->f();


fails to compile.


=item B<-Wno-pmf-conversions> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Disable the diagnostic for converting a bound pointer to member function
to a plain pointer.


=item B<-Wsign-promo> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when overload resolution chooses a promotion from unsigned or
enumerated type to a signed type, over a conversion to an unsigned type of
the same size.  Previous versions of G++ tried to preserve
unsignedness, but the standard mandates the current behavior.


=item B<-Wtemplates> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a primary template declaration is encountered.  Some coding
rules disallow templates, and this may be used to enforce that rule.
The warning is inactive inside a system header file, such as the STL, so
one can still use the STL.  One may also instantiate or specialize
templates.


=item B<-Wmultiple-inheritance> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Warn when a class is defined with multiple direct base classes.  Some
coding rules disallow multiple inheritance, and this may be used to
enforce that rule.  The warning is inactive inside a system header file,
such as the STL, so one can still use the STL.  One may also define
classes that indirectly use multiple inheritance.


=item B<-Wvirtual-inheritance>

Warn when a class is defined with a virtual direct base class.  Some
coding rules disallow multiple inheritance, and this may be used to
enforce that rule.  The warning is inactive inside a system header file,
such as the STL, so one can still use the STL.  One may also define
classes that indirectly use virtual inheritance.


=item B<-Wnamespaces>

Warn when a namespace definition is opened.  Some coding rules disallow
namespaces, and this may be used to enforce that rule.  The warning is
inactive inside a system header file, such as the STL, so one can still
use the STL.  One may also use using directives and qualified names.


=item B<-Wno-terminate> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Disable the warning about a throw-expression that will immediately
result in a call to C<terminate>.


=item B<-Wno-class-conversion> (C++ and Objective-C++ only)

Disable the warning about the case when a conversion function converts an
object to the same type, to a base class of that type, or to void; such
a conversion function will never be called.

=back



=head2 Options Controlling Objective-C and Objective-C++ Dialects


(NOTE: This manual does not describe the Objective-C and Objective-C++
languages themselves.  

This section describes the command-line options that are only meaningful
for Objective-C and Objective-C++ programs.  You can also use most of
the language-independent GNU compiler options.
For example, you might compile a file F<some_class.m> like this:

	
	gcc -g -fgnu-runtime -O -c some_class.m


In this example, B<-fgnu-runtime> is an option meant only for
Objective-C and Objective-C++ programs; you can use the other options with
any language supported by GCC.

Note that since Objective-C is an extension of the C language, Objective-C
compilations may also use options specific to the C front-end (e.g.,
B<-Wtraditional>).  Similarly, Objective-C++ compilations may use
C++-specific options (e.g., B<-Wabi>).

Here is a list of options that are I<only> for compiling Objective-C
and Objective-C++ programs:


=over 4


=item B<-fconstant-string-class=>I<class-name>

Use I<class-name> as the name of the class to instantiate for each
literal string specified with the syntax C<@"...">.  The default
class name is C<NXConstantString> if the GNU runtime is being used, and
C<NSConstantString> if the NeXT runtime is being used (see below).  The
B<-fconstant-cfstrings> option, if also present, overrides the
B<-fconstant-string-class> setting and cause C<@"..."> literals
to be laid out as constant CoreFoundation strings.


=item B<-fgnu-runtime>

Generate object code compatible with the standard GNU Objective-C
runtime.  This is the default for most types of systems.


=item B<-fnext-runtime>

Generate output compatible with the NeXT runtime.  This is the default
for NeXT-based systems, including Darwin and Mac OS X.  The macro
C<__NEXT_RUNTIME__> is predefined if (and only if) this option is
used.


=item B<-fno-nil-receivers>

Assume that all Objective-C message dispatches (C<[receiver
message:arg]>) in this translation unit ensure that the receiver is
not C<nil>.  This allows for more efficient entry points in the
runtime to be used.  This option is only available in conjunction with
the NeXT runtime and ABI version 0 or 1.


=item B<-fobjc-abi-version=>I<n>

Use version I<n> of the Objective-C ABI for the selected runtime.
This option is currently supported only for the NeXT runtime.  In that
case, Version 0 is the traditional (32-bit) ABI without support for
properties and other Objective-C 2.0 additions.  Version 1 is the
traditional (32-bit) ABI with support for properties and other
Objective-C 2.0 additions.  Version 2 is the modern (64-bit) ABI.  If
nothing is specified, the default is Version 0 on 32-bit target
machines, and Version 2 on 64-bit target machines.


=item B<-fobjc-call-cxx-cdtors>

For each Objective-C class, check if any of its instance variables is a
C++ object with a non-trivial default constructor.  If so, synthesize a
special C<- (id) .cxx_construct> instance method which runs
non-trivial default constructors on any such instance variables, in order,
and then return C<self>.  Similarly, check if any instance variable
is a C++ object with a non-trivial destructor, and if so, synthesize a
special C<- (void) .cxx_destruct> method which runs
all such default destructors, in reverse order.

The C<- (id) .cxx_construct> and C<- (void) .cxx_destruct>
methods thusly generated only operate on instance variables
declared in the current Objective-C class, and not those inherited
from superclasses.  It is the responsibility of the Objective-C
runtime to invoke all such methods in an object's inheritance
hierarchy.  The C<- (id) .cxx_construct> methods are invoked
by the runtime immediately after a new object instance is allocated;
the C<- (void) .cxx_destruct> methods are invoked immediately
before the runtime deallocates an object instance.

As of this writing, only the NeXT runtime on Mac OS X 10.4 and later has
support for invoking the C<- (id) .cxx_construct> and
C<- (void) .cxx_destruct> methods.


=item B<-fobjc-direct-dispatch>

Allow fast jumps to the message dispatcher.  On Darwin this is
accomplished via the comm page.


=item B<-fobjc-exceptions>

Enable syntactic support for structured exception handling in
Objective-C, similar to what is offered by C++.  This option
is required to use the Objective-C keywords C<@try>,
C<@throw>, C<@catch>, C<@finally> and
C<@synchronized>.  This option is available with both the GNU
runtime and the NeXT runtime (but not available in conjunction with
the NeXT runtime on Mac OS X 10.2 and earlier).


=item B<-fobjc-gc>

Enable garbage collection (GC) in Objective-C and Objective-C++
programs.  This option is only available with the NeXT runtime; the
GNU runtime has a different garbage collection implementation that
does not require special compiler flags.


=item B<-fobjc-nilcheck>

For the NeXT runtime with version 2 of the ABI, check for a nil
receiver in method invocations before doing the actual method call.
This is the default and can be disabled using
B<-fno-objc-nilcheck>.  Class methods and super calls are never
checked for nil in this way no matter what this flag is set to.
Currently this flag does nothing when the GNU runtime, or an older
version of the NeXT runtime ABI, is used.


=item B<-fobjc-std=objc1>

Conform to the language syntax of Objective-C 1.0, the language
recognized by GCC 4.0.  This only affects the Objective-C additions to
the C/C++ language; it does not affect conformance to C/C++ standards,
which is controlled by the separate C/C++ dialect option flags.  When
this option is used with the Objective-C or Objective-C++ compiler,
any Objective-C syntax that is not recognized by GCC 4.0 is rejected.
This is useful if you need to make sure that your Objective-C code can
be compiled with older versions of GCC.


=item B<-freplace-objc-classes>

Emit a special marker instructing B<ld(1)> not to statically link in
the resulting object file, and allow B<dyld(1)> to load it in at
run time instead.  This is used in conjunction with the Fix-and-Continue
debugging mode, where the object file in question may be recompiled and
dynamically reloaded in the course of program execution, without the need
to restart the program itself.  Currently, Fix-and-Continue functionality
is only available in conjunction with the NeXT runtime on Mac OS X 10.3
and later.


=item B<-fzero-link>

When compiling for the NeXT runtime, the compiler ordinarily replaces calls
to C<objc_getClass("...")> (when the name of the class is known at
compile time) with static class references that get initialized at load time,
