=item B<-fsanitize=pointer-compare>

Instrument comparison operation (E<lt>, E<lt>=, E<gt>, E<gt>=) with pointer operands.
The option must be combined with either B<-fsanitize=kernel-address> or
B<-fsanitize=address>
The option cannot be combined with B<-fsanitize=thread>.
Note: By default the check is disabled at run time.  To enable it,
add C<detect_invalid_pointer_pairs=2> to the environment variable
B<ASAN_OPTIONS>. Using C<detect_invalid_pointer_pairs=1> detects
invalid operation only when both pointers are non-null.


=item B<-fsanitize=pointer-subtract>

Instrument subtraction with pointer operands.
The option must be combined with either B<-fsanitize=kernel-address> or
B<-fsanitize=address>
The option cannot be combined with B<-fsanitize=thread>.
Note: By default the check is disabled at run time.  To enable it,
add C<detect_invalid_pointer_pairs=2> to the environment variable
B<ASAN_OPTIONS>. Using C<detect_invalid_pointer_pairs=1> detects
invalid operation only when both pointers are non-null.


=item B<-fsanitize=thread>

Enable ThreadSanitizer, a fast data race detector.
Memory access instructions are instrumented to detect
data race bugs.  See E<lt>B<https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki#threadsanitizer>E<gt> for more
details. The run-time behavior can be influenced using the B<TSAN_OPTIONS>
environment variable; see
E<lt>B<https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/ThreadSanitizerFlags>E<gt> for a list of
supported options.
The option cannot be combined with B<-fsanitize=address>,
B<-fsanitize=leak>.

Note that sanitized atomic builtins cannot throw exceptions when
operating on invalid memory addresses with non-call exceptions
(B<-fnon-call-exceptions>).


=item B<-fsanitize=leak>

Enable LeakSanitizer, a memory leak detector.
This option only matters for linking of executables and
the executable is linked against a library that overrides C<malloc>
and other allocator functions.  See
E<lt>B<https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizerLeakSanitizer>E<gt> for more
details.  The run-time behavior can be influenced using the
B<LSAN_OPTIONS> environment variable.
The option cannot be combined with B<-fsanitize=thread>.


=item B<-fsanitize=undefined>

Enable UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer, a fast undefined behavior detector.
Various computations are instrumented to detect undefined behavior
at runtime.  Current suboptions are:


=over 4



=item B<-fsanitize=shift>

This option enables checking that the result of a shift operation is
not undefined.  Note that what exactly is considered undefined differs
slightly between C and C++, as well as between ISO C90 and C99, etc.
This option has two suboptions, B<-fsanitize=shift-base> and
B<-fsanitize=shift-exponent>.


=item B<-fsanitize=shift-exponent>

This option enables checking that the second argument of a shift operation
is not negative and is smaller than the precision of the promoted first
argument.


=item B<-fsanitize=shift-base>

If the second argument of a shift operation is within range, check that the
result of a shift operation is not undefined.  Note that what exactly is
considered undefined differs slightly between C and C++, as well as between
ISO C90 and C99, etc.


=item B<-fsanitize=integer-divide-by-zero>

Detect integer division by zero as well as C<INT_MIN / -1> division.


=item B<-fsanitize=unreachable>

With this option, the compiler turns the C<__builtin_unreachable>
call into a diagnostics message call instead.  When reaching the
C<__builtin_unreachable> call, the behavior is undefined.


=item B<-fsanitize=vla-bound>

This option instructs the compiler to check that the size of a variable
length array is positive.


=item B<-fsanitize=null>

This option enables pointer checking.  Particularly, the application
built with this option turned on will issue an error message when it
tries to dereference a NULL pointer, or if a reference (possibly an
rvalue reference) is bound to a NULL pointer, or if a method is invoked
on an object pointed by a NULL pointer.


=item B<-fsanitize=return>

This option enables return statement checking.  Programs
built with this option turned on will issue an error message
when the end of a non-void function is reached without actually
returning a value.  This option works in C++ only.


=item B<-fsanitize=signed-integer-overflow>

This option enables signed integer overflow checking.  We check that
the result of C<+>, C<*>, and both unary and binary C<->
does not overflow in the signed arithmetics.  Note, integer promotion
rules must be taken into account.  That is, the following is not an
overflow:
	
	signed char a = SCHAR_MAX;
	a++;



=item B<-fsanitize=bounds>

This option enables instrumentation of array bounds.  Various out of bounds
accesses are detected.  Flexible array members, flexible array member-like
arrays, and initializers of variables with static storage are not instrumented.


=item B<-fsanitize=bounds-strict>

This option enables strict instrumentation of array bounds.  Most out of bounds
accesses are detected, including flexible array members and flexible array
member-like arrays.  Initializers of variables with static storage are not
instrumented.


=item B<-fsanitize=alignment>


This option enables checking of alignment of pointers when they are
dereferenced, or when a reference is bound to insufficiently aligned target,
or when a method or constructor is invoked on insufficiently aligned object.


=item B<-fsanitize=object-size>

This option enables instrumentation of memory references using the
C<__builtin_object_size> function.  Various out of bounds pointer
accesses are detected.


=item B<-fsanitize=float-divide-by-zero>

Detect floating-point division by zero.  Unlike other similar options,
B<-fsanitize=float-divide-by-zero> is not enabled by
B<-fsanitize=undefined>, since floating-point division by zero can
be a legitimate way of obtaining infinities and NaNs.


=item B<-fsanitize=float-cast-overflow>

This option enables floating-point type to integer conversion checking.
We check that the result of the conversion does not overflow.
Unlike other similar options, B<-fsanitize=float-cast-overflow> is
not enabled by B<-fsanitize=undefined>.
This option does not work well with C<FE_INVALID> exceptions enabled.


=item B<-fsanitize=nonnull-attribute>


This option enables instrumentation of calls, checking whether null values
are not passed to arguments marked as requiring a non-null value by the
C<nonnull> function attribute.


=item B<-fsanitize=returns-nonnull-attribute>


This option enables instrumentation of return statements in functions
marked with C<returns_nonnull> function attribute, to detect returning
of null values from such functions.


=item B<-fsanitize=bool>


This option enables instrumentation of loads from bool.  If a value other
than 0/1 is loaded, a run-time error is issued.


=item B<-fsanitize=enum>


This option enables instrumentation of loads from an enum type.  If
a value outside the range of values for the enum type is loaded,
a run-time error is issued.


=item B<-fsanitize=vptr>


This option enables instrumentation of C++ member function calls, member
accesses and some conversions between pointers to base and derived classes,
to verify the referenced object has the correct dynamic type.


=item B<-fsanitize=pointer-overflow>


This option enables instrumentation of pointer arithmetics.  If the pointer
arithmetics overflows, a run-time error is issued.


=item B<-fsanitize=builtin>


This option enables instrumentation of arguments to selected builtin
functions.  If an invalid value is passed to such arguments, a run-time
error is issued.  E.g. passing 0 as the argument to C<__builtin_ctz>
or C<__builtin_clz> invokes undefined behavior and is diagnosed
by this option.


=back


While B<-ftrapv> causes traps for signed overflows to be emitted,
B<-fsanitize=undefined> gives a diagnostic message.
This currently works only for the C family of languages.


=item B<-fno-sanitize=all>


This option disables all previously enabled sanitizers.
B<-fsanitize=all> is not allowed, as some sanitizers cannot be used
together.


=item B<-fasan-shadow-offset=>I<number>

This option forces GCC to use custom shadow offset in AddressSanitizer checks.
It is useful for experimenting with different shadow memory layouts in
Kernel AddressSanitizer.


=item B<-fsanitize-sections=>I<s1>B<,>I<s2>B<,...>

Sanitize global variables in selected user-defined sections.  I<si> may
contain wildcards.


=item B<-fsanitize-recover>[B<=>I<opts>]

B<-fsanitize-recover=> controls error recovery mode for sanitizers
mentioned in comma-separated list of I<opts>.  Enabling this option
for a sanitizer component causes it to attempt to continue
running the program as if no error happened.  This means multiple
runtime errors can be reported in a single program run, and the exit
code of the program may indicate success even when errors
have been reported.  The B<-fno-sanitize-recover=> option
can be used to alter
this behavior: only the first detected error is reported
and program then exits with a non-zero exit code.

Currently this feature only works for B<-fsanitize=undefined> (and its suboptions
except for B<-fsanitize=unreachable> and B<-fsanitize=return>),
B<-fsanitize=float-cast-overflow>, B<-fsanitize=float-divide-by-zero>,
B<-fsanitize=bounds-strict>,
B<-fsanitize=kernel-address> and B<-fsanitize=address>.
For these sanitizers error recovery is turned on by default,
except B<-fsanitize=address>, for which this feature is experimental.
B<-fsanitize-recover=all> and B<-fno-sanitize-recover=all> is also
accepted, the former enables recovery for all sanitizers that support it,
the latter disables recovery for all sanitizers that support it.

Even if a recovery mode is turned on the compiler side, it needs to be also
enabled on the runtime library side, otherwise the failures are still fatal.
The runtime library defaults to C<halt_on_error=0> for
ThreadSanitizer and UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer, while default value for
AddressSanitizer is C<halt_on_error=1>. This can be overridden through
setting the C<halt_on_error> flag in the corresponding environment variable.

Syntax without an explicit I<opts> parameter is deprecated.  It is
equivalent to specifying an I<opts> list of:

	
	undefined,float-cast-overflow,float-divide-by-zero,bounds-strict



=item B<-fsanitize-address-use-after-scope>

Enable sanitization of local variables to detect use-after-scope bugs.
The option sets B<-fstack-reuse> to B<none>.


=item B<-fsanitize-undefined-trap-on-error>

The B<-fsanitize-undefined-trap-on-error> option instructs the compiler to
report undefined behavior using C<__builtin_trap> rather than
a C<libubsan> library routine.  The advantage of this is that the
C<libubsan> library is not needed and is not linked in, so this
is usable even in freestanding environments.


=item B<-fsanitize-coverage=trace-pc>

Enable coverage-guided fuzzing code instrumentation.
Inserts a call to C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_pc> into every basic block.


=item B<-fsanitize-coverage=trace-cmp>

Enable dataflow guided fuzzing code instrumentation.
Inserts a call to C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp1>,
C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp2>, C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp4> or
C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp8> for integral comparison with both operands
variable or C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_const_cmp1>,
C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_const_cmp2>,
C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_const_cmp4> or
C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_const_cmp8> for integral comparison with one
operand constant, C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmpf> or
C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmpd> for float or double comparisons and
C<__sanitizer_cov_trace_switch> for switch statements.


=item B<-fcf-protection=>[B<full>|B<branch>|B<return>|B<none>]

Enable code instrumentation of control-flow transfers to increase
program security by checking that target addresses of control-flow
transfer instructions (such as indirect function call, function return,
indirect jump) are valid.  This prevents diverting the flow of control
to an unexpected target.  This is intended to protect against such
threats as Return-oriented Programming (ROP), and similarly
call/jmp-oriented programming (COP/JOP).

The value C<branch> tells the compiler to implement checking of
validity of control-flow transfer at the point of indirect branch
instructions, i.e. call/jmp instructions.  The value C<return>
implements checking of validity at the point of returning from a
function.  The value C<full> is an alias for specifying both
C<branch> and C<return>. The value C<none> turns off
instrumentation.

The macro C<__CET__> is defined when B<-fcf-protection> is
used.  The first bit of C<__CET__> is set to 1 for the value
C<branch> and the second bit of C<__CET__> is set to 1 for
the C<return>.

You can also use the C<nocf_check> attribute to identify
which functions and calls should be skipped from instrumentation.

Currently the x86 GNU/Linux target provides an implementation based
on Intel Control-flow Enforcement Technology (CET).


=item B<-fstack-protector>

Emit extra code to check for buffer overflows, such as stack smashing
attacks.  This is done by adding a guard variable to functions with
vulnerable objects.  This includes functions that call C<alloca>, and
functions with buffers larger than 8 bytes.  The guards are initialized
when a function is entered and then checked when the function exits.
If a guard check fails, an error message is printed and the program exits.


=item B<-fstack-protector-all>

Like B<-fstack-protector> except that all functions are protected.


=item B<-fstack-protector-strong>

Like B<-fstack-protector> but includes additional functions to
be protected --- those that have local array definitions, or have
references to local frame addresses.


=item B<-fstack-protector-explicit>

Like B<-fstack-protector> but only protects those functions which
have the C<stack_protect> attribute.


=item B<-fstack-check>

Generate code to verify that you do not go beyond the boundary of the
stack.  You should specify this flag if you are running in an
environment with multiple threads, but you only rarely need to specify it in
a single-threaded environment since stack overflow is automatically
detected on nearly all systems if there is only one stack.

Note that this switch does not actually cause checking to be done; the
operating system or the language runtime must do that.  The switch causes
generation of code to ensure that they see the stack being extended.

You can additionally specify a string parameter: B<no> means no
checking, B<generic> means force the use of old-style checking,
B<specific> means use the best checking method and is equivalent
to bare B<-fstack-check>.

Old-style checking is a generic mechanism that requires no specific
target support in the compiler but comes with the following drawbacks:


=over 4


=item Z<>1.

Modified allocation strategy for large objects: they are always
allocated dynamically if their size exceeds a fixed threshold.  Note this
may change the semantics of some code.


=item Z<>2.

Fixed limit on the size of the static frame of functions: when it is
topped by a particular function, stack checking is not reliable and
a warning is issued by the compiler.


=item Z<>3.

Inefficiency: because of both the modified allocation strategy and the
generic implementation, code performance is hampered.

=back


Note that old-style stack checking is also the fallback method for
B<specific> if no target support has been added in the compiler.

B<-fstack-check=> is designed for Ada's needs to detect infinite recursion
and stack overflows.  B<specific> is an excellent choice when compiling
Ada code.  It is not generally sufficient to protect against stack-clash
attacks.  To protect against those you want B<-fstack-clash-protection>.


=item B<-fstack-clash-protection>

Generate code to prevent stack clash style attacks.  When this option is
enabled, the compiler will only allocate one page of stack space at a time
and each page is accessed immediately after allocation.  Thus, it prevents
allocations from jumping over any stack guard page provided by the
operating system.

Most targets do not fully support stack clash protection.  However, on
those targets B<-fstack-clash-protection> will protect dynamic stack
allocations.  B<-fstack-clash-protection> may also provide limited
protection for static stack allocations if the target supports
B<-fstack-check=specific>.


=item B<-fstack-limit-register=>I<reg>


=item B<-fstack-limit-symbol=>I<sym>


=item B<-fno-stack-limit>

Generate code to ensure that the stack does not grow beyond a certain value,
either the value of a register or the address of a symbol.  If a larger
stack is required, a signal is raised at run time.  For most targets,
the signal is raised before the stack overruns the boundary, so
it is possible to catch the signal without taking special precautions.

For instance, if the stack starts at absolute address B<0x80000000>
and grows downwards, you can use the flags
B<-fstack-limit-symbol=__stack_limit> and
B<-Wl,--defsym,__stack_limit=0x7ffe0000> to enforce a stack limit
of 128KB.  Note that this may only work with the GNU linker.

You can locally override stack limit checking by using the
C<no_stack_limit> function attribute.


=item B<-fsplit-stack>

Generate code to automatically split the stack before it overflows.
The resulting program has a discontiguous stack which can only
overflow if the program is unable to allocate any more memory.  This
is most useful when running threaded programs, as it is no longer
necessary to calculate a good stack size to use for each thread.  This
is currently only implemented for the x86 targets running
GNU/Linux.

When code compiled with B<-fsplit-stack> calls code compiled
without B<-fsplit-stack>, there may not be much stack space
available for the latter code to run.  If compiling all code,
including library code, with B<-fsplit-stack> is not an option,
then the linker can fix up these calls so that the code compiled
without B<-fsplit-stack> always has a large stack.  Support for
this is implemented in the gold linker in GNU binutils release 2.21
and later.


=item B<-fvtable-verify=>[B<std>|B<preinit>|B<none>]

This option is only available when compiling C++ code.
It turns on (or off, if using B<-fvtable-verify=none>) the security
feature that verifies at run time, for every virtual call, that
the vtable pointer through which the call is made is valid for the type of
the object, and has not been corrupted or overwritten.  If an invalid vtable
pointer is detected at run time, an error is reported and execution of the
program is immediately halted.

This option causes run-time data structures to be built at program startup,
which are used for verifying the vtable pointers.  
The options B<std> and B<preinit>
control the timing of when these data structures are built.  In both cases the
data structures are built before execution reaches C<main>.  Using
B<-fvtable-verify=std> causes the data structures to be built after
shared libraries have been loaded and initialized.
B<-fvtable-verify=preinit> causes them to be built before shared
libraries have been loaded and initialized.

If this option appears multiple times in the command line with different
values specified, B<none> takes highest priority over both B<std> and
B<preinit>; B<preinit> takes priority over B<std>.


=item B<-fvtv-debug>

When used in conjunction with B<-fvtable-verify=std> or 
B<-fvtable-verify=preinit>, causes debug versions of the 
runtime functions for the vtable verification feature to be called.  
This flag also causes the compiler to log information about which 
vtable pointers it finds for each class.
This information is written to a file named F<vtv_set_ptr_data.log> 
in the directory named by the environment variable B<VTV_LOGS_DIR> 
if that is defined or the current working directory otherwise.

Note:  This feature I<appends> data to the log file. If you want a fresh log
file, be sure to delete any existing one.


=item B<-fvtv-counts>

This is a debugging flag.  When used in conjunction with
B<-fvtable-verify=std> or B<-fvtable-verify=preinit>, this
causes the compiler to keep track of the total number of virtual calls
it encounters and the number of verifications it inserts.  It also
counts the number of calls to certain run-time library functions
that it inserts and logs this information for each compilation unit.
The compiler writes this information to a file named
F<vtv_count_data.log> in the directory named by the environment
variable B<VTV_LOGS_DIR> if that is defined or the current working
directory otherwise.  It also counts the size of the vtable pointer sets
for each class, and writes this information to F<vtv_class_set_sizes.log>
in the same directory.

Note:  This feature I<appends> data to the log files.  To get fresh log
files, be sure to delete any existing ones.


=item B<-finstrument-functions>

Generate instrumentation calls for entry and exit to functions.  Just
after function entry and just before function exit, the following
profiling functions are called with the address of the current
function and its call site.  (On some platforms,
C<__builtin_return_address> does not work beyond the current
function, so the call site information may not be available to the
profiling functions otherwise.)

	
	void __cyg_profile_func_enter (void *this_fn,
	                               void *call_site);
	void __cyg_profile_func_exit  (void *this_fn,
	                               void *call_site);


The first argument is the address of the start of the current function,
which may be looked up exactly in the symbol table.

This instrumentation is also done for functions expanded inline in other
functions.  The profiling calls indicate where, conceptually, the
inline function is entered and exited.  This means that addressable
versions of such functions must be available.  If all your uses of a
function are expanded inline, this may mean an additional expansion of
code size.  If you use C<extern inline> in your C code, an
addressable version of such functions must be provided.  (This is
normally the case anyway, but if you get lucky and the optimizer always
expands the functions inline, you might have gotten away without
providing static copies.)

A function may be given the attribute C<no_instrument_function>, in
which case this instrumentation is not done.  This can be used, for
example, for the profiling functions listed above, high-priority
interrupt routines, and any functions from which the profiling functions
cannot safely be called (perhaps signal handlers, if the profiling
routines generate output or allocate memory).



=item B<-finstrument-functions-exclude-file-list=>I<file>B<,>I<file>B<,...>


Set the list of functions that are excluded from instrumentation (see
the description of B<-finstrument-functions>).  If the file that
contains a function definition matches with one of I<file>, then
that function is not instrumented.  The match is done on substrings:
if the I<file> parameter is a substring of the file name, it is
considered to be a match.

For example:

	
	-finstrument-functions-exclude-file-list=/bits/stl,include/sys


excludes any inline function defined in files whose pathnames
contain F</bits/stl> or F<include/sys>.

If, for some reason, you want to include letter B<,> in one of
I<sym>, write B<,>. For example,
B<-finstrument-functions-exclude-file-list=',,tmp'>
(note the single quote surrounding the option).


=item B<-finstrument-functions-exclude-function-list=>I<sym>B<,>I<sym>B<,...>


This is similar to B<-finstrument-functions-exclude-file-list>,
but this option sets the list of function names to be excluded from
instrumentation.  The function name to be matched is its user-visible
name, such as C<vectorE<lt>intE<gt> blah(const vectorE<lt>intE<gt> &)>, not the
internal mangled name (e.g., C<_Z4blahRSt6vectorIiSaIiEE>).  The
match is done on substrings: if the I<sym> parameter is a substring
of the function name, it is considered to be a match.  For C99 and C++
extended identifiers, the function name must be given in UTF-8, not
using universal character names.


=item B<-fpatchable-function-entry=>I<N>B<[,>I<M>B<]>

Generate I<N> NOPs right at the beginning
of each function, with the function entry point before the I<M>th NOP.
If I<M> is omitted, it defaults to C<0> so the
function entry points to the address just at the first NOP.
The NOP instructions reserve extra space which can be used to patch in
any desired instrumentation at run time, provided that the code segment
is writable.  The amount of space is controllable indirectly via
the number of NOPs; the NOP instruction used corresponds to the instruction
emitted by the internal GCC back-end interface C<gen_nop>.  This behavior
is target-specific and may also depend on the architecture variant and/or
other compilation options.

For run-time identification, the starting addresses of these areas,
which correspond to their respective function entries minus I<M>,
are additionally collected in the C<__patchable_function_entries>
section of the resulting binary.

Note that the value of C<__attribute__ ((patchable_function_entry
(N,M)))> takes precedence over command-line option
B<-fpatchable-function-entry=N,M>.  This can be used to increase
the area size or to remove it completely on a single function.
If C<N=0>, no pad location is recorded.

The NOP instructions are inserted at---and maybe before, depending on
I<M>---the function entry address, even before the prologue.


=back




=head2 Options Controlling the Preprocessor


These options control the C preprocessor, which is run on each C source
file before actual compilation.

If you use the B<-E> option, nothing is done except preprocessing.
Some of these options make sense only together with B<-E> because
they cause the preprocessor output to be unsuitable for actual
compilation.

In addition to the options listed here, there are a number of options 
to control search paths for include files documented in 
B<Directory Options>.  
Options to control preprocessor diagnostics are listed in 
B<Warning Options>.


=over 4





=item B<-D> I<name>

Predefine I<name> as a macro, with definition C<1>.


=item B<-D> I<name>B<=>I<definition>

The contents of I<definition> are tokenized and processed as if
they appeared during translation phase three in a B<#define>
directive.  In particular, the definition is truncated by
embedded newline characters.

If you are invoking the preprocessor from a shell or shell-like
program you may need to use the shell's quoting syntax to protect
characters such as spaces that have a meaning in the shell syntax.

If you wish to define a function-like macro on the command line, write
its argument list with surrounding parentheses before the equals sign
(if any).  Parentheses are meaningful to most shells, so you should
quote the option.  With B<sh> and B<csh>,
B<-D'>I<name>B<(>I<args...>B<)=>I<definition>B<'> works.

B<-D> and B<-U> options are processed in the order they
are given on the command line.  All B<-imacros> I<file> and
B<-include> I<file> options are processed after all
B<-D> and B<-U> options.


=item B<-U> I<name>

Cancel any previous definition of I<name>, either built in or
provided with a B<-D> option.


=item B<-include> I<file>

Process I<file> as if C<#include "file"> appeared as the first
line of the primary source file.  However, the first directory searched
for I<file> is the preprocessor's working directory I<instead of>
the directory containing the main source file.  If not found there, it
is searched for in the remainder of the C<#include "..."> search
chain as normal.

If multiple B<-include> options are given, the files are included
in the order they appear on the command line.


=item B<-imacros> I<file>

Exactly like B<-include>, except that any output produced by
scanning I<file> is thrown away.  Macros it defines remain defined.
This allows you to acquire all the macros from a header without also
processing its declarations.

All files specified by B<-imacros> are processed before all files
specified by B<-include>.


=item B<-undef>

Do not predefine any system-specific or GCC-specific macros.  The
standard predefined macros remain defined.


=item B<-pthread>

Define additional macros required for using the POSIX threads library.
You should use this option consistently for both compilation and linking.
This option is supported on GNU/Linux targets, most other Unix derivatives,
and also on x86 Cygwin and MinGW targets.


=item B<-M>

Instead of outputting the result of preprocessing, output a rule
suitable for B<make> describing the dependencies of the main
source file.  The preprocessor outputs one B<make> rule containing
the object file name for that source file, a colon, and the names of all
the included files, including those coming from B<-include> or
B<-imacros> command-line options.

Unless specified explicitly (with B<-MT> or B<-MQ>), the
object file name consists of the name of the source file with any
suffix replaced with object file suffix and with any leading directory
parts removed.  If there are many included files then the rule is
split into several lines using B<\>-newline.  The rule has no
commands.

This option does not suppress the preprocessor's debug output, such as
B<-dM>.  To avoid mixing such debug output with the dependency
rules you should explicitly specify the dependency output file with
B<-MF>, or use an environment variable like
B<DEPENDENCIES_OUTPUT>.  Debug output
is still sent to the regular output stream as normal.

Passing B<-M> to the driver implies B<-E>, and suppresses
warnings with an implicit B<-w>.


=item B<-MM>

Like B<-M> but do not mention header files that are found in
system header directories, nor header files that are included,
directly or indirectly, from such a header.

This implies that the choice of angle brackets or double quotes in an
B<#include> directive does not in itself determine whether that
header appears in B<-MM> dependency output.



=item B<-MF> I<file>

When used with B<-M> or B<-MM>, specifies a
file to write the dependencies to.  If no B<-MF> switch is given
the preprocessor sends the rules to the same place it would send
preprocessed output.

When used with the driver options B<-MD> or B<-MMD>,
B<-MF> overrides the default dependency output file.

If I<file> is F<->, then the dependencies are written to F<stdout>.


=item B<-MG>

In conjunction with an option such as B<-M> requesting
dependency generation, B<-MG> assumes missing header files are
generated files and adds them to the dependency list without raising
an error.  The dependency filename is taken directly from the
C<#include> directive without prepending any path.  B<-MG>
also suppresses preprocessed output, as a missing header file renders
this useless.

This feature is used in automatic updating of makefiles.


=item B<-MP>

This option instructs CPP to add a phony target for each dependency
other than the main file, causing each to depend on nothing.  These
dummy rules work around errors B<make> gives if you remove header
files without updating the F<Makefile> to match.

This is typical output:

	
	test.o: test.c test.h
	
	test.h:



=item B<-MT> I<target>


Change the target of the rule emitted by dependency generation.  By
default CPP takes the name of the main input file, deletes any
directory components and any file suffix such as B<.c>, and
appends the platform's usual object suffix.  The result is the target.

An B<-MT> option sets the target to be exactly the string you
specify.  If you want multiple targets, you can specify them as a single
argument to B<-MT>, or use multiple B<-MT> options.

For example, B<S<-MT '$(objpfx)foo.o'>> might give

	
	$(objpfx)foo.o: foo.c



=item B<-MQ> I<target>


Same as B<-MT>, but it quotes any characters which are special to
Make.  B<S<-MQ '$(objpfx)foo.o'>> gives

	
	$$(objpfx)foo.o: foo.c


The default target is automatically quoted, as if it were given with
B<-MQ>.


=item B<-MD>

B<-MD> is equivalent to B<-M -MF> I<file>, except that
B<-E> is not implied.  The driver determines I<file> based on
whether an B<-o> option is given.  If it is, the driver uses its
argument but with a suffix of F<.d>, otherwise it takes the name
of the input file, removes any directory components and suffix, and
applies a F<.d> suffix.

If B<-MD> is used in conjunction with B<-E>, any
B<-o> switch is understood to specify the dependency output file, but if used without B<-E>, each B<-o>
is understood to specify a target object file.

Since B<-E> is not implied, B<-MD> can be used to generate
a dependency output file as a side effect of the compilation process.


=item B<-MMD>

Like B<-MD> except mention only user header files, not system
header files.


=item B<-fpreprocessed>

Indicate to the preprocessor that the input file has already been
preprocessed.  This suppresses things like macro expansion, trigraph
conversion, escaped newline splicing, and processing of most directives.
The preprocessor still recognizes and removes comments, so that you can
pass a file preprocessed with B<-C> to the compiler without
problems.  In this mode the integrated preprocessor is little more than
a tokenizer for the front ends.

B<-fpreprocessed> is implicit if the input file has one of the
extensions B<.i>, B<.ii> or B<.mi>.  These are the
extensions that GCC uses for preprocessed files created by
B<-save-temps>.


=item B<-fdirectives-only>

When preprocessing, handle directives, but do not expand macros.

The option's behavior depends on the B<-E> and B<-fpreprocessed>
options.

With B<-E>, preprocessing is limited to the handling of directives
such as C<#define>, C<#ifdef>, and C<#error>.  Other
preprocessor operations, such as macro expansion and trigraph
conversion are not performed.  In addition, the B<-dD> option is
implicitly enabled.

With B<-fpreprocessed>, predefinition of command line and most
builtin macros is disabled.  Macros such as C<__LINE__>, which are
contextually dependent, are handled normally.  This enables compilation of
files previously preprocessed with C<-E -fdirectives-only>.

With both B<-E> and B<-fpreprocessed>, the rules for
B<-fpreprocessed> take precedence.  This enables full preprocessing of
files previously preprocessed with C<-E -fdirectives-only>.


=item B<-fdollars-in-identifiers>


Accept B<$> in identifiers.


=item B<-fextended-identifiers>

Accept universal character names in identifiers.  This option is
enabled by default for C99 (and later C standard versions) and C++.


=item B<-fno-canonical-system-headers>

When preprocessing, do not shorten system header paths with canonicalization.


=item B<-ftabstop=>I<width>

Set the distance between tab stops.  This helps the preprocessor report
correct column numbers in warnings or errors, even if tabs appear on the
line.  If the value is less than 1 or greater than 100, the option is
ignored.  The default is 8.


=item B<-ftrack-macro-expansion>[B<=>I<level>]

Track locations of tokens across macro expansions. This allows the
compiler to emit diagnostic about the current macro expansion stack
when a compilation error occurs in a macro expansion. Using this
option makes the preprocessor and the compiler consume more
memory. The I<level> parameter can be used to choose the level of
precision of token location tracking thus decreasing the memory
consumption if necessary. Value B<0> of I<level> de-activates
this option. Value B<1> tracks tokens locations in a
degraded mode for the sake of minimal memory overhead. In this mode
all tokens resulting from the expansion of an argument of a
function-like macro have the same location. Value B<2> tracks
tokens locations completely. This value is the most memory hungry.
When this option is given no argument, the default parameter value is
B<2>.

Note that C<-ftrack-macro-expansion=2> is activated by default.


=item B<-fmacro-prefix-map=>I<old>B<=>I<new>

When preprocessing files residing in directory F<I<old>>,
expand the C<__FILE__> and C<__BASE_FILE__> macros as if the
files resided in directory F<I<new>> instead.  This can be used
to change an absolute path to a relative path by using F<.> for
I<new> which can result in more reproducible builds that are
location independent.  This option also affects
C<__builtin_FILE()> during compilation.  See also
B<-ffile-prefix-map>.


=item B<-fexec-charset=>I<charset>

Set the execution character set, used for string and character
constants.  The default is UTF-8.  I<charset> can be any encoding
supported by the system's C<iconv> library routine.


=item B<-fwide-exec-charset=>I<charset>

Set the wide execution character set, used for wide string and
character constants.  The default is UTF-32 or UTF-16, whichever
corresponds to the width of C<wchar_t>.  As with
B<-fexec-charset>, I<charset> can be any encoding supported
by the system's C<iconv> library routine; however, you will have
problems with encodings that do not fit exactly in C<wchar_t>.


=item B<-finput-charset=>I<charset>

Set the input character set, used for translation from the character
set of the input file to the source character set used by GCC.  If the
locale does not specify, or GCC cannot get this information from the
locale, the default is UTF-8.  This can be overridden by either the locale
or this command-line option.  Currently the command-line option takes
precedence if there's a conflict.  I<charset> can be any encoding
supported by the system's C<iconv> library routine.


=item B<-fpch-deps>

When using precompiled headers, this flag
causes the dependency-output flags to also list the files from the
precompiled header's dependencies.  If not specified, only the
precompiled header are listed and not the files that were used to
create it, because those files are not consulted when a precompiled
header is used.


=item B<-fpch-preprocess>

This option allows use of a precompiled header together with B<-E>.  It inserts a special C<#pragma>,
C<#pragma GCC pch_preprocess "I<filename>"> in the output to mark
the place where the precompiled header was found, and its I<filename>.
When B<-fpreprocessed> is in use, GCC recognizes this C<#pragma>
and loads the PCH.

This option is off by default, because the resulting preprocessed output
is only really suitable as input to GCC.  It is switched on by
B<-save-temps>.

You should not write this C<#pragma> in your own code, but it is
safe to edit the filename if the PCH file is available in a different
location.  The filename may be absolute or it may be relative to GCC's
current directory.


=item B<-fworking-directory>

Enable generation of linemarkers in the preprocessor output that
let the compiler know the current working directory at the time of
preprocessing.  When this option is enabled, the preprocessor
emits, after the initial linemarker, a second linemarker with the
current working directory followed by two slashes.  GCC uses this
directory, when it's present in the preprocessed input, as the
directory emitted as the current working directory in some debugging
information formats.  This option is implicitly enabled if debugging
information is enabled, but this can be inhibited with the negated
form B<-fno-working-directory>.  If the B<-P> flag is
present in the command line, this option has no effect, since no
C<#line> directives are emitted whatsoever.


=item B<-A> I<predicate>B<=>I<answer>

Make an assertion with the predicate I<predicate> and answer
I<answer>.  This form is preferred to the older form B<-A>
I<predicate>B<(>I<answer>B<)>, which is still supported, because
it does not use shell special characters.


=item B<-A ->I<predicate>B<=>I<answer>

Cancel an assertion with the predicate I<predicate> and answer
I<answer>.


=item B<-C>

Do not discard comments.  All comments are passed through to the output
file, except for comments in processed directives, which are deleted
along with the directive.

You should be prepared for side effects when using B<-C>; it
causes the preprocessor to treat comments as tokens in their own right.
For example, comments appearing at the start of what would be a
directive line have the effect of turning that line into an ordinary
source line, since the first token on the line is no longer a B<#>.


=item B<-CC>

Do not discard comments, including during macro expansion.  This is
like B<-C>, except that comments contained within macros are
also passed through to the output file where the macro is expanded.

In addition to the side effects of the B<-C> option, the
B<-CC> option causes all C++-style comments inside a macro
to be converted to C-style comments.  This is to prevent later use
of that macro from inadvertently commenting out the remainder of
the source line.

The B<-CC> option is generally used to support lint comments.


=item B<-P>

Inhibit generation of linemarkers in the output from the preprocessor.
This might be useful when running the preprocessor on something that is
not C code, and will be sent to a program which might be confused by the
linemarkers.


=item B<-traditional>


=item B<-traditional-cpp>


Try to imitate the behavior of pre-standard C preprocessors, as
opposed to ISO C preprocessors.
See the GNU CPP manual for details.

Note that GCC does not otherwise attempt to emulate a pre-standard 
C compiler, and these options are only supported with the B<-E> 
switch, or when invoking CPP explicitly.


=item B<-trigraphs>

Support ISO C trigraphs.
These are three-character sequences, all starting with B<??>, that
are defined by ISO C to stand for single characters.  For example,
B<??/> stands for B<\>, so B<'??/n'> is a character
constant for a newline.

The nine trigraphs and their replacements are

	
	Trigraph:       ??(  ??)  ??<  ??>  ??=  ??/  ??'  ??!  ??-
	Replacement:      [    ]    {    }    #    \    ^    |    ~


By default, GCC ignores trigraphs, but in
standard-conforming modes it converts them.  See the B<-std> and
B<-ansi> options.


=item B<-remap>

Enable special code to work around file systems which only permit very
short file names, such as MS-DOS.


=item B<-H>

Print the name of each header file used, in addition to other normal
activities.  Each name is indented to show how deep in the
B<#include> stack it is.  Precompiled header files are also
printed, even if they are found to be invalid; an invalid precompiled
header file is printed with B<...x> and a valid one with B<...!> .


=item B<-d>I<letters>

Says to make debugging dumps during compilation as specified by
I<letters>.  The flags documented here are those relevant to the
preprocessor.  Other I<letters> are interpreted
by the compiler proper, or reserved for future versions of GCC, and so
are silently ignored.  If you specify I<letters> whose behavior
conflicts, the result is undefined.



=over 4


=item B<-dM>

Instead of the normal output, generate a list of B<#define>
directives for all the macros defined during the execution of the
preprocessor, including predefined macros.  This gives you a way of
finding out what is predefined in your version of the preprocessor.
Assuming you have no file F<foo.h>, the command

	
	touch foo.h; cpp -dM foo.h


shows all the predefined macros.

If you use B<-dM> without the B<-E> option, B<-dM> is
interpreted as a synonym for B<-fdump-rtl-mach>.



=item B<-dD>

Like B<-dM> except in two respects: it does I<not> include the
predefined macros, and it outputs I<both> the B<#define>
directives and the result of preprocessing.  Both kinds of output go to
the standard output file.


=item B<-dN>

Like B<-dD>, but emit only the macro names, not their expansions.


=item B<-dI>

Output B<#include> directives in addition to the result of
preprocessing.


=item B<-dU>

Like B<-dD> except that only macros that are expanded, or whose
definedness is tested in preprocessor directives, are output; the
output is delayed until the use or test of the macro; and
B<#undef> directives are also output for macros tested but
undefined at the time.

=back



=item B<-fdebug-cpp>

This option is only useful for debugging GCC.  When used from CPP or with
B<-E>, it dumps debugging information about location maps.  Every
token in the output is preceded by the dump of the map its location
belongs to.

When used from GCC without B<-E>, this option has no effect.


=item B<-Wp,>I<option>

You can use B<-Wp,>I<option> to bypass the compiler driver
and pass I<option> directly through to the preprocessor.  If
I<option> contains commas, it is split into multiple options at the
commas.  However, many options are modified, translated or interpreted
by the compiler driver before being passed to the preprocessor, and
B<-Wp> forcibly bypasses this phase.  The preprocessor's direct
interface is undocumented and subject to change, so whenever possible
you should avoid using B<-Wp> and let the driver handle the
options instead.


=item B<-Xpreprocessor> I<option>

Pass I<option> as an option to the preprocessor.  You can use this to
supply system-specific preprocessor options that GCC does not 
recognize.

If you want to pass an option that takes an argument, you must use
B<-Xpreprocessor> twice, once for the option and once for the argument.


=item B<-no-integrated-cpp>

Perform preprocessing as a separate pass before compilation.
By default, GCC performs preprocessing as an integrated part of
input tokenization and parsing.
If this option is provided, the appropriate language front end
(B<cc1>, B<cc1plus>, or B<cc1obj> for C, C++,
and Objective-C, respectively) is instead invoked twice,
once for preprocessing only and once for actual compilation
of the preprocessed input.
This option may be useful in conjunction with the B<-B> or
B<-wrapper> options to specify an alternate preprocessor or
perform additional processing of the program source between
normal preprocessing and compilation.


=back



=head2 Passing Options to the Assembler


You can pass options to the assembler.


=over 4


=item B<-Wa,>I<option>

Pass I<option> as an option to the assembler.  If I<option>
contains commas, it is split into multiple options at the commas.


=item B<-Xassembler> I<option>

Pass I<option> as an option to the assembler.  You can use this to
supply system-specific assembler options that GCC does not
recognize.

If you want to pass an option that takes an argument, you must use
B<-Xassembler> twice, once for the option and once for the argument.


=back



=head2 Options for Linking


These options come into play when the compiler links object files into
an executable output file.  They are meaningless if the compiler is
not doing a link step.


=over 4


=item I<object-file-name>

A file name that does not end in a special recognized suffix is
considered to name an object file or library.  (Object files are
distinguished from libraries by the linker according to the file
contents.)  If linking is done, these object files are used as input
to the linker.


=item B<-c>


=item B<-S>


=item B<-E>

If any of these options is used, then the linker is not run, and
object file names should not be used as arguments.  


=item B<-flinker-output=>I<type>

This option controls the code generation of the link time optimizer.  By
default the linker output is determined by the linker plugin automatically. For
debugging the compiler and in the case of incremental linking to non-lto object
file is desired, it may be useful to control the type manually.

If I<type> is B<exec> the code generation is configured to produce static
binary. In this case B<-fpic> and B<-fpie> are both disabled.

If I<type> is B<dyn> the code generation is configured to produce shared
library. In this case B<-fpic> or B<-fPIC> is preserved, but not
enabled automatically.  This makes it possible to build shared libraries without
position independent code on architectures this is possible, i.e. on x86.

If I<type> is B<pie> the code generation is configured to produce
B<-fpie> executable. This result in similar optimizations as B<exec>
except that B<-fpie> is not disabled if specified at compilation time.

If I<type> is B<rel> the compiler assumes that incremental linking is
done.  The sections containing intermediate code for link-time optimization are
merged, pre-optimized, and output to the resulting object file. In addition, if
B<-ffat-lto-objects> is specified the binary code is produced for future
non-lto linking. The object file produced by incremental linking will be smaller
than a static library produced from the same object files.  At link-time the
result of incremental linking will also load faster to compiler than a static
library assuming that majority of objects in the library are used.

Finally B<nolto-rel> configure compiler to for incremental linking where
code generation is forced, final binary is produced and the intermediate code
for later link-time optimization is stripped. When multiple object files are
linked together the resulting code will be optimized better than with link time
optimizations disabled (for example, the cross-module inlining will happen),
most of benefits of whole program optimizations are however lost. 

During the incremental link (by B<-r>) the linker plugin will default to
B<rel>. With current interfaces to GNU Binutils it is however not
possible to link incrementally LTO objects and non-LTO objects into a single
mixed object file.  In the case any of object files in incremental link cannot
be used for link-time optimization the linker plugin will output warning and
use B<nolto-rel>. To maintain the whole program optimization it is
recommended to link such objects into static library instead. Alternatively it
is possible to use H.J. Lu's binutils with support for mixed objects.


=item B<-fuse-ld=bfd>

Use the B<bfd> linker instead of the default linker.


=item B<-fuse-ld=gold>

Use the B<gold> linker instead of the default linker.


=item B<-fuse-ld=lld>

Use the LLVM B<lld> linker instead of the default linker.


=item B<-l>I<library>


=item B<-l> I<library>

Search the library named I<library> when linking.  (The second
alternative with the library as a separate argument is only for
POSIX compliance and is not recommended.)

The B<-l> option is passed directly to the linker by GCC.  Refer
to your linker documentation for exact details.  The general
description below applies to the GNU linker.  

The linker searches a standard list of directories for the library.
The directories searched include several standard system directories
plus any that you specify with B<-L>.

Static libraries are archives of object files, and have file names
like F<libI<library>.a>.  Some targets also support shared
libraries, which typically have names like F<libI<library>.so>.
If both static and shared libraries are found, the linker gives
preference to linking with the shared library unless the
B<-static> option is used.

It makes a difference where in the command you write this option; the
linker searches and processes libraries and object files in the order they
are specified.  Thus, B<foo.o -lz bar.o> searches library B<z>
after file F<foo.o> but before F<bar.o>.  If F<bar.o> refers
to functions in B<z>, those functions may not be loaded.


=item B<-lobjc>

You need this special case of the B<-l> option in order to
link an Objective-C or Objective-C++ program.


=item B<-nostartfiles>

Do not use the standard system startup files when linking.
The standard system libraries are used normally, unless B<-nostdlib>,
B<-nolibc>, or B<-nodefaultlibs> is used.


=item B<-nodefaultlibs>

Do not use the standard system libraries when linking.
Only the libraries you specify are passed to the linker, and options
specifying linkage of the system libraries, such as B<-static-libgcc>
or B<-shared-libgcc>, are ignored.  
The standard startup files are used normally, unless B<-nostartfiles>
is used.  

The compiler may generate calls to C<memcmp>,
C<memset>, C<memcpy> and C<memmove>.
These entries are usually resolved by entries in
libc.  These entry points should be supplied through some other
mechanism when this option is specified.


=item B<-nolibc>

Do not use the C library or system libraries tightly coupled with it when
linking.  Still link with the startup files, F<libgcc> or toolchain
provided language support libraries such as F<libgnat>, F<libgfortran>
or F<libstdc++> unless options preventing their inclusion are used as
well.  This typically removes B<-lc> from the link command line, as well
as system libraries that normally go with it and become meaningless when
absence of a C library is assumed, for example B<-lpthread> or
B<-lm> in some configurations.  This is intended for bare-board
targets when there is indeed no C library available.


=item B<-nostdlib>

Do not use the standard system startup files or libraries when linking.
No startup files and only the libraries you specify are passed to
the linker, and options specifying linkage of the system libraries, such as
B<-static-libgcc> or B<-shared-libgcc>, are ignored.

The compiler may generate calls to C<memcmp>, C<memset>,
C<memcpy> and C<memmove>.
These entries are usually resolved by entries in
libc.  These entry points should be supplied through some other
mechanism when this option is specified.

One of the standard libraries bypassed by B<-nostdlib> and
B<-nodefaultlibs> is F<libgcc.a>, a library of internal subroutines
which GCC uses to overcome shortcomings of particular machines, or special
needs for some languages.

In most cases, you need F<libgcc.a> even when you want to avoid
other standard libraries.  In other words, when you specify B<-nostdlib>
or B<-nodefaultlibs> you should usually specify B<-lgcc> as well.
This ensures that you have no unresolved references to internal GCC
library subroutines.
(An example of such an internal subroutine is C<__main>, used to ensure C++
constructors are called.)


=item B<-e> I<entry>


=item B<--entry=>I<entry>


Specify that the program entry point is I<entry>.  The argument is
interpreted by the linker; the GNU linker accepts either a symbol name
or an address.


=item B<-pie>

Produce a dynamically linked position independent executable on targets
that support it.  For predictable results, you must also specify the same
set of options used for compilation (B<-fpie>, B<-fPIE>,
or model suboptions) when you specify this linker option.


=item B<-no-pie>

Don't produce a dynamically linked position independent executable.


=item B<-static-pie>

Produce a static position independent executable on targets that support
it.  A static position independent executable is similar to a static
executable, but can be loaded at any address without a dynamic linker.
For predictable results, you must also specify the same set of options
used for compilation (B<-fpie>, B<-fPIE>, or model
suboptions) when you specify this linker option.


=item B<-pthread>

Link with the POSIX threads library.  This option is supported on 
GNU/Linux targets, most other Unix derivatives, and also on 
x86 Cygwin and MinGW targets.  On some targets this option also sets 
flags for the preprocessor, so it should be used consistently for both
compilation and linking.


=item B<-r>

Produce a relocatable object as output.  This is also known as partial
linking.


=item B<-rdynamic>

Pass the flag B<-export-dynamic> to the ELF linker, on targets
that support it. This instructs the linker to add all symbols, not
only used ones, to the dynamic symbol table. This option is needed
for some uses of C<dlopen> or to allow obtaining backtraces
from within a program.


=item B<-s>

Remove all symbol table and relocation information from the executable.


=item B<-static>

On systems that support dynamic linking, this overrides B<-pie>
and prevents linking with the shared libraries.  On other systems, this
option has no effect.


=item B<-shared>

Produce a shared object which can then be linked with other objects to
form an executable.  Not all systems support this option.  For predictable
results, you must also specify the same set of options used for compilation
(B<-fpic>, B<-fPIC>, or model suboptions) when
you specify this linker option.[1]


=item B<-shared-libgcc>


=item B<-static-libgcc>

On systems that provide F<libgcc> as a shared library, these options
force the use of either the shared or static version, respectively.
If no shared version of F<libgcc> was built when the compiler was
configured, these options have no effect.

There are several situations in which an application should use the
shared F<libgcc> instead of the static version.  The most common
of these is when the application wishes to throw and catch exceptions
across different shared libraries.  In that case, each of the libraries
as well as the application itself should use the shared F<libgcc>.

Therefore, the G++ driver automatically adds B<-shared-libgcc>
whenever you build a shared library or a main executable, because C++
programs typically use exceptions, so this is the right thing to do.

If, instead, you use the GCC driver to create shared libraries, you may
find that they are not always linked with the shared F<libgcc>.
If GCC finds, at its configuration time, that you have a non-GNU linker
or a GNU linker that does not support option B<--eh-frame-hdr>,
it links the shared version of F<libgcc> into shared libraries
by default.  Otherwise, it takes advantage of the linker and optimizes
away the linking with the shared version of F<libgcc>, linking with
the static version of libgcc by default.  This allows exceptions to
propagate through such shared libraries, without incurring relocation
costs at library load time.

However, if a library or main executable is supposed to throw or catch
exceptions, you must link it using the G++ driver, or using the option
B<-shared-libgcc>, such that it is linked with the shared
F<libgcc>.


=item B<-static-libasan>

When the B<-fsanitize=address> option is used to link a program,
the GCC driver automatically links against B<libasan>.  If
F<libasan> is available as a shared library, and the B<-static>
option is not used, then this links against the shared version of
F<libasan>.  The B<-static-libasan> option directs the GCC
driver to link F<libasan> statically, without necessarily linking
other libraries statically.


=item B<-static-libtsan>

When the B<-fsanitize=thread> option is used to link a program,
the GCC driver automatically links against B<libtsan>.  If
F<libtsan> is available as a shared library, and the B<-static>
option is not used, then this links against the shared version of
F<libtsan>.  The B<-static-libtsan> option directs the GCC
driver to link F<libtsan> statically, without necessarily linking
other libraries statically.


=item B<-static-liblsan>

When the B<-fsanitize=leak> option is used to link a program,
the GCC driver automatically links against B<liblsan>.  If
F<liblsan> is available as a shared library, and the B<-static>
option is not used, then this links against the shared version of
F<liblsan>.  The B<-static-liblsan> option directs the GCC
driver to link F<liblsan> statically, without necessarily linking
other libraries statically.


=item B<-static-libubsan>

When the B<-fsanitize=undefined> option is used to link a program,
the GCC driver automatically links against B<libubsan>.  If
F<libubsan> is available as a shared library, and the B<-static>
option is not used, then this links against the shared version of
F<libubsan>.  The B<-static-libubsan> option directs the GCC
driver to link F<libubsan> statically, without necessarily linking
other libraries statically.


=item B<-static-libstdc++>

When the B<g++> program is used to link a C++ program, it
normally automatically links against B<libstdc++>.  If
F<libstdc++> is available as a shared library, and the
B<-static> option is not used, then this links against the
shared version of F<libstdc++>.  That is normally fine.  However, it
is sometimes useful to freeze the version of F<libstdc++> used by
the program without going all the way to a fully static link.  The
B<-static-libstdc++> option directs the B<g++> driver to
link F<libstdc++> statically, without necessarily linking other
libraries statically.


=item B<-symbolic>

Bind references to global symbols when building a shared object.  Warn
about any unresolved references (unless overridden by the link editor
option B<-Xlinker -z -Xlinker defs>).  Only a few systems support
this option.


=item B<-T> I<script>

Use I<script> as the linker script.  This option is supported by most
systems using the GNU linker.  On some targets, such as bare-board
targets without an operating system, the B<-T> option may be required
when linking to avoid references to undefined symbols.


=item B<-Xlinker> I<option>

Pass I<option> as an option to the linker.  You can use this to
supply system-specific linker options that GCC does not recognize.

If you want to pass an option that takes a separate argument, you must use
B<-Xlinker> twice, once for the option and once for the argument.
For example, to pass B<-assert definitions>, you must write
B<-Xlinker -assert -Xlinker definitions>.  It does not work to write
B<-Xlinker "-assert definitions">, because this passes the entire
string as a single argument, which is not what the linker expects.

When using the GNU linker, it is usually more convenient to pass
arguments to linker options using the I<option>B<=>I<value>
syntax than as separate arguments.  For example, you can specify
B<-Xlinker -Map=output.map> rather than
B<-Xlinker -Map -Xlinker output.map>.  Other linkers may not support
this syntax for command-line options.


=item B<-Wl,>I<option>

Pass I<option> as an option to the linker.  If I<option> contains
commas, it is split into multiple options at the commas.  You can use this
syntax to pass an argument to the option.
For example, B<-Wl,-Map,output.map> passes B<-Map output.map> to the
linker.  When using the GNU linker, you can also get the same effect with
B<-Wl,-Map=output.map>.


=item B<-u> I<symbol>

Pretend the symbol I<symbol> is undefined, to force linking of
library modules to define it.  You can use B<-u> multiple times with
different symbols to force loading of additional library modules.


=item B<-z> I<keyword>

B<-z> is passed directly on to the linker along with the keyword
I<keyword>. See the section in the documentation of your linker for
permitted values and their meanings.

=back



=head2 Options for Directory Search


These options specify directories to search for header files, for
libraries and for parts of the compiler:


=over 4





=item B<-I> I<dir>


=item B<-iquote> I<dir>


=item B<-isystem> I<dir>


=item B<-idirafter> I<dir>

Add the directory I<dir> to the list of directories to be searched
for header files during preprocessing.
If I<dir> begins with B<=> or C<$SYSROOT>, then the B<=>
or C<$SYSROOT> is replaced by the sysroot prefix; see
B<--sysroot> and B<-isysroot>.

Directories specified with B<-iquote> apply only to the quote 
form of the directive, C<S<#include "I<file>">>.
Directories specified with B<-I>, B<-isystem>, 
or B<-idirafter> apply to lookup for both the
C<S<#include "I<file>">> and
C<S<#include E<lt>I<file>E<gt>>> directives.

You can specify any number or combination of these options on the 
command line to search for header files in several directories.  
The lookup order is as follows:


=over 4


=item Z<>1.

For the quote form of the include directive, the directory of the current
file is searched first.


=item Z<>2.

For the quote form of the include directive, the directories specified
by B<-iquote> options are searched in left-to-right order,
as they appear on the command line.


=item Z<>3.

Directories specified with B<-I> options are scanned in
left-to-right order.


=item Z<>4.

Directories specified with B<-isystem> options are scanned in
left-to-right order.


=item Z<>5.

Standard system directories are scanned.


=item Z<>6.

Directories specified with B<-idirafter> options are scanned in
left-to-right order.

=back


You can use B<-I> to override a system header
file, substituting your own version, since these directories are
searched before the standard system header file directories.  
However, you should
not use this option to add directories that contain vendor-supplied
system header files; use B<-isystem> for that.

The B<-isystem> and B<-idirafter> options also mark the directory
as a system directory, so that it gets the same special treatment that
is applied to the standard system directories.

If a standard system include directory, or a directory specified with
B<-isystem>, is also specified with B<-I>, the B<-I>
option is ignored.  The directory is still searched but as a
system directory at its normal position in the system include chain.
This is to ensure that GCC's procedure to fix buggy system headers and
the ordering for the C<#include_next> directive are not inadvertently
changed.
If you really need to change the search order for system directories,
use the B<-nostdinc> and/or B<-isystem> options.


=item B<-I->

Split the include path.
This option has been deprecated.  Please use B<-iquote> instead for
B<-I> directories before the B<-I-> and remove the B<-I->
option.

Any directories specified with B<-I>
options before B<-I-> are searched only for headers requested with
C<S<#include "I<file>">>; they are not searched for
C<S<#include E<lt>I<file>E<gt>>>.  If additional directories are
specified with B<-I> options after the B<-I->, those
directories are searched for all B<#include> directives.

In addition, B<-I-> inhibits the use of the directory of the current
file directory as the first search directory for C<S<#include
"I<file>">>.  There is no way to override this effect of B<-I->.


=item B<-iprefix> I<prefix>

Specify I<prefix> as the prefix for subsequent B<-iwithprefix>
options.  If the prefix represents a directory, you should include the
final B</>.


=item B<-iwithprefix> I<dir>


=item B<-iwithprefixbefore> I<dir>

Append I<dir> to the prefix specified previously with
B<-iprefix>, and add the resulting directory to the include search
path.  B<-iwithprefixbefore> puts it in the same place B<-I>
would; B<-iwithprefix> puts it where B<-idirafter> would.


=item B<-isysroot> I<dir>

This option is like the B<--sysroot> option, but applies only to
header files (except for Darwin targets, where it applies to both header
files and libraries).  See the B<--sysroot> option for more
information.


=item B<-imultilib> I<dir>

Use I<dir> as a subdirectory of the directory containing
target-specific C++ headers.


=item B<-nostdinc>

Do not search the standard system directories for header files.
Only the directories explicitly specified with B<-I>,
B<-iquote>, B<-isystem>, and/or B<-idirafter>
options (and the directory of the current file, if appropriate) 
are searched.


=item B<-nostdinc++>

Do not search for header files in the C++-specific standard directories,
but do still search the other standard directories.  (This option is
used when building the C++ library.)



=item B<-iplugindir=>I<dir>

Set the directory to search for plugins that are passed
by B<-fplugin=>I<name> instead of
B<-fplugin=>I<path>B</>I<name>B<.so>.  This option is not meant
to be used by the user, but only passed by the driver.


=item B<-L>I<dir>

Add directory I<dir> to the list of directories to be searched
for B<-l>.


=item B<-B>I<prefix>

This option specifies where to find the executables, libraries,
include files, and data files of the compiler itself.

The compiler driver program runs one or more of the subprograms
B<cpp>, B<cc1>, B<as> and B<ld>.  It tries
I<prefix> as a prefix for each program it tries to run, both with and
without I<machine>B</>I<version>B</> for the corresponding target
machine and compiler version.

For each subprogram to be run, the compiler driver first tries the
B<-B> prefix, if any.  If that name is not found, or if B<-B>
is not specified, the driver tries two standard prefixes, 
F</usr/lib/gcc/> and F</usr/local/lib/gcc/>.  If neither of
those results in a file name that is found, the unmodified program
name is searched for using the directories specified in your
B<PATH> environment variable.

The compiler checks to see if the path provided by B<-B>
refers to a directory, and if necessary it adds a directory
separator character at the end of the path.

B<-B> prefixes that effectively specify directory names also apply
to libraries in the linker, because the compiler translates these
options into B<-L> options for the linker.  They also apply to
include files in the preprocessor, because the compiler translates these
options into B<-isystem> options for the preprocessor.  In this case,
the compiler appends B<include> to the prefix.

The runtime support file F<libgcc.a> can also be searched for using
the B<-B> prefix, if needed.  If it is not found there, the two
standard prefixes above are tried, and that is all.  The file is left
out of the link if it is not found by those means.

Another way to specify a prefix much like the B<-B> prefix is to use
the environment variable B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX>.  

As a special kludge, if the path provided by B<-B> is
F<[dir/]stageI<N>/>, where I<N> is a number in the range 0 to
9, then it is replaced by F<[dir/]include>.  This is to help
with boot-strapping the compiler.


=item B<-no-canonical-prefixes>

Do not expand any symbolic links, resolve references to B</../>
or B</./>, or make the path absolute when generating a relative
prefix.


=item B<--sysroot=>I<dir>

Use I<dir> as the logical root directory for headers and libraries.
For example, if the compiler normally searches for headers in
F</usr/include> and libraries in F</usr/lib>, it instead
searches F<I<dir>/usr/include> and F<I<dir>/usr/lib>.

If you use both this option and the B<-isysroot> option, then
the B<--sysroot> option applies to libraries, but the
B<-isysroot> option applies to header files.

The GNU linker (beginning with version 2.16) has the necessary support
for this option.  If your linker does not support this option, the
header file aspect of B<--sysroot> still works, but the
library aspect does not.


=item B<--no-sysroot-suffix>

For some targets, a suffix is added to the root directory specified
with B<--sysroot>, depending on the other options used, so that
headers may for example be found in
F<I<dir>/I<suffix>/usr/include> instead of
F<I<dir>/usr/include>.  This option disables the addition of
such a suffix.


=back



=head2 Options for Code Generation Conventions


These machine-independent options control the interface conventions
used in code generation.

Most of them have both positive and negative forms; the negative form
of B<-ffoo> is B<-fno-foo>.  In the table below, only
one of the forms is listed---the one that is not the default.  You
can figure out the other form by either removing B<no-> or adding
it.


=over 4


=item B<-fstack-reuse=>I<reuse-level>

This option controls stack space reuse for user declared local/auto variables
and compiler generated temporaries.  I<reuse_level> can be B<all>,
B<named_vars>, or B<none>. B<all> enables stack reuse for all
local variables and temporaries, B<named_vars> enables the reuse only for
user defined local variables with names, and B<none> disables stack reuse
completely. The default value is B<all>. The option is needed when the
program extends the lifetime of a scoped local variable or a compiler generated
temporary beyond the end point defined by the language.  When a lifetime of
a variable ends, and if the variable lives in memory, the optimizing compiler
has the freedom to reuse its stack space with other temporaries or scoped
local variables whose live range does not overlap with it. Legacy code extending
local lifetime is likely to break with the stack reuse optimization.

For example,

	
	   int *p;
	   {
	     int local1;
	
	     p = &local1;
	     local1 = 10;
	     ....
	   }
	   {
	      int local2;
	      local2 = 20;
	      ...
	   }
	
	   if (*p == 10)  // out of scope use of local1
	     {
	
	     }


Another example:
	
	
	   struct A
	   {
	       A(int k) : i(k), j(k) { }
	       int i;
	       int j;
	   };
	
	   A *ap;
	
	   void foo(const A& ar)
	   {
	      ap = &ar;
	   }
	
	   void bar()
	   {
	      foo(A(10)); // temp object's lifetime ends when foo returns
	
	      {
	        A a(20);
	        ....
	      }
	      ap->i+= 10;  // ap references out of scope temp whose space
	                   // is reused with a. What is the value of ap->i?
	   }
	


The lifetime of a compiler generated temporary is well defined by the C++
standard. When a lifetime of a temporary ends, and if the temporary lives
in memory, the optimizing compiler has the freedom to reuse its stack
space with other temporaries or scoped local variables whose live range
does not overlap with it. However some of the legacy code relies on
the behavior of older compilers in which temporaries' stack space is
not reused, the aggressive stack reuse can lead to runtime errors. This
option is used to control the temporary stack reuse optimization.


=item B<-ftrapv>

This option generates traps for signed overflow on addition, subtraction,
multiplication operations.
The options B<-ftrapv> and B<-fwrapv> override each other, so using
B<-ftrapv> B<-fwrapv> on the command-line results in
B<-fwrapv> being effective.  Note that only active options override, so
using B<-ftrapv> B<-fwrapv> B<-fno-wrapv> on the command-line
results in B<-ftrapv> being effective.


=item B<-fwrapv>

This option instructs the compiler to assume that signed arithmetic
overflow of addition, subtraction and multiplication wraps around
using twos-complement representation.  This flag enables some optimizations
and disables others.
The options B<-ftrapv> and B<-fwrapv> override each other, so using
B<-ftrapv> B<-fwrapv> on the command-line results in
B<-fwrapv> being effective.  Note that only active options override, so
using B<-ftrapv> B<-fwrapv> B<-fno-wrapv> on the command-line
results in B<-ftrapv> being effective.


=item B<-fwrapv-pointer>

This option instructs the compiler to assume that pointer arithmetic
overflow on addition and subtraction wraps around using twos-complement
representation.  This flag disables some optimizations which assume
pointer overflow is invalid.


=item B<-fstrict-overflow>

This option implies B<-fno-wrapv> B<-fno-wrapv-pointer> and when
negated implies B<-fwrapv> B<-fwrapv-pointer>.


=item B<-fexceptions>

Enable exception handling.  Generates extra code needed to propagate
exceptions.  For some targets, this implies GCC generates frame
unwind information for all functions, which can produce significant data
size overhead, although it does not affect execution.  If you do not
specify this option, GCC enables it by default for languages like
C++ that normally require exception handling, and disables it for
languages like C that do not normally require it.  However, you may need
to enable this option when compiling C code that needs to interoperate
properly with exception handlers written in C++.  You may also wish to
disable this option if you are compiling older C++ programs that don't
use exception handling.


=item B<-fnon-call-exceptions>

Generate code that allows trapping instructions to throw exceptions.
Note that this requires platform-specific runtime support that does
not exist everywhere.  Moreover, it only allows I<trapping>
instructions to throw exceptions, i.e. memory references or floating-point
instructions.  It does not allow exceptions to be thrown from
arbitrary signal handlers such as C<SIGALRM>.


=item B<-fdelete-dead-exceptions>

Consider that instructions that may throw exceptions but don't otherwise
contribute to the execution of the program can be optimized away.
This option is enabled by default for the Ada front end, as permitted by
the Ada language specification.
Optimization passes that cause dead exceptions to be removed are enabled independently at different optimization levels.


=item B<-funwind-tables>

Similar to B<-fexceptions>, except that it just generates any needed
static data, but does not affect the generated code in any other way.
You normally do not need to enable this option; instead, a language processor
that needs this handling enables it on your behalf.


=item B<-fasynchronous-unwind-tables>

Generate unwind table in DWARF format, if supported by target machine.  The
table is exact at each instruction boundary, so it can be used for stack
unwinding from asynchronous events (such as debugger or garbage collector).


=item B<-fno-gnu-unique>

On systems with recent GNU assembler and C library, the C++ compiler
uses the C<STB_GNU_UNIQUE> binding to make sure that definitions
of template static data members and static local variables in inline
functions are unique even in the presence of C<RTLD_LOCAL>; this
is necessary to avoid problems with a library used by two different
C<RTLD_LOCAL> plugins depending on a definition in one of them and
therefore disagreeing with the other one about the binding of the
symbol.  But this causes C<dlclose> to be ignored for affected
DSOs; if your program relies on reinitialization of a DSO via
C<dlclose> and C<dlopen>, you can use
B<-fno-gnu-unique>.


=item B<-fpcc-struct-return>

Return "short" C<struct> and C<union> values in memory like
longer ones, rather than in registers.  This convention is less
efficient, but it has the advantage of allowing intercallability between
GCC-compiled files and files compiled with other compilers, particularly
the Portable C Compiler (pcc).

The precise convention for returning structures in memory depends
on the target configuration macros.

Short structures and unions are those whose size and alignment match
that of some integer type.

B<Warning:> code compiled with the B<-fpcc-struct-return>
switch is not binary compatible with code compiled with the
B<-freg-struct-return> switch.
Use it to conform to a non-default application binary interface.


=item B<-freg-struct-return>

Return C<struct> and C<union> values in registers when possible.
This is more efficient for small structures than
B<-fpcc-struct-return>.

If you specify neither B<-fpcc-struct-return> nor
B<-freg-struct-return>, GCC defaults to whichever convention is
standard for the target.  If there is no standard convention, GCC
defaults to B<-fpcc-struct-return>, except on targets where GCC is
the principal compiler.  In those cases, we can choose the standard, and
we chose the more efficient register return alternative.

B<Warning:> code compiled with the B<-freg-struct-return>
switch is not binary compatible with code compiled with the
B<-fpcc-struct-return> switch.
Use it to conform to a non-default application binary interface.


=item B<-fshort-enums>

Allocate to an C<enum> type only as many bytes as it needs for the
declared range of possible values.  Specifically, the C<enum> type
is equivalent to the smallest integer type that has enough room.

B<Warning:> the B<-fshort-enums> switch causes GCC to generate
code that is not binary compatible with code generated without that switch.
Use it to conform to a non-default application binary interface.


=item B<-fshort-wchar>

Override the underlying type for C<wchar_t> to be C<short
unsigned int> instead of the default for the target.  This option is
useful for building programs to run under WINE.

B<Warning:> the B<-fshort-wchar> switch causes GCC to generate
code that is not binary compatible with code generated without that switch.
Use it to conform to a non-default application binary interface.


=item B<-fno-common>

In C code, this option controls the placement of global variables
