defined without an initializer, known as I<tentative definitions> 
in the C standard.  Tentative definitions are distinct from declarations 
of a variable with the C<extern> keyword, which do not allocate storage.

Unix C compilers have traditionally allocated storage for
uninitialized global variables in a common block.  This allows the
linker to resolve all tentative definitions of the same variable
in different compilation units to the same object, or to a non-tentative
definition.  
This is the behavior specified by B<-fcommon>, and is the default for 
GCC on most targets.  
On the other hand, this behavior is not required by ISO
C, and on some targets may carry a speed or code size penalty on
variable references.

The B<-fno-common> option specifies that the compiler should instead
place uninitialized global variables in the BSS section of the object file.
This inhibits the merging of tentative definitions by the linker so
you get a multiple-definition error if the same 
variable is defined in more than one compilation unit.
Compiling with B<-fno-common> is useful on targets for which
it provides better performance, or if you wish to verify that the
program will work on other systems that always treat uninitialized
variable definitions this way.


=item B<-fno-ident>

Ignore the C<#ident> directive.


=item B<-finhibit-size-directive>

Don't output a C<.size> assembler directive, or anything else that
would cause trouble if the function is split in the middle, and the
two halves are placed at locations far apart in memory.  This option is
used when compiling F<crtstuff.c>; you should not need to use it
for anything else.


=item B<-fverbose-asm>

Put extra commentary information in the generated assembly code to
make it more readable.  This option is generally only of use to those
who actually need to read the generated assembly code (perhaps while
debugging the compiler itself).

B<-fno-verbose-asm>, the default, causes the
extra information to be omitted and is useful when comparing two assembler
files.

The added comments include:


=over 4



=item Z<>*

information on the compiler version and command-line options,


=item Z<>*

the source code lines associated with the assembly instructions,
in the form FILENAME:LINENUMBER:CONTENT OF LINE,


=item Z<>*

hints on which high-level expressions correspond to
the various assembly instruction operands.


=back


For example, given this C source file:

	
	int test (int n)
	{
	  int i;
	  int total = 0;
	
	  for (i = 0; i < n; i++)
	    total += i * i;
	
	  return total;
	}


compiling to (x86_64) assembly via B<-S> and emitting the result
direct to stdout via B<-o> B<->

	
	gcc -S test.c -fverbose-asm -Os -o -


gives output similar to this:

	
		.file	"test.c"
	# GNU C11 (GCC) version 7.0.0 20160809 (experimental) (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)
	  [...snip...]
	# options passed:
	  [...snip...]
	
		.text
		.globl	test
		.type	test, @function
	test:
	.LFB0:
		.cfi_startproc
	# test.c:4:   int total = 0;
		xorl	%eax, %eax	# <retval>
	# test.c:6:   for (i = 0; i < n; i++)
		xorl	%edx, %edx	# i
	.L2:
	# test.c:6:   for (i = 0; i < n; i++)
		cmpl	%edi, %edx	# n, i
		jge	.L5	#,
	# test.c:7:     total += i * i;
		movl	%edx, %ecx	# i, tmp92
		imull	%edx, %ecx	# i, tmp92
	# test.c:6:   for (i = 0; i < n; i++)
		incl	%edx	# i
	# test.c:7:     total += i * i;
		addl	%ecx, %eax	# tmp92, <retval>
		jmp	.L2	#
	.L5:
	# test.c:10: }
		ret
		.cfi_endproc
	.LFE0:
		.size	test, .-test
		.ident	"GCC: (GNU) 7.0.0 20160809 (experimental)"
		.section	.note.GNU-stack,"",@progbits


The comments are intended for humans rather than machines and hence the
precise format of the comments is subject to change.


=item B<-frecord-gcc-switches>

This switch causes the command line used to invoke the
compiler to be recorded into the object file that is being created.
This switch is only implemented on some targets and the exact format
of the recording is target and binary file format dependent, but it
usually takes the form of a section containing ASCII text.  This
switch is related to the B<-fverbose-asm> switch, but that
switch only records information in the assembler output file as
comments, so it never reaches the object file.
See also B<-grecord-gcc-switches> for another
way of storing compiler options into the object file.


=item B<-fpic>

Generate position-independent code (PIC) suitable for use in a shared
library, if supported for the target machine.  Such code accesses all
constant addresses through a global offset table (GOT).  The dynamic
loader resolves the GOT entries when the program starts (the dynamic
loader is not part of GCC; it is part of the operating system).  If
the GOT size for the linked executable exceeds a machine-specific
maximum size, you get an error message from the linker indicating that
B<-fpic> does not work; in that case, recompile with B<-fPIC>
instead.  (These maximums are 8k on the SPARC, 28k on AArch64 and 32k
on the m68k and RS/6000.  The x86 has no such limit.)

Position-independent code requires special support, and therefore works
only on certain machines.  For the x86, GCC supports PIC for System V
but not for the Sun 386i.  Code generated for the IBM RS/6000 is always
position-independent.

When this flag is set, the macros C<__pic__> and C<__PIC__>
are defined to 1.


=item B<-fPIC>

If supported for the target machine, emit position-independent code,
suitable for dynamic linking and avoiding any limit on the size of the
global offset table.  This option makes a difference on AArch64, m68k,
PowerPC and SPARC.

Position-independent code requires special support, and therefore works
only on certain machines.

When this flag is set, the macros C<__pic__> and C<__PIC__>
are defined to 2.


=item B<-fpie>


=item B<-fPIE>

These options are similar to B<-fpic> and B<-fPIC>, but the
generated position-independent code can be only linked into executables.
Usually these options are used to compile code that will be linked using
the B<-pie> GCC option.

B<-fpie> and B<-fPIE> both define the macros
C<__pie__> and C<__PIE__>.  The macros have the value 1
for B<-fpie> and 2 for B<-fPIE>.


=item B<-fno-plt>

Do not use the PLT for external function calls in position-independent code.
Instead, load the callee address at call sites from the GOT and branch to it.
This leads to more efficient code by eliminating PLT stubs and exposing
GOT loads to optimizations.  On architectures such as 32-bit x86 where
PLT stubs expect the GOT pointer in a specific register, this gives more
register allocation freedom to the compiler.
Lazy binding requires use of the PLT; 
with B<-fno-plt> all external symbols are resolved at load time.

Alternatively, the function attribute C<noplt> can be used to avoid calls
through the PLT for specific external functions.

In position-dependent code, a few targets also convert calls to
functions that are marked to not use the PLT to use the GOT instead.


=item B<-fno-jump-tables>

Do not use jump tables for switch statements even where it would be
more efficient than other code generation strategies.  This option is
of use in conjunction with B<-fpic> or B<-fPIC> for
building code that forms part of a dynamic linker and cannot
reference the address of a jump table.  On some targets, jump tables
do not require a GOT and this option is not needed.


=item B<-ffixed->I<reg>

Treat the register named I<reg> as a fixed register; generated code
should never refer to it (except perhaps as a stack pointer, frame
pointer or in some other fixed role).

I<reg> must be the name of a register.  The register names accepted
are machine-specific and are defined in the C<REGISTER_NAMES>
macro in the machine description macro file.

This flag does not have a negative form, because it specifies a
three-way choice.


=item B<-fcall-used->I<reg>

Treat the register named I<reg> as an allocable register that is
clobbered by function calls.  It may be allocated for temporaries or
variables that do not live across a call.  Functions compiled this way
do not save and restore the register I<reg>.

It is an error to use this flag with the frame pointer or stack pointer.
Use of this flag for other registers that have fixed pervasive roles in
the machine's execution model produces disastrous results.

This flag does not have a negative form, because it specifies a
three-way choice.


=item B<-fcall-saved->I<reg>

Treat the register named I<reg> as an allocable register saved by
functions.  It may be allocated even for temporaries or variables that
live across a call.  Functions compiled this way save and restore
the register I<reg> if they use it.

It is an error to use this flag with the frame pointer or stack pointer.
Use of this flag for other registers that have fixed pervasive roles in
the machine's execution model produces disastrous results.

A different sort of disaster results from the use of this flag for
a register in which function values may be returned.

This flag does not have a negative form, because it specifies a
three-way choice.


=item B<-fpack-struct[=>I<n>B<]>

Without a value specified, pack all structure members together without
holes.  When a value is specified (which must be a small power of two), pack
structure members according to this value, representing the maximum
alignment (that is, objects with default alignment requirements larger than
this are output potentially unaligned at the next fitting location.

B<Warning:> the B<-fpack-struct> switch causes GCC to generate
code that is not binary compatible with code generated without that switch.
Additionally, it makes the code suboptimal.
Use it to conform to a non-default application binary interface.


=item B<-fleading-underscore>

This option and its counterpart, B<-fno-leading-underscore>, forcibly
change the way C symbols are represented in the object file.  One use
is to help link with legacy assembly code.

B<Warning:> the B<-fleading-underscore> switch causes GCC to
generate code that is not binary compatible with code generated without that
switch.  Use it to conform to a non-default application binary interface.
Not all targets provide complete support for this switch.


=item B<-ftls-model=>I<model>

Alter the thread-local storage model to be used.
The I<model> argument should be one of B<global-dynamic>,
B<local-dynamic>, B<initial-exec> or B<local-exec>.
Note that the choice is subject to optimization: the compiler may use
a more efficient model for symbols not visible outside of the translation
unit, or if B<-fpic> is not given on the command line.

The default without B<-fpic> is B<initial-exec>; with
B<-fpic> the default is B<global-dynamic>.


=item B<-ftrampolines>

For targets that normally need trampolines for nested functions, always
generate them instead of using descriptors.  Otherwise, for targets that
do not need them, like for example HP-PA or IA-64, do nothing.

A trampoline is a small piece of code that is created at run time on the
stack when the address of a nested function is taken, and is used to call
the nested function indirectly.  Therefore, it requires the stack to be
made executable in order for the program to work properly.

B<-fno-trampolines> is enabled by default on a language by language
basis to let the compiler avoid generating them, if it computes that this
is safe, and replace them with descriptors.  Descriptors are made up of data
only, but the generated code must be prepared to deal with them.  As of this
writing, B<-fno-trampolines> is enabled by default only for Ada.

Moreover, code compiled with B<-ftrampolines> and code compiled with
B<-fno-trampolines> are not binary compatible if nested functions are
present.  This option must therefore be used on a program-wide basis and be
manipulated with extreme care.


=item B<-fvisibility=>[B<default>|B<internal>|B<hidden>|B<protected>]

Set the default ELF image symbol visibility to the specified option---all
symbols are marked with this unless overridden within the code.
Using this feature can very substantially improve linking and
load times of shared object libraries, produce more optimized
code, provide near-perfect API export and prevent symbol clashes.
It is B<strongly> recommended that you use this in any shared objects
you distribute.

Despite the nomenclature, B<default> always means public; i.e.,
available to be linked against from outside the shared object.
B<protected> and B<internal> are pretty useless in real-world
usage so the only other commonly used option is B<hidden>.
The default if B<-fvisibility> isn't specified is
B<default>, i.e., make every symbol public.

A good explanation of the benefits offered by ensuring ELF
symbols have the correct visibility is given by "How To Write
Shared Libraries" by Ulrich Drepper (which can be found at
S<E<lt>B<https://www.akkadia.org/drepper/>>E<gt>)---however a superior
solution made possible by this option to marking things hidden when
the default is public is to make the default hidden and mark things
public.  This is the norm with DLLs on Windows and with B<-fvisibility=hidden>
and C<__attribute__ ((visibility("default")))> instead of
C<__declspec(dllexport)> you get almost identical semantics with
identical syntax.  This is a great boon to those working with
cross-platform projects.

For those adding visibility support to existing code, you may find
C<#pragma GCC visibility> of use.  This works by you enclosing
the declarations you wish to set visibility for with (for example)
C<#pragma GCC visibility push(hidden)> and
C<#pragma GCC visibility pop>.
Bear in mind that symbol visibility should be viewed B<as
part of the API interface contract> and thus all new code should
always specify visibility when it is not the default; i.e., declarations
only for use within the local DSO should B<always> be marked explicitly
as hidden as so to avoid PLT indirection overheads---making this
abundantly clear also aids readability and self-documentation of the code.
Note that due to ISO C++ specification requirements, C<operator new> and
C<operator delete> must always be of default visibility.

Be aware that headers from outside your project, in particular system
headers and headers from any other library you use, may not be
expecting to be compiled with visibility other than the default.  You
may need to explicitly say C<#pragma GCC visibility push(default)>
before including any such headers.

C<extern> declarations are not affected by B<-fvisibility>, so
a lot of code can be recompiled with B<-fvisibility=hidden> with
no modifications.  However, this means that calls to C<extern>
functions with no explicit visibility use the PLT, so it is more
effective to use C<__attribute ((visibility))> and/or
C<#pragma GCC visibility> to tell the compiler which C<extern>
declarations should be treated as hidden.

Note that B<-fvisibility> does affect C++ vague linkage
entities. This means that, for instance, an exception class that is
be thrown between DSOs must be explicitly marked with default
visibility so that the B<type_info> nodes are unified between
the DSOs.

An overview of these techniques, their benefits and how to use them
is at E<lt>B<http://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Visibility>E<gt>.


=item B<-fstrict-volatile-bitfields>

This option should be used if accesses to volatile bit-fields (or other
structure fields, although the compiler usually honors those types
anyway) should use a single access of the width of the
field's type, aligned to a natural alignment if possible.  For
example, targets with memory-mapped peripheral registers might require
all such accesses to be 16 bits wide; with this flag you can
declare all peripheral bit-fields as C<unsigned short> (assuming short
is 16 bits on these targets) to force GCC to use 16-bit accesses
instead of, perhaps, a more efficient 32-bit access.

If this option is disabled, the compiler uses the most efficient
instruction.  In the previous example, that might be a 32-bit load
instruction, even though that accesses bytes that do not contain
any portion of the bit-field, or memory-mapped registers unrelated to
the one being updated.

In some cases, such as when the C<packed> attribute is applied to a 
structure field, it may not be possible to access the field with a single
read or write that is correctly aligned for the target machine.  In this
case GCC falls back to generating multiple accesses rather than code that 
will fault or truncate the result at run time.

Note:  Due to restrictions of the C/C++11 memory model, write accesses are
not allowed to touch non bit-field members.  It is therefore recommended
to define all bits of the field's type as bit-field members.

The default value of this option is determined by the application binary
interface for the target processor.


=item B<-fsync-libcalls>

This option controls whether any out-of-line instance of the C<__sync>
family of functions may be used to implement the C++11 C<__atomic>
family of functions.

The default value of this option is enabled, thus the only useful form
of the option is B<-fno-sync-libcalls>.  This option is used in
the implementation of the F<libatomic> runtime library.


=back



=head2 GCC Developer Options


This section describes command-line options that are primarily of
interest to GCC developers, including options to support compiler
testing and investigation of compiler bugs and compile-time
performance problems.  This includes options that produce debug dumps
at various points in the compilation; that print statistics such as
memory use and execution time; and that print information about GCC's
configuration, such as where it searches for libraries.  You should
rarely need to use any of these options for ordinary compilation and
linking tasks.

Many developer options that cause GCC to dump output to a file take an
optional B<=>I<filename> suffix. You can specify B<stdout>
or B<-> to dump to standard output, and B<stderr> for standard
error.

If B<=>I<filename> is omitted, a default dump file name is
constructed by concatenating the base dump file name, a pass number,
phase letter, and pass name.  The base dump file name is the name of
output file produced by the compiler if explicitly specified and not
an executable; otherwise it is the source file name.
The pass number is determined by the order passes are registered with
the compiler's pass manager. 
This is generally the same as the order of execution, but passes
registered by plugins, target-specific passes, or passes that are
otherwise registered late are numbered higher than the pass named
B<final>, even if they are executed earlier.  The phase letter is
one of B<i> (inter-procedural analysis), B<l>
(language-specific), B<r> (RTL), or B<t> (tree). 
The files are created in the directory of the output file. 


=over 4



=item B<-d>I<letters>


=item B<-fdump-rtl->I<pass>


=item B<-fdump-rtl->I<pass>B<=>I<filename>

Says to make debugging dumps during compilation at times specified by
I<letters>.  This is used for debugging the RTL-based passes of the
compiler.

Some B<-d>I<letters> switches have different meaning when
B<-E> is used for preprocessing.  

Debug dumps can be enabled with a B<-fdump-rtl> switch or some
B<-d> option I<letters>.  Here are the possible
letters for use in I<pass> and I<letters>, and their meanings:


=over 4



=item B<-fdump-rtl-alignments>

Dump after branch alignments have been computed.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-asmcons>

Dump after fixing rtl statements that have unsatisfied in/out constraints.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-auto_inc_dec>

Dump after auto-inc-dec discovery.  This pass is only run on
architectures that have auto inc or auto dec instructions.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-barriers>

Dump after cleaning up the barrier instructions.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-bbpart>

Dump after partitioning hot and cold basic blocks.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-bbro>

Dump after block reordering.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-btl1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-btl2>

B<-fdump-rtl-btl1> and B<-fdump-rtl-btl2> enable dumping
after the two branch
target load optimization passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-bypass>

Dump after jump bypassing and control flow optimizations.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-combine>

Dump after the RTL instruction combination pass.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-compgotos>

Dump after duplicating the computed gotos.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-ce1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-ce2>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-ce3>

B<-fdump-rtl-ce1>, B<-fdump-rtl-ce2>, and
B<-fdump-rtl-ce3> enable dumping after the three
if conversion passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-cprop_hardreg>

Dump after hard register copy propagation.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-csa>

Dump after combining stack adjustments.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-cse1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-cse2>

B<-fdump-rtl-cse1> and B<-fdump-rtl-cse2> enable dumping after
the two common subexpression elimination passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-dce>

Dump after the standalone dead code elimination passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-dbr>

Dump after delayed branch scheduling.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-dce1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-dce2>

B<-fdump-rtl-dce1> and B<-fdump-rtl-dce2> enable dumping after
the two dead store elimination passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-eh>

Dump after finalization of EH handling code.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-eh_ranges>

Dump after conversion of EH handling range regions.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-expand>

Dump after RTL generation.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-fwprop1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-fwprop2>

B<-fdump-rtl-fwprop1> and B<-fdump-rtl-fwprop2> enable
dumping after the two forward propagation passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-gcse1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-gcse2>

B<-fdump-rtl-gcse1> and B<-fdump-rtl-gcse2> enable dumping
after global common subexpression elimination.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-init-regs>

Dump after the initialization of the registers.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-initvals>

Dump after the computation of the initial value sets.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-into_cfglayout>

Dump after converting to cfglayout mode.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-ira>

Dump after iterated register allocation.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-jump>

Dump after the second jump optimization.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-loop2>

B<-fdump-rtl-loop2> enables dumping after the rtl
loop optimization passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-mach>

Dump after performing the machine dependent reorganization pass, if that
pass exists.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-mode_sw>

Dump after removing redundant mode switches.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-rnreg>

Dump after register renumbering.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-outof_cfglayout>

Dump after converting from cfglayout mode.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-peephole2>

Dump after the peephole pass.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-postreload>

Dump after post-reload optimizations.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-pro_and_epilogue>

Dump after generating the function prologues and epilogues.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-sched1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-sched2>

B<-fdump-rtl-sched1> and B<-fdump-rtl-sched2> enable dumping
after the basic block scheduling passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-ree>

Dump after sign/zero extension elimination.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-seqabstr>

Dump after common sequence discovery.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-shorten>

Dump after shortening branches.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-sibling>

Dump after sibling call optimizations.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-split1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-split2>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-split3>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-split4>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-split5>

These options enable dumping after five rounds of
instruction splitting.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-sms>

Dump after modulo scheduling.  This pass is only run on some
architectures.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-stack>

Dump after conversion from GCC's "flat register file" registers to the
x87's stack-like registers.  This pass is only run on x86 variants.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-subreg1>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-subreg2>

B<-fdump-rtl-subreg1> and B<-fdump-rtl-subreg2> enable dumping after
the two subreg expansion passes.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-unshare>

Dump after all rtl has been unshared.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-vartrack>

Dump after variable tracking.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-vregs>

Dump after converting virtual registers to hard registers.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-web>

Dump after live range splitting.


=item B<-fdump-rtl-regclass>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-subregs_of_mode_init>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-subregs_of_mode_finish>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-dfinit>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-dfinish>

These dumps are defined but always produce empty files.


=item B<-da>


=item B<-fdump-rtl-all>

Produce all the dumps listed above.


=item B<-dA>

Annotate the assembler output with miscellaneous debugging information.


=item B<-dD>

Dump all macro definitions, at the end of preprocessing, in addition to
normal output.


=item B<-dH>

Produce a core dump whenever an error occurs.


=item B<-dp>

Annotate the assembler output with a comment indicating which
pattern and alternative is used.  The length and cost of each instruction are
also printed.


=item B<-dP>

Dump the RTL in the assembler output as a comment before each instruction.
Also turns on B<-dp> annotation.


=item B<-dx>

Just generate RTL for a function instead of compiling it.  Usually used
with B<-fdump-rtl-expand>.

=back



=item B<-fdump-debug>

Dump debugging information generated during the debug
generation phase.


=item B<-fdump-earlydebug>

Dump debugging information generated during the early debug
generation phase.


=item B<-fdump-noaddr>

When doing debugging dumps, suppress address output.  This makes it more
feasible to use diff on debugging dumps for compiler invocations with
different compiler binaries and/or different
text / bss / data / heap / stack / dso start locations.


=item B<-freport-bug>

Collect and dump debug information into a temporary file if an
internal compiler error (ICE) occurs.


=item B<-fdump-unnumbered>

When doing debugging dumps, suppress instruction numbers and address output.
This makes it more feasible to use diff on debugging dumps for compiler
invocations with different options, in particular with and without
B<-g>.


=item B<-fdump-unnumbered-links>

When doing debugging dumps (see B<-d> option above), suppress
instruction numbers for the links to the previous and next instructions
in a sequence.


=item B<-fdump-ipa->I<switch>


=item B<-fdump-ipa->I<switch>B<->I<options>

Control the dumping at various stages of inter-procedural analysis
language tree to a file.  The file name is generated by appending a
switch specific suffix to the source file name, and the file is created
in the same directory as the output file.  The following dumps are
possible:


=over 4


=item B<all>

Enables all inter-procedural analysis dumps.


=item B<cgraph>

Dumps information about call-graph optimization, unused function removal,
and inlining decisions.


=item B<inline>

Dump after function inlining.


=back


Additionally, the options B<-optimized>, B<-missed>,
B<-note>, and B<-all> can be provided, with the same meaning
as for B<-fopt-info>, defaulting to B<-optimized>.

For example, B<-fdump-ipa-inline-optimized-missed> will emit
information on callsites that were inlined, along with callsites
that were not inlined.

By default, the dump will contain messages about successful
optimizations (equivalent to B<-optimized>) together with
low-level details about the analysis.


=item B<-fdump-lang-all>


=item B<-fdump-lang->I<switch>


=item B<-fdump-lang->I<switch>B<->I<options>


=item B<-fdump-lang->I<switch>B<->I<options>B<=>I<filename>

Control the dumping of language-specific information.  The I<options>
and I<filename> portions behave as described in the
B<-fdump-tree> option.  The following I<switch> values are
accepted:


=over 4


=item B<all>


Enable all language-specific dumps.


=item B<class>

Dump class hierarchy information.  Virtual table information is emitted
unless 'B<slim>' is specified.  This option is applicable to C++ only.


=item B<raw>

Dump the raw internal tree data.  This option is applicable to C++ only.


=back



=item B<-fdump-passes>

Print on F<stderr> the list of optimization passes that are turned
on and off by the current command-line options.


=item B<-fdump-statistics->I<option>

Enable and control dumping of pass statistics in a separate file.  The
file name is generated by appending a suffix ending in
B<.statistics> to the source file name, and the file is created in
the same directory as the output file.  If the B<->I<option>
form is used, B<-stats> causes counters to be summed over the
whole compilation unit while B<-details> dumps every event as
the passes generate them.  The default with no option is to sum
counters for each function compiled.


=item B<-fdump-tree-all>


=item B<-fdump-tree->I<switch>


=item B<-fdump-tree->I<switch>B<->I<options>


=item B<-fdump-tree->I<switch>B<->I<options>B<=>I<filename>

Control the dumping at various stages of processing the intermediate
language tree to a file.  If the B<->I<options>
form is used, I<options> is a list of B<-> separated options
which control the details of the dump.  Not all options are applicable
to all dumps; those that are not meaningful are ignored.  The
following options are available


=over 4


=item B<address>

Print the address of each node.  Usually this is not meaningful as it
changes according to the environment and source file.  Its primary use
is for tying up a dump file with a debug environment.

=item B<asmname>

If C<DECL_ASSEMBLER_NAME> has been set for a given decl, use that
in the dump instead of C<DECL_NAME>.  Its primary use is ease of
use working backward from mangled names in the assembly file.

=item B<slim>

When dumping front-end intermediate representations, inhibit dumping
of members of a scope or body of a function merely because that scope
has been reached.  Only dump such items when they are directly reachable
by some other path.

When dumping pretty-printed trees, this option inhibits dumping the
bodies of control structures.

When dumping RTL, print the RTL in slim (condensed) form instead of
the default LISP-like representation.

=item B<raw>

Print a raw representation of the tree.  By default, trees are
pretty-printed into a C-like representation.

=item B<details>

Enable more detailed dumps (not honored by every dump option). Also
include information from the optimization passes.

=item B<stats>

Enable dumping various statistics about the pass (not honored by every dump
option).

=item B<blocks>

Enable showing basic block boundaries (disabled in raw dumps).

=item B<graph>

For each of the other indicated dump files (B<-fdump-rtl->I<pass>),
dump a representation of the control flow graph suitable for viewing with
GraphViz to F<I<file>.I<passid>.I<pass>.dot>.  Each function in
the file is pretty-printed as a subgraph, so that GraphViz can render them
all in a single plot.

This option currently only works for RTL dumps, and the RTL is always
dumped in slim form.

=item B<vops>

Enable showing virtual operands for every statement.

=item B<lineno>

Enable showing line numbers for statements.

=item B<uid>

Enable showing the unique ID (C<DECL_UID>) for each variable.

=item B<verbose>

Enable showing the tree dump for each statement.

=item B<eh>

Enable showing the EH region number holding each statement.

=item B<scev>

Enable showing scalar evolution analysis details.

=item B<optimized>

Enable showing optimization information (only available in certain
passes).

=item B<missed>

Enable showing missed optimization information (only available in certain
passes).

=item B<note>

Enable other detailed optimization information (only available in
certain passes).

=item B<all>

Turn on all options, except B<raw>, B<slim>, B<verbose>
and B<lineno>.

=item B<optall>

Turn on all optimization options, i.e., B<optimized>,
B<missed>, and B<note>.

=back


To determine what tree dumps are available or find the dump for a pass
of interest follow the steps below.


=over 4


=item Z<>1.

Invoke GCC with B<-fdump-passes> and in the F<stderr> output
look for a code that corresponds to the pass you are interested in.
For example, the codes C<tree-evrp>, C<tree-vrp1>, and
C<tree-vrp2> correspond to the three Value Range Propagation passes.
The number at the end distinguishes distinct invocations of the same pass.

=item Z<>2.

To enable the creation of the dump file, append the pass code to
the B<-fdump-> option prefix and invoke GCC with it.  For example,
to enable the dump from the Early Value Range Propagation pass, invoke
GCC with the B<-fdump-tree-evrp> option.  Optionally, you may
specify the name of the dump file.  If you don't specify one, GCC
creates as described below.

=item Z<>3.

Find the pass dump in a file whose name is composed of three components
separated by a period: the name of the source file GCC was invoked to
compile, a numeric suffix indicating the pass number followed by the
letter B<t> for tree passes (and the letter B<r> for RTL passes),
and finally the pass code.  For example, the Early VRP pass dump might
be in a file named F<myfile.c.038t.evrp> in the current working
directory.  Note that the numeric codes are not stable and may change
from one version of GCC to another.

=back



=item B<-fopt-info>


=item B<-fopt-info->I<options>


=item B<-fopt-info->I<options>B<=>I<filename>

Controls optimization dumps from various optimization passes. If the
B<->I<options> form is used, I<options> is a list of
B<-> separated option keywords to select the dump details and
optimizations.  

The I<options> can be divided into three groups:

=over 4


=item Z<>1.

options describing what kinds of messages should be emitted,

=item Z<>2.

options describing the verbosity of the dump, and

=item Z<>3.

options describing which optimizations should be included.

=back

The options from each group can be freely mixed as they are
non-overlapping. However, in case of any conflicts,
the later options override the earlier options on the command
line. 

The following options control which kinds of messages should be emitted:


=over 4


=item B<optimized>

Print information when an optimization is successfully applied. It is
up to a pass to decide which information is relevant. For example, the
vectorizer passes print the source location of loops which are
successfully vectorized.

=item B<missed>

Print information about missed optimizations. Individual passes
control which information to include in the output. 

=item B<note>

Print verbose information about optimizations, such as certain
transformations, more detailed messages about decisions etc.

=item B<all>

Print detailed optimization information. This includes
B<optimized>, B<missed>, and B<note>.

=back


The following option controls the dump verbosity:


=over 4


=item B<internals>

By default, only "high-level" messages are emitted. This option enables
additional, more detailed, messages, which are likely to only be of interest
to GCC developers.

=back


One or more of the following option keywords can be used to describe a
group of optimizations:


=over 4


=item B<ipa>

Enable dumps from all interprocedural optimizations.

=item B<loop>

Enable dumps from all loop optimizations.

=item B<inline>

Enable dumps from all inlining optimizations.

=item B<omp>

Enable dumps from all OMP (Offloading and Multi Processing) optimizations.

=item B<vec>

Enable dumps from all vectorization optimizations.

=item B<optall>

Enable dumps from all optimizations. This is a superset of
the optimization groups listed above.

=back


If I<options> is
omitted, it defaults to B<optimized-optall>, which means to dump messages
about successful optimizations from all the passes, omitting messages
that are treated as "internals".

If the I<filename> is provided, then the dumps from all the
applicable optimizations are concatenated into the I<filename>.
Otherwise the dump is output onto F<stderr>. Though multiple
B<-fopt-info> options are accepted, only one of them can include
a I<filename>. If other filenames are provided then all but the
first such option are ignored.

Note that the output I<filename> is overwritten
in case of multiple translation units. If a combined output from
multiple translation units is desired, F<stderr> should be used
instead.

In the following example, the optimization info is output to
F<stderr>:

	
	gcc -O3 -fopt-info


This example:
	
	gcc -O3 -fopt-info-missed=missed.all


outputs missed optimization report from all the passes into
F<missed.all>, and this one:

	
	gcc -O2 -ftree-vectorize -fopt-info-vec-missed


prints information about missed optimization opportunities from
vectorization passes on F<stderr>.  
Note that B<-fopt-info-vec-missed> is equivalent to 
B<-fopt-info-missed-vec>.  The order of the optimization group
names and message types listed after B<-fopt-info> does not matter.

As another example,
	
	gcc -O3 -fopt-info-inline-optimized-missed=inline.txt


outputs information about missed optimizations as well as
optimized locations from all the inlining passes into
F<inline.txt>.

Finally, consider:

	
	gcc -fopt-info-vec-missed=vec.miss -fopt-info-loop-optimized=loop.opt


Here the two output filenames F<vec.miss> and F<loop.opt> are
in conflict since only one output file is allowed. In this case, only
the first option takes effect and the subsequent options are
ignored. Thus only F<vec.miss> is produced which contains
dumps from the vectorizer about missed opportunities.


=item B<-fsave-optimization-record>

Write a SRCFILE.opt-record.json.gz file detailing what optimizations
were performed, for those optimizations that support B<-fopt-info>.

This option is experimental and the format of the data within the
compressed JSON file is subject to change.

It is roughly equivalent to a machine-readable version of
B<-fopt-info-all>, as a collection of messages with source file,
line number and column number, with the following additional data for
each message:


=over 4



=item Z<>*

the execution count of the code being optimized, along with metadata about
whether this was from actual profile data, or just an estimate, allowing
consumers to prioritize messages by code hotness,


=item Z<>*

the function name of the code being optimized, where applicable,


=item Z<>*

the "inlining chain" for the code being optimized, so that when
a function is inlined into several different places (which might
themselves be inlined), the reader can distinguish between the copies,


=item Z<>*

objects identifying those parts of the message that refer to expressions,
statements or symbol-table nodes, which of these categories they are, and,
when available, their source code location,


=item Z<>*

the GCC pass that emitted the message, and


=item Z<>*

the location in GCC's own code from which the message was emitted


=back


Additionally, some messages are logically nested within other
messages, reflecting implementation details of the optimization
passes.


=item B<-fsched-verbose=>I<n>

On targets that use instruction scheduling, this option controls the
amount of debugging output the scheduler prints to the dump files.

For I<n> greater than zero, B<-fsched-verbose> outputs the
same information as B<-fdump-rtl-sched1> and B<-fdump-rtl-sched2>.
For I<n> greater than one, it also output basic block probabilities,
detailed ready list information and unit/insn info.  For I<n> greater
than two, it includes RTL at abort point, control-flow and regions info.
And for I<n> over four, B<-fsched-verbose> also includes
dependence info.




=item B<-fenable->I<kind>B<->I<pass>


=item B<-fdisable->I<kind>B<->I<pass>B<=>I<range-list>


This is a set of options that are used to explicitly disable/enable
optimization passes.  These options are intended for use for debugging GCC.
Compiler users should use regular options for enabling/disabling
passes instead.


=over 4



=item B<-fdisable-ipa->I<pass>

Disable IPA pass I<pass>. I<pass> is the pass name.  If the same pass is
statically invoked in the compiler multiple times, the pass name should be
appended with a sequential number starting from 1.


=item B<-fdisable-rtl->I<pass>


=item B<-fdisable-rtl->I<pass>B<=>I<range-list>

Disable RTL pass I<pass>.  I<pass> is the pass name.  If the same pass is
statically invoked in the compiler multiple times, the pass name should be
appended with a sequential number starting from 1.  I<range-list> is a 
comma-separated list of function ranges or assembler names.  Each range is a number
pair separated by a colon.  The range is inclusive in both ends.  If the range
is trivial, the number pair can be simplified as a single number.  If the
function's call graph node's I<uid> falls within one of the specified ranges,
the I<pass> is disabled for that function.  The I<uid> is shown in the
function header of a dump file, and the pass names can be dumped by using
option B<-fdump-passes>.


=item B<-fdisable-tree->I<pass>


=item B<-fdisable-tree->I<pass>B<=>I<range-list>

Disable tree pass I<pass>.  See B<-fdisable-rtl> for the description of
option arguments.


=item B<-fenable-ipa->I<pass>

Enable IPA pass I<pass>.  I<pass> is the pass name.  If the same pass is
statically invoked in the compiler multiple times, the pass name should be
appended with a sequential number starting from 1.


=item B<-fenable-rtl->I<pass>


=item B<-fenable-rtl->I<pass>B<=>I<range-list>

Enable RTL pass I<pass>.  See B<-fdisable-rtl> for option argument
description and examples.


=item B<-fenable-tree->I<pass>


=item B<-fenable-tree->I<pass>B<=>I<range-list>

Enable tree pass I<pass>.  See B<-fdisable-rtl> for the description
of option arguments.


=back


Here are some examples showing uses of these options.

	
	
	# disable ccp1 for all functions
	   -fdisable-tree-ccp1
	# disable complete unroll for function whose cgraph node uid is 1
	   -fenable-tree-cunroll=1
	# disable gcse2 for functions at the following ranges [1,1],
	# [300,400], and [400,1000]
	# disable gcse2 for functions foo and foo2
	   -fdisable-rtl-gcse2=foo,foo2
	# disable early inlining
	   -fdisable-tree-einline
	# disable ipa inlining
	   -fdisable-ipa-inline
	# enable tree full unroll
	   -fenable-tree-unroll
	



=item B<-fchecking>


=item B<-fchecking=>I<n>

Enable internal consistency checking.  The default depends on
the compiler configuration.  B<-fchecking=2> enables further
internal consistency checking that might affect code generation.


=item B<-frandom-seed=>I<string>

This option provides a seed that GCC uses in place of
random numbers in generating certain symbol names
that have to be different in every compiled file.  It is also used to
place unique stamps in coverage data files and the object files that
produce them.  You can use the B<-frandom-seed> option to produce
reproducibly identical object files.

The I<string> can either be a number (decimal, octal or hex) or an
arbitrary string (in which case it's converted to a number by
computing CRC32).

The I<string> should be different for every file you compile.


=item B<-save-temps>


=item B<-save-temps=cwd>

Store the usual "temporary" intermediate files permanently; place them
in the current directory and name them based on the source file.  Thus,
compiling F<foo.c> with B<-c -save-temps> produces files
F<foo.i> and F<foo.s>, as well as F<foo.o>.  This creates a
preprocessed F<foo.i> output file even though the compiler now
normally uses an integrated preprocessor.

When used in combination with the B<-x> command-line option,
B<-save-temps> is sensible enough to avoid over writing an
input source file with the same extension as an intermediate file.
The corresponding intermediate file may be obtained by renaming the
source file before using B<-save-temps>.

If you invoke GCC in parallel, compiling several different source
files that share a common base name in different subdirectories or the
same source file compiled for multiple output destinations, it is
likely that the different parallel compilers will interfere with each
other, and overwrite the temporary files.  For instance:

	
	gcc -save-temps -o outdir1/foo.o indir1/foo.c&
	gcc -save-temps -o outdir2/foo.o indir2/foo.c&


may result in F<foo.i> and F<foo.o> being written to
simultaneously by both compilers.


=item B<-save-temps=obj>

Store the usual "temporary" intermediate files permanently.  If the
B<-o> option is used, the temporary files are based on the
object file.  If the B<-o> option is not used, the
B<-save-temps=obj> switch behaves like B<-save-temps>.

For example:

	
	gcc -save-temps=obj -c foo.c
	gcc -save-temps=obj -c bar.c -o dir/xbar.o
	gcc -save-temps=obj foobar.c -o dir2/yfoobar


creates F<foo.i>, F<foo.s>, F<dir/xbar.i>,
F<dir/xbar.s>, F<dir2/yfoobar.i>, F<dir2/yfoobar.s>, and
F<dir2/yfoobar.o>.


=item B<-time>[B<=>I<file>]

Report the CPU time taken by each subprocess in the compilation
sequence.  For C source files, this is the compiler proper and assembler
(plus the linker if linking is done).

Without the specification of an output file, the output looks like this:

	
	# cc1 0.12 0.01
	# as 0.00 0.01


The first number on each line is the "user time", that is time spent
executing the program itself.  The second number is "system time",
time spent executing operating system routines on behalf of the program.
Both numbers are in seconds.

With the specification of an output file, the output is appended to the
named file, and it looks like this:

	
	0.12 0.01 cc1 <options>
	0.00 0.01 as <options>


The "user time" and the "system time" are moved before the program
name, and the options passed to the program are displayed, so that one
can later tell what file was being compiled, and with which options.


=item B<-fdump-final-insns>[B<=>I<file>]

Dump the final internal representation (RTL) to I<file>.  If the
optional argument is omitted (or if I<file> is C<.>), the name
of the dump file is determined by appending C<.gkd> to the
compilation output file name.


=item B<-fcompare-debug>[B<=>I<opts>]

If no error occurs during compilation, run the compiler a second time,
adding I<opts> and B<-fcompare-debug-second> to the arguments
passed to the second compilation.  Dump the final internal
representation in both compilations, and print an error if they differ.

If the equal sign is omitted, the default B<-gtoggle> is used.

The environment variable B<GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG>, if defined, non-empty
and nonzero, implicitly enables B<-fcompare-debug>.  If
B<GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG> is defined to a string starting with a dash,
then it is used for I<opts>, otherwise the default B<-gtoggle>
is used.

B<-fcompare-debug=>, with the equal sign but without I<opts>,
is equivalent to B<-fno-compare-debug>, which disables the dumping
of the final representation and the second compilation, preventing even
B<GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG> from taking effect.

To verify full coverage during B<-fcompare-debug> testing, set
B<GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG> to say B<-fcompare-debug-not-overridden>,
which GCC rejects as an invalid option in any actual compilation
(rather than preprocessing, assembly or linking).  To get just a
warning, setting B<GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG> to B<-w%n-fcompare-debug
not overridden> will do.


=item B<-fcompare-debug-second>

This option is implicitly passed to the compiler for the second
compilation requested by B<-fcompare-debug>, along with options to
silence warnings, and omitting other options that would cause the compiler
to produce output to files or to standard output as a side effect.  Dump
files and preserved temporary files are renamed so as to contain the
C<.gk> additional extension during the second compilation, to avoid
overwriting those generated by the first.

When this option is passed to the compiler driver, it causes the
I<first> compilation to be skipped, which makes it useful for little
other than debugging the compiler proper.


=item B<-gtoggle>

Turn off generation of debug info, if leaving out this option
generates it, or turn it on at level 2 otherwise.  The position of this
argument in the command line does not matter; it takes effect after all
other options are processed, and it does so only once, no matter how
many times it is given.  This is mainly intended to be used with
B<-fcompare-debug>.


=item B<-fvar-tracking-assignments-toggle>

Toggle B<-fvar-tracking-assignments>, in the same way that
B<-gtoggle> toggles B<-g>.


=item B<-Q>

Makes the compiler print out each function name as it is compiled, and
print some statistics about each pass when it finishes.


=item B<-ftime-report>

Makes the compiler print some statistics about the time consumed by each
pass when it finishes.


=item B<-ftime-report-details>

Record the time consumed by infrastructure parts separately for each pass.


=item B<-fira-verbose=>I<n>

Control the verbosity of the dump file for the integrated register allocator.
The default value is 5.  If the value I<n> is greater or equal to 10,
the dump output is sent to stderr using the same format as I<n> minus 10.


=item B<-flto-report>

Prints a report with internal details on the workings of the link-time
optimizer.  The contents of this report vary from version to version.
It is meant to be useful to GCC developers when processing object
files in LTO mode (via B<-flto>).

Disabled by default.


=item B<-flto-report-wpa>

Like B<-flto-report>, but only print for the WPA phase of Link
Time Optimization.


=item B<-fmem-report>

Makes the compiler print some statistics about permanent memory
allocation when it finishes.


=item B<-fmem-report-wpa>

Makes the compiler print some statistics about permanent memory
allocation for the WPA phase only.


=item B<-fpre-ipa-mem-report>


=item B<-fpost-ipa-mem-report>

Makes the compiler print some statistics about permanent memory
allocation before or after interprocedural optimization.


=item B<-fprofile-report>

Makes the compiler print some statistics about consistency of the
(estimated) profile and effect of individual passes.


=item B<-fstack-usage>

Makes the compiler output stack usage information for the program, on a
per-function basis.  The filename for the dump is made by appending
F<.su> to the I<auxname>.  I<auxname> is generated from the name of
the output file, if explicitly specified and it is not an executable,
otherwise it is the basename of the source file.  An entry is made up
of three fields:


=over 4


=item Z<>*

The name of the function.

=item Z<>*

A number of bytes.

=item Z<>*

One or more qualifiers: C<static>, C<dynamic>, C<bounded>.

=back


The qualifier C<static> means that the function manipulates the stack
statically: a fixed number of bytes are allocated for the frame on function
entry and released on function exit; no stack adjustments are otherwise made
in the function.  The second field is this fixed number of bytes.

The qualifier C<dynamic> means that the function manipulates the stack
dynamically: in addition to the static allocation described above, stack
adjustments are made in the body of the function, for example to push/pop
arguments around function calls.  If the qualifier C<bounded> is also
present, the amount of these adjustments is bounded at compile time and
the second field is an upper bound of the total amount of stack used by
the function.  If it is not present, the amount of these adjustments is
not bounded at compile time and the second field only represents the
bounded part.


=item B<-fstats>

Emit statistics about front-end processing at the end of the compilation.
This option is supported only by the C++ front end, and
the information is generally only useful to the G++ development team.


=item B<-fdbg-cnt-list>

Print the name and the counter upper bound for all debug counters.



=item B<-fdbg-cnt=>I<counter-value-list>

Set the internal debug counter lower and upper bound.  I<counter-value-list>
is a comma-separated list of I<name>:I<lower_bound>:I<upper_bound>
tuples which sets the lower and the upper bound of each debug
counter I<name>.  The I<lower_bound> is optional and is zero
initialized if not set.
All debug counters have the initial upper bound of C<UINT_MAX>;
thus C<dbg_cnt> returns true always unless the upper bound
is set by this option.
For example, with B<-fdbg-cnt=dce:2:4,tail_call:10>,
C<dbg_cnt(dce)> returns true only for third and fourth invocation.
For C<dbg_cnt(tail_call)> true is returned for first 10 invocations.


=item B<-print-file-name=>I<library>

Print the full absolute name of the library file I<library> that
would be used when linking---and don't do anything else.  With this
option, GCC does not compile or link anything; it just prints the
file name.


=item B<-print-multi-directory>

Print the directory name corresponding to the multilib selected by any
other switches present in the command line.  This directory is supposed
to exist in B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX>.


=item B<-print-multi-lib>

Print the mapping from multilib directory names to compiler switches
that enable them.  The directory name is separated from the switches by
B<;>, and each switch starts with an B<@> instead of the
B<->, without spaces between multiple switches.  This is supposed to
ease shell processing.


=item B<-print-multi-os-directory>

Print the path to OS libraries for the selected
multilib, relative to some F<lib> subdirectory.  If OS libraries are
present in the F<lib> subdirectory and no multilibs are used, this is
usually just F<.>, if OS libraries are present in F<libI<suffix>>
sibling directories this prints e.g. F<../lib64>, F<../lib> or
F<../lib32>, or if OS libraries are present in F<lib/I<subdir>>
subdirectories it prints e.g. F<amd64>, F<sparcv9> or F<ev6>.


=item B<-print-multiarch>

Print the path to OS libraries for the selected multiarch,
relative to some F<lib> subdirectory.


=item B<-print-prog-name=>I<program>

Like B<-print-file-name>, but searches for a program such as B<cpp>.


=item B<-print-libgcc-file-name>

Same as B<-print-file-name=libgcc.a>.

This is useful when you use B<-nostdlib> or B<-nodefaultlibs>
but you do want to link with F<libgcc.a>.  You can do:

	
	gcc -nostdlib <files>... `gcc -print-libgcc-file-name`



=item B<-print-search-dirs>

Print the name of the configured installation directory and a list of
program and library directories B<gcc> searches---and don't do anything else.

This is useful when B<gcc> prints the error message
B<installation problem, cannot exec cpp0: No such file or directory>.
To resolve this you either need to put F<cpp0> and the other compiler
components where B<gcc> expects to find them, or you can set the environment
variable B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX> to the directory where you installed them.
Don't forget the trailing B</>.



=item B<-print-sysroot>

Print the target sysroot directory that is used during
compilation.  This is the target sysroot specified either at configure
time or using the B<--sysroot> option, possibly with an extra
suffix that depends on compilation options.  If no target sysroot is
specified, the option prints nothing.


=item B<-print-sysroot-headers-suffix>

Print the suffix added to the target sysroot when searching for
headers, or give an error if the compiler is not configured with such
a suffix---and don't do anything else.


=item B<-dumpmachine>

Print the compiler's target machine (for example,
B<i686-pc-linux-gnu>)---and don't do anything else.


=item B<-dumpversion>

Print the compiler version (for example, C<3.0>, C<6.3.0> or C<7>)---and don't do
anything else.  This is the compiler version used in filesystem paths and
specs. Depending on how the compiler has been configured it can be just
a single number (major version), two numbers separated by a dot (major and
minor version) or three numbers separated by dots (major, minor and patchlevel
version).


=item B<-dumpfullversion>

Print the full compiler version---and don't do anything else. The output is
always three numbers separated by dots, major, minor and patchlevel version.


=item B<-dumpspecs>

Print the compiler's built-in specs---and don't do anything else.  (This
is used when GCC itself is being built.)  

=back



=head2 Machine-Dependent Options


Each target machine supported by GCC can have its own options---for
example, to allow you to compile for a particular processor variant or
ABI, or to control optimizations specific to that machine.  By
convention, the names of machine-specific options start with
B<-m>.

Some configurations of the compiler also support additional target-specific
options, usually for compatibility with other compilers on the same
platform.




=head3 AArch64 Options


These options are defined for AArch64 implementations:


=over 4



=item B<-mabi=>I<name>

Generate code for the specified data model.  Permissible values
are B<ilp32> for SysV-like data model where int, long int and pointers
are 32 bits, and B<lp64> for SysV-like data model where int is 32 bits,
but long int and pointers are 64 bits.

The default depends on the specific target configuration.  Note that
the LP64 and ILP32 ABIs are not link-compatible; you must compile your
entire program with the same ABI, and link with a compatible set of libraries.


=item B<-mbig-endian>

Generate big-endian code.  This is the default when GCC is configured for an
B<aarch64_be-*-*> target.


=item B<-mgeneral-regs-only>

Generate code which uses only the general-purpose registers.  This will prevent
the compiler from using floating-point and Advanced SIMD registers but will not
impose any restrictions on the assembler.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

Generate little-endian code.  This is the default when GCC is configured for an
B<aarch64-*-*> but not an B<aarch64_be-*-*> target.


=item B<-mcmodel=tiny>

Generate code for the tiny code model.  The program and its statically defined
symbols must be within 1MB of each other.  Programs can be statically or
dynamically linked.


=item B<-mcmodel=small>

Generate code for the small code model.  The program and its statically defined
symbols must be within 4GB of each other.  Programs can be statically or
dynamically linked.  This is the default code model.


=item B<-mcmodel=large>

Generate code for the large code model.  This makes no assumptions about
addresses and sizes of sections.  Programs can be statically linked only.


=item B<-mstrict-align>


=item B<-mno-strict-align>

Avoid or allow generating memory accesses that may not be aligned on a natural
object boundary as described in the architecture specification.


=item B<-momit-leaf-frame-pointer>


=item B<-mno-omit-leaf-frame-pointer>

Omit or keep the frame pointer in leaf functions.  The former behavior is the
default.


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard=>I<guard>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset>

Generate stack protection code using canary at I<guard>.  Supported
locations are B<global> for a global canary or B<sysreg> for a
canary in an appropriate system register.

With the latter choice the options
B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg> and
B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset> furthermore specify
which system register to use as base register for reading the canary,
and from what offset from that base register. There is no default
register or offset as this is entirely for use within the Linux
kernel.


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard=>I<guard>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset>

Generate stack protection code using canary at I<guard>.  Supported
locations are B<global> for a global canary or B<sysreg> for a
canary in an appropriate system register.

With the latter choice the options
B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg> and
B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset> furthermore specify
which system register to use as base register for reading the canary,
and from what offset from that base register. There is no default
register or offset as this is entirely for use within the Linux
kernel.


=item B<-mtls-dialect=desc>

Use TLS descriptors as the thread-local storage mechanism for dynamic accesses
of TLS variables.  This is the default.


=item B<-mtls-dialect=traditional>

Use traditional TLS as the thread-local storage mechanism for dynamic accesses
of TLS variables.


=item B<-mtls-size=>I<size>

Specify bit size of immediate TLS offsets.  Valid values are 12, 24, 32, 48.
This option requires binutils 2.26 or newer.


=item B<-mfix-cortex-a53-835769>


=item B<-mno-fix-cortex-a53-835769>

Enable or disable the workaround for the ARM Cortex-A53 erratum number 835769.
This involves inserting a NOP instruction between memory instructions and
64-bit integer multiply-accumulate instructions.


=item B<-mfix-cortex-a53-843419>


=item B<-mno-fix-cortex-a53-843419>

Enable or disable the workaround for the ARM Cortex-A53 erratum number 843419.
This erratum workaround is made at link time and this will only pass the
corresponding flag to the linker.


=item B<-mlow-precision-recip-sqrt>


=item B<-mno-low-precision-recip-sqrt>

Enable or disable the reciprocal square root approximation.
This option only has an effect if B<-ffast-math> or
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is used as well.  Enabling this reduces
precision of reciprocal square root results to about 16 bits for
single precision and to 32 bits for double precision.


=item B<-mlow-precision-sqrt>


=item B<-mno-low-precision-sqrt>

Enable or disable the square root approximation.
This option only has an effect if B<-ffast-math> or
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is used as well.  Enabling this reduces
precision of square root results to about 16 bits for
single precision and to 32 bits for double precision.
If enabled, it implies B<-mlow-precision-recip-sqrt>.


=item B<-mlow-precision-div>


=item B<-mno-low-precision-div>

Enable or disable the division approximation.
This option only has an effect if B<-ffast-math> or
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is used as well.  Enabling this reduces
precision of division results to about 16 bits for
single precision and to 32 bits for double precision.


=item B<-mtrack-speculation>


=item B<-mno-track-speculation>

Enable or disable generation of additional code to track speculative
execution through conditional branches.  The tracking state can then
be used by the compiler when expanding calls to
C<__builtin_speculation_safe_copy> to permit a more efficient code
sequence to be generated.


=item B<-march=>I<name>

Specify the name of the target architecture and, optionally, one or
more feature modifiers.  This option has the form
B<-march=>I<arch>{B<+>[B<no>]I<feature>}*.

The permissible values for I<arch> are B<armv8-a>,
B<armv8.1-a>, B<armv8.2-a>, B<armv8.3-a>, B<armv8.4-a>,
B<armv8.5-a> or I<native>.

The value B<armv8.5-a> implies B<armv8.4-a> and enables compiler
support for the ARMv8.5-A architecture extensions.

The value B<armv8.4-a> implies B<armv8.3-a> and enables compiler
support for the ARMv8.4-A architecture extensions.

The value B<armv8.3-a> implies B<armv8.2-a> and enables compiler
support for the ARMv8.3-A architecture extensions.

The value B<armv8.2-a> implies B<armv8.1-a> and enables compiler
support for the ARMv8.2-A architecture extensions.

The value B<armv8.1-a> implies B<armv8-a> and enables compiler
support for the ARMv8.1-A architecture extension.  In particular, it
enables the B<+crc>, B<+lse>, and B<+rdma> features.

The value B<native> is available on native AArch64 GNU/Linux and
causes the compiler to pick the architecture of the host system.  This
option has no effect if the compiler is unable to recognize the
architecture of the host system,

The permissible values for I<feature> are listed in the sub-section
on B<aarch64-feature-modifiers,,>B<-march> B<and> B<-mcpu>
B<Feature Modifiers>.  Where conflicting feature modifiers are
specified, the right-most feature is used.

GCC uses I<name> to determine what kind of instructions it can emit
when generating assembly code.  If B<-march> is specified
without either of B<-mtune> or B<-mcpu> also being
specified, the code is tuned to perform well across a range of target
processors implementing the target architecture.


=item B<-mtune=>I<name>

Specify the name of the target processor for which GCC should tune the
performance of the code.  Permissible values for this option are:
B<generic>, B<cortex-a35>, B<cortex-a53>, B<cortex-a55>,
B<cortex-a57>, B<cortex-a72>, B<cortex-a73>, B<cortex-a75>,
B<cortex-a76>, B<ares>, B<exynos-m1>, B<emag>, B<falkor>,
B<neoverse-e1>,B<neoverse-n1>,B<qdf24xx>, B<saphira>,
B<phecda>, B<xgene1>, B<vulcan>, B<octeontx>,
B<octeontx81>,  B<octeontx83>, B<thunderx>, B<thunderxt88>,
B<thunderxt88p1>, B<thunderxt81>, B<tsv110>,
B<thunderxt83>, B<thunderx2t99>,
B<cortex-a57.cortex-a53>, B<cortex-a72.cortex-a53>,
B<cortex-a73.cortex-a35>, B<cortex-a73.cortex-a53>,
B<cortex-a75.cortex-a55>, B<cortex-a76.cortex-a55>
B<native>.

The values B<cortex-a57.cortex-a53>, B<cortex-a72.cortex-a53>,
B<cortex-a73.cortex-a35>, B<cortex-a73.cortex-a53>,
B<cortex-a75.cortex-a55>, B<cortex-a76.cortex-a55> specify that GCC
should tune for a big.LITTLE system.

Additionally on native AArch64 GNU/Linux systems the value
B<native> tunes performance to the host system.  This option has no effect
if the compiler is unable to recognize the processor of the host system.

Where none of B<-mtune=>, B<-mcpu=> or B<-march=>
are specified, the code is tuned to perform well across a range
of target processors.

This option cannot be suffixed by feature modifiers.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<name>

Specify the name of the target processor, optionally suffixed by one
or more feature modifiers.  This option has the form
B<-mcpu=>I<cpu>{B<+>[B<no>]I<feature>}*, where
the permissible values for I<cpu> are the same as those available
for B<-mtune>.  The permissible values for I<feature> are
documented in the sub-section on
B<aarch64-feature-modifiers,,>B<-march> B<and> B<-mcpu>
B<Feature Modifiers>.  Where conflicting feature modifiers are
specified, the right-most feature is used.

GCC uses I<name> to determine what kind of instructions it can emit when
generating assembly code (as if by B<-march>) and to determine
the target processor for which to tune for performance (as if
by B<-mtune>).  Where this option is used in conjunction
with B<-march> or B<-mtune>, those options take precedence
over the appropriate part of this option.


=item B<-moverride=>I<string>

Override tuning decisions made by the back-end in response to a
B<-mtune=> switch.  The syntax, semantics, and accepted values
for I<string> in this option are not guaranteed to be consistent
across releases.

This option is only intended to be useful when developing GCC.


=item B<-mverbose-cost-dump>

Enable verbose cost model dumping in the debug dump files.  This option is
provided for use in debugging the compiler.


=item B<-mpc-relative-literal-loads>


=item B<-mno-pc-relative-literal-loads>

Enable or disable PC-relative literal loads.  With this option literal pools are
accessed using a single instruction and emitted after each function.  This
limits the maximum size of functions to 1MB.  This is enabled by default for
B<-mcmodel=tiny>.


=item B<-msign-return-address=>I<scope>

Select the function scope on which return address signing will be applied.
Permissible values are B<none>, which disables return address signing,
B<non-leaf>, which enables pointer signing for functions which are not leaf
functions, and B<all>, which enables pointer signing for all functions.  The
default value is B<none>. This option has been deprecated by
-mbranch-protection.


=item B<-mbranch-protection=>I<none>B<|>I<standard>B<|>I<pac-ret>B<[+>I<leaf>B<]|>I<bti>

Select the branch protection features to use.
B<none> is the default and turns off all types of branch protection.
B<standard> turns on all types of branch protection features.  If a feature
has additional tuning options, then B<standard> sets it to its standard
level.
B<pac-ret[+>I<leaf>B<]> turns on return address signing to its standard
level: signing functions that save the return address to memory (non-leaf
functions will practically always do this) using the a-key.  The optional
argument B<leaf> can be used to extend the signing to include leaf
functions.
B<bti> turns on branch target identification mechanism.


=item B<-msve-vector-bits=>I<bits>

Specify the number of bits in an SVE vector register.  This option only has
an effect when SVE is enabled.

GCC supports two forms of SVE code generation: "vector-length
agnostic" output that works with any size of vector register and
"vector-length specific" output that allows GCC to make assumptions
about the vector length when it is useful for optimization reasons.
The possible values of B<bits> are: B<scalable>, B<128>,
B<256>, B<512>, B<1024> and B<2048>.
Specifying B<scalable> selects vector-length agnostic
output.  At present B<-msve-vector-bits=128> also generates vector-length
agnostic output.  All other values generate vector-length specific code.
The behavior of these values may change in future releases and no value except
B<scalable> should be relied on for producing code that is portable across
different hardware SVE vector lengths.

The default is B<-msve-vector-bits=scalable>, which produces
vector-length agnostic code.

=back



=head4 B<-march> and B<-mcpu> Feature Modifiers


Feature modifiers used with B<-march> and B<-mcpu> can be any of
the following and their inverses B<no>I<feature>:


=over 4


=item B<crc>

Enable CRC extension.  This is on by default for
B<-march=armv8.1-a>.

=item B<crypto>

Enable Crypto extension.  This also enables Advanced SIMD and floating-point
instructions.

=item B<fp>

Enable floating-point instructions.  This is on by default for all possible
values for options B<-march> and B<-mcpu>.

=item B<simd>

Enable Advanced SIMD instructions.  This also enables floating-point
instructions.  This is on by default for all possible values for options
B<-march> and B<-mcpu>.

=item B<sve>

Enable Scalable Vector Extension instructions.  This also enables Advanced
SIMD and floating-point instructions.

=item B<lse>

Enable Large System Extension instructions.  This is on by default for
B<-march=armv8.1-a>.

=item B<rdma>

Enable Round Double Multiply Accumulate instructions.  This is on by default
for B<-march=armv8.1-a>.

=item B<fp16>

Enable FP16 extension.  This also enables floating-point instructions.

=item B<fp16fml>

Enable FP16 fmla extension.  This also enables FP16 extensions and
floating-point instructions. This option is enabled by default for B<-march=armv8.4-a>. Use of this option with architectures prior to Armv8.2-A is not supported.


=item B<rcpc>

Enable the RcPc extension.  This does not change code generation from GCC,
but is passed on to the assembler, enabling inline asm statements to use
instructions from the RcPc extension.

=item B<dotprod>

Enable the Dot Product extension.  This also enables Advanced SIMD instructions.

=item B<aes>

Enable the Armv8-a aes and pmull crypto extension.  This also enables Advanced
SIMD instructions.

=item B<sha2>

Enable the Armv8-a sha2 crypto extension.  This also enables Advanced SIMD instructions.

=item B<sha3>

Enable the sha512 and sha3 crypto extension.  This also enables Advanced SIMD
instructions. Use of this option with architectures prior to Armv8.2-A is not supported.

=item B<sm4>

Enable the sm3 and sm4 crypto extension.  This also enables Advanced SIMD instructions.
Use of this option with architectures prior to Armv8.2-A is not supported.

=item B<profile>

Enable the Statistical Profiling extension.  This option is only to enable the
extension at the assembler level and does not affect code generation.

=item B<rng>

Enable the Armv8.5-a Random Number instructions.  This option is only to
enable the extension at the assembler level and does not affect code
generation.

=item B<memtag>

Enable the Armv8.5-a Memory Tagging Extensions.  This option is only to
enable the extension at the assembler level and does not affect code
generation.

=item B<sb>

Enable the Armv8-a Speculation Barrier instruction.  This option is only to
enable the extension at the assembler level and does not affect code
generation.  This option is enabled by default for B<-march=armv8.5-a>.

=item B<ssbs>

Enable the Armv8-a Speculative Store Bypass Safe instruction.  This option
is only to enable the extension at the assembler level and does not affect code
generation.  This option is enabled by default for B<-march=armv8.5-a>.

=item B<predres>

Enable the Armv8-a Execution and Data Prediction Restriction instructions.
This option is only to enable the extension at the assembler level and does
not affect code generation.  This option is enabled by default for
B<-march=armv8.5-a>.


=back


Feature B<crypto> implies B<aes>, B<sha2>, and B<simd>,
which implies B<fp>.
Conversely, B<nofp> implies B<nosimd>, which implies
B<nocrypto>, B<noaes> and B<nosha2>.


=head3 Adapteva Epiphany Options


These B<-m> options are defined for Adapteva Epiphany:


=over 4


=item B<-mhalf-reg-file>

Don't allocate any register in the range C<r32>...C<r63>.
That allows code to run on hardware variants that lack these registers.


=item B<-mprefer-short-insn-regs>

Preferentially allocate registers that allow short instruction generation.
This can result in increased instruction count, so this may either reduce or
increase overall code size.


=item B<-mbranch-cost=>I<num>

Set the cost of branches to roughly I<num> "simple" instructions.
This cost is only a heuristic and is not guaranteed to produce
consistent results across releases.


=item B<-mcmove>

Enable the generation of conditional moves.


=item B<-mnops=>I<num>

Emit I<num> NOPs before every other generated instruction.


=item B<-mno-soft-cmpsf>

For single-precision floating-point comparisons, emit an C<fsub> instruction
and test the flags.  This is faster than a software comparison, but can
get incorrect results in the presence of NaNs, or when two different small
numbers are compared such that their difference is calculated as zero.
The default is B<-msoft-cmpsf>, which uses slower, but IEEE-compliant,
software comparisons.


=item B<-mstack-offset=>I<num>

Set the offset between the top of the stack and the stack pointer.
E.g., a value of 8 means that the eight bytes in the range C<sp+0...sp+7>
can be used by leaf functions without stack allocation.
Values other than B<8> or B<16> are untested and unlikely to work.
Note also that this option changes the ABI; compiling a program with a
different stack offset than the libraries have been compiled with
generally does not work.
This option can be useful if you want to evaluate if a different stack
offset would give you better code, but to actually use a different stack
offset to build working programs, it is recommended to configure the
toolchain with the appropriate B<--with-stack-offset=>I<num> option.


=item B<-mno-round-nearest>

Make the scheduler assume that the rounding mode has been set to
truncating.  The default is B<-mround-nearest>.


=item B<-mlong-calls>

If not otherwise specified by an attribute, assume all calls might be beyond
the offset range of the C<b> / C<bl> instructions, and therefore load the
function address into a register before performing a (otherwise direct) call.
This is the default.


=item B<-mshort-calls>

If not otherwise specified by an attribute, assume all direct calls are
in the range of the C<b> / C<bl> instructions, so use these instructions
for direct calls.  The default is B<-mlong-calls>.


=item B<-msmall16>

Assume addresses can be loaded as 16-bit unsigned values.  This does not
apply to function addresses for which B<-mlong-calls> semantics
are in effect.


=item B<-mfp-mode=>I<mode>

Set the prevailing mode of the floating-point unit.
This determines the floating-point mode that is provided and expected
at function call and return time.  Making this mode match the mode you
predominantly need at function start can make your programs smaller and
faster by avoiding unnecessary mode switches.

I<mode> can be set to one the following values:


=over 4


=item B<caller>

Any mode at function entry is valid, and retained or restored when
the function returns, and when it calls other functions.
This mode is useful for compiling libraries or other compilation units
you might want to incorporate into different programs with different
prevailing FPU modes, and the convenience of being able to use a single
object file outweighs the size and speed overhead for any extra
mode switching that might be needed, compared with what would be needed
with a more specific choice of prevailing FPU mode.


=item B<truncate>

This is the mode used for floating-point calculations with
truncating (i.e. round towards zero) rounding mode.  That includes
conversion from floating point to integer.


=item B<round-nearest>

This is the mode used for floating-point calculations with
round-to-nearest-or-even rounding mode.


=item B<int>

This is the mode used to perform integer calculations in the FPU, e.g.
integer multiply, or integer multiply-and-accumulate.

=back


The default is B<-mfp-mode=caller>


=item B<-mno-split-lohi>


=item B<-mno-postinc>


=item B<-mno-postmodify>

Code generation tweaks that disable, respectively, splitting of 32-bit
loads, generation of post-increment addresses, and generation of
post-modify addresses.  The defaults are B<msplit-lohi>,
B<-mpost-inc>, and B<-mpost-modify>.


=item B<-mnovect-double>

Change the preferred SIMD mode to SImode.  The default is
B<-mvect-double>, which uses DImode as preferred SIMD mode.


=item B<-max-vect-align=>I<num>

The maximum alignment for SIMD vector mode types.
I<num> may be 4 or 8.  The default is 8.
Note that this is an ABI change, even though many library function
interfaces are unaffected if they don't use SIMD vector modes
in places that affect size and/or alignment of relevant types.


=item B<-msplit-vecmove-early>

Split vector moves into single word moves before reload.  In theory this
can give better register allocation, but so far the reverse seems to be
generally the case.


=item B<-m1reg->I<reg>

Specify a register to hold the constant -1, which makes loading small negative
constants and certain bitmasks faster.
Allowable values for I<reg> are B<r43> and B<r63>,
which specify use of that register as a fixed register,
and B<none>, which means that no register is used for this
purpose.  The default is B<-m1reg-none>.


=back



=head3 AMD GCN Options


These options are defined specifically for the AMD GCN port.


=over 4



=item B<-march=>I<gpu>


=item B<-mtune=>I<gpu>

Set architecture type or tuning for I<gpu>. Supported values for I<gpu>
are


=over 4


=item B<fiji>

Compile for GCN3 Fiji devices (gfx803).


=item B<gfx900>

Compile for GCN5 Vega 10 devices (gfx900).


=back



=item B<-mstack-size=>I<bytes>

Specify how many I<bytes> of stack space will be requested for each GPU
thread (wave-front).  Beware that there may be many threads and limited memory
available.  The size of the stack allocation may also have an impact on
run-time performance.  The default is 32KB when using OpenACC or OpenMP, and
1MB otherwise.


=back



=head3 ARC Options


The following options control the architecture variant for which code
is being compiled:


=over 4



=item B<-mbarrel-shifter>

Generate instructions supported by barrel shifter.  This is the default
unless B<-mcpu=ARC601> or B<-mcpu=ARCEM> is in effect.


=item B<-mjli-always>

Force to call a function using jli_s instruction.  This option is
valid only for ARCv2 architecture.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu>

Set architecture type, register usage, and instruction scheduling
parameters for I<cpu>.  There are also shortcut alias options
available for backward compatibility and convenience.  Supported
values for I<cpu> are


=over 4


=item B<arc600>

Compile for ARC600.  Aliases: B<-mA6>, B<-mARC600>.


=item B<arc601>

Compile for ARC601.  Alias: B<-mARC601>.


=item B<arc700>
