Compile for ARC700.  Aliases: B<-mA7>, B<-mARC700>.
This is the default when configured with B<--with-cpu=arc700>.


=item B<arcem>

Compile for ARC EM.


=item B<archs>

Compile for ARC HS.


=item B<em>

Compile for ARC EM CPU with no hardware extensions.


=item B<em4>

Compile for ARC EM4 CPU.


=item B<em4_dmips>

Compile for ARC EM4 DMIPS CPU.


=item B<em4_fpus>

Compile for ARC EM4 DMIPS CPU with the single-precision floating-point
extension.


=item B<em4_fpuda>

Compile for ARC EM4 DMIPS CPU with single-precision floating-point and
double assist instructions.


=item B<hs>

Compile for ARC HS CPU with no hardware extensions except the atomic
instructions.


=item B<hs34>

Compile for ARC HS34 CPU.


=item B<hs38>

Compile for ARC HS38 CPU.


=item B<hs38_linux>

Compile for ARC HS38 CPU with all hardware extensions on.


=item B<arc600_norm>

Compile for ARC 600 CPU with C<norm> instructions enabled.


=item B<arc600_mul32x16>

Compile for ARC 600 CPU with C<norm> and 32x16-bit multiply 
instructions enabled.


=item B<arc600_mul64>

Compile for ARC 600 CPU with C<norm> and C<mul64>-family 
instructions enabled.


=item B<arc601_norm>

Compile for ARC 601 CPU with C<norm> instructions enabled.


=item B<arc601_mul32x16>

Compile for ARC 601 CPU with C<norm> and 32x16-bit multiply
instructions enabled.


=item B<arc601_mul64>

Compile for ARC 601 CPU with C<norm> and C<mul64>-family
instructions enabled.


=item B<nps400>

Compile for ARC 700 on NPS400 chip.


=item B<em_mini>

Compile for ARC EM minimalist configuration featuring reduced register
set.


=back



=item B<-mdpfp>


=item B<-mdpfp-compact>

Generate double-precision FPX instructions, tuned for the compact
implementation.


=item B<-mdpfp-fast>

Generate double-precision FPX instructions, tuned for the fast
implementation.


=item B<-mno-dpfp-lrsr>

Disable C<lr> and C<sr> instructions from using FPX extension
aux registers.


=item B<-mea>

Generate extended arithmetic instructions.  Currently only
C<divaw>, C<adds>, C<subs>, and C<sat16> are
supported.  This is always enabled for B<-mcpu=ARC700>.


=item B<-mno-mpy>

Do not generate C<mpy>-family instructions for ARC700.  This option is
deprecated.


=item B<-mmul32x16>

Generate 32x16-bit multiply and multiply-accumulate instructions.


=item B<-mmul64>

Generate C<mul64> and C<mulu64> instructions.  
Only valid for B<-mcpu=ARC600>.


=item B<-mnorm>

Generate C<norm> instructions.  This is the default if B<-mcpu=ARC700>
is in effect.


=item B<-mspfp>


=item B<-mspfp-compact>

Generate single-precision FPX instructions, tuned for the compact
implementation.


=item B<-mspfp-fast>

Generate single-precision FPX instructions, tuned for the fast
implementation.


=item B<-msimd>

Enable generation of ARC SIMD instructions via target-specific
builtins.  Only valid for B<-mcpu=ARC700>.


=item B<-msoft-float>

This option ignored; it is provided for compatibility purposes only.
Software floating-point code is emitted by default, and this default
can overridden by FPX options; B<-mspfp>, B<-mspfp-compact>, or
B<-mspfp-fast> for single precision, and B<-mdpfp>,
B<-mdpfp-compact>, or B<-mdpfp-fast> for double precision.


=item B<-mswap>

Generate C<swap> instructions.


=item B<-matomic>

This enables use of the locked load/store conditional extension to implement
atomic memory built-in functions.  Not available for ARC 6xx or ARC
EM cores.


=item B<-mdiv-rem>

Enable C<div> and C<rem> instructions for ARCv2 cores.


=item B<-mcode-density>

Enable code density instructions for ARC EM.  
This option is on by default for ARC HS.


=item B<-mll64>

Enable double load/store operations for ARC HS cores.


=item B<-mtp-regno=>I<regno>

Specify thread pointer register number.


=item B<-mmpy-option=>I<multo>

Compile ARCv2 code with a multiplier design option.  You can specify 
the option using either a string or numeric value for I<multo>.  
B<wlh1> is the default value.  The recognized values are:


=over 4


=item B<0>


=item B<none>

No multiplier available.


=item B<1>


=item B<w>

16x16 multiplier, fully pipelined.
The following instructions are enabled: C<mpyw> and C<mpyuw>.


=item B<2>


=item B<wlh1>

32x32 multiplier, fully
pipelined (1 stage).  The following instructions are additionally
enabled: C<mpy>, C<mpyu>, C<mpym>, C<mpymu>, and C<mpy_s>.


=item B<3>


=item B<wlh2>

32x32 multiplier, fully pipelined
(2 stages).  The following instructions are additionally enabled: C<mpy>,
C<mpyu>, C<mpym>, C<mpymu>, and C<mpy_s>.


=item B<4>


=item B<wlh3>

Two 16x16 multipliers, blocking,
sequential.  The following instructions are additionally enabled: C<mpy>,
C<mpyu>, C<mpym>, C<mpymu>, and C<mpy_s>.


=item B<5>


=item B<wlh4>

One 16x16 multiplier, blocking,
sequential.  The following instructions are additionally enabled: C<mpy>,
C<mpyu>, C<mpym>, C<mpymu>, and C<mpy_s>.


=item B<6>


=item B<wlh5>

One 32x4 multiplier, blocking,
sequential.  The following instructions are additionally enabled: C<mpy>,
C<mpyu>, C<mpym>, C<mpymu>, and C<mpy_s>.


=item B<7>


=item B<plus_dmpy>

ARC HS SIMD support.


=item B<8>


=item B<plus_macd>

ARC HS SIMD support.


=item B<9>


=item B<plus_qmacw>

ARC HS SIMD support.


=back


This option is only available for ARCv2 cores.


=item B<-mfpu=>I<fpu>

Enables support for specific floating-point hardware extensions for ARCv2
cores.  Supported values for I<fpu> are:


=over 4



=item B<fpus>

Enables support for single-precision floating-point hardware
extensions.


=item B<fpud>

Enables support for double-precision floating-point hardware
extensions.  The single-precision floating-point extension is also
enabled.  Not available for ARC EM.


=item B<fpuda>

Enables support for double-precision floating-point hardware
extensions using double-precision assist instructions.  The single-precision
floating-point extension is also enabled.  This option is
only available for ARC EM.


=item B<fpuda_div>

Enables support for double-precision floating-point hardware
extensions using double-precision assist instructions.
The single-precision floating-point, square-root, and divide 
extensions are also enabled.  This option is
only available for ARC EM.


=item B<fpuda_fma>

Enables support for double-precision floating-point hardware
extensions using double-precision assist instructions.
The single-precision floating-point and fused multiply and add 
hardware extensions are also enabled.  This option is
only available for ARC EM.


=item B<fpuda_all>

Enables support for double-precision floating-point hardware
extensions using double-precision assist instructions.
All single-precision floating-point hardware extensions are also
enabled.  This option is only available for ARC EM.


=item B<fpus_div>

Enables support for single-precision floating-point, square-root and divide 
hardware extensions.


=item B<fpud_div>

Enables support for double-precision floating-point, square-root and divide 
hardware extensions.  This option
includes option B<fpus_div>. Not available for ARC EM.


=item B<fpus_fma>

Enables support for single-precision floating-point and 
fused multiply and add hardware extensions.


=item B<fpud_fma>

Enables support for double-precision floating-point and 
fused multiply and add hardware extensions.  This option
includes option B<fpus_fma>.  Not available for ARC EM.


=item B<fpus_all>

Enables support for all single-precision floating-point hardware
extensions.


=item B<fpud_all>

Enables support for all single- and double-precision floating-point
hardware extensions.  Not available for ARC EM.


=back



=item B<-mirq-ctrl-saved=>I<register-range>B<,> I<blink>B<,> I<lp_count>

Specifies general-purposes registers that the processor automatically
saves/restores on interrupt entry and exit.  I<register-range> is
specified as two registers separated by a dash.  The register range
always starts with C<r0>, the upper limit is C<fp> register.
I<blink> and I<lp_count> are optional.  This option is only
valid for ARC EM and ARC HS cores.


=item B<-mrgf-banked-regs=>I<number>

Specifies the number of registers replicated in second register bank
on entry to fast interrupt.  Fast interrupts are interrupts with the
highest priority level P0.  These interrupts save only PC and STATUS32
registers to avoid memory transactions during interrupt entry and exit
sequences.  Use this option when you are using fast interrupts in an
ARC V2 family processor.  Permitted values are 4, 8, 16, and 32.


=item B<-mlpc-width=>I<width>

Specify the width of the C<lp_count> register.  Valid values for
I<width> are 8, 16, 20, 24, 28 and 32 bits.  The default width is
fixed to 32 bits.  If the width is less than 32, the compiler does not
attempt to transform loops in your program to use the zero-delay loop
mechanism unless it is known that the C<lp_count> register can
hold the required loop-counter value.  Depending on the width
specified, the compiler and run-time library might continue to use the
loop mechanism for various needs.  This option defines macro
C<__ARC_LPC_WIDTH__> with the value of I<width>.


=item B<-mrf16>

This option instructs the compiler to generate code for a 16-entry
register file.  This option defines the C<__ARC_RF16__>
preprocessor macro.


=item B<-mbranch-index>

Enable use of C<bi> or C<bih> instructions to implement jump
tables.


=back


The following options are passed through to the assembler, and also
define preprocessor macro symbols.


=over 4


=item B<-mdsp-packa>

Passed down to the assembler to enable the DSP Pack A extensions.
Also sets the preprocessor symbol C<__Xdsp_packa>.  This option is
deprecated.


=item B<-mdvbf>

Passed down to the assembler to enable the dual Viterbi butterfly
extension.  Also sets the preprocessor symbol C<__Xdvbf>.  This
option is deprecated.


=item B<-mlock>

Passed down to the assembler to enable the locked load/store
conditional extension.  Also sets the preprocessor symbol
C<__Xlock>.


=item B<-mmac-d16>

Passed down to the assembler.  Also sets the preprocessor symbol
C<__Xxmac_d16>.  This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mmac-24>

Passed down to the assembler.  Also sets the preprocessor symbol
C<__Xxmac_24>.  This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mrtsc>

Passed down to the assembler to enable the 64-bit time-stamp counter
extension instruction.  Also sets the preprocessor symbol
C<__Xrtsc>.  This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mswape>

Passed down to the assembler to enable the swap byte ordering
extension instruction.  Also sets the preprocessor symbol
C<__Xswape>.


=item B<-mtelephony>

Passed down to the assembler to enable dual- and single-operand
instructions for telephony.  Also sets the preprocessor symbol
C<__Xtelephony>.  This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mxy>

Passed down to the assembler to enable the XY memory extension.  Also
sets the preprocessor symbol C<__Xxy>.


=back


The following options control how the assembly code is annotated:


=over 4


=item B<-misize>

Annotate assembler instructions with estimated addresses.


=item B<-mannotate-align>

Explain what alignment considerations lead to the decision to make an
instruction short or long.


=back


The following options are passed through to the linker:


=over 4


=item B<-marclinux>

Passed through to the linker, to specify use of the C<arclinux> emulation.
This option is enabled by default in tool chains built for
S<C<arc-linux-uclibc>> and S<C<arceb-linux-uclibc>> targets
when profiling is not requested.


=item B<-marclinux_prof>

Passed through to the linker, to specify use of the
C<arclinux_prof> emulation.  This option is enabled by default in
tool chains built for S<C<arc-linux-uclibc>> and
S<C<arceb-linux-uclibc>> targets when profiling is requested.


=back


The following options control the semantics of generated code:


=over 4


=item B<-mlong-calls>

Generate calls as register indirect calls, thus providing access
to the full 32-bit address range.


=item B<-mmedium-calls>

Don't use less than 25-bit addressing range for calls, which is the
offset available for an unconditional branch-and-link
instruction.  Conditional execution of function calls is suppressed, to
allow use of the 25-bit range, rather than the 21-bit range with
conditional branch-and-link.  This is the default for tool chains built
for S<C<arc-linux-uclibc>> and S<C<arceb-linux-uclibc>> targets.


=item B<-G> I<num>

Put definitions of externally-visible data in a small data section if
that data is no bigger than I<num> bytes.  The default value of
I<num> is 4 for any ARC configuration, or 8 when we have double
load/store operations.


=item B<-mno-sdata>

Do not generate sdata references.  This is the default for tool chains
built for S<C<arc-linux-uclibc>> and S<C<arceb-linux-uclibc>>
targets.


=item B<-mvolatile-cache>

Use ordinarily cached memory accesses for volatile references.  This is the
default.


=item B<-mno-volatile-cache>

Enable cache bypass for volatile references.


=back


The following options fine tune code generation:

=over 4


=item B<-malign-call>

Do alignment optimizations for call instructions.


=item B<-mauto-modify-reg>

Enable the use of pre/post modify with register displacement.


=item B<-mbbit-peephole>

Enable bbit peephole2.


=item B<-mno-brcc>

This option disables a target-specific pass in F<arc_reorg> to
generate compare-and-branch (C<brI<cc>>) instructions.  
It has no effect on
generation of these instructions driven by the combiner pass.


=item B<-mcase-vector-pcrel>

Use PC-relative switch case tables to enable case table shortening.
This is the default for B<-Os>.


=item B<-mcompact-casesi>

Enable compact C<casesi> pattern.  This is the default for B<-Os>,
and only available for ARCv1 cores.  This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mno-cond-exec>

Disable the ARCompact-specific pass to generate conditional 
execution instructions.

Due to delay slot scheduling and interactions between operand numbers,
literal sizes, instruction lengths, and the support for conditional execution,
the target-independent pass to generate conditional execution is often lacking,
so the ARC port has kept a special pass around that tries to find more
conditional execution generation opportunities after register allocation,
branch shortening, and delay slot scheduling have been done.  This pass
generally, but not always, improves performance and code size, at the cost of
extra compilation time, which is why there is an option to switch it off.
If you have a problem with call instructions exceeding their allowable
offset range because they are conditionalized, you should consider using
B<-mmedium-calls> instead.


=item B<-mearly-cbranchsi>

Enable pre-reload use of the C<cbranchsi> pattern.


=item B<-mexpand-adddi>

Expand C<adddi3> and C<subdi3> at RTL generation time into
C<add.f>, C<adc> etc.  This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mindexed-loads>

Enable the use of indexed loads.  This can be problematic because some
optimizers then assume that indexed stores exist, which is not
the case.


=item B<-mlra>

Enable Local Register Allocation.  This is still experimental for ARC,
so by default the compiler uses standard reload
(i.e. B<-mno-lra>).


=item B<-mlra-priority-none>

Don't indicate any priority for target registers.


=item B<-mlra-priority-compact>

Indicate target register priority for r0..r3 / r12..r15.


=item B<-mlra-priority-noncompact>

Reduce target register priority for r0..r3 / r12..r15.


=item B<-mmillicode>

When optimizing for size (using B<-Os>), prologues and epilogues
that have to save or restore a large number of registers are often
shortened by using call to a special function in libgcc; this is
referred to as a I<millicode> call.  As these calls can pose
performance issues, and/or cause linking issues when linking in a
nonstandard way, this option is provided to turn on or off millicode
call generation.


=item B<-mcode-density-frame>

This option enable the compiler to emit C<enter> and C<leave>
instructions.  These instructions are only valid for CPUs with
code-density feature.


=item B<-mmixed-code>

Tweak register allocation to help 16-bit instruction generation.
This generally has the effect of decreasing the average instruction size
while increasing the instruction count.


=item B<-mq-class>

Enable B<q> instruction alternatives.
This is the default for B<-Os>.


=item B<-mRcq>

Enable B<Rcq> constraint handling.  
Most short code generation depends on this.
This is the default.


=item B<-mRcw>

Enable B<Rcw> constraint handling.  
Most ccfsm condexec mostly depends on this.
This is the default.


=item B<-msize-level=>I<level>

Fine-tune size optimization with regards to instruction lengths and alignment.
The recognized values for I<level> are:

=over 4


=item B<0>

No size optimization.  This level is deprecated and treated like B<1>.


=item B<1>

Short instructions are used opportunistically.


=item B<2>

In addition, alignment of loops and of code after barriers are dropped.


=item B<3>

In addition, optional data alignment is dropped, and the option B<Os> is enabled.


=back


This defaults to B<3> when B<-Os> is in effect.  Otherwise,
the behavior when this is not set is equivalent to level B<1>.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu>

Set instruction scheduling parameters for I<cpu>, overriding any implied
by B<-mcpu=>.

Supported values for I<cpu> are


=over 4


=item B<ARC600>

Tune for ARC600 CPU.


=item B<ARC601>

Tune for ARC601 CPU.


=item B<ARC700>

Tune for ARC700 CPU with standard multiplier block.


=item B<ARC700-xmac>

Tune for ARC700 CPU with XMAC block.


=item B<ARC725D>

Tune for ARC725D CPU.


=item B<ARC750D>

Tune for ARC750D CPU.


=back



=item B<-mmultcost=>I<num>

Cost to assume for a multiply instruction, with B<4> being equal to a
normal instruction.


=item B<-munalign-prob-threshold=>I<probability>

Set probability threshold for unaligning branches.
When tuning for B<ARC700> and optimizing for speed, branches without
filled delay slot are preferably emitted unaligned and long, unless
profiling indicates that the probability for the branch to be taken
is below I<probability>.  
The default is (REG_BR_PROB_BASE/2), i.e. 5000.


=back


The following options are maintained for backward compatibility, but
are now deprecated and will be removed in a future release:


=over 4



=item B<-margonaut>

Obsolete FPX.


=item B<-mbig-endian>


=item B<-EB>

Compile code for big-endian targets.  Use of these options is now
deprecated.  Big-endian code is supported by configuring GCC to build
S<C<arceb-elf32>> and S<C<arceb-linux-uclibc>> targets,
for which big endian is the default.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>


=item B<-EL>

Compile code for little-endian targets.  Use of these options is now
deprecated.  Little-endian code is supported by configuring GCC to build 
S<C<arc-elf32>> and S<C<arc-linux-uclibc>> targets,
for which little endian is the default.


=item B<-mbarrel_shifter>

Replaced by B<-mbarrel-shifter>.


=item B<-mdpfp_compact>

Replaced by B<-mdpfp-compact>.


=item B<-mdpfp_fast>

Replaced by B<-mdpfp-fast>.


=item B<-mdsp_packa>

Replaced by B<-mdsp-packa>.


=item B<-mEA>

Replaced by B<-mea>.


=item B<-mmac_24>

Replaced by B<-mmac-24>.


=item B<-mmac_d16>

Replaced by B<-mmac-d16>.


=item B<-mspfp_compact>

Replaced by B<-mspfp-compact>.


=item B<-mspfp_fast>

Replaced by B<-mspfp-fast>.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu>

Values B<arc600>, B<arc601>, B<arc700> and
B<arc700-xmac> for I<cpu> are replaced by B<ARC600>,
B<ARC601>, B<ARC700> and B<ARC700-xmac> respectively.


=item B<-multcost=>I<num>

Replaced by B<-mmultcost>.


=back



=head3 ARM Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the ARM port:


=over 4


=item B<-mabi=>I<name>

Generate code for the specified ABI.  Permissible values are: B<apcs-gnu>,
B<atpcs>, B<aapcs>, B<aapcs-linux> and B<iwmmxt>.


=item B<-mapcs-frame>

Generate a stack frame that is compliant with the ARM Procedure Call
Standard for all functions, even if this is not strictly necessary for
correct execution of the code.  Specifying B<-fomit-frame-pointer>
with this option causes the stack frames not to be generated for
leaf functions.  The default is B<-mno-apcs-frame>.
This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mapcs>

This is a synonym for B<-mapcs-frame> and is deprecated.



=item B<-mthumb-interwork>

Generate code that supports calling between the ARM and Thumb
instruction sets.  Without this option, on pre-v5 architectures, the
two instruction sets cannot be reliably used inside one program.  The
default is B<-mno-thumb-interwork>, since slightly larger code
is generated when B<-mthumb-interwork> is specified.  In AAPCS
configurations this option is meaningless.


=item B<-mno-sched-prolog>

Prevent the reordering of instructions in the function prologue, or the
merging of those instruction with the instructions in the function's
body.  This means that all functions start with a recognizable set
of instructions (or in fact one of a choice from a small set of
different function prologues), and this information can be used to
locate the start of functions inside an executable piece of code.  The
default is B<-msched-prolog>.


=item B<-mfloat-abi=>I<name>

Specifies which floating-point ABI to use.  Permissible values
are: B<soft>, B<softfp> and B<hard>.

Specifying B<soft> causes GCC to generate output containing
library calls for floating-point operations.
B<softfp> allows the generation of code using hardware floating-point
instructions, but still uses the soft-float calling conventions.
B<hard> allows generation of floating-point instructions
and uses FPU-specific calling conventions.

The default depends on the specific target configuration.  Note that
the hard-float and soft-float ABIs are not link-compatible; you must
compile your entire program with the same ABI, and link with a
compatible set of libraries.


=item B<-mgeneral-regs-only>

Generate code which uses only the general-purpose registers.  This will prevent
the compiler from using floating-point and Advanced SIMD registers but will not
impose any restrictions on the assembler.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

Generate code for a processor running in little-endian mode.  This is
the default for all standard configurations.


=item B<-mbig-endian>

Generate code for a processor running in big-endian mode; the default is
to compile code for a little-endian processor.


=item B<-mbe8>


=item B<-mbe32>

When linking a big-endian image select between BE8 and BE32 formats.
The option has no effect for little-endian images and is ignored.  The
default is dependent on the selected target architecture.  For ARMv6
and later architectures the default is BE8, for older architectures
the default is BE32.  BE32 format has been deprecated by ARM.


=item B<-march=>I<name>[B<+extension...>]

This specifies the name of the target ARM architecture.  GCC uses this
name to determine what kind of instructions it can emit when generating
assembly code.  This option can be used in conjunction with or instead
of the B<-mcpu=> option.

Permissible names are:
B<armv4t>,
B<armv5t>, B<armv5te>,
B<armv6>, B<armv6j>, B<armv6k>, B<armv6kz>, B<armv6t2>,
B<armv6z>, B<armv6zk>,
B<armv7>, B<armv7-a>, B<armv7ve>, 
B<armv8-a>, B<armv8.1-a>, B<armv8.2-a>, B<armv8.3-a>,
B<armv8.4-a>,
B<armv8.5-a>,
B<armv7-r>,
B<armv8-r>,
B<armv6-m>, B<armv6s-m>,
B<armv7-m>, B<armv7e-m>,
B<armv8-m.base>, B<armv8-m.main>,
B<iwmmxt> and B<iwmmxt2>.

Additionally, the following architectures, which lack support for the
Thumb execution state, are recognized but support is deprecated: B<armv4>.

Many of the architectures support extensions.  These can be added by
appending B<+>I<extension> to the architecture name.  Extension
options are processed in order and capabilities accumulate.  An extension
will also enable any necessary base extensions
upon which it depends.  For example, the B<+crypto> extension
will always enable the B<+simd> extension.  The exception to the
additive construction is for extensions that are prefixed with
B<+no...>: these extensions disable the specified option and
any other extensions that may depend on the presence of that
extension.

For example, B<-march=armv7-a+simd+nofp+vfpv4> is equivalent to
writing B<-march=armv7-a+vfpv4> since the B<+simd> option is
entirely disabled by the B<+nofp> option that follows it.

Most extension names are generically named, but have an effect that is
dependent upon the architecture to which it is applied.  For example,
the B<+simd> option can be applied to both B<armv7-a> and
B<armv8-a> architectures, but will enable the original ARMv7-A
Advanced SIMD (Neon) extensions for B<armv7-a> and the ARMv8-A
variant for B<armv8-a>.

The table below lists the supported extensions for each architecture.
Architectures not mentioned do not support any extensions.


=over 4


=item B<armv5te>


=item B<armv6>


=item B<armv6j>


=item B<armv6k>


=item B<armv6kz>


=item B<armv6t2>


=item B<armv6z>


=item B<armv6zk>


=over 4


=item B<+fp>

The VFPv2 floating-point instructions.  The extension B<+vfpv2> can be
used as an alias for this extension.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point instructions.

=back



=item B<armv7>

The common subset of the ARMv7-A, ARMv7-R and ARMv7-M architectures.

=over 4


=item B<+fp>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision
registers.  The extension B<+vfpv3-d16> can be used as an alias
for this extension.  Note that floating-point is not supported by the
base ARMv7-M architecture, but is compatible with both the ARMv7-A and
ARMv7-R architectures.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point instructions.

=back



=item B<armv7-a>


=over 4


=item B<+mp>

The multiprocessing extension.


=item B<+sec>

The security extension.


=item B<+fp>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision
registers.  The extension B<+vfpv3-d16> can be used as an alias
for this extension.


=item B<+simd>

The Advanced SIMD (Neon) v1 and the VFPv3 floating-point instructions.
The extensions B<+neon> and B<+neon-vfpv3> can be used as aliases
for this extension.


=item B<+vfpv3>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 32 double-precision
registers.


=item B<+vfpv3-d16-fp16>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision
registers and the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+vfpv3-fp16>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 32 double-precision
registers and the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+vfpv4-d16>

The VFPv4 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision
registers.


=item B<+vfpv4>

The VFPv4 floating-point instructions, with 32 double-precision
registers.


=item B<+neon-fp16>

The Advanced SIMD (Neon) v1 and the VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with
the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+neon-vfpv4>

The Advanced SIMD (Neon) v2 and the VFPv4 floating-point instructions.


=item B<+nosimd>

Disable the Advanced SIMD instructions (does not disable floating point).


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point and Advanced SIMD instructions.

=back



=item B<armv7ve>

The extended version of the ARMv7-A architecture with support for
virtualization.

=over 4


=item B<+fp>

The VFPv4 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision registers.
The extension B<+vfpv4-d16> can be used as an alias for this extension.


=item B<+simd>

The Advanced SIMD (Neon) v2 and the VFPv4 floating-point instructions.  The
extension B<+neon-vfpv4> can be used as an alias for this extension.


=item B<+vfpv3-d16>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision
registers.


=item B<+vfpv3>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 32 double-precision
registers.


=item B<+vfpv3-d16-fp16>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision
registers and the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+vfpv3-fp16>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with 32 double-precision
registers and the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+vfpv4-d16>

The VFPv4 floating-point instructions, with 16 double-precision
registers.


=item B<+vfpv4>

The VFPv4 floating-point instructions, with 32 double-precision
registers.


=item B<+neon>

The Advanced SIMD (Neon) v1 and the VFPv3 floating-point instructions.
The extension B<+neon-vfpv3> can be used as an alias for this extension.


=item B<+neon-fp16>

The Advanced SIMD (Neon) v1 and the VFPv3 floating-point instructions, with
the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+nosimd>

Disable the Advanced SIMD instructions (does not disable floating point).


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point and Advanced SIMD instructions.

=back



=item B<armv8-a>


=over 4


=item B<+crc>

The Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) instructions.

=item B<+simd>

The ARMv8-A Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions.

=item B<+crypto>

The cryptographic instructions.

=item B<+nocrypto>

Disable the cryptographic instructions.

=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point, Advanced SIMD and cryptographic instructions.

=item B<+sb>

Speculation Barrier Instruction.

=item B<+predres>

Execution and Data Prediction Restriction Instructions.

=back



=item B<armv8.1-a>


=over 4


=item B<+simd>

The ARMv8.1-A Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions.


=item B<+crypto>

The cryptographic instructions.  This also enables the Advanced SIMD and
floating-point instructions.


=item B<+nocrypto>

Disable the cryptographic instructions.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point, Advanced SIMD and cryptographic instructions.


=item B<+sb>

Speculation Barrier Instruction.


=item B<+predres>

Execution and Data Prediction Restriction Instructions.

=back



=item B<armv8.2-a>


=item B<armv8.3-a>


=over 4


=item B<+fp16>

The half-precision floating-point data processing instructions.
This also enables the Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions.


=item B<+fp16fml>

The half-precision floating-point fmla extension.  This also enables
the half-precision floating-point extension and Advanced SIMD and
floating-point instructions.


=item B<+simd>

The ARMv8.1-A Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions.


=item B<+crypto>

The cryptographic instructions.  This also enables the Advanced SIMD and
floating-point instructions.


=item B<+dotprod>

Enable the Dot Product extension.  This also enables Advanced SIMD instructions.


=item B<+nocrypto>

Disable the cryptographic extension.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point, Advanced SIMD and cryptographic instructions.


=item B<+sb>

Speculation Barrier Instruction.


=item B<+predres>

Execution and Data Prediction Restriction Instructions.

=back



=item B<armv8.4-a>


=over 4


=item B<+fp16>

The half-precision floating-point data processing instructions.
This also enables the Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions as well
as the Dot Product extension and the half-precision floating-point fmla
extension.


=item B<+simd>

The ARMv8.3-A Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions as well as the
Dot Product extension.


=item B<+crypto>

The cryptographic instructions.  This also enables the Advanced SIMD and
floating-point instructions as well as the Dot Product extension.


=item B<+nocrypto>

Disable the cryptographic extension.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point, Advanced SIMD and cryptographic instructions.


=item B<+sb>

Speculation Barrier Instruction.


=item B<+predres>

Execution and Data Prediction Restriction Instructions.

=back



=item B<armv8.5-a>


=over 4


=item B<+fp16>

The half-precision floating-point data processing instructions.
This also enables the Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions as well
as the Dot Product extension and the half-precision floating-point fmla
extension.


=item B<+simd>

The ARMv8.3-A Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions as well as the
Dot Product extension.


=item B<+crypto>

The cryptographic instructions.  This also enables the Advanced SIMD and
floating-point instructions as well as the Dot Product extension.


=item B<+nocrypto>

Disable the cryptographic extension.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point, Advanced SIMD and cryptographic instructions.

=back



=item B<armv7-r>


=over 4


=item B<+fp.sp>

The single-precision VFPv3 floating-point instructions.  The extension
B<+vfpv3xd> can be used as an alias for this extension.


=item B<+fp>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions with 16 double-precision registers.
The extension +vfpv3-d16 can be used as an alias for this extension.


=item B<+vfpv3xd-d16-fp16>

The single-precision VFPv3 floating-point instructions with 16 double-precision
registers and the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+vfpv3-d16-fp16>

The VFPv3 floating-point instructions with 16 double-precision
registers and the half-precision floating-point conversion operations.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point extension.


=item B<+idiv>

The ARM-state integer division instructions.


=item B<+noidiv>

Disable the ARM-state integer division extension.

=back



=item B<armv7e-m>


=over 4


=item B<+fp>

The single-precision VFPv4 floating-point instructions.


=item B<+fpv5>

The single-precision FPv5 floating-point instructions.


=item B<+fp.dp>

The single- and double-precision FPv5 floating-point instructions.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point extensions.

=back



=item B<armv8-m.main>


=over 4


=item B<+dsp>

The DSP instructions.


=item B<+nodsp>

Disable the DSP extension.


=item B<+fp>

The single-precision floating-point instructions.


=item B<+fp.dp>

The single- and double-precision floating-point instructions.


=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point extension.

=back



=item B<armv8-r>


=over 4


=item B<+crc>

The Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) instructions.

=item B<+fp.sp>

The single-precision FPv5 floating-point instructions.

=item B<+simd>

The ARMv8-A Advanced SIMD and floating-point instructions.

=item B<+crypto>

The cryptographic instructions.

=item B<+nocrypto>

Disable the cryptographic instructions.

=item B<+nofp>

Disable the floating-point, Advanced SIMD and cryptographic instructions.

=back



=back


B<-march=native> causes the compiler to auto-detect the architecture
of the build computer.  At present, this feature is only supported on
GNU/Linux, and not all architectures are recognized.  If the auto-detect
is unsuccessful the option has no effect.


=item B<-mtune=>I<name>

This option specifies the name of the target ARM processor for
which GCC should tune the performance of the code.
For some ARM implementations better performance can be obtained by using
this option.
Permissible names are: B<arm7tdmi>, B<arm7tdmi-s>, B<arm710t>,
B<arm720t>, B<arm740t>, B<strongarm>, B<strongarm110>,
B<strongarm1100>, 0B<strongarm1110>, B<arm8>, B<arm810>,
B<arm9>, B<arm9e>, B<arm920>, B<arm920t>, B<arm922t>,
B<arm946e-s>, B<arm966e-s>, B<arm968e-s>, B<arm926ej-s>,
B<arm940t>, B<arm9tdmi>, B<arm10tdmi>, B<arm1020t>,
B<arm1026ej-s>, B<arm10e>, B<arm1020e>, B<arm1022e>,
B<arm1136j-s>, B<arm1136jf-s>, B<mpcore>, B<mpcorenovfp>,
B<arm1156t2-s>, B<arm1156t2f-s>, B<arm1176jz-s>, B<arm1176jzf-s>,
B<generic-armv7-a>, B<cortex-a5>, B<cortex-a7>, B<cortex-a8>,
B<cortex-a9>, B<cortex-a12>, B<cortex-a15>, B<cortex-a17>,
B<cortex-a32>, B<cortex-a35>, B<cortex-a53>, B<cortex-a55>,
B<cortex-a57>, B<cortex-a72>, B<cortex-a73>, B<cortex-a75>,
B<cortex-a76>, B<ares>, B<cortex-r4>, B<cortex-r4f>,
B<cortex-r5>, B<cortex-r7>, B<cortex-r8>, B<cortex-r52>,
B<cortex-m0>, B<cortex-m0plus>, B<cortex-m1>, B<cortex-m3>,
B<cortex-m4>, B<cortex-m7>, B<cortex-m23>, B<cortex-m33>,
B<cortex-m1.small-multiply>, B<cortex-m0.small-multiply>,
B<cortex-m0plus.small-multiply>, B<exynos-m1>, B<marvell-pj4>,
B<neoverse-n1>, B<xscale>, B<iwmmxt>, B<iwmmxt2>,
B<ep9312>, B<fa526>, B<fa626>, B<fa606te>, B<fa626te>,
B<fmp626>, B<fa726te>, B<xgene1>.

Additionally, this option can specify that GCC should tune the performance
of the code for a big.LITTLE system.  Permissible names are:
B<cortex-a15.cortex-a7>, B<cortex-a17.cortex-a7>,
B<cortex-a57.cortex-a53>, B<cortex-a72.cortex-a53>,
B<cortex-a72.cortex-a35>, B<cortex-a73.cortex-a53>,
B<cortex-a75.cortex-a55>, B<cortex-a76.cortex-a55>.

B<-mtune=generic->I<arch> specifies that GCC should tune the
performance for a blend of processors within architecture I<arch>.
The aim is to generate code that run well on the current most popular
processors, balancing between optimizations that benefit some CPUs in the
range, and avoiding performance pitfalls of other CPUs.  The effects of
this option may change in future GCC versions as CPU models come and go.

B<-mtune> permits the same extension options as B<-mcpu>, but
the extension options do not affect the tuning of the generated code.

B<-mtune=native> causes the compiler to auto-detect the CPU
of the build computer.  At present, this feature is only supported on
GNU/Linux, and not all architectures are recognized.  If the auto-detect is
unsuccessful the option has no effect.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<name>[B<+extension...>]

This specifies the name of the target ARM processor.  GCC uses this name
to derive the name of the target ARM architecture (as if specified
by B<-march>) and the ARM processor type for which to tune for
performance (as if specified by B<-mtune>).  Where this option
is used in conjunction with B<-march> or B<-mtune>,
those options take precedence over the appropriate part of this option.

Many of the supported CPUs implement optional architectural
extensions.  Where this is so the architectural extensions are
normally enabled by default.  If implementations that lack the
extension exist, then the extension syntax can be used to disable
those extensions that have been omitted.  For floating-point and
Advanced SIMD (Neon) instructions, the settings of the options
B<-mfloat-abi> and B<-mfpu> must also be considered:
floating-point and Advanced SIMD instructions will only be used if
B<-mfloat-abi> is not set to B<soft>; and any setting of
B<-mfpu> other than B<auto> will override the available
floating-point and SIMD extension instructions.

For example, B<cortex-a9> can be found in three major
configurations: integer only, with just a floating-point unit or with
floating-point and Advanced SIMD.  The default is to enable all the
instructions, but the extensions B<+nosimd> and B<+nofp> can
be used to disable just the SIMD or both the SIMD and floating-point
instructions respectively.

Permissible names for this option are the same as those for
B<-mtune>.

The following extension options are common to the listed CPUs:


=over 4


=item B<+nodsp>

Disable the DSP instructions on B<cortex-m33>.


=item B<+nofp>

Disables the floating-point instructions on B<arm9e>,
B<arm946e-s>, B<arm966e-s>, B<arm968e-s>, B<arm10e>,
B<arm1020e>, B<arm1022e>, B<arm926ej-s>,
B<arm1026ej-s>, B<cortex-r5>, B<cortex-r7>, B<cortex-r8>,
B<cortex-m4>, B<cortex-m7> and B<cortex-m33>.
Disables the floating-point and SIMD instructions on
B<generic-armv7-a>, B<cortex-a5>, B<cortex-a7>,
B<cortex-a8>, B<cortex-a9>, B<cortex-a12>,
B<cortex-a15>, B<cortex-a17>, B<cortex-a15.cortex-a7>,
B<cortex-a17.cortex-a7>, B<cortex-a32>, B<cortex-a35>,
B<cortex-a53> and B<cortex-a55>.


=item B<+nofp.dp>

Disables the double-precision component of the floating-point instructions
on B<cortex-r5>, B<cortex-r7>, B<cortex-r8>, B<cortex-r52> and
B<cortex-m7>.


=item B<+nosimd>

Disables the SIMD (but not floating-point) instructions on
B<generic-armv7-a>, B<cortex-a5>, B<cortex-a7>
and B<cortex-a9>.


=item B<+crypto>

Enables the cryptographic instructions on B<cortex-a32>,
B<cortex-a35>, B<cortex-a53>, B<cortex-a55>, B<cortex-a57>,
B<cortex-a72>, B<cortex-a73>, B<cortex-a75>, B<exynos-m1>,
B<xgene1>, B<cortex-a57.cortex-a53>, B<cortex-a72.cortex-a53>,
B<cortex-a73.cortex-a35>, B<cortex-a73.cortex-a53> and
B<cortex-a75.cortex-a55>.

=back


Additionally the B<generic-armv7-a> pseudo target defaults to
VFPv3 with 16 double-precision registers.  It supports the following
extension options: B<mp>, B<sec>, B<vfpv3-d16>,
B<vfpv3>, B<vfpv3-d16-fp16>, B<vfpv3-fp16>,
B<vfpv4-d16>, B<vfpv4>, B<neon>, B<neon-vfpv3>,
B<neon-fp16>, B<neon-vfpv4>.  The meanings are the same as for
the extensions to B<-march=armv7-a>.

B<-mcpu=generic->I<arch> is also permissible, and is
equivalent to B<-march=>I<arch> B<-mtune=generic->I<arch>.
See B<-mtune> for more information.

B<-mcpu=native> causes the compiler to auto-detect the CPU
of the build computer.  At present, this feature is only supported on
GNU/Linux, and not all architectures are recognized.  If the auto-detect
is unsuccessful the option has no effect.


=item B<-mfpu=>I<name>

This specifies what floating-point hardware (or hardware emulation) is
available on the target.  Permissible names are: B<auto>, B<vfpv2>,
B<vfpv3>,
B<vfpv3-fp16>, B<vfpv3-d16>, B<vfpv3-d16-fp16>, B<vfpv3xd>,
B<vfpv3xd-fp16>, B<neon-vfpv3>, B<neon-fp16>, B<vfpv4>,
B<vfpv4-d16>, B<fpv4-sp-d16>, B<neon-vfpv4>,
B<fpv5-d16>, B<fpv5-sp-d16>,
B<fp-armv8>, B<neon-fp-armv8> and B<crypto-neon-fp-armv8>.
Note that B<neon> is an alias for B<neon-vfpv3> and B<vfp>
is an alias for B<vfpv2>.

The setting B<auto> is the default and is special.  It causes the
compiler to select the floating-point and Advanced SIMD instructions
based on the settings of B<-mcpu> and B<-march>.

If the selected floating-point hardware includes the NEON extension
(e.g. B<-mfpu=neon>), note that floating-point
operations are not generated by GCC's auto-vectorization pass unless
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is also specified.  This is
because NEON hardware does not fully implement the IEEE 754 standard for
floating-point arithmetic (in particular denormal values are treated as
zero), so the use of NEON instructions may lead to a loss of precision.

You can also set the fpu name at function level by using the C<target("fpu=")> function attributes or pragmas.


=item B<-mfp16-format=>I<name>

Specify the format of the C<__fp16> half-precision floating-point type.
Permissible names are B<none>, B<ieee>, and B<alternative>;
the default is B<none>, in which case the C<__fp16> type is not
defined.  


=item B<-mstructure-size-boundary=>I<n>

The sizes of all structures and unions are rounded up to a multiple
of the number of bits set by this option.  Permissible values are 8, 32
and 64.  The default value varies for different toolchains.  For the COFF
targeted toolchain the default value is 8.  A value of 64 is only allowed
if the underlying ABI supports it.

Specifying a larger number can produce faster, more efficient code, but
can also increase the size of the program.  Different values are potentially
incompatible.  Code compiled with one value cannot necessarily expect to
work with code or libraries compiled with another value, if they exchange
information using structures or unions.

This option is deprecated.


=item B<-mabort-on-noreturn>

Generate a call to the function C<abort> at the end of a
C<noreturn> function.  It is executed if the function tries to
return.


=item B<-mlong-calls>


=item B<-mno-long-calls>

Tells the compiler to perform function calls by first loading the
address of the function into a register and then performing a subroutine
call on this register.  This switch is needed if the target function
lies outside of the 64-megabyte addressing range of the offset-based
version of subroutine call instruction.

Even if this switch is enabled, not all function calls are turned
into long calls.  The heuristic is that static functions, functions
that have the C<short_call> attribute, functions that are inside
the scope of a C<#pragma no_long_calls> directive, and functions whose
definitions have already been compiled within the current compilation
unit are not turned into long calls.  The exceptions to this rule are
that weak function definitions, functions with the C<long_call>
attribute or the C<section> attribute, and functions that are within
the scope of a C<#pragma long_calls> directive are always
turned into long calls.

This feature is not enabled by default.  Specifying
B<-mno-long-calls> restores the default behavior, as does
placing the function calls within the scope of a C<#pragma
long_calls_off> directive.  Note these switches have no effect on how
the compiler generates code to handle function calls via function
pointers.


=item B<-msingle-pic-base>

Treat the register used for PIC addressing as read-only, rather than
loading it in the prologue for each function.  The runtime system is
responsible for initializing this register with an appropriate value
before execution begins.


=item B<-mpic-register=>I<reg>

Specify the register to be used for PIC addressing.
For standard PIC base case, the default is any suitable register
determined by compiler.  For single PIC base case, the default is
B<R9> if target is EABI based or stack-checking is enabled,
otherwise the default is B<R10>.


=item B<-mpic-data-is-text-relative>

Assume that the displacement between the text and data segments is fixed
at static link time.  This permits using PC-relative addressing
operations to access data known to be in the data segment.  For
non-VxWorks RTP targets, this option is enabled by default.  When
disabled on such targets, it will enable B<-msingle-pic-base> by
default.


=item B<-mpoke-function-name>

Write the name of each function into the text section, directly
preceding the function prologue.  The generated code is similar to this:

	
	     t0
	         .ascii "arm_poke_function_name", 0
	         .align
	     t1
	         .word 0xff000000 + (t1 - t0)
	     arm_poke_function_name
	         mov     ip, sp
	         stmfd   sp!, {fp, ip, lr, pc}
	         sub     fp, ip, #4


When performing a stack backtrace, code can inspect the value of
C<pc> stored at C<fp + 0>.  If the trace function then looks at
location C<pc - 12> and the top 8 bits are set, then we know that
there is a function name embedded immediately preceding this location
and has length C<((pc[-3]) & 0xff000000)>.


=item B<-mthumb>


=item B<-marm>


Select between generating code that executes in ARM and Thumb
states.  The default for most configurations is to generate code
that executes in ARM state, but the default can be changed by
configuring GCC with the B<--with-mode=>I<state>
configure option.

You can also override the ARM and Thumb mode for each function
by using the C<target("thumb")> and C<target("arm")> function attributes or pragmas.


=item B<-mflip-thumb> 

Switch ARM/Thumb modes on alternating functions.
This option is provided for regression testing of mixed Thumb/ARM code
generation, and is not intended for ordinary use in compiling code.


=item B<-mtpcs-frame>

Generate a stack frame that is compliant with the Thumb Procedure Call
Standard for all non-leaf functions.  (A leaf function is one that does
not call any other functions.)  The default is B<-mno-tpcs-frame>.


=item B<-mtpcs-leaf-frame>

Generate a stack frame that is compliant with the Thumb Procedure Call
Standard for all leaf functions.  (A leaf function is one that does
not call any other functions.)  The default is B<-mno-apcs-leaf-frame>.


=item B<-mcallee-super-interworking>

Gives all externally visible functions in the file being compiled an ARM
instruction set header which switches to Thumb mode before executing the
rest of the function.  This allows these functions to be called from
non-interworking code.  This option is not valid in AAPCS configurations
because interworking is enabled by default.


=item B<-mcaller-super-interworking>

Allows calls via function pointers (including virtual functions) to
execute correctly regardless of whether the target code has been
compiled for interworking or not.  There is a small overhead in the cost
of executing a function pointer if this option is enabled.  This option
is not valid in AAPCS configurations because interworking is enabled
by default.


=item B<-mtp=>I<name>

Specify the access model for the thread local storage pointer.  The valid
models are B<soft>, which generates calls to C<__aeabi_read_tp>,
B<cp15>, which fetches the thread pointer from C<cp15> directly
(supported in the arm6k architecture), and B<auto>, which uses the
best available method for the selected processor.  The default setting is
B<auto>.


=item B<-mtls-dialect=>I<dialect>

Specify the dialect to use for accessing thread local storage.  Two
I<dialect>s are supported---B<gnu> and B<gnu2>.  The
B<gnu> dialect selects the original GNU scheme for supporting
local and global dynamic TLS models.  The B<gnu2> dialect
selects the GNU descriptor scheme, which provides better performance
for shared libraries.  The GNU descriptor scheme is compatible with
the original scheme, but does require new assembler, linker and
library support.  Initial and local exec TLS models are unaffected by
this option and always use the original scheme.


=item B<-mword-relocations>

Only generate absolute relocations on word-sized values (i.e. R_ARM_ABS32).
This is enabled by default on targets (uClinux, SymbianOS) where the runtime
loader imposes this restriction, and when B<-fpic> or B<-fPIC>
is specified. This option conflicts with B<-mslow-flash-data>.


=item B<-mfix-cortex-m3-ldrd>

Some Cortex-M3 cores can cause data corruption when C<ldrd> instructions
with overlapping destination and base registers are used.  This option avoids
generating these instructions.  This option is enabled by default when
B<-mcpu=cortex-m3> is specified.


=item B<-munaligned-access>


=item B<-mno-unaligned-access>

Enables (or disables) reading and writing of 16- and 32- bit values
from addresses that are not 16- or 32- bit aligned.  By default
unaligned access is disabled for all pre-ARMv6, all ARMv6-M and for
ARMv8-M Baseline architectures, and enabled for all other
architectures.  If unaligned access is not enabled then words in packed
data structures are accessed a byte at a time.

The ARM attribute C<Tag_CPU_unaligned_access> is set in the
generated object file to either true or false, depending upon the
setting of this option.  If unaligned access is enabled then the
preprocessor symbol C<__ARM_FEATURE_UNALIGNED> is also
defined.


=item B<-mneon-for-64bits>

Enables using Neon to handle scalar 64-bits operations. This is
disabled by default since the cost of moving data from core registers
to Neon is high.


=item B<-mslow-flash-data>

Assume loading data from flash is slower than fetching instruction.
Therefore literal load is minimized for better performance.
This option is only supported when compiling for ARMv7 M-profile and
off by default. It conflicts with B<-mword-relocations>.


=item B<-masm-syntax-unified>

Assume inline assembler is using unified asm syntax.  The default is
currently off which implies divided syntax.  This option has no impact
on Thumb2. However, this may change in future releases of GCC.
Divided syntax should be considered deprecated.


=item B<-mrestrict-it>

Restricts generation of IT blocks to conform to the rules of ARMv8-A.
IT blocks can only contain a single 16-bit instruction from a select
set of instructions. This option is on by default for ARMv8-A Thumb mode.


=item B<-mprint-tune-info>

Print CPU tuning information as comment in assembler file.  This is
an option used only for regression testing of the compiler and not
intended for ordinary use in compiling code.  This option is disabled
by default.


=item B<-mverbose-cost-dump>

Enable verbose cost model dumping in the debug dump files.  This option is
provided for use in debugging the compiler.


=item B<-mpure-code>

Do not allow constant data to be placed in code sections.
Additionally, when compiling for ELF object format give all text sections the
ELF processor-specific section attribute C<SHF_ARM_PURECODE>.  This option
is only available when generating non-pic code for M-profile targets with the
MOVT instruction.


=item B<-mcmse>

Generate secure code as per the "ARMv8-M Security Extensions: Requirements on
Development Tools Engineering Specification", which can be found on
E<lt>B<http://infocenter.arm.com/help/topic/com.arm.doc.ecm0359818/ECM0359818_armv8m_security_extensions_reqs_on_dev_tools_1_0.pdf>E<gt>.

=back



=head3 AVR Options


These options are defined for AVR implementations:


=over 4


=item B<-mmcu=>I<mcu>

Specify Atmel AVR instruction set architectures (ISA) or MCU type.

The default for this option is@tie{}B<avr2>.

GCC supports the following AVR devices and ISAs:





=over 4



=item C<avr2>

"Classic" devices with up to 8@tie{}KiB of program memory.
I<mcu>@tie{}= C<attiny22>, C<attiny26>, C<at90c8534>, C<at90s2313>, C<at90s2323>, C<at90s2333>, C<at90s2343>, C<at90s4414>, C<at90s4433>, C<at90s4434>, C<at90s8515>, C<at90s8535>.


=item C<avr25>

"Classic" devices with up to 8@tie{}KiB of program memory and with the C<MOVW> instruction.
I<mcu>@tie{}= C<ata5272>, C<ata6616c>, C<attiny13>, C<attiny13a>, C<attiny2313>, C<attiny2313a>, C<attiny24>, C<attiny24a>, C<attiny25>, C<attiny261>, C<attiny261a>, C<attiny43u>, C<attiny4313>, C<attiny44>, C<attiny44a>, C<attiny441>, C<attiny45>, C<attiny461>, C<attiny461a>, C<attiny48>, C<attiny828>, C<attiny84>, C<attiny84a>, C<attiny841>, C<attiny85>, C<attiny861>, C<attiny861a>, C<attiny87>, C<attiny88>, C<at86rf401>.


=item C<avr3>

"Classic" devices with 16@tie{}KiB up to 64@tie{}KiB of  program memory.
I<mcu>@tie{}= C<at43usb355>, C<at76c711>.


=item C<avr31>

"Classic" devices with 128@tie{}KiB of program memory.
I<mcu>@tie{}= C<atmega103>, C<at43usb320>.


=item C<avr35>

"Classic" devices with 16@tie{}KiB up to 64@tie{}KiB of program memory and with the C<MOVW> instruction.
I<mcu>@tie{}= C<ata5505>, C<ata6617c>, C<ata664251>, C<atmega16u2>, C<atmega32u2>, C<atmega8u2>, C<attiny1634>, C<attiny167>, C<at90usb162>, C<at90usb82>.


=item C<avr4>

"Enhanced" devices with up to 8@tie{}KiB of program memory.
I<mcu>@tie{}= C<ata6285>, C<ata6286>, C<ata6289>, C<ata6612c>, C<atmega48>, C<atmega48a>, C<atmega48p>, C<atmega48pa>, C<atmega48pb>, C<atmega8>, C<atmega8a>, C<atmega8hva>, C<atmega8515>, C<atmega8535>, C<atmega88>, C<atmega88a>, C<atmega88p>, C<atmega88pa>, C<atmega88pb>, C<at90pwm1>, C<at90pwm2>, C<at90pwm2b>, C<at90pwm3>, C<at90pwm3b>, C<at90pwm81>.
