=item B<-mabsdata>


Assume that all data in static storage can be accessed by LDS / STS
instructions.  This option has only an effect on reduced Tiny devices like
ATtiny40.  See also the C<absdata>
B<AVR Variable Attributes,variable attribute>.


=item B<-maccumulate-args>

Accumulate outgoing function arguments and acquire/release the needed
stack space for outgoing function arguments once in function
prologue/epilogue.  Without this option, outgoing arguments are pushed
before calling a function and popped afterwards.

Popping the arguments after the function call can be expensive on
AVR so that accumulating the stack space might lead to smaller
executables because arguments need not be removed from the
stack after such a function call.

This option can lead to reduced code size for functions that perform
several calls to functions that get their arguments on the stack like
calls to printf-like functions.


=item B<-mbranch-cost=>I<cost>

Set the branch costs for conditional branch instructions to
I<cost>.  Reasonable values for I<cost> are small, non-negative
integers. The default branch cost is 0.


=item B<-mcall-prologues>

Functions prologues/epilogues are expanded as calls to appropriate
subroutines.  Code size is smaller.


=item B<-mgas-isr-prologues>

Interrupt service routines (ISRs) may use the C<__gcc_isr> pseudo
instruction supported by GNU Binutils.
If this option is on, the feature can still be disabled for individual
ISRs by means of the B<AVR Function Attributes,,C<no_gccisr>>
function attribute.  This feature is activated per default
if optimization is on (but not with B<-Og>, @pxref{Optimize Options}),
and if GNU Binutils support S<PR21683> (C<https://sourceware.org/PR21683>).


=item B<-mint8>

Assume C<int> to be 8-bit integer.  This affects the sizes of all types: a
C<char> is 1 byte, an C<int> is 1 byte, a C<long> is 2 bytes,
and C<long long> is 4 bytes.  Please note that this option does not
conform to the C standards, but it results in smaller code
size.


=item B<-mmain-is-OS_task>

Do not save registers in C<main>.  The effect is the same like
attaching attribute B<AVR Function Attributes,,C<OS_task>>
to C<main>. It is activated per default if optimization is on.


=item B<-mn-flash=>I<num>

Assume that the flash memory has a size of 
I<num> times 64@tie{}KiB.


=item B<-mno-interrupts>

Generated code is not compatible with hardware interrupts.
Code size is smaller.


=item B<-mrelax>

Try to replace C<CALL> resp. C<JMP> instruction by the shorter
C<RCALL> resp. C<RJMP> instruction if applicable.
Setting B<-mrelax> just adds the B<--mlink-relax> option to
the assembler's command line and the B<--relax> option to the
linker's command line.

Jump relaxing is performed by the linker because jump offsets are not
known before code is located. Therefore, the assembler code generated by the
compiler is the same, but the instructions in the executable may
differ from instructions in the assembler code.

Relaxing must be turned on if linker stubs are needed, see the
section on C<EIND> and linker stubs below.


=item B<-mrmw>

Assume that the device supports the Read-Modify-Write
instructions C<XCH>, C<LAC>, C<LAS> and C<LAT>.


=item B<-mshort-calls>


Assume that C<RJMP> and C<RCALL> can target the whole
program memory.

This option is used internally for multilib selection.  It is
not an optimization option, and you don't need to set it by hand.


=item B<-msp8>

Treat the stack pointer register as an 8-bit register,
i.e. assume the high byte of the stack pointer is zero.
In general, you don't need to set this option by hand.

This option is used internally by the compiler to select and
build multilibs for architectures C<avr2> and C<avr25>.
These architectures mix devices with and without C<SPH>.
For any setting other than B<-mmcu=avr2> or B<-mmcu=avr25>
the compiler driver adds or removes this option from the compiler
proper's command line, because the compiler then knows if the device
or architecture has an 8-bit stack pointer and thus no C<SPH>
register or not.


=item B<-mstrict-X>

Use address register C<X> in a way proposed by the hardware.  This means
that C<X> is only used in indirect, post-increment or
pre-decrement addressing.

Without this option, the C<X> register may be used in the same way
as C<Y> or C<Z> which then is emulated by additional
instructions.  
For example, loading a value with C<X+const> addressing with a
small non-negative C<const E<lt> 64> to a register I<Rn> is
performed as

	
	adiw r26, const   ; X += const
	ld   <Rn>, X        ; <Rn> = *X
	sbiw r26, const   ; X -= const



=item B<-mtiny-stack>

Only change the lower 8@tie{}bits of the stack pointer.


=item B<-mfract-convert-truncate>

Allow to use truncation instead of rounding towards zero for fractional fixed-point types.


=item B<-nodevicelib>

Don't link against AVR-LibC's device specific library C<libE<lt>mcuE<gt>.a>.


=item B<-Waddr-space-convert>

Warn about conversions between address spaces in the case where the
resulting address space is not contained in the incoming address space.


=item B<-Wmisspelled-isr>

Warn if the ISR is misspelled, i.e. without __vector prefix.
Enabled by default.

=back



=head4 C<EIND> and Devices with More Than 128 Ki Bytes of Flash

Pointers in the implementation are 16@tie{}bits wide.
The address of a function or label is represented as word address so
that indirect jumps and calls can target any code address in the
range of 64@tie{}Ki words.

In order to facilitate indirect jump on devices with more than 128@tie{}Ki
bytes of program memory space, there is a special function register called
C<EIND> that serves as most significant part of the target address
when C<EICALL> or C<EIJMP> instructions are used.

Indirect jumps and calls on these devices are handled as follows by
the compiler and are subject to some limitations:


=over 4



=item Z<>*

The compiler never sets C<EIND>.


=item Z<>*

The compiler uses C<EIND> implicitly in C<EICALL>/C<EIJMP>
instructions or might read C<EIND> directly in order to emulate an
indirect call/jump by means of a C<RET> instruction.


=item Z<>*

The compiler assumes that C<EIND> never changes during the startup
code or during the application. In particular, C<EIND> is not
saved/restored in function or interrupt service routine
prologue/epilogue.


=item Z<>*

For indirect calls to functions and computed goto, the linker
generates I<stubs>. Stubs are jump pads sometimes also called
I<trampolines>. Thus, the indirect call/jump jumps to such a stub.
The stub contains a direct jump to the desired address.


=item Z<>*

Linker relaxation must be turned on so that the linker generates
the stubs correctly in all situations. See the compiler option
B<-mrelax> and the linker option B<--relax>.
There are corner cases where the linker is supposed to generate stubs
but aborts without relaxation and without a helpful error message.


=item Z<>*

The default linker script is arranged for code with C<EIND = 0>.
If code is supposed to work for a setup with C<EIND != 0>, a custom
linker script has to be used in order to place the sections whose
name start with C<.trampolines> into the segment where C<EIND>
points to.


=item Z<>*

The startup code from libgcc never sets C<EIND>.
Notice that startup code is a blend of code from libgcc and AVR-LibC.
For the impact of AVR-LibC on C<EIND>, see the
S<AVR-LibC user manual> (C<http://nongnu.org/avr-libc/user-manual/>).


=item Z<>*

It is legitimate for user-specific startup code to set up C<EIND>
early, for example by means of initialization code located in
section C<.init3>. Such code runs prior to general startup code
that initializes RAM and calls constructors, but after the bit
of startup code from AVR-LibC that sets C<EIND> to the segment
where the vector table is located.
	
	#include <avr/io.h>
	
	static void
	__attribute__((section(".init3"),naked,used,no_instrument_function))
	init3_set_eind (void)
	{
	  __asm volatile ("ldi r24,pm_hh8(__trampolines_start)\n\t"
	                  "out %i0,r24" :: "n" (&EIND) : "r24","memory");
	}


The C<__trampolines_start> symbol is defined in the linker script.


=item Z<>*

Stubs are generated automatically by the linker if
the following two conditions are met:

=over 4



=item -<The address of a label is taken by means of the C<gs> modifier>

(short for I<generate stubs>) like so:
	
	LDI r24, lo8(gs(<func>))
	LDI r25, hi8(gs(<func>))


=item -<The final location of that label is in a code segment>

I<outside> the segment where the stubs are located.

=back



=item Z<>*

The compiler emits such C<gs> modifiers for code labels in the
following situations:

=over 4


=item -<Taking address of a function or code label.>


=item -<Computed goto.>


=item -<If prologue-save function is used, see B<-mcall-prologues>>

command-line option.

=item -<Switch/case dispatch tables. If you do not want such dispatch>

tables you can specify the B<-fno-jump-tables> command-line option.

=item -<C and C++ constructors/destructors called during startup/shutdown.>


=item -<If the tools hit a C<gs()> modifier explained above.>


=back



=item Z<>*

Jumping to non-symbolic addresses like so is I<not> supported:

	
	int main (void)
	{
	    /* Call function at word address 0x2 */
	    return ((int(*)(void)) 0x2)();
	}


Instead, a stub has to be set up, i.e. the function has to be called
through a symbol (C<func_4> in the example):

	
	int main (void)
	{
	    extern int func_4 (void);
	
	    /* Call function at byte address 0x4 */
	    return func_4();
	}


and the application be linked with B<-Wl,--defsym,func_4=0x4>.
Alternatively, C<func_4> can be defined in the linker script.

=back



=head4 Handling of the C<RAMPD>, C<RAMPX>, C<RAMPY> and C<RAMPZ> Special Function Registers

Some AVR devices support memories larger than the 64@tie{}KiB range
that can be accessed with 16-bit pointers.  To access memory locations
outside this 64@tie{}KiB range, the content of a C<RAMP>
register is used as high part of the address:
The C<X>, C<Y>, C<Z> address register is concatenated
with the C<RAMPX>, C<RAMPY>, C<RAMPZ> special function
register, respectively, to get a wide address. Similarly,
C<RAMPD> is used together with direct addressing.


=over 4


=item Z<>*

The startup code initializes the C<RAMP> special function
registers with zero.


=item Z<>*

If a B<AVR Named Address Spaces,named address space> other than
generic or C<__flash> is used, then C<RAMPZ> is set
as needed before the operation.


=item Z<>*

If the device supports RAM larger than 64@tie{}KiB and the compiler
needs to change C<RAMPZ> to accomplish an operation, C<RAMPZ>
is reset to zero after the operation.


=item Z<>*

If the device comes with a specific C<RAMP> register, the ISR
prologue/epilogue saves/restores that SFR and initializes it with
zero in case the ISR code might (implicitly) use it.


=item Z<>*

RAM larger than 64@tie{}KiB is not supported by GCC for AVR targets.
If you use inline assembler to read from locations outside the
16-bit address range and change one of the C<RAMP> registers,
you must reset it to zero after the access.


=back



=head4 AVR Built-in Macros


GCC defines several built-in macros so that the user code can test
for the presence or absence of features.  Almost any of the following
built-in macros are deduced from device capabilities and thus
triggered by the B<-mmcu=> command-line option.

For even more AVR-specific built-in macros see
B<AVR Named Address Spaces> and B<AVR Built-in Functions>.


=over 4



=item C<__AVR_ARCH__>

Build-in macro that resolves to a decimal number that identifies the
architecture and depends on the B<-mmcu=>I<mcu> option.
Possible values are:

C<2>, C<25>, C<3>, C<31>, C<35>,
C<4>, C<5>, C<51>, C<6>

for I<mcu>=C<avr2>, C<avr25>, C<avr3>, C<avr31>,
C<avr35>, C<avr4>, C<avr5>, C<avr51>, C<avr6>,

respectively and

C<100>,
C<102>, C<103>, C<104>,
C<105>, C<106>, C<107>

for I<mcu>=C<avrtiny>,
C<avrxmega2>, C<avrxmega3>, C<avrxmega4>,
C<avrxmega5>, C<avrxmega6>, C<avrxmega7>, respectively.
If I<mcu> specifies a device, this built-in macro is set
accordingly. For example, with B<-mmcu=atmega8> the macro is
defined to C<4>.


=item C<__AVR_I<Device>__>

Setting B<-mmcu=>I<device> defines this built-in macro which reflects
the device's name. For example, B<-mmcu=atmega8> defines the
built-in macro C<__AVR_ATmega8__>, B<-mmcu=attiny261a> defines
C<__AVR_ATtiny261A__>, etc.

The built-in macros' names follow
the scheme C<__AVR_I<Device>__> where I<Device> is
the device name as from the AVR user manual. The difference between
I<Device> in the built-in macro and I<device> in
B<-mmcu=>I<device> is that the latter is always lowercase.

If I<device> is not a device but only a core architecture like
B<avr51>, this macro is not defined.


=item C<__AVR_DEVICE_NAME__>

Setting B<-mmcu=>I<device> defines this built-in macro to
the device's name. For example, with B<-mmcu=atmega8> the macro
is defined to C<atmega8>.

If I<device> is not a device but only a core architecture like
B<avr51>, this macro is not defined.


=item C<__AVR_XMEGA__>

The device / architecture belongs to the XMEGA family of devices.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_ELPM__>

The device has the C<ELPM> instruction.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_ELPMX__>

The device has the C<ELPM RI<n>,Z> and C<ELPM
RI<n>,Z+> instructions.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_MOVW__>

The device has the C<MOVW> instruction to perform 16-bit
register-register moves.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_LPMX__>

The device has the C<LPM RI<n>,Z> and
C<LPM RI<n>,Z+> instructions.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_MUL__>

The device has a hardware multiplier. 


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_JMP_CALL__>

The device has the C<JMP> and C<CALL> instructions.
This is the case for devices with more than 8@tie{}KiB of program
memory.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_EIJMP_EICALL__>


=item C<__AVR_3_BYTE_PC__>

The device has the C<EIJMP> and C<EICALL> instructions.
This is the case for devices with more than 128@tie{}KiB of program memory.
This also means that the program counter
(PC) is 3@tie{}bytes wide.


=item C<__AVR_2_BYTE_PC__>

The program counter (PC) is 2@tie{}bytes wide. This is the case for devices
with up to 128@tie{}KiB of program memory.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_8BIT_SP__>


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_16BIT_SP__>

The stack pointer (SP) register is treated as 8-bit respectively
16-bit register by the compiler.
The definition of these macros is affected by B<-mtiny-stack>.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_SPH__>


=item C<__AVR_SP8__>

The device has the SPH (high part of stack pointer) special function
register or has an 8-bit stack pointer, respectively.
The definition of these macros is affected by B<-mmcu=> and
in the cases of B<-mmcu=avr2> and B<-mmcu=avr25> also
by B<-msp8>.


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_RAMPD__>


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_RAMPX__>


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_RAMPY__>


=item C<__AVR_HAVE_RAMPZ__>

The device has the C<RAMPD>, C<RAMPX>, C<RAMPY>,
C<RAMPZ> special function register, respectively.


=item C<__NO_INTERRUPTS__>

This macro reflects the B<-mno-interrupts> command-line option.


=item C<__AVR_ERRATA_SKIP__>


=item C<__AVR_ERRATA_SKIP_JMP_CALL__>

Some AVR devices (AT90S8515, ATmega103) must not skip 32-bit
instructions because of a hardware erratum.  Skip instructions are
C<SBRS>, C<SBRC>, C<SBIS>, C<SBIC> and C<CPSE>.
The second macro is only defined if C<__AVR_HAVE_JMP_CALL__> is also
set.


=item C<__AVR_ISA_RMW__>

The device has Read-Modify-Write instructions (XCH, LAC, LAS and LAT).


=item C<__AVR_SFR_OFFSET__=I<offset>>

Instructions that can address I/O special function registers directly
like C<IN>, C<OUT>, C<SBI>, etc. may use a different
address as if addressed by an instruction to access RAM like C<LD>
or C<STS>. This offset depends on the device architecture and has
to be subtracted from the RAM address in order to get the
respective I/O@tie{}address.


=item C<__AVR_SHORT_CALLS__>

The B<-mshort-calls> command line option is set.


=item C<__AVR_PM_BASE_ADDRESS__=I<addr>>

Some devices support reading from flash memory by means of C<LD*>
instructions.  The flash memory is seen in the data address space
at an offset of C<__AVR_PM_BASE_ADDRESS__>.  If this macro
is not defined, this feature is not available.  If defined,
the address space is linear and there is no need to put
C<.rodata> into RAM.  This is handled by the default linker
description file, and is currently available for
C<avrtiny> and C<avrxmega3>.  Even more convenient,
there is no need to use address spaces like C<__flash> or
features like attribute C<progmem> and C<pgm_read_*>.


=item C<__WITH_AVRLIBC__>

The compiler is configured to be used together with AVR-Libc.
See the B<--with-avrlibc> configure option.


=back



=head3 Blackfin Options



=over 4


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu>[B<->I<sirevision>]

Specifies the name of the target Blackfin processor.  Currently, I<cpu>
can be one of B<bf512>, B<bf514>, B<bf516>, B<bf518>,
B<bf522>, B<bf523>, B<bf524>, B<bf525>, B<bf526>,
B<bf527>, B<bf531>, B<bf532>, B<bf533>,
B<bf534>, B<bf536>, B<bf537>, B<bf538>, B<bf539>,
B<bf542>, B<bf544>, B<bf547>, B<bf548>, B<bf549>,
B<bf542m>, B<bf544m>, B<bf547m>, B<bf548m>, B<bf549m>,
B<bf561>, B<bf592>.

The optional I<sirevision> specifies the silicon revision of the target
Blackfin processor.  Any workarounds available for the targeted silicon revision
are enabled.  If I<sirevision> is B<none>, no workarounds are enabled.
If I<sirevision> is B<any>, all workarounds for the targeted processor
are enabled.  The C<__SILICON_REVISION__> macro is defined to two
hexadecimal digits representing the major and minor numbers in the silicon
revision.  If I<sirevision> is B<none>, the C<__SILICON_REVISION__>
is not defined.  If I<sirevision> is B<any>, the
C<__SILICON_REVISION__> is defined to be C<0xffff>.
If this optional I<sirevision> is not used, GCC assumes the latest known
silicon revision of the targeted Blackfin processor.

GCC defines a preprocessor macro for the specified I<cpu>.
For the B<bfin-elf> toolchain, this option causes the hardware BSP
provided by libgloss to be linked in if B<-msim> is not given.

Without this option, B<bf532> is used as the processor by default.

Note that support for B<bf561> is incomplete.  For B<bf561>,
only the preprocessor macro is defined.


=item B<-msim>

Specifies that the program will be run on the simulator.  This causes
the simulator BSP provided by libgloss to be linked in.  This option
has effect only for B<bfin-elf> toolchain.
Certain other options, such as B<-mid-shared-library> and
B<-mfdpic>, imply B<-msim>.


=item B<-momit-leaf-frame-pointer>

Don't keep the frame pointer in a register for leaf functions.  This
avoids the instructions to save, set up and restore frame pointers and
makes an extra register available in leaf functions.


=item B<-mspecld-anomaly>

When enabled, the compiler ensures that the generated code does not
contain speculative loads after jump instructions. If this option is used,
C<__WORKAROUND_SPECULATIVE_LOADS> is defined.


=item B<-mno-specld-anomaly>

Don't generate extra code to prevent speculative loads from occurring.


=item B<-mcsync-anomaly>

When enabled, the compiler ensures that the generated code does not
contain CSYNC or SSYNC instructions too soon after conditional branches.
If this option is used, C<__WORKAROUND_SPECULATIVE_SYNCS> is defined.


=item B<-mno-csync-anomaly>

Don't generate extra code to prevent CSYNC or SSYNC instructions from
occurring too soon after a conditional branch.


=item B<-mlow64k>

When enabled, the compiler is free to take advantage of the knowledge that
the entire program fits into the low 64k of memory.


=item B<-mno-low64k>

Assume that the program is arbitrarily large.  This is the default.


=item B<-mstack-check-l1>

Do stack checking using information placed into L1 scratchpad memory by the
uClinux kernel.


=item B<-mid-shared-library>

Generate code that supports shared libraries via the library ID method.
This allows for execute in place and shared libraries in an environment
without virtual memory management.  This option implies B<-fPIC>.
With a B<bfin-elf> target, this option implies B<-msim>.


=item B<-mno-id-shared-library>

Generate code that doesn't assume ID-based shared libraries are being used.
This is the default.


=item B<-mleaf-id-shared-library>

Generate code that supports shared libraries via the library ID method,
but assumes that this library or executable won't link against any other
ID shared libraries.  That allows the compiler to use faster code for jumps
and calls.


=item B<-mno-leaf-id-shared-library>

Do not assume that the code being compiled won't link against any ID shared
libraries.  Slower code is generated for jump and call insns.


=item B<-mshared-library-id=n>

Specifies the identification number of the ID-based shared library being
compiled.  Specifying a value of 0 generates more compact code; specifying
other values forces the allocation of that number to the current
library but is no more space- or time-efficient than omitting this option.


=item B<-msep-data>

Generate code that allows the data segment to be located in a different
area of memory from the text segment.  This allows for execute in place in
an environment without virtual memory management by eliminating relocations
against the text section.


=item B<-mno-sep-data>

Generate code that assumes that the data segment follows the text segment.
This is the default.


=item B<-mlong-calls>


=item B<-mno-long-calls>

Tells the compiler to perform function calls by first loading the
address of the function into a register and then performing a subroutine
call on this register.  This switch is needed if the target function
lies outside of the 24-bit addressing range of the offset-based
version of subroutine call instruction.

This feature is not enabled by default.  Specifying
B<-mno-long-calls> restores the default behavior.  Note these
switches have no effect on how the compiler generates code to handle
function calls via function pointers.


=item B<-mfast-fp>

Link with the fast floating-point library. This library relaxes some of
the IEEE floating-point standard's rules for checking inputs against
Not-a-Number (NAN), in the interest of performance.


=item B<-minline-plt>

Enable inlining of PLT entries in function calls to functions that are
not known to bind locally.  It has no effect without B<-mfdpic>.


=item B<-mmulticore>

Build a standalone application for multicore Blackfin processors. 
This option causes proper start files and link scripts supporting 
multicore to be used, and defines the macro C<__BFIN_MULTICORE>. 
It can only be used with B<-mcpu=bf561>[B<->I<sirevision>]. 

This option can be used with B<-mcorea> or B<-mcoreb>, which
selects the one-application-per-core programming model.  Without
B<-mcorea> or B<-mcoreb>, the single-application/dual-core
programming model is used. In this model, the main function of Core B
should be named as C<coreb_main>.

If this option is not used, the single-core application programming
model is used.


=item B<-mcorea>

Build a standalone application for Core A of BF561 when using
the one-application-per-core programming model. Proper start files
and link scripts are used to support Core A, and the macro
C<__BFIN_COREA> is defined.
This option can only be used in conjunction with B<-mmulticore>.


=item B<-mcoreb>

Build a standalone application for Core B of BF561 when using
the one-application-per-core programming model. Proper start files
and link scripts are used to support Core B, and the macro
C<__BFIN_COREB> is defined. When this option is used, C<coreb_main>
should be used instead of C<main>. 
This option can only be used in conjunction with B<-mmulticore>.


=item B<-msdram>

Build a standalone application for SDRAM. Proper start files and
link scripts are used to put the application into SDRAM, and the macro
C<__BFIN_SDRAM> is defined.
The loader should initialize SDRAM before loading the application.


=item B<-micplb>

Assume that ICPLBs are enabled at run time.  This has an effect on certain
anomaly workarounds.  For Linux targets, the default is to assume ICPLBs
are enabled; for standalone applications the default is off.

=back



=head3 C6X Options



=over 4


=item B<-march=>I<name>

This specifies the name of the target architecture.  GCC uses this
name to determine what kind of instructions it can emit when generating
assembly code.  Permissible names are: B<c62x>,
B<c64x>, B<c64x+>, B<c67x>, B<c67x+>, B<c674x>.


=item B<-mbig-endian>

Generate code for a big-endian target.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

Generate code for a little-endian target.  This is the default.


=item B<-msim>

Choose startup files and linker script suitable for the simulator.


=item B<-msdata=default>

Put small global and static data in the C<.neardata> section,
which is pointed to by register C<B14>.  Put small uninitialized
global and static data in the C<.bss> section, which is adjacent
to the C<.neardata> section.  Put small read-only data into the
C<.rodata> section.  The corresponding sections used for large
pieces of data are C<.fardata>, C<.far> and C<.const>.


=item B<-msdata=all>

Put all data, not just small objects, into the sections reserved for
small data, and use addressing relative to the C<B14> register to
access them.


=item B<-msdata=none>

Make no use of the sections reserved for small data, and use absolute
addresses to access all data.  Put all initialized global and static
data in the C<.fardata> section, and all uninitialized data in the
C<.far> section.  Put all constant data into the C<.const>
section.

=back



=head3 CRIS Options


These options are defined specifically for the CRIS ports.


=over 4


=item B<-march=>I<architecture-type>


=item B<-mcpu=>I<architecture-type>

Generate code for the specified architecture.  The choices for
I<architecture-type> are B<v3>, B<v8> and B<v10> for
respectively ETRAXS< >4, ETRAXS< >100, and ETRAXS< >100S< >LX.
Default is B<v0> except for cris-axis-linux-gnu, where the default is
B<v10>.


=item B<-mtune=>I<architecture-type>

Tune to I<architecture-type> everything applicable about the generated
code, except for the ABI and the set of available instructions.  The
choices for I<architecture-type> are the same as for
B<-march=>I<architecture-type>.


=item B<-mmax-stack-frame=>I<n>

Warn when the stack frame of a function exceeds I<n> bytes.


=item B<-metrax4>


=item B<-metrax100>

The options B<-metrax4> and B<-metrax100> are synonyms for
B<-march=v3> and B<-march=v8> respectively.


=item B<-mmul-bug-workaround>


=item B<-mno-mul-bug-workaround>

Work around a bug in the C<muls> and C<mulu> instructions for CPU
models where it applies.  This option is active by default.


=item B<-mpdebug>

Enable CRIS-specific verbose debug-related information in the assembly
code.  This option also has the effect of turning off the B<#NO_APP>
formatted-code indicator to the assembler at the beginning of the
assembly file.


=item B<-mcc-init>

Do not use condition-code results from previous instruction; always emit
compare and test instructions before use of condition codes.


=item B<-mno-side-effects>

Do not emit instructions with side effects in addressing modes other than
post-increment.


=item B<-mstack-align>


=item B<-mno-stack-align>


=item B<-mdata-align>


=item B<-mno-data-align>


=item B<-mconst-align>


=item B<-mno-const-align>

These options (B<no-> options) arrange (eliminate arrangements) for the
stack frame, individual data and constants to be aligned for the maximum
single data access size for the chosen CPU model.  The default is to
arrange for 32-bit alignment.  ABI details such as structure layout are
not affected by these options.


=item B<-m32-bit>


=item B<-m16-bit>


=item B<-m8-bit>

Similar to the stack- data- and const-align options above, these options
arrange for stack frame, writable data and constants to all be 32-bit,
16-bit or 8-bit aligned.  The default is 32-bit alignment.


=item B<-mno-prologue-epilogue>


=item B<-mprologue-epilogue>

With B<-mno-prologue-epilogue>, the normal function prologue and
epilogue which set up the stack frame are omitted and no return
instructions or return sequences are generated in the code.  Use this
option only together with visual inspection of the compiled code: no
warnings or errors are generated when call-saved registers must be saved,
or storage for local variables needs to be allocated.


=item B<-mno-gotplt>


=item B<-mgotplt>

With B<-fpic> and B<-fPIC>, don't generate (do generate)
instruction sequences that load addresses for functions from the PLT part
of the GOT rather than (traditional on other architectures) calls to the
PLT.  The default is B<-mgotplt>.


=item B<-melf>

Legacy no-op option only recognized with the cris-axis-elf and
cris-axis-linux-gnu targets.


=item B<-mlinux>

Legacy no-op option only recognized with the cris-axis-linux-gnu target.


=item B<-sim>

This option, recognized for the cris-axis-elf, arranges
to link with input-output functions from a simulator library.  Code,
initialized data and zero-initialized data are allocated consecutively.


=item B<-sim2>

Like B<-sim>, but pass linker options to locate initialized data at
0x40000000 and zero-initialized data at 0x80000000.

=back



=head3 CR16 Options


These options are defined specifically for the CR16 ports.


=over 4



=item B<-mmac>

Enable the use of multiply-accumulate instructions. Disabled by default.


=item B<-mcr16cplus>


=item B<-mcr16c>

Generate code for CR16C or CR16C+ architecture. CR16C+ architecture 
is default.


=item B<-msim>

Links the library libsim.a which is in compatible with simulator. Applicable
to ELF compiler only.


=item B<-mint32>

Choose integer type as 32-bit wide.


=item B<-mbit-ops>

Generates C<sbit>/C<cbit> instructions for bit manipulations.


=item B<-mdata-model=>I<model>

Choose a data model. The choices for I<model> are B<near>,
B<far> or B<medium>. B<medium> is default.
However, B<far> is not valid with B<-mcr16c>, as the
CR16C architecture does not support the far data model.

=back



=head3 C-SKY Options


GCC supports these options when compiling for C-SKY V2 processors.


=over 4



=item B<-march=>I<arch>

Specify the C-SKY target architecture.  Valid values for I<arch> are:
B<ck801>, B<ck802>, B<ck803>, B<ck807>, and B<ck810>.
The default is B<ck810>.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu>

Specify the C-SKY target processor.  Valid values for I<cpu> are:
B<ck801>, B<ck801t>,
B<ck802>, B<ck802t>, B<ck802j>,
B<ck803>, B<ck803h>, B<ck803t>, B<ck803ht>,
B<ck803f>, B<ck803fh>, B<ck803e>, B<ck803eh>,
B<ck803et>, B<ck803eht>, B<ck803ef>, B<ck803efh>,
B<ck803ft>, B<ck803eft>, B<ck803efht>, B<ck803r1>,
B<ck803hr1>, B<ck803tr1>, B<ck803htr1>, B<ck803fr1>,
B<ck803fhr1>, B<ck803er1>, B<ck803ehr1>, B<ck803etr1>,
B<ck803ehtr1>, B<ck803efr1>, B<ck803efhr1>, B<ck803ftr1>,
B<ck803eftr1>, B<ck803efhtr1>,
B<ck803s>, B<ck803st>, B<ck803se>, B<ck803sf>,
B<ck803sef>, B<ck803seft>,
B<ck807e>, B<ck807ef>, B<ck807>, B<ck807f>,
B<ck810e>, B<ck810et>, B<ck810ef>, B<ck810eft>,
B<ck810>, B<ck810v>, B<ck810f>, B<ck810t>, B<ck810fv>,
B<ck810tv>, B<ck810ft>, and B<ck810ftv>.


=item B<-mbig-endian>


=item B<-EB>


=item B<-mlittle-endian>


=item B<-EL>


Select big- or little-endian code.  The default is little-endian.


=item B<-mhard-float>


=item B<-msoft-float>


Select hardware or software floating-point implementations.
The default is soft float.


=item B<-mdouble-float>


=item B<-mno-double-float>

When B<-mhard-float> is in effect, enable generation of
double-precision float instructions.  This is the default except
when compiling for CK803.


=item B<-mfdivdu>


=item B<-mno-fdivdu>

When B<-mhard-float> is in effect, enable generation of
C<frecipd>, C<fsqrtd>, and C<fdivd> instructions.
This is the default except when compiling for CK803.


=item B<-mfpu=>I<fpu>

Select the floating-point processor.  This option can only be used with
B<-mhard-float>.
Values for I<fpu> are
B<fpv2_sf> (equivalent to B<-mno-double-float -mno-fdivdu>),
B<fpv2> (B<-mdouble-float -mno-divdu>), and
B<fpv2_divd> (B<-mdouble-float -mdivdu>).


=item B<-melrw>


=item B<-mno-elrw>

Enable the extended C<lrw> instruction.  This option defaults to on
for CK801 and off otherwise.


=item B<-mistack>


=item B<-mno-istack>

Enable interrupt stack instructions; the default is off.

The B<-mistack> option is required to handle the
C<interrupt> and C<isr> function attributes.


=item B<-mmp>

Enable multiprocessor instructions; the default is off.


=item B<-mcp>

Enable coprocessor instructions; the default is off.


=item B<-mcache>

Enable coprocessor instructions; the default is off.


=item B<-msecurity>

Enable C-SKY security instructions; the default is off.


=item B<-mtrust>

Enable C-SKY trust instructions; the default is off.


=item B<-mdsp>


=item B<-medsp>


=item B<-mvdsp>

Enable C-SKY DSP, Enhanced DSP, or Vector DSP instructions, respectively.
All of these options default to off.


=item B<-mdiv>


=item B<-mno-div>

Generate divide instructions.  Default is off.


=item B<-msmart>


=item B<-mno-smart>

Generate code for Smart Mode, using only registers numbered 0-7 to allow
use of 16-bit instructions.  This option is ignored for CK801 where this
is the required behavior, and it defaults to on for CK802.
For other targets, the default is off.


=item B<-mhigh-registers>


=item B<-mno-high-registers>

Generate code using the high registers numbered 16-31.  This option
is not supported on CK801, CK802, or CK803, and is enabled by default
for other processors.


=item B<-manchor>


=item B<-mno-anchor>

Generate code using global anchor symbol addresses.


=item B<-mpushpop>


=item B<-mno-pushpop>

Generate code using C<push> and C<pop> instructions.  This option
defaults to on.


=item B<-mmultiple-stld>


=item B<-mstm>


=item B<-mno-multiple-stld>


=item B<-mno-stm>

Generate code using C<stm> and C<ldm> instructions.  This option
isn't supported on CK801 but is enabled by default on other processors.


=item B<-mconstpool>


=item B<-mno-constpool>

Create constant pools in the compiler instead of deferring it to the
assembler.  This option is the default and required for correct code
generation on CK801 and CK802, and is optional on other processors.


=item B<-mstack-size>


=item B<-mno-stack-size>

Emit C<.stack_size> directives for each function in the assembly
output.  This option defaults to off.


=item B<-mccrt>


=item B<-mno-ccrt>

Generate code for the C-SKY compiler runtime instead of libgcc.  This
option defaults to off.


=item B<-mbranch-cost=>I<n>

Set the branch costs to roughly C<n> instructions.  The default is 1.


=item B<-msched-prolog>


=item B<-mno-sched-prolog>

Permit scheduling of function prologue and epilogue sequences.  Using
this option can result in code that is not compliant with the C-SKY V2 ABI
prologue requirements and that cannot be debugged or backtraced.
It is disabled by default.


=back



=head3 Darwin Options


These options are defined for all architectures running the Darwin operating
system.

FSF GCC on Darwin does not create "fat" object files; it creates
an object file for the single architecture that GCC was built to
target.  Apple's GCC on Darwin does create "fat" files if multiple
B<-arch> options are used; it does so by running the compiler or
linker multiple times and joining the results together with
F<lipo>.

The subtype of the file created (like B<ppc7400> or B<ppc970> or
B<i686>) is determined by the flags that specify the ISA
that GCC is targeting, like B<-mcpu> or B<-march>.  The
B<-force_cpusubtype_ALL> option can be used to override this.

The Darwin tools vary in their behavior when presented with an ISA
mismatch.  The assembler, F<as>, only permits instructions to
be used that are valid for the subtype of the file it is generating,
so you cannot put 64-bit instructions in a B<ppc750> object file.
The linker for shared libraries, F</usr/bin/libtool>, fails
and prints an error if asked to create a shared library with a less
restrictive subtype than its input files (for instance, trying to put
a B<ppc970> object file in a B<ppc7400> library).  The linker
for executables, B<ld>, quietly gives the executable the most
restrictive subtype of any of its input files.


=over 4


=item B<-F>I<dir>

Add the framework directory I<dir> to the head of the list of
directories to be searched for header files.  These directories are
interleaved with those specified by B<-I> options and are
scanned in a left-to-right order.

A framework directory is a directory with frameworks in it.  A
framework is a directory with a F<Headers> and/or
F<PrivateHeaders> directory contained directly in it that ends
in F<.framework>.  The name of a framework is the name of this
directory excluding the F<.framework>.  Headers associated with
the framework are found in one of those two directories, with
F<Headers> being searched first.  A subframework is a framework
directory that is in a framework's F<Frameworks> directory.
Includes of subframework headers can only appear in a header of a
framework that contains the subframework, or in a sibling subframework
header.  Two subframeworks are siblings if they occur in the same
framework.  A subframework should not have the same name as a
framework; a warning is issued if this is violated.  Currently a
subframework cannot have subframeworks; in the future, the mechanism
may be extended to support this.  The standard frameworks can be found
in F</System/Library/Frameworks> and
F</Library/Frameworks>.  An example include looks like
C<#include E<lt>Framework/header.hE<gt>>, where F<Framework> denotes
the name of the framework and F<header.h> is found in the
F<PrivateHeaders> or F<Headers> directory.


=item B<-iframework>I<dir>

Like B<-F> except the directory is a treated as a system
directory.  The main difference between this B<-iframework> and
B<-F> is that with B<-iframework> the compiler does not
warn about constructs contained within header files found via
I<dir>.  This option is valid only for the C family of languages.


=item B<-gused>

Emit debugging information for symbols that are used.  For stabs
debugging format, this enables B<-feliminate-unused-debug-symbols>.
This is by default ON.


=item B<-gfull>

Emit debugging information for all symbols and types.


=item B<-mmacosx-version-min=>I<version>

The earliest version of MacOS X that this executable will run on
is I<version>.  Typical values of I<version> include C<10.1>,
C<10.2>, and C<10.3.9>.

If the compiler was built to use the system's headers by default,
then the default for this option is the system version on which the
compiler is running, otherwise the default is to make choices that
are compatible with as many systems and code bases as possible.


=item B<-mkernel>

Enable kernel development mode.  The B<-mkernel> option sets
B<-static>, B<-fno-common>, B<-fno-use-cxa-atexit>,
B<-fno-exceptions>, B<-fno-non-call-exceptions>,
B<-fapple-kext>, B<-fno-weak> and B<-fno-rtti> where
applicable.  This mode also sets B<-mno-altivec>,
B<-msoft-float>, B<-fno-builtin> and
B<-mlong-branch> for PowerPC targets.


=item B<-mone-byte-bool>

Override the defaults for C<bool> so that C<sizeof(bool)==1>.
By default C<sizeof(bool)> is C<4> when compiling for
Darwin/PowerPC and C<1> when compiling for Darwin/x86, so this
option has no effect on x86.

B<Warning:> The B<-mone-byte-bool> switch causes GCC
to generate code that is not binary compatible with code generated
without that switch.  Using this switch may require recompiling all
other modules in a program, including system libraries.  Use this
switch to conform to a non-default data model.


=item B<-mfix-and-continue>


=item B<-ffix-and-continue>


=item B<-findirect-data>

Generate code suitable for fast turnaround development, such as to
allow GDB to dynamically load F<.o> files into already-running
programs.  B<-findirect-data> and B<-ffix-and-continue>
are provided for backwards compatibility.


=item B<-all_load>

Loads all members of static archive libraries.
See man ld(1) for more information.


=item B<-arch_errors_fatal>

Cause the errors having to do with files that have the wrong architecture
to be fatal.


=item B<-bind_at_load>

Causes the output file to be marked such that the dynamic linker will
bind all undefined references when the file is loaded or launched.


=item B<-bundle>

Produce a Mach-o bundle format file.
See man ld(1) for more information.


=item B<-bundle_loader> I<executable>

This option specifies the I<executable> that will load the build
output file being linked.  See man ld(1) for more information.


=item B<-dynamiclib>

When passed this option, GCC produces a dynamic library instead of
an executable when linking, using the Darwin F<libtool> command.


=item B<-force_cpusubtype_ALL>

This causes GCC's output file to have the B<ALL> subtype, instead of
one controlled by the B<-mcpu> or B<-march> option.


=item B<-allowable_client>  I<client_name>


=item B<-client_name>

=item B<-current_version>

=item B<-dependency-file>

=item B<-segs_read_only_addr>


=item B<-segs_read_write_addr>

=head3 DEC Alpha Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the DEC Alpha implementations:


=over 4


=item B<-mno-soft-float>


=item B<-msoft-float>

Use (do not use) the hardware floating-point instructions for
floating-point operations.  When B<-msoft-float> is specified,
functions in F<libgcc.a> are used to perform floating-point
operations.  Unless they are replaced by routines that emulate the
floating-point operations, or compiled in such a way as to call such
emulations routines, these routines issue floating-point
operations.   If you are compiling for an Alpha without floating-point
operations, you must ensure that the library is built so as not to call
them.

Note that Alpha implementations without floating-point operations are
required to have floating-point registers.


=item B<-mfp-reg>


=item B<-mno-fp-regs>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the floating-point register set.
B<-mno-fp-regs> implies B<-msoft-float>.  If the floating-point
register set is not used, floating-point operands are passed in integer
registers as if they were integers and floating-point results are passed
in C<$0> instead of C<$f0>.  This is a non-standard calling sequence,
so any function with a floating-point argument or return value called by code
compiled with B<-mno-fp-regs> must also be compiled with that
option.

A typical use of this option is building a kernel that does not use,
and hence need not save and restore, any floating-point registers.


=item B<-mieee>

The Alpha architecture implements floating-point hardware optimized for
maximum performance.  It is mostly compliant with the IEEE floating-point
standard.  However, for full compliance, software assistance is
required.  This option generates code fully IEEE-compliant code
I<except> that the I<inexact-flag> is not maintained (see below).
If this option is turned on, the preprocessor macro C<_IEEE_FP> is
defined during compilation.  The resulting code is less efficient but is
able to correctly support denormalized numbers and exceptional IEEE
values such as not-a-number and plus/minus infinity.  Other Alpha
compilers call this option B<-ieee_with_no_inexact>.


=item B<-mieee-with-inexact>

This is like B<-mieee> except the generated code also maintains
the IEEE I<inexact-flag>.  Turning on this option causes the
generated code to implement fully-compliant IEEE math.  In addition to
C<_IEEE_FP>, C<_IEEE_FP_EXACT> is defined as a preprocessor
macro.  On some Alpha implementations the resulting code may execute
significantly slower than the code generated by default.  Since there is
very little code that depends on the I<inexact-flag>, you should
normally not specify this option.  Other Alpha compilers call this
option B<-ieee_with_inexact>.


=item B<-mfp-trap-mode=>I<trap-mode>

This option controls what floating-point related traps are enabled.
Other Alpha compilers call this option B<-fptm> I<trap-mode>.
The trap mode can be set to one of four values:


=over 4


=item B<n>

This is the default (normal) setting.  The only traps that are enabled
are the ones that cannot be disabled in software (e.g., division by zero
trap).


=item B<u>

In addition to the traps enabled by B<n>, underflow traps are enabled
as well.


=item B<su>

Like B<u>, but the instructions are marked to be safe for software
completion (see Alpha architecture manual for details).


=item B<sui>

Like B<su>, but inexact traps are enabled as well.

=back



=item B<-mfp-rounding-mode=>I<rounding-mode>

Selects the IEEE rounding mode.  Other Alpha compilers call this option
B<-fprm> I<rounding-mode>.  The I<rounding-mode> can be one
of:


=over 4


=item B<n>

Normal IEEE rounding mode.  Floating-point numbers are rounded towards
the nearest machine number or towards the even machine number in case
of a tie.


=item B<m>

Round towards minus infinity.


=item B<c>

Chopped rounding mode.  Floating-point numbers are rounded towards zero.


=item B<d>

Dynamic rounding mode.  A field in the floating-point control register
(I<fpcr>, see Alpha architecture reference manual) controls the
rounding mode in effect.  The C library initializes this register for
rounding towards plus infinity.  Thus, unless your program modifies the
I<fpcr>, B<d> corresponds to round towards plus infinity.

=back



=item B<-mtrap-precision=>I<trap-precision>

In the Alpha architecture, floating-point traps are imprecise.  This
means without software assistance it is impossible to recover from a
floating trap and program execution normally needs to be terminated.
GCC can generate code that can assist operating system trap handlers
in determining the exact location that caused a floating-point trap.
Depending on the requirements of an application, different levels of
precisions can be selected:


=over 4


=item B<p>

Program precision.  This option is the default and means a trap handler
can only identify which program caused a floating-point exception.


=item B<f>

Function precision.  The trap handler can determine the function that
caused a floating-point exception.


=item B<i>

Instruction precision.  The trap handler can determine the exact
instruction that caused a floating-point exception.

=back


Other Alpha compilers provide the equivalent options called
B<-scope_safe> and B<-resumption_safe>.


=item B<-mieee-conformant>

This option marks the generated code as IEEE conformant.  You must not
use this option unless you also specify B<-mtrap-precision=i> and either
B<-mfp-trap-mode=su> or B<-mfp-trap-mode=sui>.  Its only effect
is to emit the line B<.eflag 48> in the function prologue of the
generated assembly file.


=item B<-mbuild-constants>

Normally GCC examines a 32- or 64-bit integer constant to
see if it can construct it from smaller constants in two or three
instructions.  If it cannot, it outputs the constant as a literal and
generates code to load it from the data segment at run time.

Use this option to require GCC to construct I<all> integer constants
using code, even if it takes more instructions (the maximum is six).

You typically use this option to build a shared library dynamic
loader.  Itself a shared library, it must relocate itself in memory
before it can find the variables and constants in its own data segment.


=item B<-mbwx>


=item B<-mno-bwx>


=item B<-mcix>


=item B<-mno-cix>


=item B<-mfix>


=item B<-mno-fix>


=item B<-mmax>


=item B<-mno-max>

Indicate whether GCC should generate code to use the optional BWX,
CIX, FIX and MAX instruction sets.  The default is to use the instruction
sets supported by the CPU type specified via B<-mcpu=> option or that
of the CPU on which GCC was built if none is specified.


=item B<-mfloat-vax>


=item B<-mfloat-ieee>

Generate code that uses (does not use) VAX F and G floating-point
arithmetic instead of IEEE single and double precision.


=item B<-mexplicit-relocs>


=item B<-mno-explicit-relocs>

Older Alpha assemblers provided no way to generate symbol relocations
except via assembler macros.  Use of these macros does not allow
optimal instruction scheduling.  GNU binutils as of version 2.12
supports a new syntax that allows the compiler to explicitly mark
which relocations should apply to which instructions.  This option
is mostly useful for debugging, as GCC detects the capabilities of
the assembler when it is built and sets the default accordingly.


=item B<-msmall-data>


=item B<-mlarge-data>

When B<-mexplicit-relocs> is in effect, static data is
accessed via I<gp-relative> relocations.  When B<-msmall-data>
is used, objects 8 bytes long or smaller are placed in a I<small data area>
(the C<.sdata> and C<.sbss> sections) and are accessed via
16-bit relocations off of the C<$gp> register.  This limits the
size of the small data area to 64KB, but allows the variables to be
directly accessed via a single instruction.

The default is B<-mlarge-data>.  With this option the data area
is limited to just below 2GB.  Programs that require more than 2GB of
data must use C<malloc> or C<mmap> to allocate the data in the
heap instead of in the program's data segment.

When generating code for shared libraries, B<-fpic> implies
B<-msmall-data> and B<-fPIC> implies B<-mlarge-data>.


=item B<-msmall-text>


=item B<-mlarge-text>

When B<-msmall-text> is used, the compiler assumes that the
code of the entire program (or shared library) fits in 4MB, and is
thus reachable with a branch instruction.  When B<-msmall-data>
is used, the compiler can assume that all local symbols share the
same C<$gp> value, and thus reduce the number of instructions
required for a function call from 4 to 1.

The default is B<-mlarge-text>.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type>

Set the instruction set and instruction scheduling parameters for
machine type I<cpu_type>.  You can specify either the B<EV>
style name or the corresponding chip number.  GCC supports scheduling
parameters for the EV4, EV5 and EV6 family of processors and
chooses the default values for the instruction set from the processor
you specify.  If you do not specify a processor type, GCC defaults
to the processor on which the compiler was built.

Supported values for I<cpu_type> are


=over 4


=item B<ev4>


=item B<ev45>


=item B<21064>

Schedules as an EV4 and has no instruction set extensions.


=item B<ev5>


=item B<21164>

Schedules as an EV5 and has no instruction set extensions.


=item B<ev56>


=item B<21164a>

Schedules as an EV5 and supports the BWX extension.


=item B<pca56>


=item B<21164pc>


=item B<21164PC>

Schedules as an EV5 and supports the BWX and MAX extensions.


=item B<ev6>


=item B<21264>

Schedules as an EV6 and supports the BWX, FIX, and MAX extensions.


=item B<ev67>


=item B<21264a>

Schedules as an EV6 and supports the BWX, CIX, FIX, and MAX extensions.

=back


Native toolchains also support the value B<native>,
which selects the best architecture option for the host processor.
B<-mcpu=native> has no effect if GCC does not recognize
the processor.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu_type>

Set only the instruction scheduling parameters for machine type
I<cpu_type>.  The instruction set is not changed.

Native toolchains also support the value B<native>,
which selects the best architecture option for the host processor.
B<-mtune=native> has no effect if GCC does not recognize
the processor.


=item B<-mmemory-latency=>I<time>

Sets the latency the scheduler should assume for typical memory
references as seen by the application.  This number is highly
dependent on the memory access patterns used by the application
and the size of the external cache on the machine.

Valid options for I<time> are


=over 4


=item I<number>

A decimal number representing clock cycles.


=item B<L1>


=item B<L2>


=item B<L3>


=item B<main>

The compiler contains estimates of the number of clock cycles for
"typical" EV4 & EV5 hardware for the Level 1, 2 & 3 caches
(also called Dcache, Scache, and Bcache), as well as to main memory.
Note that L3 is only valid for EV5.


=back


=back



=head3 FR30 Options


These options are defined specifically for the FR30 port.


=over 4



=item B<-msmall-model>

Use the small address space model.  This can produce smaller code, but
it does assume that all symbolic values and addresses fit into a
20-bit range.


=item B<-mno-lsim>

Assume that runtime support has been provided and so there is no need
to include the simulator library (F<libsim.a>) on the linker
command line.


=back



=head3 FT32 Options


These options are defined specifically for the FT32 port.


=over 4



=item B<-msim>

Specifies that the program will be run on the simulator.  This causes
an alternate runtime startup and library to be linked.
You must not use this option when generating programs that will run on
real hardware; you must provide your own runtime library for whatever
I/O functions are needed.


=item B<-mlra>

Enable Local Register Allocation.  This is still experimental for FT32,
so by default the compiler uses standard reload.


=item B<-mnodiv>

Do not use div and mod instructions.


=item B<-mft32b>

Enable use of the extended instructions of the FT32B processor.


=item B<-mcompress>

Compress all code using the Ft32B code compression scheme.


=item B<-mnopm>

Do not generate code that reads program memory.


=back



=head3 FRV Options



=over 4


=item B<-mgpr-32>


Only use the first 32 general-purpose registers.


=item B<-mgpr-64>


Use all 64 general-purpose registers.


=item B<-mfpr-32>


Use only the first 32 floating-point registers.


=item B<-mfpr-64>


Use all 64 floating-point registers.


=item B<-mhard-float>


Use hardware instructions for floating-point operations.


=item B<-msoft-float>


Use library routines for floating-point operations.


=item B<-malloc-cc>


Dynamically allocate condition code registers.


=item B<-mfixed-cc>


Do not try to dynamically allocate condition code registers, only
use C<icc0> and C<fcc0>.


=item B<-mdword>


Change ABI to use double word insns.


=item B<-mno-dword>


Do not use double word instructions.


=item B<-mdouble>


Use floating-point double instructions.


=item B<-mno-double>


Do not use floating-point double instructions.


=item B<-mmedia>


Use media instructions.


=item B<-mno-media>


Do not use media instructions.


=item B<-mmuladd>


Use multiply and add/subtract instructions.


=item B<-mno-muladd>


Do not use multiply and add/subtract instructions.


=item B<-mfdpic>


Select the FDPIC ABI, which uses function descriptors to represent
pointers to functions.  Without any PIC/PIE-related options, it
implies B<-fPIE>.  With B<-fpic> or B<-fpie>, it
assumes GOT entries and small data are within a 12-bit range from the
GOT base address; with B<-fPIC> or B<-fPIE>, GOT offsets
are computed with 32 bits.
With a B<bfin-elf> target, this option implies B<-msim>.


=item B<-minline-plt>


Enable inlining of PLT entries in function calls to functions that are
not known to bind locally.  It has no effect without B<-mfdpic>.
It's enabled by default if optimizing for speed and compiling for
shared libraries (i.e., B<-fPIC> or B<-fpic>), or when an
optimization option such as B<-O3> or above is present in the
command line.


=item B<-mTLS>


Assume a large TLS segment when generating thread-local code.


=item B<-mtls>


Do not assume a large TLS segment when generating thread-local code.


=item B<-mgprel-ro>


Enable the use of C<GPREL> relocations in the FDPIC ABI for data
that is known to be in read-only sections.  It's enabled by default,
except for B<-fpic> or B<-fpie>: even though it may help
make the global offset table smaller, it trades 1 instruction for 4.
With B<-fPIC> or B<-fPIE>, it trades 3 instructions for 4,
one of which may be shared by multiple symbols, and it avoids the need
for a GOT entry for the referenced symbol, so it's more likely to be a
win.  If it is not, B<-mno-gprel-ro> can be used to disable it.


=item B<-multilib-library-pic>


Link with the (library, not FD) pic libraries.  It's implied by
B<-mlibrary-pic>, as well as by B<-fPIC> and
B<-fpic> without B<-mfdpic>.  You should never have to use
it explicitly.


=item B<-mlinked-fp>


Follow the EABI requirement of always creating a frame pointer whenever
a stack frame is allocated.  This option is enabled by default and can
be disabled with B<-mno-linked-fp>.


=item B<-mlong-calls>


Use indirect addressing to call functions outside the current
compilation unit.  This allows the functions to be placed anywhere
within the 32-bit address space.


=item B<-malign-labels>


Try to align labels to an 8-byte boundary by inserting NOPs into the
previous packet.  This option only has an effect when VLIW packing
is enabled.  It doesn't create new packets; it merely adds NOPs to
existing ones.


=item B<-mlibrary-pic>


Generate position-independent EABI code.


=item B<-macc-4>


Use only the first four media accumulator registers.


=item B<-macc-8>


Use all eight media accumulator registers.


=item B<-mpack>


Pack VLIW instructions.


=item B<-mno-pack>


Do not pack VLIW instructions.


=item B<-mno-eflags>


Do not mark ABI switches in e_flags.


=item B<-mcond-move>


Enable the use of conditional-move instructions (default).

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mno-cond-move>


Disable the use of conditional-move instructions.

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mscc>


Enable the use of conditional set instructions (default).

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mno-scc>


Disable the use of conditional set instructions.

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mcond-exec>


Enable the use of conditional execution (default).

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mno-cond-exec>


Disable the use of conditional execution.

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mvliw-branch>


Run a pass to pack branches into VLIW instructions (default).

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mno-vliw-branch>


Do not run a pass to pack branches into VLIW instructions.

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mmulti-cond-exec>


Enable optimization of C<&&> and C<||> in conditional execution
(default).

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mno-multi-cond-exec>


Disable optimization of C<&&> and C<||> in conditional execution.

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mnested-cond-exec>


Enable nested conditional execution optimizations (default).

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-mno-nested-cond-exec>


Disable nested conditional execution optimizations.

This switch is mainly for debugging the compiler and will likely be removed
in a future version.


=item B<-moptimize-membar>


This switch removes redundant C<membar> instructions from the
compiler-generated code.  It is enabled by default.


=item B<-mno-optimize-membar>


This switch disables the automatic removal of redundant C<membar>
instructions from the generated code.


=item B<-mtomcat-stats>


Cause gas to print out tomcat statistics.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu>


Select the processor type for which to generate code.  Possible values are
B<frv>, B<fr550>, B<tomcat>, B<fr500>, B<fr450>,
B<fr405>, B<fr400>, B<fr300> and B<simple>.


=back



=head3 GNU/Linux Options


These B<-m> options are defined for GNU/Linux targets:


=over 4


=item B<-mglibc>

Use the GNU C library.  This is the default except
on B<*-*-linux-*uclibc*>, B<*-*-linux-*musl*> and
B<*-*-linux-*android*> targets.


=item B<-muclibc>

Use uClibc C library.  This is the default on
B<*-*-linux-*uclibc*> targets.


=item B<-mmusl>

Use the musl C library.  This is the default on
B<*-*-linux-*musl*> targets.


=item B<-mbionic>

Use Bionic C library.  This is the default on
B<*-*-linux-*android*> targets.


=item B<-mandroid>

Compile code compatible with Android platform.  This is the default on
B<*-*-linux-*android*> targets.

When compiling, this option enables B<-mbionic>, B<-fPIC>,
B<-fno-exceptions> and B<-fno-rtti> by default.  When linking,
this option makes the GCC driver pass Android-specific options to the linker.
Finally, this option causes the preprocessor macro C<__ANDROID__>
to be defined.


=item B<-tno-android-cc>

Disable compilation effects of B<-mandroid>, i.e., do not enable
B<-mbionic>, B<-fPIC>, B<-fno-exceptions> and
B<-fno-rtti> by default.


=item B<-tno-android-ld>

Disable linking effects of B<-mandroid>, i.e., pass standard Linux
linking options to the linker.


=back



=head3 H8/300 Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the H8/300 implementations:


=over 4


=item B<-mrelax>

Shorten some address references at link time, when possible; uses the
linker option B<-relax>.  


=item B<-mh>

Generate code for the H8/300H.


=item B<-ms>

Generate code for the H8S.


=item B<-mn>

Generate code for the H8S and H8/300H in the normal mode.  This switch
must be used either with B<-mh> or B<-ms>.


=item B<-ms2600>

Generate code for the H8S/2600.  This switch must be used with B<-ms>.


=item B<-mexr>

Extended registers are stored on stack before execution of function
with monitor attribute. Default option is B<-mexr>.
This option is valid only for H8S targets.


=item B<-mno-exr>

Extended registers are not stored on stack before execution of function 
with monitor attribute. Default option is B<-mno-exr>. 
This option is valid only for H8S targets.


=item B<-mint32>

Make C<int> data 32 bits by default.


=item B<-malign-300>

On the H8/300H and H8S, use the same alignment rules as for the H8/300.
The default for the H8/300H and H8S is to align longs and floats on
4-byte boundaries.
B<-malign-300> causes them to be aligned on 2-byte boundaries.
This option has no effect on the H8/300.

=back



=head3 HPPA Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the HPPA family of computers:


=over 4


=item B<-march=>I<architecture-type>

Generate code for the specified architecture.  The choices for
I<architecture-type> are B<1.0> for PA 1.0, B<1.1> for PA
1.1, and B<2.0> for PA 2.0 processors.  Refer to
F</usr/lib/sched.models> on an HP-UX system to determine the proper
architecture option for your machine.  Code compiled for lower numbered
architectures runs on higher numbered architectures, but not the
other way around.


=item B<-mpa-risc-1-0>


=item B<-mpa-risc-1-1>


=item B<-mpa-risc-2-0>

Synonyms for B<-march=1.0>, B<-march=1.1>, and B<-march=2.0> respectively.


=item B<-mcaller-copies>

The caller copies function arguments passed by hidden reference.  This
option should be used with care as it is not compatible with the default
32-bit runtime.  However, only aggregates larger than eight bytes are
passed by hidden reference and the option provides better compatibility
with OpenMP.


=item B<-mjump-in-delay>

This option is ignored and provided for compatibility purposes only.


=item B<-mdisable-fpregs>

Prevent floating-point registers from being used in any manner.  This is
necessary for compiling kernels that perform lazy context switching of
floating-point registers.  If you use this option and attempt to perform
floating-point operations, the compiler aborts.


=item B<-mdisable-indexing>

Prevent the compiler from using indexing address modes.  This avoids some
rather obscure problems when compiling MIG generated code under MACH.


=item B<-mno-space-regs>

Generate code that assumes the target has no space registers.  This allows
GCC to generate faster indirect calls and use unscaled index address modes.

Such code is suitable for level 0 PA systems and kernels.


=item B<-mfast-indirect-calls>

Generate code that assumes calls never cross space boundaries.  This
allows GCC to emit code that performs faster indirect calls.

This option does not work in the presence of shared libraries or nested
functions.


=item B<-mfixed-range=>I<register-range>

Generate code treating the given register range as fixed registers.
A fixed register is one that the register allocator cannot use.  This is
useful when compiling kernel code.  A register range is specified as
two registers separated by a dash.  Multiple register ranges can be
specified separated by a comma.


=item B<-mlong-load-store>

Generate 3-instruction load and store sequences as sometimes required by
the HP-UX 10 linker.  This is equivalent to the B<+k> option to
the HP compilers.


=item B<-mportable-runtime>

Use the portable calling conventions proposed by HP for ELF systems.


=item B<-mgas>

Enable the use of assembler directives only GAS understands.


=item B<-mschedule=>I<cpu-type>

Schedule code according to the constraints for the machine type
I<cpu-type>.  The choices for I<cpu-type> are B<700>
B<7100>, B<7100LC>, B<7200>, B<7300> and B<8000>.  Refer
to F</usr/lib/sched.models> on an HP-UX system to determine the
proper scheduling option for your machine.  The default scheduling is
B<8000>.


=item B<-mlinker-opt>

Enable the optimization pass in the HP-UX linker.  Note this makes symbolic
debugging impossible.  It also triggers a bug in the HP-UX 8 and HP-UX 9
linkers in which they give bogus error messages when linking some programs.


=item B<-msoft-float>

Generate output containing library calls for floating point.
B<Warning:> the requisite libraries are not available for all HPPA
targets.  Normally the facilities of the machine's usual C compiler are
used, but this cannot be done directly in cross-compilation.  You must make
your own arrangements to provide suitable library functions for
cross-compilation.

B<-msoft-float> changes the calling convention in the output file;
therefore, it is only useful if you compile I<all> of a program with
this option.  In particular, you need to compile F<libgcc.a>, the
library that comes with GCC, with B<-msoft-float> in order for
this to work.


=item B<-msio>

Generate the predefine, C<_SIO>, for server IO.  The default is
B<-mwsio>.  This generates the predefines, C<__hp9000s700>,
C<__hp9000s700__> and C<_WSIO>, for workstation IO.  These
options are available under HP-UX and HI-UX.


=item B<-mgnu-ld>

Use options specific to GNU B<ld>.
This passes B<-shared> to B<ld> when
building a shared library.  It is the default when GCC is configured,
explicitly or implicitly, with the GNU linker.  This option does not
affect which B<ld> is called; it only changes what parameters
are passed to that B<ld>.
The B<ld> that is called is determined by the
B<--with-ld> configure option, GCC's program search path, and
finally by the user's B<PATH>.  The linker used by GCC can be printed
using B<which `gcc -print-prog-name=ld`>.  This option is only available
on the 64-bit HP-UX GCC, i.e. configured with B<hppa*64*-*-hpux*>.


=item B<-mhp-ld>

Use options specific to HP B<ld>.
This passes B<-b> to B<ld> when building
a shared library and passes B<+Accept TypeMismatch> to B<ld> on all
links.  It is the default when GCC is configured, explicitly or
implicitly, with the HP linker.  This option does not affect
which B<ld> is called; it only changes what parameters are passed to that
B<ld>.
The B<ld> that is called is determined by the B<--with-ld>
configure option, GCC's program search path, and finally by the user's
B<PATH>.  The linker used by GCC can be printed using B<which
`gcc -print-prog-name=ld`>.  This option is only available on the 64-bit
HP-UX GCC, i.e. configured with B<hppa*64*-*-hpux*>.


=item B<-mlong-calls>

Generate code that uses long call sequences.  This ensures that a call
is always able to reach linker generated stubs.  The default is to generate
long calls only when the distance from the call site to the beginning
of the function or translation unit, as the case may be, exceeds a
predefined limit set by the branch type being used.  The limits for
normal calls are 7,600,000 and 240,000 bytes, respectively for the
PA 2.0 and PA 1.X architectures.  Sibcalls are always limited at
240,000 bytes.

Distances are measured from the beginning of functions when using the
B<-ffunction-sections> option, or when using the B<-mgas>
and B<-mno-portable-runtime> options together under HP-UX with
the SOM linker.

It is normally not desirable to use this option as it degrades
performance.  However, it may be useful in large applications,
particularly when partial linking is used to build the application.

The types of long calls used depends on the capabilities of the
assembler and linker, and the type of code being generated.  The
impact on systems that support long absolute calls, and long pic
symbol-difference or pc-relative calls should be relatively small.
However, an indirect call is used on 32-bit ELF systems in pic code
and it is quite long.


=item B<-munix=>I<unix-std>

Generate compiler predefines and select a startfile for the specified
UNIX standard.  The choices for I<unix-std> are B<93>, B<95>
and B<98>.  B<93> is supported on all HP-UX versions.  B<95>
is available on HP-UX 10.10 and later.  B<98> is available on HP-UX
11.11 and later.  The default values are B<93> for HP-UX 10.00,
B<95> for HP-UX 10.10 though to 11.00, and B<98> for HP-UX 11.11
and later.

B<-munix=93> provides the same predefines as GCC 3.3 and 3.4.
B<-munix=95> provides additional predefines for C<XOPEN_UNIX>
and C<_XOPEN_SOURCE_EXTENDED>, and the startfile F<unix95.o>.
B<-munix=98> provides additional predefines for C<_XOPEN_UNIX>,
C<_XOPEN_SOURCE_EXTENDED>, C<_INCLUDE__STDC_A1_SOURCE> and
C<_INCLUDE_XOPEN_SOURCE_500>, and the startfile F<unix98.o>.

It is I<important> to note that this option changes the interfaces
for various library routines.  It also affects the operational behavior
of the C library.  Thus, I<extreme> care is needed in using this
option.

Library code that is intended to operate with more than one UNIX
standard must test, set and restore the variable C<__xpg4_extended_mask>
as appropriate.  Most GNU software doesn't provide this capability.


=item B<-nolibdld>

Suppress the generation of link options to search libdld.sl when the
B<-static> option is specified on HP-UX 10 and later.


=item B<-static>

The HP-UX implementation of setlocale in libc has a dependency on
libdld.sl.  There isn't an archive version of libdld.sl.  Thus,
when the B<-static> option is specified, special link options
are needed to resolve this dependency.

On HP-UX 10 and later, the GCC driver adds the necessary options to
link with libdld.sl when the B<-static> option is specified.
This causes the resulting binary to be dynamic.  On the 64-bit port,
the linkers generate dynamic binaries by default in any case.  The
B<-nolibdld> option can be used to prevent the GCC driver from
adding these link options.


=item B<-threads>

Add support for multithreading with the I<dce thread> library
under HP-UX.  This option sets flags for both the preprocessor and
linker.

=back



=head3 IA-64 Options


These are the B<-m> options defined for the Intel IA-64 architecture.


=over 4


=item B<-mbig-endian>

Generate code for a big-endian target.  This is the default for HP-UX.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

Generate code for a little-endian target.  This is the default for AIX5
and GNU/Linux.


=item B<-mgnu-as>


=item B<-mno-gnu-as>

Generate (or don't) code for the GNU assembler.  This is the default.


=item B<-mgnu-ld>


=item B<-mno-gnu-ld>

Generate (or don't) code for the GNU linker.  This is the default.


=item B<-mno-pic>

Generate code that does not use a global pointer register.  The result
is not position independent code, and violates the IA-64 ABI.


=item B<-mvolatile-asm-stop>


=item B<-mno-volatile-asm-stop>

Generate (or don't) a stop bit immediately before and after volatile asm
statements.


=item B<-mregister-names>


=item B<-mno-register-names>

Generate (or don't) B<in>, B<loc>, and B<out> register names for
the stacked registers.  This may make assembler output more readable.


=item B<-mno-sdata>


=item B<-msdata>

Disable (or enable) optimizations that use the small data section.  This may
be useful for working around optimizer bugs.


=item B<-mconstant-gp>

Generate code that uses a single constant global pointer value.  This is
useful when compiling kernel code.


=item B<-mauto-pic>

Generate code that is self-relocatable.  This implies B<-mconstant-gp>.
This is useful when compiling firmware code.


=item B<-minline-float-divide-min-latency>

Generate code for inline divides of floating-point values
using the minimum latency algorithm.


=item B<-minline-float-divide-max-throughput>

Generate code for inline divides of floating-point values
using the maximum throughput algorithm.


=item B<-mno-inline-float-divide>

Do not generate inline code for divides of floating-point values.


=item B<-minline-int-divide-min-latency>

Generate code for inline divides of integer values
using the minimum latency algorithm.


=item B<-minline-int-divide-max-throughput>

Generate code for inline divides of integer values
using the maximum throughput algorithm.


=item B<-mno-inline-int-divide>

Do not generate inline code for divides of integer values.


=item B<-minline-sqrt-min-latency>

Generate code for inline square roots
using the minimum latency algorithm.


=item B<-minline-sqrt-max-throughput>

Generate code for inline square roots
using the maximum throughput algorithm.


=item B<-mno-inline-sqrt>

Do not generate inline code for C<sqrt>.


=item B<-mfused-madd>


=item B<-mno-fused-madd>

Do (don't) generate code that uses the fused multiply/add or multiply/subtract
instructions.  The default is to use these instructions.


=item B<-mno-dwarf2-asm>


=item B<-mdwarf2-asm>

Don't (or do) generate assembler code for the DWARF line number debugging
info.  This may be useful when not using the GNU assembler.


=item B<-mearly-stop-bits>


=item B<-mno-early-stop-bits>

Allow stop bits to be placed earlier than immediately preceding the
instruction that triggered the stop bit.  This can improve instruction
scheduling, but does not always do so.


=item B<-mfixed-range=>I<register-range>

Generate code treating the given register range as fixed registers.
A fixed register is one that the register allocator cannot use.  This is
useful when compiling kernel code.  A register range is specified as
two registers separated by a dash.  Multiple register ranges can be
specified separated by a comma.


=item B<-mtls-size=>I<tls-size>

Specify bit size of immediate TLS offsets.  Valid values are 14, 22, and
64.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu-type>

Tune the instruction scheduling for a particular CPU, Valid values are
B<itanium>, B<itanium1>, B<merced>, B<itanium2>,
and B<mckinley>.


=item B<-milp32>


=item B<-mlp64>

Generate code for a 32-bit or 64-bit environment.
The 32-bit environment sets int, long and pointer to 32 bits.
The 64-bit environment sets int to 32 bits and long and pointer
to 64 bits.  These are HP-UX specific flags.


=item B<-mno-sched-br-data-spec>


=item B<-msched-br-data-spec>

(Dis/En)able data speculative scheduling before reload.
This results in generation of C<ld.a> instructions and
the corresponding check instructions (C<ld.c> / C<chk.a>).
The default setting is disabled.


=item B<-msched-ar-data-spec>


=item B<-mno-sched-ar-data-spec>

(En/Dis)able data speculative scheduling after reload.
This results in generation of C<ld.a> instructions and
the corresponding check instructions (C<ld.c> / C<chk.a>).
The default setting is enabled.


=item B<-mno-sched-control-spec>


=item B<-msched-control-spec>

(Dis/En)able control speculative scheduling.  This feature is
available only during region scheduling (i.e. before reload).
This results in generation of the C<ld.s> instructions and
the corresponding check instructions C<chk.s>.
The default setting is disabled.


=item B<-msched-br-in-data-spec>


=item B<-mno-sched-br-in-data-spec>

(En/Dis)able speculative scheduling of the instructions that
are dependent on the data speculative loads before reload.
This is effective only with B<-msched-br-data-spec> enabled.
The default setting is enabled.


=item B<-msched-ar-in-data-spec>


=item B<-mno-sched-ar-in-data-spec>

(En/Dis)able speculative scheduling of the instructions that
are dependent on the data speculative loads after reload.
This is effective only with B<-msched-ar-data-spec> enabled.
The default setting is enabled.


=item B<-msched-in-control-spec>


=item B<-mno-sched-in-control-spec>

(En/Dis)able speculative scheduling of the instructions that
are dependent on the control speculative loads.
This is effective only with B<-msched-control-spec> enabled.
The default setting is enabled.


=item B<-mno-sched-prefer-non-data-spec-insns>


=item B<-msched-prefer-non-data-spec-insns>

If enabled, data-speculative instructions are chosen for schedule
only if there are no other choices at the moment.  This makes
the use of the data speculation much more conservative.
The default setting is disabled.


=item B<-mno-sched-prefer-non-control-spec-insns>


=item B<-msched-prefer-non-control-spec-insns>

If enabled, control-speculative instructions are chosen for schedule
only if there are no other choices at the moment.  This makes
the use of the control speculation much more conservative.
The default setting is disabled.


=item B<-mno-sched-count-spec-in-critical-path>


=item B<-msched-count-spec-in-critical-path>

If enabled, speculative dependencies are considered during
computation of the instructions priorities.  This makes the use of the
speculation a bit more conservative.
The default setting is disabled.


=item B<-msched-spec-ldc>

Use a simple data speculation check.  This option is on by default.


=item B<-msched-control-spec-ldc>

Use a simple check for control speculation.  This option is on by default.


=item B<-msched-stop-bits-after-every-cycle>

Place a stop bit after every cycle when scheduling.  This option is on
by default.


=item B<-msched-fp-mem-deps-zero-cost>

Assume that floating-point stores and loads are not likely to cause a conflict
when placed into the same instruction group.  This option is disabled by
default.


=item B<-msel-sched-dont-check-control-spec>

Generate checks for control speculation in selective scheduling.
This flag is disabled by default.


=item B<-msched-max-memory-insns=>I<max-insns>

Limit on the number of memory insns per instruction group, giving lower
priority to subsequent memory insns attempting to schedule in the same
instruction group. Frequently useful to prevent cache bank conflicts.
The default value is 1.


=item B<-msched-max-memory-insns-hard-limit>

Makes the limit specified by B<msched-max-memory-insns> a hard limit,
disallowing more than that number in an instruction group.
Otherwise, the limit is "soft", meaning that non-memory operations
are preferred when the limit is reached, but memory operations may still
be scheduled.


=back



=head3 LM32 Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the LatticeMico32 architecture:


=over 4


=item B<-mbarrel-shift-enabled>

Enable barrel-shift instructions.


=item B<-mdivide-enabled>
