Enable divide and modulus instructions.


=item B<-mmultiply-enabled>

Enable multiply instructions.


=item B<-msign-extend-enabled>

Enable sign extend instructions.


=item B<-muser-enabled>

Enable user-defined instructions.


=back



=head3 M32C Options



=over 4


=item B<-mcpu=>I<name>

Select the CPU for which code is generated.  I<name> may be one of
B<r8c> for the R8C/Tiny series, B<m16c> for the M16C (up to
/60) series, B<m32cm> for the M16C/80 series, or B<m32c> for
the M32C/80 series.


=item B<-msim>

Specifies that the program will be run on the simulator.  This causes
an alternate runtime library to be linked in which supports, for
example, file I/O.  You must not use this option when generating
programs that will run on real hardware; you must provide your own
runtime library for whatever I/O functions are needed.


=item B<-memregs=>I<number>

Specifies the number of memory-based pseudo-registers GCC uses
during code generation.  These pseudo-registers are used like real
registers, so there is a tradeoff between GCC's ability to fit the
code into available registers, and the performance penalty of using
memory instead of registers.  Note that all modules in a program must
be compiled with the same value for this option.  Because of that, you
must not use this option with GCC's default runtime libraries.


=back



=head3 M32R/D Options


These B<-m> options are defined for Renesas M32R/D architectures:


=over 4


=item B<-m32r2>

Generate code for the M32R/2.


=item B<-m32rx>

Generate code for the M32R/X.


=item B<-m32r>

Generate code for the M32R.  This is the default.


=item B<-mmodel=small>

Assume all objects live in the lower 16MB of memory (so that their addresses
can be loaded with the C<ld24> instruction), and assume all subroutines
are reachable with the C<bl> instruction.
This is the default.

The addressability of a particular object can be set with the
C<model> attribute.


=item B<-mmodel=medium>

Assume objects may be anywhere in the 32-bit address space (the compiler
generates C<seth/add3> instructions to load their addresses), and
assume all subroutines are reachable with the C<bl> instruction.


=item B<-mmodel=large>

Assume objects may be anywhere in the 32-bit address space (the compiler
generates C<seth/add3> instructions to load their addresses), and
assume subroutines may not be reachable with the C<bl> instruction
(the compiler generates the much slower C<seth/add3/jl>
instruction sequence).


=item B<-msdata=none>

Disable use of the small data area.  Variables are put into
one of C<.data>, C<.bss>, or C<.rodata> (unless the
C<section> attribute has been specified).
This is the default.

The small data area consists of sections C<.sdata> and C<.sbss>.
Objects may be explicitly put in the small data area with the
C<section> attribute using one of these sections.


=item B<-msdata=sdata>

Put small global and static data in the small data area, but do not
generate special code to reference them.


=item B<-msdata=use>

Put small global and static data in the small data area, and generate
special instructions to reference them.


=item B<-G> I<num>

Put global and static objects less than or equal to I<num> bytes
into the small data or BSS sections instead of the normal data or BSS
sections.  The default value of I<num> is 8.
The B<-msdata> option must be set to one of B<sdata> or B<use>
for this option to have any effect.

All modules should be compiled with the same B<-G> I<num> value.
Compiling with different values of I<num> may or may not work; if it
doesn't the linker gives an error message---incorrect code is not
generated.


=item B<-mdebug>

Makes the M32R-specific code in the compiler display some statistics
that might help in debugging programs.


=item B<-malign-loops>

Align all loops to a 32-byte boundary.


=item B<-mno-align-loops>

Do not enforce a 32-byte alignment for loops.  This is the default.


=item B<-missue-rate=>I<number>

Issue I<number> instructions per cycle.  I<number> can only be 1
or 2.


=item B<-mbranch-cost=>I<number>

I<number> can only be 1 or 2.  If it is 1 then branches are
preferred over conditional code, if it is 2, then the opposite applies.


=item B<-mflush-trap=>I<number>

Specifies the trap number to use to flush the cache.  The default is
12.  Valid numbers are between 0 and 15 inclusive.


=item B<-mno-flush-trap>

Specifies that the cache cannot be flushed by using a trap.


=item B<-mflush-func=>I<name>

Specifies the name of the operating system function to call to flush
the cache.  The default is B<_flush_cache>, but a function call
is only used if a trap is not available.


=item B<-mno-flush-func>

Indicates that there is no OS function for flushing the cache.


=back



=head3 M680x0 Options


These are the B<-m> options defined for M680x0 and ColdFire processors.
The default settings depend on which architecture was selected when
the compiler was configured; the defaults for the most common choices
are given below.


=over 4


=item B<-march=>I<arch>

Generate code for a specific M680x0 or ColdFire instruction set
architecture.  Permissible values of I<arch> for M680x0
architectures are: B<68000>, B<68010>, B<68020>,
B<68030>, B<68040>, B<68060> and B<cpu32>.  ColdFire
architectures are selected according to Freescale's ISA classification
and the permissible values are: B<isaa>, B<isaaplus>,
B<isab> and B<isac>.

GCC defines a macro C<__mcfI<arch>__> whenever it is generating
code for a ColdFire target.  The I<arch> in this macro is one of the
B<-march> arguments given above.

When used together, B<-march> and B<-mtune> select code
that runs on a family of similar processors but that is optimized
for a particular microarchitecture.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu>

Generate code for a specific M680x0 or ColdFire processor.
The M680x0 I<cpu>s are: B<68000>, B<68010>, B<68020>,
B<68030>, B<68040>, B<68060>, B<68302>, B<68332>
and B<cpu32>.  The ColdFire I<cpu>s are given by the table
below, which also classifies the CPUs into families:


=over 4


=item Family : B<-mcpu> arguments


=item B<51> : B<51> B<51ac> B<51ag> B<51cn> B<51em> B<51je> B<51jf> B<51jg> B<51jm> B<51mm> B<51qe> B<51qm>


=item B<5206> : B<5202> B<5204> B<5206>


=item B<5206e> : B<5206e>


=item B<5208> : B<5207> B<5208>


=item B<5211a> : B<5210a> B<5211a>


=item B<5213> : B<5211> B<5212> B<5213>


=item B<5216> : B<5214> B<5216>


=item B<52235> : B<52230> B<52231> B<52232> B<52233> B<52234> B<52235>


=item B<5225> : B<5224> B<5225>


=item B<52259> : B<52252> B<52254> B<52255> B<52256> B<52258> B<52259>


=item B<5235> : B<5232> B<5233> B<5234> B<5235> B<523x>


=item B<5249> : B<5249>


=item B<5250> : B<5250>


=item B<5271> : B<5270> B<5271>


=item B<5272> : B<5272>


=item B<5275> : B<5274> B<5275>


=item B<5282> : B<5280> B<5281> B<5282> B<528x>


=item B<53017> : B<53011> B<53012> B<53013> B<53014> B<53015> B<53016> B<53017>


=item B<5307> : B<5307>


=item B<5329> : B<5327> B<5328> B<5329> B<532x>


=item B<5373> : B<5372> B<5373> B<537x>


=item B<5407> : B<5407>


=item B<5475> : B<5470> B<5471> B<5472> B<5473> B<5474> B<5475> B<547x> B<5480> B<5481> B<5482> B<5483> B<5484> B<5485>


=back


B<-mcpu=>I<cpu> overrides B<-march=>I<arch> if
I<arch> is compatible with I<cpu>.  Other combinations of
B<-mcpu> and B<-march> are rejected.

GCC defines the macro C<__mcf_cpu_I<cpu>> when ColdFire target
I<cpu> is selected.  It also defines C<__mcf_family_I<family>>,
where the value of I<family> is given by the table above.


=item B<-mtune=>I<tune>

Tune the code for a particular microarchitecture within the
constraints set by B<-march> and B<-mcpu>.
The M680x0 microarchitectures are: B<68000>, B<68010>,
B<68020>, B<68030>, B<68040>, B<68060>
and B<cpu32>.  The ColdFire microarchitectures
are: B<cfv1>, B<cfv2>, B<cfv3>, B<cfv4> and B<cfv4e>.

You can also use B<-mtune=68020-40> for code that needs
to run relatively well on 68020, 68030 and 68040 targets.
B<-mtune=68020-60> is similar but includes 68060 targets
as well.  These two options select the same tuning decisions as
B<-m68020-40> and B<-m68020-60> respectively.

GCC defines the macros C<__mcI<arch>> and C<__mcI<arch>__>
when tuning for 680x0 architecture I<arch>.  It also defines
C<mcI<arch>> unless either B<-ansi> or a non-GNU B<-std>
option is used.  If GCC is tuning for a range of architectures,
as selected by B<-mtune=68020-40> or B<-mtune=68020-60>,
it defines the macros for every architecture in the range.

GCC also defines the macro C<__mI<uarch>__> when tuning for
ColdFire microarchitecture I<uarch>, where I<uarch> is one
of the arguments given above.


=item B<-m68000>


=item B<-mc68000>

Generate output for a 68000.  This is the default
when the compiler is configured for 68000-based systems.
It is equivalent to B<-march=68000>.

Use this option for microcontrollers with a 68000 or EC000 core,
including the 68008, 68302, 68306, 68307, 68322, 68328 and 68356.


=item B<-m68010>

Generate output for a 68010.  This is the default
when the compiler is configured for 68010-based systems.
It is equivalent to B<-march=68010>.


=item B<-m68020>


=item B<-mc68020>

Generate output for a 68020.  This is the default
when the compiler is configured for 68020-based systems.
It is equivalent to B<-march=68020>.


=item B<-m68030>

Generate output for a 68030.  This is the default when the compiler is
configured for 68030-based systems.  It is equivalent to
B<-march=68030>.


=item B<-m68040>

Generate output for a 68040.  This is the default when the compiler is
configured for 68040-based systems.  It is equivalent to
B<-march=68040>.

This option inhibits the use of 68881/68882 instructions that have to be
emulated by software on the 68040.  Use this option if your 68040 does not
have code to emulate those instructions.


=item B<-m68060>

Generate output for a 68060.  This is the default when the compiler is
configured for 68060-based systems.  It is equivalent to
B<-march=68060>.

This option inhibits the use of 68020 and 68881/68882 instructions that
have to be emulated by software on the 68060.  Use this option if your 68060
does not have code to emulate those instructions.


=item B<-mcpu32>

Generate output for a CPU32.  This is the default
when the compiler is configured for CPU32-based systems.
It is equivalent to B<-march=cpu32>.

Use this option for microcontrollers with a
CPU32 or CPU32+ core, including the 68330, 68331, 68332, 68333, 68334,
68336, 68340, 68341, 68349 and 68360.


=item B<-m5200>

Generate output for a 520X ColdFire CPU.  This is the default
when the compiler is configured for 520X-based systems.
It is equivalent to B<-mcpu=5206>, and is now deprecated
in favor of that option.

Use this option for microcontroller with a 5200 core, including
the MCF5202, MCF5203, MCF5204 and MCF5206.


=item B<-m5206e>

Generate output for a 5206e ColdFire CPU.  The option is now
deprecated in favor of the equivalent B<-mcpu=5206e>.


=item B<-m528x>

Generate output for a member of the ColdFire 528X family.
The option is now deprecated in favor of the equivalent
B<-mcpu=528x>.


=item B<-m5307>

Generate output for a ColdFire 5307 CPU.  The option is now deprecated
in favor of the equivalent B<-mcpu=5307>.


=item B<-m5407>

Generate output for a ColdFire 5407 CPU.  The option is now deprecated
in favor of the equivalent B<-mcpu=5407>.


=item B<-mcfv4e>

Generate output for a ColdFire V4e family CPU (e.g. 547x/548x).
This includes use of hardware floating-point instructions.
The option is equivalent to B<-mcpu=547x>, and is now
deprecated in favor of that option.


=item B<-m68020-40>

Generate output for a 68040, without using any of the new instructions.
This results in code that can run relatively efficiently on either a
68020/68881 or a 68030 or a 68040.  The generated code does use the
68881 instructions that are emulated on the 68040.

The option is equivalent to B<-march=68020> B<-mtune=68020-40>.


=item B<-m68020-60>

Generate output for a 68060, without using any of the new instructions.
This results in code that can run relatively efficiently on either a
68020/68881 or a 68030 or a 68040.  The generated code does use the
68881 instructions that are emulated on the 68060.

The option is equivalent to B<-march=68020> B<-mtune=68020-60>.


=item B<-mhard-float>


=item B<-m68881>

Generate floating-point instructions.  This is the default for 68020
and above, and for ColdFire devices that have an FPU.  It defines the
macro C<__HAVE_68881__> on M680x0 targets and C<__mcffpu__>
on ColdFire targets.


=item B<-msoft-float>

Do not generate floating-point instructions; use library calls instead.
This is the default for 68000, 68010, and 68832 targets.  It is also
the default for ColdFire devices that have no FPU.


=item B<-mdiv>


=item B<-mno-div>

Generate (do not generate) ColdFire hardware divide and remainder
instructions.  If B<-march> is used without B<-mcpu>,
the default is "on" for ColdFire architectures and "off" for M680x0
architectures.  Otherwise, the default is taken from the target CPU
(either the default CPU, or the one specified by B<-mcpu>).  For
example, the default is "off" for B<-mcpu=5206> and "on" for
B<-mcpu=5206e>.

GCC defines the macro C<__mcfhwdiv__> when this option is enabled.


=item B<-mshort>

Consider type C<int> to be 16 bits wide, like C<short int>.
Additionally, parameters passed on the stack are also aligned to a
16-bit boundary even on targets whose API mandates promotion to 32-bit.


=item B<-mno-short>

Do not consider type C<int> to be 16 bits wide.  This is the default.


=item B<-mnobitfield>


=item B<-mno-bitfield>

Do not use the bit-field instructions.  The B<-m68000>, B<-mcpu32>
and B<-m5200> options imply S<B<-mnobitfield>>.


=item B<-mbitfield>

Do use the bit-field instructions.  The B<-m68020> option implies
B<-mbitfield>.  This is the default if you use a configuration
designed for a 68020.


=item B<-mrtd>

Use a different function-calling convention, in which functions
that take a fixed number of arguments return with the C<rtd>
instruction, which pops their arguments while returning.  This
saves one instruction in the caller since there is no need to pop
the arguments there.

This calling convention is incompatible with the one normally
used on Unix, so you cannot use it if you need to call libraries
compiled with the Unix compiler.

Also, you must provide function prototypes for all functions that
take variable numbers of arguments (including C<printf>);
otherwise incorrect code is generated for calls to those
functions.

In addition, seriously incorrect code results if you call a
function with too many arguments.  (Normally, extra arguments are
harmlessly ignored.)

The C<rtd> instruction is supported by the 68010, 68020, 68030,
68040, 68060 and CPU32 processors, but not by the 68000 or 5200.

The default is B<-mno-rtd>.


=item B<-malign-int>


=item B<-mno-align-int>

Control whether GCC aligns C<int>, C<long>, C<long long>,
C<float>, C<double>, and C<long double> variables on a 32-bit
boundary (B<-malign-int>) or a 16-bit boundary (B<-mno-align-int>).
Aligning variables on 32-bit boundaries produces code that runs somewhat
faster on processors with 32-bit busses at the expense of more memory.

B<Warning:> if you use the B<-malign-int> switch, GCC
aligns structures containing the above types differently than
most published application binary interface specifications for the m68k.


=item B<-mpcrel>

Use the pc-relative addressing mode of the 68000 directly, instead of
using a global offset table.  At present, this option implies B<-fpic>,
allowing at most a 16-bit offset for pc-relative addressing.  B<-fPIC> is
not presently supported with B<-mpcrel>, though this could be supported for
68020 and higher processors.


=item B<-mno-strict-align>


=item B<-mstrict-align>

Do not (do) assume that unaligned memory references are handled by
the system.


=item B<-msep-data>

Generate code that allows the data segment to be located in a different
area of memory from the text segment.  This allows for execute-in-place in
an environment without virtual memory management.  This option implies
B<-fPIC>.


=item B<-mno-sep-data>

Generate code that assumes that the data segment follows the text segment.
This is the default.


=item B<-mid-shared-library>

Generate code that supports shared libraries via the library ID method.
This allows for execute-in-place and shared libraries in an environment
without virtual memory management.  This option implies B<-fPIC>.


=item B<-mno-id-shared-library>

Generate code that doesn't assume ID-based shared libraries are being used.
This is the default.


=item B<-mshared-library-id=n>

Specifies the identification number of the ID-based shared library being
compiled.  Specifying a value of 0 generates more compact code; specifying
other values forces the allocation of that number to the current
library, but is no more space- or time-efficient than omitting this option.


=item B<-mxgot>


=item B<-mno-xgot>

When generating position-independent code for ColdFire, generate code
that works if the GOT has more than 8192 entries.  This code is
larger and slower than code generated without this option.  On M680x0
processors, this option is not needed; B<-fPIC> suffices.

GCC normally uses a single instruction to load values from the GOT.
While this is relatively efficient, it only works if the GOT
is smaller than about 64k.  Anything larger causes the linker
to report an error such as:

	
	relocation truncated to fit: R_68K_GOT16O foobar


If this happens, you should recompile your code with B<-mxgot>.
It should then work with very large GOTs.  However, code generated with
B<-mxgot> is less efficient, since it takes 4 instructions to fetch
the value of a global symbol.

Note that some linkers, including newer versions of the GNU linker,
can create multiple GOTs and sort GOT entries.  If you have such a linker,
you should only need to use B<-mxgot> when compiling a single
object file that accesses more than 8192 GOT entries.  Very few do.

These options have no effect unless GCC is generating
position-independent code.


=item B<-mlong-jump-table-offsets>

Use 32-bit offsets in C<switch> tables.  The default is to use
16-bit offsets.


=back



=head3 MCore Options


These are the B<-m> options defined for the Motorola M*Core
processors.


=over 4



=item B<-mhardlit>


=item B<-mno-hardlit>

Inline constants into the code stream if it can be done in two
instructions or less.


=item B<-mdiv>


=item B<-mno-div>

Use the divide instruction.  (Enabled by default).


=item B<-mrelax-immediate>


=item B<-mno-relax-immediate>

Allow arbitrary-sized immediates in bit operations.


=item B<-mwide-bitfields>


=item B<-mno-wide-bitfields>

Always treat bit-fields as C<int>-sized.


=item B<-m4byte-functions>


=item B<-mno-4byte-functions>

Force all functions to be aligned to a 4-byte boundary.


=item B<-mcallgraph-data>


=item B<-mno-callgraph-data>

Emit callgraph information.


=item B<-mslow-bytes>


=item B<-mno-slow-bytes>

Prefer word access when reading byte quantities.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>


=item B<-mbig-endian>

Generate code for a little-endian target.


=item B<-m210>


=item B<-m340>

Generate code for the 210 processor.


=item B<-mno-lsim>

Assume that runtime support has been provided and so omit the
simulator library (F<libsim.a)> from the linker command line.


=item B<-mstack-increment=>I<size>

Set the maximum amount for a single stack increment operation.  Large
values can increase the speed of programs that contain functions
that need a large amount of stack space, but they can also trigger a
segmentation fault if the stack is extended too much.  The default
value is 0x1000.


=back



=head3 MeP Options



=over 4



=item B<-mabsdiff>

Enables the C<abs> instruction, which is the absolute difference
between two registers.


=item B<-mall-opts>

Enables all the optional instructions---average, multiply, divide, bit
operations, leading zero, absolute difference, min/max, clip, and
saturation.



=item B<-maverage>

Enables the C<ave> instruction, which computes the average of two
registers.


=item B<-mbased=>I<n>

Variables of size I<n> bytes or smaller are placed in the
C<.based> section by default.  Based variables use the C<$tp>
register as a base register, and there is a 128-byte limit to the
C<.based> section.


=item B<-mbitops>

Enables the bit operation instructions---bit test (C<btstm>), set
(C<bsetm>), clear (C<bclrm>), invert (C<bnotm>), and
test-and-set (C<tas>).


=item B<-mc=>I<name>

Selects which section constant data is placed in.  I<name> may
be B<tiny>, B<near>, or B<far>.


=item B<-mclip>

Enables the C<clip> instruction.  Note that B<-mclip> is not
useful unless you also provide B<-mminmax>.


=item B<-mconfig=>I<name>

Selects one of the built-in core configurations.  Each MeP chip has
one or more modules in it; each module has a core CPU and a variety of
coprocessors, optional instructions, and peripherals.  The
C<MeP-Integrator> tool, not part of GCC, provides these
configurations through this option; using this option is the same as
using all the corresponding command-line options.  The default
configuration is B<default>.


=item B<-mcop>

Enables the coprocessor instructions.  By default, this is a 32-bit
coprocessor.  Note that the coprocessor is normally enabled via the
B<-mconfig=> option.


=item B<-mcop32>

Enables the 32-bit coprocessor's instructions.


=item B<-mcop64>

Enables the 64-bit coprocessor's instructions.


=item B<-mivc2>

Enables IVC2 scheduling.  IVC2 is a 64-bit VLIW coprocessor.


=item B<-mdc>

Causes constant variables to be placed in the C<.near> section.


=item B<-mdiv>

Enables the C<div> and C<divu> instructions.


=item B<-meb>

Generate big-endian code.


=item B<-mel>

Generate little-endian code.


=item B<-mio-volatile>

Tells the compiler that any variable marked with the C<io>
attribute is to be considered volatile.


=item B<-ml>

Causes variables to be assigned to the C<.far> section by default.


=item B<-mleadz>

Enables the C<leadz> (leading zero) instruction.


=item B<-mm>

Causes variables to be assigned to the C<.near> section by default.


=item B<-mminmax>

Enables the C<min> and C<max> instructions.


=item B<-mmult>

Enables the multiplication and multiply-accumulate instructions.


=item B<-mno-opts>

Disables all the optional instructions enabled by B<-mall-opts>.


=item B<-mrepeat>

Enables the C<repeat> and C<erepeat> instructions, used for
low-overhead looping.


=item B<-ms>

Causes all variables to default to the C<.tiny> section.  Note
that there is a 65536-byte limit to this section.  Accesses to these
variables use the C<%gp> base register.


=item B<-msatur>

Enables the saturation instructions.  Note that the compiler does not
currently generate these itself, but this option is included for
compatibility with other tools, like C<as>.


=item B<-msdram>

Link the SDRAM-based runtime instead of the default ROM-based runtime.


=item B<-msim>

Link the simulator run-time libraries.


=item B<-msimnovec>

Link the simulator runtime libraries, excluding built-in support
for reset and exception vectors and tables.


=item B<-mtf>

Causes all functions to default to the C<.far> section.  Without
this option, functions default to the C<.near> section.


=item B<-mtiny=>I<n>

Variables that are I<n> bytes or smaller are allocated to the
C<.tiny> section.  These variables use the C<$gp> base
register.  The default for this option is 4, but note that there's a
65536-byte limit to the C<.tiny> section.


=back



=head3 MicroBlaze Options



=over 4



=item B<-msoft-float>

Use software emulation for floating point (default).


=item B<-mhard-float>

Use hardware floating-point instructions.


=item B<-mmemcpy>

Do not optimize block moves, use C<memcpy>.


=item B<-mno-clearbss>

This option is deprecated.  Use B<-fno-zero-initialized-in-bss> instead.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu-type>

Use features of, and schedule code for, the given CPU.
Supported values are in the format B<v>I<X>B<.>I<YY>B<.>I<Z>,
where I<X> is a major version, I<YY> is the minor version, and
I<Z> is compatibility code.  Example values are B<v3.00.a>,
B<v4.00.b>, B<v5.00.a>, B<v5.00.b>, B<v6.00.a>.


=item B<-mxl-soft-mul>

Use software multiply emulation (default).


=item B<-mxl-soft-div>

Use software emulation for divides (default).


=item B<-mxl-barrel-shift>

Use the hardware barrel shifter.


=item B<-mxl-pattern-compare>

Use pattern compare instructions.


=item B<-msmall-divides>

Use table lookup optimization for small signed integer divisions.


=item B<-mxl-stack-check>

This option is deprecated.  Use B<-fstack-check> instead.


=item B<-mxl-gp-opt>

Use GP-relative C<.sdata>/C<.sbss> sections.


=item B<-mxl-multiply-high>

Use multiply high instructions for high part of 32x32 multiply.


=item B<-mxl-float-convert>

Use hardware floating-point conversion instructions.


=item B<-mxl-float-sqrt>

Use hardware floating-point square root instruction.


=item B<-mbig-endian>

Generate code for a big-endian target.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

Generate code for a little-endian target.


=item B<-mxl-reorder>

Use reorder instructions (swap and byte reversed load/store).


=item B<-mxl-mode->I<app-model>

Select application model I<app-model>.  Valid models are

=over 4


=item B<executable>

normal executable (default), uses startup code F<crt0.o>.


=item B<-mpic-data-is-text-relative>

Assume that the displacement between the text and data segments is fixed
at static link time.  This allows data to be referenced by offset from start of
text address instead of GOT since PC-relative addressing is not supported.


=item B<xmdstub>

for use with Xilinx Microprocessor Debugger (XMD) based
software intrusive debug agent called xmdstub. This uses startup file
F<crt1.o> and sets the start address of the program to 0x800.


=item B<bootstrap>

for applications that are loaded using a bootloader.
This model uses startup file F<crt2.o> which does not contain a processor
reset vector handler. This is suitable for transferring control on a
processor reset to the bootloader rather than the application.


=item B<novectors>

for applications that do not require any of the
MicroBlaze vectors. This option may be useful for applications running
within a monitoring application. This model uses F<crt3.o> as a startup file.

=back


Option B<-xl-mode->I<app-model> is a deprecated alias for
B<-mxl-mode->I<app-model>.


=back



=head3 MIPS Options



=over 4



=item B<-EB>

Generate big-endian code.


=item B<-EL>

Generate little-endian code.  This is the default for B<mips*el-*-*>
configurations.


=item B<-march=>I<arch>

Generate code that runs on I<arch>, which can be the name of a
generic MIPS ISA, or the name of a particular processor.
The ISA names are:
B<mips1>, B<mips2>, B<mips3>, B<mips4>,
B<mips32>, B<mips32r2>, B<mips32r3>, B<mips32r5>,
B<mips32r6>, B<mips64>, B<mips64r2>, B<mips64r3>,
B<mips64r5> and B<mips64r6>.
The processor names are:
B<4kc>, B<4km>, B<4kp>, B<4ksc>,
B<4kec>, B<4kem>, B<4kep>, B<4ksd>,
B<5kc>, B<5kf>,
B<20kc>,
B<24kc>, B<24kf2_1>, B<24kf1_1>,
B<24kec>, B<24kef2_1>, B<24kef1_1>,
B<34kc>, B<34kf2_1>, B<34kf1_1>, B<34kn>,
B<74kc>, B<74kf2_1>, B<74kf1_1>, B<74kf3_2>,
B<1004kc>, B<1004kf2_1>, B<1004kf1_1>,
B<i6400>, B<i6500>,
B<interaptiv>,
B<loongson2e>, B<loongson2f>, B<loongson3a>, B<gs464>,
B<gs464e>, B<gs264e>,
B<m4k>,
B<m14k>, B<m14kc>, B<m14ke>, B<m14kec>,
B<m5100>, B<m5101>,
B<octeon>, B<octeon+>, B<octeon2>, B<octeon3>,
B<orion>,
B<p5600>, B<p6600>,
B<r2000>, B<r3000>, B<r3900>, B<r4000>, B<r4400>,
B<r4600>, B<r4650>, B<r4700>, B<r5900>,
B<r6000>, B<r8000>,
B<rm7000>, B<rm9000>,
B<r10000>, B<r12000>, B<r14000>, B<r16000>,
B<sb1>,
B<sr71000>,
B<vr4100>, B<vr4111>, B<vr4120>, B<vr4130>, B<vr4300>,
B<vr5000>, B<vr5400>, B<vr5500>,
B<xlr> and B<xlp>.
The special value B<from-abi> selects the
most compatible architecture for the selected ABI (that is,
B<mips1> for 32-bit ABIs and B<mips3> for 64-bit ABIs).

The native Linux/GNU toolchain also supports the value B<native>,
which selects the best architecture option for the host processor.
B<-march=native> has no effect if GCC does not recognize
the processor.

In processor names, a final B<000> can be abbreviated as B<k>
(for example, B<-march=r2k>).  Prefixes are optional, and
B<vr> may be written B<r>.

Names of the form I<n>B<f2_1> refer to processors with
FPUs clocked at half the rate of the core, names of the form
I<n>B<f1_1> refer to processors with FPUs clocked at the same
rate as the core, and names of the form I<n>B<f3_2> refer to
processors with FPUs clocked a ratio of 3:2 with respect to the core.
For compatibility reasons, I<n>B<f> is accepted as a synonym
for I<n>B<f2_1> while I<n>B<x> and I<b>B<fx> are
accepted as synonyms for I<n>B<f1_1>.

GCC defines two macros based on the value of this option.  The first
is C<_MIPS_ARCH>, which gives the name of target architecture, as
a string.  The second has the form C<_MIPS_ARCH_I<foo>>,
where I<foo> is the capitalized value of C<_MIPS_ARCH>.
For example, B<-march=r2000> sets C<_MIPS_ARCH>
to C<"r2000"> and defines the macro C<_MIPS_ARCH_R2000>.

Note that the C<_MIPS_ARCH> macro uses the processor names given
above.  In other words, it has the full prefix and does not
abbreviate B<000> as B<k>.  In the case of B<from-abi>,
the macro names the resolved architecture (either C<"mips1"> or
C<"mips3">).  It names the default architecture when no
B<-march> option is given.


=item B<-mtune=>I<arch>

Optimize for I<arch>.  Among other things, this option controls
the way instructions are scheduled, and the perceived cost of arithmetic
operations.  The list of I<arch> values is the same as for
B<-march>.

When this option is not used, GCC optimizes for the processor
specified by B<-march>.  By using B<-march> and
B<-mtune> together, it is possible to generate code that
runs on a family of processors, but optimize the code for one
particular member of that family.

B<-mtune> defines the macros C<_MIPS_TUNE> and
C<_MIPS_TUNE_I<foo>>, which work in the same way as the
B<-march> ones described above.


=item B<-mips1>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips1>.


=item B<-mips2>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips2>.


=item B<-mips3>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips3>.


=item B<-mips4>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips4>.


=item B<-mips32>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips32>.


=item B<-mips32r3>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips32r3>.


=item B<-mips32r5>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips32r5>.


=item B<-mips32r6>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips32r6>.


=item B<-mips64>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips64>.


=item B<-mips64r2>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips64r2>.


=item B<-mips64r3>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips64r3>.


=item B<-mips64r5>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips64r5>.


=item B<-mips64r6>

Equivalent to B<-march=mips64r6>.


=item B<-mips16>


=item B<-mno-mips16>

Generate (do not generate) MIPS16 code.  If GCC is targeting a
MIPS32 or MIPS64 architecture, it makes use of the MIPS16e ASE.

MIPS16 code generation can also be controlled on a per-function basis
by means of C<mips16> and C<nomips16> attributes.



=item B<-mflip-mips16>

Generate MIPS16 code on alternating functions.  This option is provided
for regression testing of mixed MIPS16/non-MIPS16 code generation, and is
not intended for ordinary use in compiling user code.


=item B<-minterlink-compressed>


=item B<-mno-interlink-compressed>

Require (do not require) that code using the standard (uncompressed) MIPS ISA
be link-compatible with MIPS16 and microMIPS code, and vice versa.

For example, code using the standard ISA encoding cannot jump directly
to MIPS16 or microMIPS code; it must either use a call or an indirect jump.
B<-minterlink-compressed> therefore disables direct jumps unless GCC
knows that the target of the jump is not compressed.


=item B<-minterlink-mips16>


=item B<-mno-interlink-mips16>

Aliases of B<-minterlink-compressed> and
B<-mno-interlink-compressed>.  These options predate the microMIPS ASE
and are retained for backwards compatibility.


=item B<-mabi=32>


=item B<-mabi=o64>


=item B<-mabi=n32>


=item B<-mabi=64>


=item B<-mabi=eabi>

Generate code for the given ABI.

Note that the EABI has a 32-bit and a 64-bit variant.  GCC normally
generates 64-bit code when you select a 64-bit architecture, but you
can use B<-mgp32> to get 32-bit code instead.

For information about the O64 ABI, see
E<lt>B<http://gcc.gnu.org/projects/mipso64-abi.html>E<gt>.

GCC supports a variant of the o32 ABI in which floating-point registers
are 64 rather than 32 bits wide.  You can select this combination with
B<-mabi=32> B<-mfp64>.  This ABI relies on the C<mthc1>
and C<mfhc1> instructions and is therefore only supported for
MIPS32R2, MIPS32R3 and MIPS32R5 processors.

The register assignments for arguments and return values remain the
same, but each scalar value is passed in a single 64-bit register
rather than a pair of 32-bit registers.  For example, scalar
floating-point values are returned in B<$f0> only, not a
B<$f0>/B<$f1> pair.  The set of call-saved registers also
remains the same in that the even-numbered double-precision registers
are saved.

Two additional variants of the o32 ABI are supported to enable
a transition from 32-bit to 64-bit registers.  These are FPXX
(B<-mfpxx>) and FP64A (B<-mfp64> B<-mno-odd-spreg>).
The FPXX extension mandates that all code must execute correctly
when run using 32-bit or 64-bit registers.  The code can be interlinked
with either FP32 or FP64, but not both.
The FP64A extension is similar to the FP64 extension but forbids the
use of odd-numbered single-precision registers.  This can be used
in conjunction with the C<FRE> mode of FPUs in MIPS32R5
processors and allows both FP32 and FP64A code to interlink and
run in the same process without changing FPU modes.


=item B<-mabicalls>


=item B<-mno-abicalls>

Generate (do not generate) code that is suitable for SVR4-style
dynamic objects.  B<-mabicalls> is the default for SVR4-based
systems.


=item B<-mshared>


=item B<-mno-shared>

Generate (do not generate) code that is fully position-independent,
and that can therefore be linked into shared libraries.  This option
only affects B<-mabicalls>.

All B<-mabicalls> code has traditionally been position-independent,
regardless of options like B<-fPIC> and B<-fpic>.  However,
as an extension, the GNU toolchain allows executables to use absolute
accesses for locally-binding symbols.  It can also use shorter GP
initialization sequences and generate direct calls to locally-defined
functions.  This mode is selected by B<-mno-shared>.

B<-mno-shared> depends on binutils 2.16 or higher and generates
objects that can only be linked by the GNU linker.  However, the option
does not affect the ABI of the final executable; it only affects the ABI
of relocatable objects.  Using B<-mno-shared> generally makes
executables both smaller and quicker.

B<-mshared> is the default.


=item B<-mplt>


=item B<-mno-plt>

Assume (do not assume) that the static and dynamic linkers
support PLTs and copy relocations.  This option only affects
B<-mno-shared -mabicalls>.  For the n64 ABI, this option
has no effect without B<-msym32>.

You can make B<-mplt> the default by configuring
GCC with B<--with-mips-plt>.  The default is
B<-mno-plt> otherwise.


=item B<-mxgot>


=item B<-mno-xgot>

Lift (do not lift) the usual restrictions on the size of the global
offset table.

GCC normally uses a single instruction to load values from the GOT.
While this is relatively efficient, it only works if the GOT
is smaller than about 64k.  Anything larger causes the linker
to report an error such as:

	
	relocation truncated to fit: R_MIPS_GOT16 foobar


If this happens, you should recompile your code with B<-mxgot>.
This works with very large GOTs, although the code is also
less efficient, since it takes three instructions to fetch the
value of a global symbol.

Note that some linkers can create multiple GOTs.  If you have such a
linker, you should only need to use B<-mxgot> when a single object
file accesses more than 64k's worth of GOT entries.  Very few do.

These options have no effect unless GCC is generating position
independent code.


=item B<-mgp32>

Assume that general-purpose registers are 32 bits wide.


=item B<-mgp64>

Assume that general-purpose registers are 64 bits wide.


=item B<-mfp32>

Assume that floating-point registers are 32 bits wide.


=item B<-mfp64>

Assume that floating-point registers are 64 bits wide.


=item B<-mfpxx>

Do not assume the width of floating-point registers.


=item B<-mhard-float>

Use floating-point coprocessor instructions.


=item B<-msoft-float>

Do not use floating-point coprocessor instructions.  Implement
floating-point calculations using library calls instead.


=item B<-mno-float>

Equivalent to B<-msoft-float>, but additionally asserts that the
program being compiled does not perform any floating-point operations.
This option is presently supported only by some bare-metal MIPS
configurations, where it may select a special set of libraries
that lack all floating-point support (including, for example, the
floating-point C<printf> formats).  
If code compiled with B<-mno-float> accidentally contains
floating-point operations, it is likely to suffer a link-time
or run-time failure.


=item B<-msingle-float>

Assume that the floating-point coprocessor only supports single-precision
operations.


=item B<-mdouble-float>

Assume that the floating-point coprocessor supports double-precision
operations.  This is the default.


=item B<-modd-spreg>


=item B<-mno-odd-spreg>

Enable the use of odd-numbered single-precision floating-point registers
for the o32 ABI.  This is the default for processors that are known to
support these registers.  When using the o32 FPXX ABI, B<-mno-odd-spreg>
is set by default.


=item B<-mabs=2008>


=item B<-mabs=legacy>

These options control the treatment of the special not-a-number (NaN)
IEEE 754 floating-point data with the C<abs.I<fmt>> and
C<neg.I<fmt>> machine instructions.

By default or when B<-mabs=legacy> is used the legacy
treatment is selected.  In this case these instructions are considered
arithmetic and avoided where correct operation is required and the
input operand might be a NaN.  A longer sequence of instructions that
manipulate the sign bit of floating-point datum manually is used
instead unless the B<-ffinite-math-only> option has also been
specified.

The B<-mabs=2008> option selects the IEEE 754-2008 treatment.  In
this case these instructions are considered non-arithmetic and therefore
operating correctly in all cases, including in particular where the
input operand is a NaN.  These instructions are therefore always used
for the respective operations.


=item B<-mnan=2008>


=item B<-mnan=legacy>

These options control the encoding of the special not-a-number (NaN)
IEEE 754 floating-point data.

The B<-mnan=legacy> option selects the legacy encoding.  In this
case quiet NaNs (qNaNs) are denoted by the first bit of their trailing
significand field being 0, whereas signaling NaNs (sNaNs) are denoted
by the first bit of their trailing significand field being 1.

The B<-mnan=2008> option selects the IEEE 754-2008 encoding.  In
this case qNaNs are denoted by the first bit of their trailing
significand field being 1, whereas sNaNs are denoted by the first bit of
their trailing significand field being 0.

The default is B<-mnan=legacy> unless GCC has been configured with
B<--with-nan=2008>.


=item B<-mllsc>


=item B<-mno-llsc>

Use (do not use) B<ll>, B<sc>, and B<sync> instructions to
implement atomic memory built-in functions.  When neither option is
specified, GCC uses the instructions if the target architecture
supports them.

B<-mllsc> is useful if the runtime environment can emulate the
instructions and B<-mno-llsc> can be useful when compiling for
nonstandard ISAs.  You can make either option the default by
configuring GCC with B<--with-llsc> and B<--without-llsc>
respectively.  B<--with-llsc> is the default for some
configurations; see the installation documentation for details.


=item B<-mdsp>


=item B<-mno-dsp>

Use (do not use) revision 1 of the MIPS DSP ASE.
  This option defines the
preprocessor macro C<__mips_dsp>.  It also defines
C<__mips_dsp_rev> to 1.


=item B<-mdspr2>


=item B<-mno-dspr2>

Use (do not use) revision 2 of the MIPS DSP ASE.
  This option defines the
preprocessor macros C<__mips_dsp> and C<__mips_dspr2>.
It also defines C<__mips_dsp_rev> to 2.


=item B<-msmartmips>


=item B<-mno-smartmips>

Use (do not use) the MIPS SmartMIPS ASE.


=item B<-mpaired-single>


=item B<-mno-paired-single>

Use (do not use) paired-single floating-point instructions.
  This option requires
hardware floating-point support to be enabled.


=item B<-mdmx>


=item B<-mno-mdmx>

Use (do not use) MIPS Digital Media Extension instructions.
This option can only be used when generating 64-bit code and requires
hardware floating-point support to be enabled.


=item B<-mips3d>


=item B<-mno-mips3d>

Use (do not use) the MIPS-3D ASE.  
The option B<-mips3d> implies B<-mpaired-single>.


=item B<-mmicromips>


=item B<-mno-micromips>

Generate (do not generate) microMIPS code.

MicroMIPS code generation can also be controlled on a per-function basis
by means of C<micromips> and C<nomicromips> attributes.



=item B<-mmt>


=item B<-mno-mt>

Use (do not use) MT Multithreading instructions.


=item B<-mmcu>


=item B<-mno-mcu>

Use (do not use) the MIPS MCU ASE instructions.


=item B<-meva>


=item B<-mno-eva>

Use (do not use) the MIPS Enhanced Virtual Addressing instructions.


=item B<-mvirt>


=item B<-mno-virt>

Use (do not use) the MIPS Virtualization (VZ) instructions.


=item B<-mxpa>


=item B<-mno-xpa>

Use (do not use) the MIPS eXtended Physical Address (XPA) instructions.


=item B<-mcrc>


=item B<-mno-crc>

Use (do not use) the MIPS Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) instructions.


=item B<-mginv>


=item B<-mno-ginv>

Use (do not use) the MIPS Global INValidate (GINV) instructions.


=item B<-mloongson-mmi>


=item B<-mno-loongson-mmi>

Use (do not use) the MIPS Loongson MultiMedia extensions Instructions (MMI).


=item B<-mloongson-ext>


=item B<-mno-loongson-ext>

Use (do not use) the MIPS Loongson EXTensions (EXT) instructions.


=item B<-mloongson-ext2>


=item B<-mno-loongson-ext2>

Use (do not use) the MIPS Loongson EXTensions r2 (EXT2) instructions.


=item B<-mlong64>

Force C<long> types to be 64 bits wide.  See B<-mlong32> for
an explanation of the default and the way that the pointer size is
determined.


=item B<-mlong32>

Force C<long>, C<int>, and pointer types to be 32 bits wide.

The default size of C<int>s, C<long>s and pointers depends on
the ABI.  All the supported ABIs use 32-bit C<int>s.  The n64 ABI
uses 64-bit C<long>s, as does the 64-bit EABI; the others use
32-bit C<long>s.  Pointers are the same size as C<long>s,
or the same size as integer registers, whichever is smaller.


=item B<-msym32>


=item B<-mno-sym32>

Assume (do not assume) that all symbols have 32-bit values, regardless
of the selected ABI.  This option is useful in combination with
B<-mabi=64> and B<-mno-abicalls> because it allows GCC
to generate shorter and faster references to symbolic addresses.


=item B<-G> I<num>

Put definitions of externally-visible data in a small data section
if that data is no bigger than I<num> bytes.  GCC can then generate
more efficient accesses to the data; see B<-mgpopt> for details.

The default B<-G> option depends on the configuration.


=item B<-mlocal-sdata>


=item B<-mno-local-sdata>

Extend (do not extend) the B<-G> behavior to local data too,
such as to static variables in C.  B<-mlocal-sdata> is the
default for all configurations.

If the linker complains that an application is using too much small data,
you might want to try rebuilding the less performance-critical parts with
B<-mno-local-sdata>.  You might also want to build large
libraries with B<-mno-local-sdata>, so that the libraries leave
more room for the main program.


=item B<-mextern-sdata>


=item B<-mno-extern-sdata>

Assume (do not assume) that externally-defined data is in
a small data section if the size of that data is within the B<-G> limit.
B<-mextern-sdata> is the default for all configurations.

If you compile a module I<Mod> with B<-mextern-sdata> B<-G>
I<num> B<-mgpopt>, and I<Mod> references a variable I<Var>
that is no bigger than I<num> bytes, you must make sure that I<Var>
is placed in a small data section.  If I<Var> is defined by another
module, you must either compile that module with a high-enough
B<-G> setting or attach a C<section> attribute to I<Var>'s
definition.  If I<Var> is common, you must link the application
with a high-enough B<-G> setting.

The easiest way of satisfying these restrictions is to compile
and link every module with the same B<-G> option.  However,
you may wish to build a library that supports several different
small data limits.  You can do this by compiling the library with
the highest supported B<-G> setting and additionally using
B<-mno-extern-sdata> to stop the library from making assumptions
about externally-defined data.


=item B<-mgpopt>


=item B<-mno-gpopt>

Use (do not use) GP-relative accesses for symbols that are known to be
in a small data section; see B<-G>, B<-mlocal-sdata> and
B<-mextern-sdata>.  B<-mgpopt> is the default for all
configurations.

B<-mno-gpopt> is useful for cases where the C<$gp> register
might not hold the value of C<_gp>.  For example, if the code is
part of a library that might be used in a boot monitor, programs that
call boot monitor routines pass an unknown value in C<$gp>.
(In such situations, the boot monitor itself is usually compiled
with B<-G0>.)

B<-mno-gpopt> implies B<-mno-local-sdata> and
B<-mno-extern-sdata>.


=item B<-membedded-data>


=item B<-mno-embedded-data>

Allocate variables to the read-only data section first if possible, then
next in the small data section if possible, otherwise in data.  This gives
slightly slower code than the default, but reduces the amount of RAM required
when executing, and thus may be preferred for some embedded systems.


=item B<-muninit-const-in-rodata>


=item B<-mno-uninit-const-in-rodata>

Put uninitialized C<const> variables in the read-only data section.
This option is only meaningful in conjunction with B<-membedded-data>.


=item B<-mcode-readable=>I<setting>

Specify whether GCC may generate code that reads from executable sections.
There are three possible settings:


=over 4


=item B<-mcode-readable=yes>

Instructions may freely access executable sections.  This is the
default setting.


=item B<-mcode-readable=pcrel>

MIPS16 PC-relative load instructions can access executable sections,
but other instructions must not do so.  This option is useful on 4KSc
and 4KSd processors when the code TLBs have the Read Inhibit bit set.
It is also useful on processors that can be configured to have a dual
instruction/data SRAM interface and that, like the M4K, automatically
redirect PC-relative loads to the instruction RAM.


=item B<-mcode-readable=no>

Instructions must not access executable sections.  This option can be
useful on targets that are configured to have a dual instruction/data
SRAM interface but that (unlike the M4K) do not automatically redirect
PC-relative loads to the instruction RAM.

=back



=item B<-msplit-addresses>


=item B<-mno-split-addresses>

Enable (disable) use of the C<%hi()> and C<%lo()> assembler
relocation operators.  This option has been superseded by
B<-mexplicit-relocs> but is retained for backwards compatibility.


=item B<-mexplicit-relocs>


=item B<-mno-explicit-relocs>

Use (do not use) assembler relocation operators when dealing with symbolic
addresses.  The alternative, selected by B<-mno-explicit-relocs>,
is to use assembler macros instead.

B<-mexplicit-relocs> is the default if GCC was configured
to use an assembler that supports relocation operators.


=item B<-mcheck-zero-division>


=item B<-mno-check-zero-division>

Trap (do not trap) on integer division by zero.

The default is B<-mcheck-zero-division>.


=item B<-mdivide-traps>


=item B<-mdivide-breaks>

MIPS systems check for division by zero by generating either a
conditional trap or a break instruction.  Using traps results in
smaller code, but is only supported on MIPS II and later.  Also, some
versions of the Linux kernel have a bug that prevents trap from
generating the proper signal (C<SIGFPE>).  Use B<-mdivide-traps> to
allow conditional traps on architectures that support them and
B<-mdivide-breaks> to force the use of breaks.

The default is usually B<-mdivide-traps>, but this can be
overridden at configure time using B<--with-divide=breaks>.
Divide-by-zero checks can be completely disabled using
B<-mno-check-zero-division>.


=item B<-mload-store-pairs>


=item B<-mno-load-store-pairs>

Enable (disable) an optimization that pairs consecutive load or store
instructions to enable load/store bonding.  This option is enabled by
default but only takes effect when the selected architecture is known
to support bonding.


=item B<-mmemcpy>


=item B<-mno-memcpy>

Force (do not force) the use of C<memcpy> for non-trivial block
moves.  The default is B<-mno-memcpy>, which allows GCC to inline
most constant-sized copies.


=item B<-mlong-calls>


=item B<-mno-long-calls>

Disable (do not disable) use of the C<jal> instruction.  Calling
functions using C<jal> is more efficient but requires the caller
and callee to be in the same 256 megabyte segment.

This option has no effect on abicalls code.  The default is
B<-mno-long-calls>.


=item B<-mmad>


=item B<-mno-mad>

Enable (disable) use of the C<mad>, C<madu> and C<mul>
instructions, as provided by the R4650 ISA.


=item B<-mimadd>


=item B<-mno-imadd>

Enable (disable) use of the C<madd> and C<msub> integer
instructions.  The default is B<-mimadd> on architectures
that support C<madd> and C<msub> except for the 74k 
architecture where it was found to generate slower code.


=item B<-mfused-madd>


=item B<-mno-fused-madd>

Enable (disable) use of the floating-point multiply-accumulate
instructions, when they are available.  The default is
B<-mfused-madd>.

On the R8000 CPU when multiply-accumulate instructions are used,
the intermediate product is calculated to infinite precision
and is not subject to the FCSR Flush to Zero bit.  This may be
undesirable in some circumstances.  On other processors the result
is numerically identical to the equivalent computation using
separate multiply, add, subtract and negate instructions.


=item B<-nocpp>

Tell the MIPS assembler to not run its preprocessor over user
assembler files (with a B<.s> suffix) when assembling them.


=item B<-mfix-24k>


=item B<-mno-fix-24k>

Work around the 24K E48 (lost data on stores during refill) errata.
The workarounds are implemented by the assembler rather than by GCC.


=item B<-mfix-r4000>


=item B<-mno-fix-r4000>

Work around certain R4000 CPU errata:

=over 4


=item Z<>-

A double-word or a variable shift may give an incorrect result if executed
immediately after starting an integer division.

=item Z<>-

A double-word or a variable shift may give an incorrect result if executed
while an integer multiplication is in progress.

=item Z<>-

An integer division may give an incorrect result if started in a delay slot
of a taken branch or a jump.

=back



=item B<-mfix-r4400>


=item B<-mno-fix-r4400>

Work around certain R4400 CPU errata:

=over 4


=item Z<>-

A double-word or a variable shift may give an incorrect result if executed
immediately after starting an integer division.

=back



=item B<-mfix-r10000>


=item B<-mno-fix-r10000>

Work around certain R10000 errata:

=over 4


=item Z<>-

C<ll>/C<sc> sequences may not behave atomically on revisions
prior to 3.0.  They may deadlock on revisions 2.6 and earlier.

=back


This option can only be used if the target architecture supports
branch-likely instructions.  B<-mfix-r10000> is the default when
B<-march=r10000> is used; B<-mno-fix-r10000> is the default
otherwise.


=item B<-mfix-r5900>


=item B<-mno-fix-r5900>

Do not attempt to schedule the preceding instruction into the delay slot
of a branch instruction placed at the end of a short loop of six
instructions or fewer and always schedule a C<nop> instruction there
instead.  The short loop bug under certain conditions causes loops to
execute only once or twice, due to a hardware bug in the R5900 chip.  The
workaround is implemented by the assembler rather than by GCC.


=item B<-mfix-rm7000>


=item B<-mno-fix-rm7000>

Work around the RM7000 C<dmult>/C<dmultu> errata.  The
workarounds are implemented by the assembler rather than by GCC.


=item B<-mfix-vr4120>


=item B<-mno-fix-vr4120>

Work around certain VR4120 errata:

=over 4


=item Z<>-

C<dmultu> does not always produce the correct result.

=item Z<>-

C<div> and C<ddiv> do not always produce the correct result if one
of the operands is negative.

=back

The workarounds for the division errata rely on special functions in
F<libgcc.a>.  At present, these functions are only provided by
the C<mips64vr*-elf> configurations.

Other VR4120 errata require a NOP to be inserted between certain pairs of
instructions.  These errata are handled by the assembler, not by GCC itself.


=item B<-mfix-vr4130>

Work around the VR4130 C<mflo>/C<mfhi> errata.  The
workarounds are implemented by the assembler rather than by GCC,
although GCC avoids using C<mflo> and C<mfhi> if the
VR4130 C<macc>, C<macchi>, C<dmacc> and C<dmacchi>
instructions are available instead.


=item B<-mfix-sb1>


=item B<-mno-fix-sb1>

Work around certain SB-1 CPU core errata.
(This flag currently works around the SB-1 revision 2
"F1" and "F2" floating-point errata.)


=item B<-mr10k-cache-barrier=>I<setting>

Specify whether GCC should insert cache barriers to avoid the
side effects of speculation on R10K processors.

In common with many processors, the R10K tries to predict the outcome
of a conditional branch and speculatively executes instructions from
the "taken" branch.  It later aborts these instructions if the
predicted outcome is wrong.  However, on the R10K, even aborted
instructions can have side effects.

This problem only affects kernel stores and, depending on the system,
kernel loads.  As an example, a speculatively-executed store may load
the target memory into cache and mark the cache line as dirty, even if
the store itself is later aborted.  If a DMA operation writes to the
same area of memory before the "dirty" line is flushed, the cached
data overwrites the DMA-ed data.  See the R10K processor manual
for a full description, including other potential problems.

One workaround is to insert cache barrier instructions before every memory
access that might be speculatively executed and that might have side
effects even if aborted.  B<-mr10k-cache-barrier=>I<setting>
controls GCC's implementation of this workaround.  It assumes that
aborted accesses to any byte in the following regions does not have
side effects:


=over 4


=item Z<>1.

the memory occupied by the current function's stack frame;


=item Z<>2.

the memory occupied by an incoming stack argument;


=item Z<>3.

the memory occupied by an object with a link-time-constant address.

=back


It is the kernel's responsibility to ensure that speculative
accesses to these regions are indeed safe.

If the input program contains a function declaration such as:

	
	void foo (void);


then the implementation of C<foo> must allow C<j foo> and
C<jal foo> to be executed speculatively.  GCC honors this
restriction for functions it compiles itself.  It expects non-GCC
functions (such as hand-written assembly code) to do the same.

The option has three forms:


=over 4


=item B<-mr10k-cache-barrier=load-store>

Insert a cache barrier before a load or store that might be
speculatively executed and that might have side effects even
if aborted.


=item B<-mr10k-cache-barrier=store>

Insert a cache barrier before a store that might be speculatively
executed and that might have side effects even if aborted.


=item B<-mr10k-cache-barrier=none>

Disable the insertion of cache barriers.  This is the default setting.

=back



=item B<-mflush-func=>I<func>


=item B<-mno-flush-func>

Specifies the function to call to flush the I and D caches, or to not
call any such function.  If called, the function must take the same
arguments as the common C<_flush_func>, that is, the address of the
memory range for which the cache is being flushed, the size of the
memory range, and the number 3 (to flush both caches).  The default
depends on the target GCC was configured for, but commonly is either
C<_flush_func> or C<__cpu_flush>.


=item B<mbranch-cost=>I<num>

Set the cost of branches to roughly I<num> "simple" instructions.
This cost is only a heuristic and is not guaranteed to produce
consistent results across releases.  A zero cost redundantly selects
the default, which is based on the B<-mtune> setting.


=item B<-mbranch-likely>


=item B<-mno-branch-likely>

Enable or disable use of Branch Likely instructions, regardless of the
default for the selected architecture.  By default, Branch Likely
instructions may be generated if they are supported by the selected
architecture.  An exception is for the MIPS32 and MIPS64 architectures
and processors that implement those architectures; for those, Branch
Likely instructions are not be generated by default because the MIPS32
and MIPS64 architectures specifically deprecate their use.


=item B<-mcompact-branches=never>


=item B<-mcompact-branches=optimal>


=item B<-mcompact-branches=always>

These options control which form of branches will be generated.  The
default is B<-mcompact-branches=optimal>.

The B<-mcompact-branches=never> option ensures that compact branch
instructions will never be generated.

The B<-mcompact-branches=always> option ensures that a compact
branch instruction will be generated if available.  If a compact branch
instruction is not available, a delay slot form of the branch will be
used instead.

This option is supported from MIPS Release 6 onwards.

The B<-mcompact-branches=optimal> option will cause a delay slot
branch to be used if one is available in the current ISA and the delay
slot is successfully filled.  If the delay slot is not filled, a compact
branch will be chosen if one is available.


=item B<-mfp-exceptions>


=item B<-mno-fp-exceptions>

Specifies whether FP exceptions are enabled.  This affects how
FP instructions are scheduled for some processors.
The default is that FP exceptions are
enabled.

For instance, on the SB-1, if FP exceptions are disabled, and we are emitting
64-bit code, then we can use both FP pipes.  Otherwise, we can only use one
FP pipe.


=item B<-mvr4130-align>


=item B<-mno-vr4130-align>

The VR4130 pipeline is two-way superscalar, but can only issue two
instructions together if the first one is 8-byte aligned.  When this
option is enabled, GCC aligns pairs of instructions that it
thinks should execute in parallel.

This option only has an effect when optimizing for the VR4130.
It normally makes code faster, but at the expense of making it bigger.
It is enabled by default at optimization level B<-O3>.


=item B<-msynci>


=item B<-mno-synci>

Enable (disable) generation of C<synci> instructions on
architectures that support it.  The C<synci> instructions (if
enabled) are generated when C<__builtin___clear_cache> is
compiled.

This option defaults to B<-mno-synci>, but the default can be
overridden by configuring GCC with B<--with-synci>.

When compiling code for single processor systems, it is generally safe
to use C<synci>.  However, on many multi-core (SMP) systems, it
does not invalidate the instruction caches on all cores and may lead
to undefined behavior.


=item B<-mrelax-pic-calls>


=item B<-mno-relax-pic-calls>

Try to turn PIC calls that are normally dispatched via register
C<$25> into direct calls.  This is only possible if the linker can
resolve the destination at link time and if the destination is within
range for a direct call.

B<-mrelax-pic-calls> is the default if GCC was configured to use
an assembler and a linker that support the C<.reloc> assembly
directive and B<-mexplicit-relocs> is in effect.  With
B<-mno-explicit-relocs>, this optimization can be performed by the
assembler and the linker alone without help from the compiler.


=item B<-mmcount-ra-address>


=item B<-mno-mcount-ra-address>

Emit (do not emit) code that allows C<_mcount> to modify the
calling function's return address.  When enabled, this option extends
the usual C<_mcount> interface with a new I<ra-address>
parameter, which has type C<intptr_t *> and is passed in register
C<$12>.  C<_mcount> can then modify the return address by
doing both of the following:

=over 4


=item Z<>*

Returning the new address in register C<$31>.

=item Z<>*

Storing the new address in C<*I<ra-address>>,
if I<ra-address> is nonnull.

=back


The default is B<-mno-mcount-ra-address>.


=item B<-mframe-header-opt>


=item B<-mno-frame-header-opt>

Enable (disable) frame header optimization in the o32 ABI.  When using the
o32 ABI, calling functions will allocate 16 bytes on the stack for the called
function to write out register arguments.  When enabled, this optimization
will suppress the allocation of the frame header if it can be determined that
it is unused.

This optimization is off by default at all optimization levels.


=item B<-mlxc1-sxc1>


=item B<-mno-lxc1-sxc1>

When applicable, enable (disable) the generation of C<lwxc1>,
C<swxc1>, C<ldxc1>, C<sdxc1> instructions.  Enabled by default.


=item B<-mmadd4>


=item B<-mno-madd4>

When applicable, enable (disable) the generation of 4-operand C<madd.s>,
C<madd.d> and related instructions.  Enabled by default.


=back



=head3 MMIX Options


These options are defined for the MMIX:


=over 4


=item B<-mlibfuncs>


=item B<-mno-libfuncs>

Specify that intrinsic library functions are being compiled, passing all
values in registers, no matter the size.


=item B<-mepsilon>


=item B<-mno-epsilon>

Generate floating-point comparison instructions that compare with respect
to the C<rE> epsilon register.


=item B<-mabi=mmixware>


=item B<-mabi=gnu>

Generate code that passes function parameters and return values that (in
the called function) are seen as registers C<$0> and up, as opposed to
the GNU ABI which uses global registers C<$231> and up.


=item B<-mzero-extend>


=item B<-mno-zero-extend>

When reading data from memory in sizes shorter than 64 bits, use (do not
use) zero-extending load instructions by default, rather than
sign-extending ones.


=item B<-mknuthdiv>


=item B<-mno-knuthdiv>

Make the result of a division yielding a remainder have the same sign as
the divisor.  With the default, B<-mno-knuthdiv>, the sign of the
remainder follows the sign of the dividend.  Both methods are
arithmetically valid, the latter being almost exclusively used.


=item B<-mtoplevel-symbols>


=item B<-mno-toplevel-symbols>

Prepend (do not prepend) a B<:> to all global symbols, so the assembly
code can be used with the C<PREFIX> assembly directive.


=item B<-melf>

Generate an executable in the ELF format, rather than the default
B<mmo> format used by the B<mmix> simulator.


=item B<-mbranch-predict>


=item B<-mno-branch-predict>

Use (do not use) the probable-branch instructions, when static branch
prediction indicates a probable branch.


=item B<-mbase-addresses>


=item B<-mno-base-addresses>

Generate (do not generate) code that uses I<base addresses>.  Using a
base address automatically generates a request (handled by the assembler
and the linker) for a constant to be set up in a global register.  The
register is used for one or more base address requests within the range 0
to 255 from the value held in the register.  The generally leads to short
and fast code, but the number of different data items that can be
addressed is limited.  This means that a program that uses lots of static
data may require B<-mno-base-addresses>.


=item B<-msingle-exit>


=item B<-mno-single-exit>

Force (do not force) generated code to have a single exit point in each
function.

=back



=head3 MN10300 Options


These B<-m> options are defined for Matsushita MN10300 architectures:


=over 4


=item B<-mmult-bug>

Generate code to avoid bugs in the multiply instructions for the MN10300
processors.  This is the default.


=item B<-mno-mult-bug>

Do not generate code to avoid bugs in the multiply instructions for the
MN10300 processors.


=item B<-mam33>

Generate code using features specific to the AM33 processor.


=item B<-mno-am33>

Do not generate code using features specific to the AM33 processor.  This
is the default.


=item B<-mam33-2>

Generate code using features specific to the AM33/2.0 processor.


=item B<-mam34>

Generate code using features specific to the AM34 processor.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu-type>

Use the timing characteristics of the indicated CPU type when
scheduling instructions.  This does not change the targeted processor
type.  The CPU type must be one of B<mn10300>, B<am33>,
B<am33-2> or B<am34>.


=item B<-mreturn-pointer-on-d0>

When generating a function that returns a pointer, return the pointer
in both C<a0> and C<d0>.  Otherwise, the pointer is returned
only in C<a0>, and attempts to call such functions without a prototype
result in errors.  Note that this option is on by default; use
B<-mno-return-pointer-on-d0> to disable it.


=item B<-mno-crt0>

Do not link in the C run-time initialization object file.


=item B<-mrelax>

Indicate to the linker that it should perform a relaxation optimization pass
to shorten branches, calls and absolute memory addresses.  This option only
has an effect when used on the command line for the final link step.

This option makes symbolic debugging impossible.


=item B<-mliw>

Allow the compiler to generate I<Long Instruction Word>
instructions if the target is the B<AM33> or later.  This is the
default.  This option defines the preprocessor macro C<__LIW__>.


=item B<-mno-liw>

Do not allow the compiler to generate I<Long Instruction Word>
instructions.  This option defines the preprocessor macro
C<__NO_LIW__>.


=item B<-msetlb>

Allow the compiler to generate the I<SETLB> and I<Lcc>
instructions if the target is the B<AM33> or later.  This is the
default.  This option defines the preprocessor macro C<__SETLB__>.


=item B<-mno-setlb>

Do not allow the compiler to generate I<SETLB> or I<Lcc>
instructions.  This option defines the preprocessor macro
C<__NO_SETLB__>.


=back



=head3 Moxie Options



=over 4



=item B<-meb>

Generate big-endian code.  This is the default for B<moxie-*-*>
configurations.


=item B<-mel>

Generate little-endian code.


=item B<-mmul.x>

Generate mul.x and umul.x instructions.  This is the default for
B<moxiebox-*-*> configurations.


=item B<-mno-crt0>

Do not link in the C run-time initialization object file.


=back



=head3 MSP430 Options


These options are defined for the MSP430:


=over 4



=item B<-masm-hex>

Force assembly output to always use hex constants.  Normally such
constants are signed decimals, but this option is available for
testsuite and/or aesthetic purposes.


=item B<-mmcu=>

Select the MCU to target.  This is used to create a C preprocessor
symbol based upon the MCU name, converted to upper case and pre- and
post-fixed with B<__>.  This in turn is used by the
F<msp430.h> header file to select an MCU-specific supplementary
header file.

The option also sets the ISA to use.  If the MCU name is one that is
known to only support the 430 ISA then that is selected, otherwise the
430X ISA is selected.  A generic MCU name of B<msp430> can also be
used to select the 430 ISA.  Similarly the generic B<msp430x> MCU
name selects the 430X ISA.

In addition an MCU-specific linker script is added to the linker
command line.  The script's name is the name of the MCU with
F<.ld> appended.  Thus specifying B<-mmcu=xxx> on the B<gcc>
command line defines the C preprocessor symbol C<__XXX__> and
cause the linker to search for a script called F<xxx.ld>.

This option is also passed on to the assembler.


=item B<-mwarn-mcu>


=item B<-mno-warn-mcu>

This option enables or disables warnings about conflicts between the
MCU name specified by the B<-mmcu> option and the ISA set by the
B<-mcpu> option and/or the hardware multiply support set by the
B<-mhwmult> option.  It also toggles warnings about unrecognized
MCU names.  This option is on by default.


=item B<-mcpu=>

Specifies the ISA to use.  Accepted values are B<msp430>,
B<msp430x> and B<msp430xv2>.  This option is deprecated.  The
B<-mmcu=> option should be used to select the ISA.


=item B<-msim>

Link to the simulator runtime libraries and linker script.  Overrides
any scripts that would be selected by the B<-mmcu=> option.


=item B<-mlarge>

Use large-model addressing (20-bit pointers, 32-bit C<size_t>).


=item B<-msmall>

Use small-model addressing (16-bit pointers, 16-bit C<size_t>).


=item B<-mrelax>

This option is passed to the assembler and linker, and allows the
linker to perform certain optimizations that cannot be done until
the final link.


=item B<mhwmult=>

Describes the type of hardware multiply supported by the target.
Accepted values are B<none> for no hardware multiply, B<16bit>
for the original 16-bit-only multiply supported by early MCUs.
B<32bit> for the 16/32-bit multiply supported by later MCUs and
B<f5series> for the 16/32-bit multiply supported by F5-series MCUs.
A value of B<auto> can also be given.  This tells GCC to deduce
the hardware multiply support based upon the MCU name provided by the
B<-mmcu> option.  If no B<-mmcu> option is specified or if
the MCU name is not recognized then no hardware multiply support is
assumed.  C<auto> is the default setting.

Hardware multiplies are normally performed by calling a library
routine.  This saves space in the generated code.  When compiling at
B<-O3> or higher however the hardware multiplier is invoked
inline.  This makes for bigger, but faster code.

The hardware multiply routines disable interrupts whilst running and
restore the previous interrupt state when they finish.  This makes
them safe to use inside interrupt handlers as well as in normal code.


=item B<-minrt>

Enable the use of a minimum runtime environment - no static
initializers or constructors.  This is intended for memory-constrained
devices.  The compiler includes special symbols in some objects
that tell the linker and runtime which code fragments are required.


=item B<-mcode-region=>


=item B<-mdata-region=>

These options tell the compiler where to place functions and data that
do not have one of the C<lower>, C<upper>, C<either> or
C<section> attributes.  Possible values are C<lower>,
C<upper>, C<either> or C<any>.  The first three behave
like the corresponding attribute.  The fourth possible value -
C<any> - is the default.  It leaves placement entirely up to the
linker script and how it assigns the standard sections
(C<.text>, C<.data>, etc) to the memory regions.


=item B<-msilicon-errata=>

This option passes on a request to assembler to enable the fixes for
the named silicon errata.


=item B<-msilicon-errata-warn=>

This option passes on a request to the assembler to enable warning
messages when a silicon errata might need to be applied.


=back



=head3 NDS32 Options


These options are defined for NDS32 implementations:


=over 4



=item B<-mbig-endian>

Generate code in big-endian mode.


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

Generate code in little-endian mode.


=item B<-mreduced-regs>

Use reduced-set registers for register allocation.


=item B<-mfull-regs>

Use full-set registers for register allocation.


=item B<-mcmov>

Generate conditional move instructions.


=item B<-mno-cmov>

Do not generate conditional move instructions.


=item B<-mext-perf>

Generate performance extension instructions.


=item B<-mno-ext-perf>

Do not generate performance extension instructions.


=item B<-mext-perf2>

Generate performance extension 2 instructions.


=item B<-mno-ext-perf2>

Do not generate performance extension 2 instructions.


=item B<-mext-string>

Generate string extension instructions.


=item B<-mno-ext-string>

Do not generate string extension instructions.


=item B<-mv3push>

Generate v3 push25/pop25 instructions.


=item B<-mno-v3push>

Do not generate v3 push25/pop25 instructions.


=item B<-m16-bit>

Generate 16-bit instructions.


=item B<-mno-16-bit>

Do not generate 16-bit instructions.


=item B<-misr-vector-size=>I<num>

Specify the size of each interrupt vector, which must be 4 or 16.


=item B<-mcache-block-size=>I<num>

Specify the size of each cache block,
which must be a power of 2 between 4 and 512.


=item B<-march=>I<arch>

Specify the name of the target architecture.


=item B<-mcmodel=>I<code-model>

Set the code model to one of

=over 4


=item B<small>

All the data and read-only data segments must be within 512KB addressing space.
The text segment must be within 16MB addressing space.

=item B<medium>

The data segment must be within 512KB while the read-only data segment can be
within 4GB addressing space.  The text segment should be still within 16MB
addressing space.

=item B<large>

All the text and data segments can be within 4GB addressing space.

=back



=item B<-mctor-dtor>

Enable constructor/destructor feature.


=item B<-mrelax>

Guide linker to relax instructions.


=back



=head3 Nios II Options


These are the options defined for the Altera Nios II processor.


=over 4



=item B<-G> I<num>

Put global and static objects less than or equal to I<num> bytes
into the small data or BSS sections instead of the normal data or BSS
sections.  The default value of I<num> is 8.


=item B<-mgpopt=>I<option>


=item B<-mgpopt>


=item B<-mno-gpopt>

Generate (do not generate) GP-relative accesses.  The following 
I<option> names are recognized:


=over 4



=item B<none>

Do not generate GP-relative accesses.


=item B<local>

Generate GP-relative accesses for small data objects that are not 
external, weak, or uninitialized common symbols.  
Also use GP-relative addressing for objects that
have been explicitly placed in a small data section via a C<section>
attribute.


=item B<global>

As for B<local>, but also generate GP-relative accesses for
small data objects that are external, weak, or common.  If you use this option,
you must ensure that all parts of your program (including libraries) are
compiled with the same B<-G> setting.


=item B<data>

Generate GP-relative accesses for all data objects in the program.  If you
use this option, the entire data and BSS segments
of your program must fit in 64K of memory and you must use an appropriate
linker script to allocate them within the addressable range of the
global pointer.


=item B<all>

Generate GP-relative addresses for function pointers as well as data
pointers.  If you use this option, the entire text, data, and BSS segments
of your program must fit in 64K of memory and you must use an appropriate
linker script to allocate them within the addressable range of the
global pointer.


=back


B<-mgpopt> is equivalent to B<-mgpopt=local>, and
B<-mno-gpopt> is equivalent to B<-mgpopt=none>.

The default is B<-mgpopt> except when B<-fpic> or
B<-fPIC> is specified to generate position-independent code.
Note that the Nios II ABI does not permit GP-relative accesses from
shared libraries.

You may need to specify B<-mno-gpopt> explicitly when building
programs that include large amounts of small data, including large
GOT data sections.  In this case, the 16-bit offset for GP-relative
addressing may not be large enough to allow access to the entire 
small data section.


=item B<-mgprel-sec=>I<regexp>

This option specifies additional section names that can be accessed via
GP-relative addressing.  It is most useful in conjunction with 
C<section> attributes on variable declarations and a custom linker script.  
The I<regexp> is a POSIX Extended Regular Expression.

This option does not affect the behavior of the B<-G> option, and 
the specified sections are in addition to the standard C<.sdata>
and C<.sbss> small-data sections that are recognized by B<-mgpopt>.


=item B<-mr0rel-sec=>I<regexp>

This option specifies names of sections that can be accessed via a 
16-bit offset from C<r0>; that is, in the low 32K or high 32K 
of the 32-bit address space.  It is most useful in conjunction with 
C<section> attributes on variable declarations and a custom linker script.  
The I<regexp> is a POSIX Extended Regular Expression.

In contrast to the use of GP-relative addressing for small data, 
zero-based addressing is never generated by default and there are no 
conventional section names used in standard linker scripts for sections
in the low or high areas of memory.


=item B<-mel>


=item B<-meb>

Generate little-endian (default) or big-endian (experimental) code,
respectively.


=item B<-march=>I<arch>

This specifies the name of the target Nios II architecture.  GCC uses this
name to determine what kind of instructions it can emit when generating
assembly code.  Permissible names are: B<r1>, B<r2>.

The preprocessor macro C<__nios2_arch__> is available to programs,
with value 1 or 2, indicating the targeted ISA level.


=item B<-mbypass-cache>


=item B<-mno-bypass-cache>

Force all load and store instructions to always bypass cache by 
using I/O variants of the instructions. The default is not to
bypass the cache.


=item B<-mno-cache-volatile> 


=item B<-mcache-volatile>       

Volatile memory access bypass the cache using the I/O variants of 
the load and store instructions. The default is not to bypass the cache.


=item B<-mno-fast-sw-div>


=item B<-mfast-sw-div>

Do not use table-based fast divide for small numbers. The default 
is to use the fast divide at B<-O3> and above.


=item B<-mno-hw-mul>


=item B<-mhw-mul>


=item B<-mno-hw-mulx>


=item B<-mhw-mulx>


=item B<-mno-hw-div>


=item B<-mhw-div>

Enable or disable emitting C<mul>, C<mulx> and C<div> family of 
instructions by the compiler. The default is to emit C<mul>
and not emit C<div> and C<mulx>.


=item B<-mbmx>


=item B<-mno-bmx>


=item B<-mcdx>


=item B<-mno-cdx>

Enable or disable generation of Nios II R2 BMX (bit manipulation) and
CDX (code density) instructions.  Enabling these instructions also
requires B<-march=r2>.  Since these instructions are optional
extensions to the R2 architecture, the default is not to emit them.


=item B<-mcustom->I<insn>B<=>I<N>


=item B<-mno-custom->I<insn>

Each B<-mcustom->I<insn>B<=>I<N> option enables use of a
custom instruction with encoding I<N> when generating code that uses 
I<insn>.  For example, B<-mcustom-fadds=253> generates custom
instruction 253 for single-precision floating-point add operations instead
of the default behavior of using a library call.

The following values of I<insn> are supported.  Except as otherwise
noted, floating-point operations are expected to be implemented with
normal IEEE 754 semantics and correspond directly to the C operators or the
equivalent GCC built-in functions.

Single-precision floating point:

=over 4



=item B<fadds>, B<fsubs>, B<fdivs>, B<fmuls>

Binary arithmetic operations.


=item B<fnegs>

Unary negation.


=item B<fabss>

Unary absolute value.


=item B<fcmpeqs>, B<fcmpges>, B<fcmpgts>, B<fcmples>, B<fcmplts>, B<fcmpnes>

Comparison operations.


=item B<fmins>, B<fmaxs>

Floating-point minimum and maximum.  These instructions are only
generated if B<-ffinite-math-only> is specified.
