=item B<fsqrts>

Unary square root operation.


=item B<fcoss>, B<fsins>, B<ftans>, B<fatans>, B<fexps>, B<flogs>

Floating-point trigonometric and exponential functions.  These instructions
are only generated if B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is also specified.


=back


Double-precision floating point:

=over 4



=item B<faddd>, B<fsubd>, B<fdivd>, B<fmuld>

Binary arithmetic operations.


=item B<fnegd>

Unary negation.


=item B<fabsd>

Unary absolute value.


=item B<fcmpeqd>, B<fcmpged>, B<fcmpgtd>, B<fcmpled>, B<fcmpltd>, B<fcmpned>

Comparison operations.


=item B<fmind>, B<fmaxd>

Double-precision minimum and maximum.  These instructions are only
generated if B<-ffinite-math-only> is specified.


=item B<fsqrtd>

Unary square root operation.


=item B<fcosd>, B<fsind>, B<ftand>, B<fatand>, B<fexpd>, B<flogd>

Double-precision trigonometric and exponential functions.  These instructions
are only generated if B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is also specified.


=back


Conversions:

=over 4


=item B<fextsd>

Conversion from single precision to double precision.


=item B<ftruncds>

Conversion from double precision to single precision.


=item B<fixsi>, B<fixsu>, B<fixdi>, B<fixdu>

Conversion from floating point to signed or unsigned integer types, with
truncation towards zero.


=item B<round>

Conversion from single-precision floating point to signed integer,
rounding to the nearest integer and ties away from zero.
This corresponds to the C<__builtin_lroundf> function when
B<-fno-math-errno> is used.


=item B<floatis>, B<floatus>, B<floatid>, B<floatud>

Conversion from signed or unsigned integer types to floating-point types.


=back


In addition, all of the following transfer instructions for internal
registers X and Y must be provided to use any of the double-precision
floating-point instructions.  Custom instructions taking two
double-precision source operands expect the first operand in the
64-bit register X.  The other operand (or only operand of a unary
operation) is given to the custom arithmetic instruction with the
least significant half in source register I<src1> and the most
significant half in I<src2>.  A custom instruction that returns a
double-precision result returns the most significant 32 bits in the
destination register and the other half in 32-bit register Y.  
GCC automatically generates the necessary code sequences to write
register X and/or read register Y when double-precision floating-point
instructions are used.


=over 4



=item B<fwrx>

Write I<src1> into the least significant half of X and I<src2> into
the most significant half of X.


=item B<fwry>

Write I<src1> into Y.


=item B<frdxhi>, B<frdxlo>

Read the most or least (respectively) significant half of X and store it in
I<dest>.


=item B<frdy>

Read the value of Y and store it into I<dest>.

=back


Note that you can gain more local control over generation of Nios II custom
instructions by using the C<target("custom-I<insn>=I<N>")>
and C<target("no-custom-I<insn>")> function attributes
or pragmas.


=item B<-mcustom-fpu-cfg=>I<name>


This option enables a predefined, named set of custom instruction encodings
(see B<-mcustom->I<insn> above).  
Currently, the following sets are defined:

B<-mcustom-fpu-cfg=60-1> is equivalent to:
B<-mcustom-fmuls=252 
-mcustom-fadds=253 
-mcustom-fsubs=254 
-fsingle-precision-constant>

B<-mcustom-fpu-cfg=60-2> is equivalent to:
B<-mcustom-fmuls=252 
-mcustom-fadds=253 
-mcustom-fsubs=254 
-mcustom-fdivs=255 
-fsingle-precision-constant>

B<-mcustom-fpu-cfg=72-3> is equivalent to:
B<-mcustom-floatus=243 
-mcustom-fixsi=244 
-mcustom-floatis=245 
-mcustom-fcmpgts=246 
-mcustom-fcmples=249 
-mcustom-fcmpeqs=250 
-mcustom-fcmpnes=251 
-mcustom-fmuls=252 
-mcustom-fadds=253 
-mcustom-fsubs=254 
-mcustom-fdivs=255 
-fsingle-precision-constant>

Custom instruction assignments given by individual
B<-mcustom->I<insn>B<=> options override those given by
B<-mcustom-fpu-cfg=>, regardless of the
order of the options on the command line.

Note that you can gain more local control over selection of a FPU
configuration by using the C<target("custom-fpu-cfg=I<name>")>
function attribute
or pragma.


=back


These additional B<-m> options are available for the Altera Nios II
ELF (bare-metal) target:


=over 4



=item B<-mhal>

Link with HAL BSP.  This suppresses linking with the GCC-provided C runtime
startup and termination code, and is typically used in conjunction with
B<-msys-crt0=> to specify the location of the alternate startup code
provided by the HAL BSP.


=item B<-msmallc>

Link with a limited version of the C library, B<-lsmallc>, rather than
Newlib.


=item B<-msys-crt0=>I<startfile>

I<startfile> is the file name of the startfile (crt0) to use 
when linking.  This option is only useful in conjunction with B<-mhal>.


=item B<-msys-lib=>I<systemlib>

I<systemlib> is the library name of the library that provides
low-level system calls required by the C library,
e.g. C<read> and C<write>.
This option is typically used to link with a library provided by a HAL BSP.


=back



=head3 Nvidia PTX Options


These options are defined for Nvidia PTX:


=over 4



=item B<-m32>


=item B<-m64>

Generate code for 32-bit or 64-bit ABI.


=item B<-misa=>I<ISA-string>

Generate code for given the specified PTX ISA (e.g. B<sm_35>).  ISA
strings must be lower-case.  Valid ISA strings include B<sm_30> and
B<sm_35>.  The default ISA is sm_30.


=item B<-mmainkernel>

Link in code for a __main kernel.  This is for stand-alone instead of
offloading execution.


=item B<-moptimize>

Apply partitioned execution optimizations.  This is the default when any
level of optimization is selected.


=item B<-msoft-stack>

Generate code that does not use C<.local> memory
directly for stack storage. Instead, a per-warp stack pointer is
maintained explicitly. This enables variable-length stack allocation (with
variable-length arrays or C<alloca>), and when global memory is used for
underlying storage, makes it possible to access automatic variables from other
threads, or with atomic instructions. This code generation variant is used
for OpenMP offloading, but the option is exposed on its own for the purpose
of testing the compiler; to generate code suitable for linking into programs
using OpenMP offloading, use option B<-mgomp>.


=item B<-muniform-simt>

Switch to code generation variant that allows to execute all threads in each
warp, while maintaining memory state and side effects as if only one thread
in each warp was active outside of OpenMP SIMD regions.  All atomic operations
and calls to runtime (malloc, free, vprintf) are conditionally executed (iff
current lane index equals the master lane index), and the register being
assigned is copied via a shuffle instruction from the master lane.  Outside of
SIMD regions lane 0 is the master; inside, each thread sees itself as the
master.  Shared memory array C<int __nvptx_uni[]> stores all-zeros or
all-ones bitmasks for each warp, indicating current mode (0 outside of SIMD
regions).  Each thread can bitwise-and the bitmask at position C<tid.y>
with current lane index to compute the master lane index.


=item B<-mgomp>

Generate code for use in OpenMP offloading: enables B<-msoft-stack> and
B<-muniform-simt> options, and selects corresponding multilib variant.


=back



=head3 OpenRISC Options


These options are defined for OpenRISC:


=over 4



=item B<-mboard=>I<name>

Configure a board specific runtime.  This will be passed to the linker for
newlib board library linking.  The default is C<or1ksim>.


=item B<-mnewlib>

For compatibility, it's always newlib for elf now.


=item B<-mhard-div>

Generate code for hardware which supports divide instructions.  This is the
default.


=item B<-mhard-mul>

Generate code for hardware which supports multiply instructions.  This is the
default.


=item B<-mcmov>

Generate code for hardware which supports the conditional move (C<l.cmov>)
instruction.


=item B<-mror>

Generate code for hardware which supports rotate right instructions.


=item B<-msext>

Generate code for hardware which supports sign-extension instructions.


=item B<-msfimm>

Generate code for hardware which supports set flag immediate (C<l.sf*i>)
instructions.


=item B<-mshftimm>

Generate code for hardware which supports shift immediate related instructions
(i.e. C<l.srai>, C<l.srli>, C<l.slli>, C<1.rori>).  Note, to
enable generation of the C<l.rori> instruction the B<-mror> flag must
also be specified.


=item B<-msoft-div>

Generate code for hardware which requires divide instruction emulation.


=item B<-msoft-mul>

Generate code for hardware which requires multiply instruction emulation.


=back



=head3 PDP-11 Options


These options are defined for the PDP-11:


=over 4


=item B<-mfpu>

Use hardware FPP floating point.  This is the default.  (FIS floating
point on the PDP-11/40 is not supported.)  Implies -m45.


=item B<-msoft-float>

Do not use hardware floating point.


=item B<-mac0>

Return floating-point results in ac0 (fr0 in Unix assembler syntax).


=item B<-mno-ac0>

Return floating-point results in memory.  This is the default.


=item B<-m40>

Generate code for a PDP-11/40.  Implies -msoft-float -mno-split.


=item B<-m45>

Generate code for a PDP-11/45.  This is the default.


=item B<-m10>

Generate code for a PDP-11/10.  Implies -msoft-float -mno-split.


=item B<-mint16>


=item B<-mno-int32>

Use 16-bit C<int>.  This is the default.


=item B<-mint32>


=item B<-mno-int16>

Use 32-bit C<int>.


=item B<-msplit>

Target has split instruction and data space.  Implies -m45.


=item B<-munix-asm>

Use Unix assembler syntax.


=item B<-mdec-asm>

Use DEC assembler syntax.


=item B<-mgnu-asm>

Use GNU assembler syntax.  This is the default.


=item B<-mlra>

Use the new LRA register allocator.  By default, the old "reload"
allocator is used.

=back



=head3 picoChip Options


These B<-m> options are defined for picoChip implementations:


=over 4



=item B<-mae=>I<ae_type>

Set the instruction set, register set, and instruction scheduling
parameters for array element type I<ae_type>.  Supported values
for I<ae_type> are B<ANY>, B<MUL>, and B<MAC>.

B<-mae=ANY> selects a completely generic AE type.  Code
generated with this option runs on any of the other AE types.  The
code is not as efficient as it would be if compiled for a specific
AE type, and some types of operation (e.g., multiplication) do not
work properly on all types of AE.

B<-mae=MUL> selects a MUL AE type.  This is the most useful AE type
for compiled code, and is the default.

B<-mae=MAC> selects a DSP-style MAC AE.  Code compiled with this
option may suffer from poor performance of byte (char) manipulation,
since the DSP AE does not provide hardware support for byte load/stores.


=item B<-msymbol-as-address>

Enable the compiler to directly use a symbol name as an address in a
load/store instruction, without first loading it into a
register.  Typically, the use of this option generates larger
programs, which run faster than when the option isn't used.  However, the
results vary from program to program, so it is left as a user option,
rather than being permanently enabled.


=item B<-mno-inefficient-warnings>

Disables warnings about the generation of inefficient code.  These
warnings can be generated, for example, when compiling code that
performs byte-level memory operations on the MAC AE type.  The MAC AE has
no hardware support for byte-level memory operations, so all byte
load/stores must be synthesized from word load/store operations.  This is
inefficient and a warning is generated to indicate
that you should rewrite the code to avoid byte operations, or to target
an AE type that has the necessary hardware support.  This option disables
these warnings.


=back



=head3 PowerPC Options


These are listed under 


=head3 RISC-V Options


These command-line options are defined for RISC-V targets:


=over 4


=item B<-mbranch-cost=>I<n>

Set the cost of branches to roughly I<n> instructions.


=item B<-mplt>


=item B<-mno-plt>

When generating PIC code, do or don't allow the use of PLTs. Ignored for
non-PIC.  The default is B<-mplt>.


=item B<-mabi=>I<ABI-string>

Specify integer and floating-point calling convention.  I<ABI-string>
contains two parts: the size of integer types and the registers used for
floating-point types.  For example B<-march=rv64ifd -mabi=lp64d> means that
B<long> and pointers are 64-bit (implicitly defining B<int> to be
32-bit), and that floating-point values up to 64 bits wide are passed in F
registers.  Contrast this with B<-march=rv64ifd -mabi=lp64f>, which still
allows the compiler to generate code that uses the F and D extensions but only
allows floating-point values up to 32 bits long to be passed in registers; or
B<-march=rv64ifd -mabi=lp64>, in which no floating-point arguments will be
passed in registers.

The default for this argument is system dependent, users who want a specific
calling convention should specify one explicitly.  The valid calling
conventions are: B<ilp32>, B<ilp32f>, B<ilp32d>, B<lp64>,
B<lp64f>, and B<lp64d>.  Some calling conventions are impossible to
implement on some ISAs: for example, B<-march=rv32if -mabi=ilp32d> is
invalid because the ABI requires 64-bit values be passed in F registers, but F
registers are only 32 bits wide.  There is also the B<ilp32e> ABI that can
only be used with the B<rv32e> architecture.  This ABI is not well
specified at present, and is subject to change.


=item B<-mfdiv>


=item B<-mno-fdiv>

Do or don't use hardware floating-point divide and square root instructions.
This requires the F or D extensions for floating-point registers.  The default
is to use them if the specified architecture has these instructions.


=item B<-mdiv>


=item B<-mno-div>

Do or don't use hardware instructions for integer division.  This requires the
M extension.  The default is to use them if the specified architecture has
these instructions.


=item B<-march=>I<ISA-string>

Generate code for given RISC-V ISA (e.g. B<rv64im>).  ISA strings must be
lower-case.  Examples include B<rv64i>, B<rv32g>, B<rv32e>, and
B<rv32imaf>.


=item B<-mtune=>I<processor-string>

Optimize the output for the given processor, specified by microarchitecture
name.  Permissible values for this option are: B<rocket>,
B<sifive-3-series>, B<sifive-5-series>, B<sifive-7-series>,
and B<size>.

When B<-mtune=> is not specified, the default is B<rocket>.

The B<size> choice is not intended for use by end-users.  This is used
when B<-Os> is specified.  It overrides the instruction cost info
provided by B<-mtune=>, but does not override the pipeline info.  This
helps reduce code size while still giving good performance.


=item B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary=>I<num>

Attempt to keep the stack boundary aligned to a 2 raised to I<num>
byte boundary.  If B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary> is not specified,
the default is 4 (16 bytes or 128-bits).

B<Warning:> If you use this switch, then you must build all modules with
the same value, including any libraries.  This includes the system libraries
and startup modules.


=item B<-msmall-data-limit=>I<n>

Put global and static data smaller than I<n> bytes into a special section
(on some targets).


=item B<-msave-restore>


=item B<-mno-save-restore>

Do or don't use smaller but slower prologue and epilogue code that uses
library function calls.  The default is to use fast inline prologues and
epilogues.


=item B<-mstrict-align>


=item B<-mno-strict-align>

Do not or do generate unaligned memory accesses.  The default is set depending
on whether the processor we are optimizing for supports fast unaligned access
or not.


=item B<-mcmodel=medlow>

Generate code for the medium-low code model. The program and its statically
defined symbols must lie within a single 2 GiB address range and must lie
between absolute addresses -2 GiB and +2 GiB. Programs can be
statically or dynamically linked. This is the default code model.


=item B<-mcmodel=medany>

Generate code for the medium-any code model. The program and its statically
defined symbols must be within any single 2 GiB address range. Programs can be
statically or dynamically linked.


=item B<-mexplicit-relocs>


=item B<-mno-exlicit-relocs>

Use or do not use assembler relocation operators when dealing with symbolic
addresses.  The alternative is to use assembler macros instead, which may
limit optimization.


=item B<-mrelax>


=item B<-mno-relax>

Take advantage of linker relaxations to reduce the number of instructions
required to materialize symbol addresses. The default is to take advantage of
linker relaxations.


=item B<-memit-attribute>


=item B<-mno-emit-attribute>

Emit (do not emit) RISC-V attribute to record extra information into ELF
objects.  This feature requires at least binutils 2.32.

=back



=head3 RL78 Options



=over 4



=item B<-msim>

Links in additional target libraries to support operation within a
simulator.


=item B<-mmul=none>


=item B<-mmul=g10>


=item B<-mmul=g13>


=item B<-mmul=g14>


=item B<-mmul=rl78>

Specifies the type of hardware multiplication and division support to
be used.  The simplest is C<none>, which uses software for both
multiplication and division.  This is the default.  The C<g13>
value is for the hardware multiply/divide peripheral found on the
RL78/G13 (S2 core) targets.  The C<g14> value selects the use of
the multiplication and division instructions supported by the RL78/G14
(S3 core) parts.  The value C<rl78> is an alias for C<g14> and
the value C<mg10> is an alias for C<none>.

In addition a C preprocessor macro is defined, based upon the setting
of this option.  Possible values are: C<__RL78_MUL_NONE__>,
C<__RL78_MUL_G13__> or C<__RL78_MUL_G14__>.


=item B<-mcpu=g10>


=item B<-mcpu=g13>


=item B<-mcpu=g14>


=item B<-mcpu=rl78>

Specifies the RL78 core to target.  The default is the G14 core, also
known as an S3 core or just RL78.  The G13 or S2 core does not have
multiply or divide instructions, instead it uses a hardware peripheral
for these operations.  The G10 or S1 core does not have register
banks, so it uses a different calling convention.

If this option is set it also selects the type of hardware multiply
support to use, unless this is overridden by an explicit
B<-mmul=none> option on the command line.  Thus specifying
B<-mcpu=g13> enables the use of the G13 hardware multiply
peripheral and specifying B<-mcpu=g10> disables the use of
hardware multiplications altogether.

Note, although the RL78/G14 core is the default target, specifying
B<-mcpu=g14> or B<-mcpu=rl78> on the command line does
change the behavior of the toolchain since it also enables G14
hardware multiply support.  If these options are not specified on the
command line then software multiplication routines will be used even
though the code targets the RL78 core.  This is for backwards
compatibility with older toolchains which did not have hardware
multiply and divide support.

In addition a C preprocessor macro is defined, based upon the setting
of this option.  Possible values are: C<__RL78_G10__>,
C<__RL78_G13__> or C<__RL78_G14__>.


=item B<-mg10>


=item B<-mg13>


=item B<-mg14>


=item B<-mrl78>

These are aliases for the corresponding B<-mcpu=> option.  They
are provided for backwards compatibility.


=item B<-mallregs>

Allow the compiler to use all of the available registers.  By default
registers C<r24..r31> are reserved for use in interrupt handlers.
With this option enabled these registers can be used in ordinary
functions as well.


=item B<-m64bit-doubles>


=item B<-m32bit-doubles>

Make the C<double> data type be 64 bits (B<-m64bit-doubles>)
or 32 bits (B<-m32bit-doubles>) in size.  The default is
B<-m32bit-doubles>.


=item B<-msave-mduc-in-interrupts>


=item B<-mno-save-mduc-in-interrupts>

Specifies that interrupt handler functions should preserve the
MDUC registers.  This is only necessary if normal code might use
the MDUC registers, for example because it performs multiplication
and division operations.  The default is to ignore the MDUC registers
as this makes the interrupt handlers faster.  The target option -mg13
needs to be passed for this to work as this feature is only available
on the G13 target (S2 core).  The MDUC registers will only be saved
if the interrupt handler performs a multiplication or division
operation or it calls another function.


=back



=head3 IBM RS/6000 and PowerPC Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the IBM RS/6000 and PowerPC:

=over 4


=item B<-mpowerpc-gpopt>


=item B<-mno-powerpc-gpopt>


=item B<-mpowerpc-gfxopt>


=item B<-mno-powerpc-gfxopt>


=item B<-mpowerpc64>


=item B<-mno-powerpc64>


=item B<-mmfcrf>


=item B<-mno-mfcrf>


=item B<-mpopcntb>


=item B<-mno-popcntb>


=item B<-mpopcntd>


=item B<-mno-popcntd>


=item B<-mfprnd>


=item B<-mno-fprnd>


=item B<-mcmpb>


=item B<-mno-cmpb>


=item B<-mmfpgpr>


=item B<-mno-mfpgpr>


=item B<-mhard-dfp>


=item B<-mno-hard-dfp>

You use these options to specify which instructions are available on the
processor you are using.  The default value of these options is
determined when configuring GCC.  Specifying the
B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type> overrides the specification of these
options.  We recommend you use the B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type> option
rather than the options listed above.

Specifying B<-mpowerpc-gpopt> allows
GCC to use the optional PowerPC architecture instructions in the
General Purpose group, including floating-point square root.  Specifying
B<-mpowerpc-gfxopt> allows GCC to
use the optional PowerPC architecture instructions in the Graphics
group, including floating-point select.

The B<-mmfcrf> option allows GCC to generate the move from
condition register field instruction implemented on the POWER4
processor and other processors that support the PowerPC V2.01
architecture.
The B<-mpopcntb> option allows GCC to generate the popcount and
double-precision FP reciprocal estimate instruction implemented on the
POWER5 processor and other processors that support the PowerPC V2.02
architecture.
The B<-mpopcntd> option allows GCC to generate the popcount
instruction implemented on the POWER7 processor and other processors
that support the PowerPC V2.06 architecture.
The B<-mfprnd> option allows GCC to generate the FP round to
integer instructions implemented on the POWER5+ processor and other
processors that support the PowerPC V2.03 architecture.
The B<-mcmpb> option allows GCC to generate the compare bytes
instruction implemented on the POWER6 processor and other processors
that support the PowerPC V2.05 architecture.
The B<-mmfpgpr> option allows GCC to generate the FP move to/from
general-purpose register instructions implemented on the POWER6X
processor and other processors that support the extended PowerPC V2.05
architecture.
The B<-mhard-dfp> option allows GCC to generate the decimal
floating-point instructions implemented on some POWER processors.

The B<-mpowerpc64> option allows GCC to generate the additional
64-bit instructions that are found in the full PowerPC64 architecture
and to treat GPRs as 64-bit, doubleword quantities.  GCC defaults to
B<-mno-powerpc64>.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type>

Set architecture type, register usage, and
instruction scheduling parameters for machine type I<cpu_type>.
Supported values for I<cpu_type> are B<401>, B<403>,
B<405>, B<405fp>, B<440>, B<440fp>, B<464>, B<464fp>,
B<476>, B<476fp>, B<505>, B<601>, B<602>, B<603>,
B<603e>, B<604>, B<604e>, B<620>, B<630>, B<740>,
B<7400>, B<7450>, B<750>, B<801>, B<821>, B<823>,
B<860>, B<970>, B<8540>, B<a2>, B<e300c2>,
B<e300c3>, B<e500mc>, B<e500mc64>, B<e5500>,
B<e6500>, B<ec603e>, B<G3>, B<G4>, B<G5>,
B<titan>, B<power3>, B<power4>, B<power5>, B<power5+>,
B<power6>, B<power6x>, B<power7>, B<power8>,
B<power9>, B<powerpc>, B<powerpc64>, B<powerpc64le>,
B<rs64>, and B<native>.

B<-mcpu=powerpc>, B<-mcpu=powerpc64>, and
B<-mcpu=powerpc64le> specify pure 32-bit PowerPC (either
endian), 64-bit big endian PowerPC and 64-bit little endian PowerPC
architecture machine types, with an appropriate, generic processor
model assumed for scheduling purposes.

Specifying B<native> as cpu type detects and selects the
architecture option that corresponds to the host processor of the
system performing the compilation.
B<-mcpu=native> has no effect if GCC does not recognize the
processor.

The other options specify a specific processor.  Code generated under
those options runs best on that processor, and may not run at all on
others.

The B<-mcpu> options automatically enable or disable the
following options:

B<-maltivec  -mfprnd  -mhard-float  -mmfcrf  -mmultiple 
-mpopcntb  -mpopcntd  -mpowerpc64 
-mpowerpc-gpopt  -mpowerpc-gfxopt 
-mmulhw  -mdlmzb  -mmfpgpr  -mvsx 
-mcrypto  -mhtm  -mpower8-fusion  -mpower8-vector 
-mquad-memory  -mquad-memory-atomic  -mfloat128  -mfloat128-hardware>

The particular options set for any particular CPU varies between
compiler versions, depending on what setting seems to produce optimal
code for that CPU; it doesn't necessarily reflect the actual hardware's
capabilities.  If you wish to set an individual option to a particular
value, you may specify it after the B<-mcpu> option, like
B<-mcpu=970 -mno-altivec>.

On AIX, the B<-maltivec> and B<-mpowerpc64> options are
not enabled or disabled by the B<-mcpu> option at present because
AIX does not have full support for these options.  You may still
enable or disable them individually if you're sure it'll work in your
environment.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu_type>

Set the instruction scheduling parameters for machine type
I<cpu_type>, but do not set the architecture type or register usage,
as B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type> does.  The same
values for I<cpu_type> are used for B<-mtune> as for
B<-mcpu>.  If both are specified, the code generated uses the
architecture and registers set by B<-mcpu>, but the
scheduling parameters set by B<-mtune>.


=item B<-mcmodel=small>

Generate PowerPC64 code for the small model: The TOC is limited to
64k.


=item B<-mcmodel=medium>

Generate PowerPC64 code for the medium model: The TOC and other static
data may be up to a total of 4G in size.  This is the default for 64-bit
Linux.


=item B<-mcmodel=large>

Generate PowerPC64 code for the large model: The TOC may be up to 4G
in size.  Other data and code is only limited by the 64-bit address
space.


=item B<-maltivec>


=item B<-mno-altivec>

Generate code that uses (does not use) AltiVec instructions, and also
enable the use of built-in functions that allow more direct access to
the AltiVec instruction set.  You may also need to set
B<-mabi=altivec> to adjust the current ABI with AltiVec ABI
enhancements.

When B<-maltivec> is used, the element order for AltiVec intrinsics
such as C<vec_splat>, C<vec_extract>, and C<vec_insert> 
match array element order corresponding to the endianness of the
target.  That is, element zero identifies the leftmost element in a
vector register when targeting a big-endian platform, and identifies
the rightmost element in a vector register when targeting a
little-endian platform.


=item B<-mvrsave>


=item B<-mno-vrsave>

Generate VRSAVE instructions when generating AltiVec code.


=item B<-msecure-plt>

Generate code that allows B<ld> and B<ld.so>
to build executables and shared
libraries with non-executable C<.plt> and C<.got> sections.
This is a PowerPC
32-bit SYSV ABI option.


=item B<-mbss-plt>

Generate code that uses a BSS C<.plt> section that B<ld.so>
fills in, and
requires C<.plt> and C<.got>
sections that are both writable and executable.
This is a PowerPC 32-bit SYSV ABI option.


=item B<-misel>


=item B<-mno-isel>

This switch enables or disables the generation of ISEL instructions.


=item B<-mvsx>


=item B<-mno-vsx>

Generate code that uses (does not use) vector/scalar (VSX)
instructions, and also enable the use of built-in functions that allow
more direct access to the VSX instruction set.


=item B<-mcrypto>


=item B<-mno-crypto>

Enable the use (disable) of the built-in functions that allow direct
access to the cryptographic instructions that were added in version
2.07 of the PowerPC ISA.


=item B<-mhtm>


=item B<-mno-htm>

Enable (disable) the use of the built-in functions that allow direct
access to the Hardware Transactional Memory (HTM) instructions that
were added in version 2.07 of the PowerPC ISA.


=item B<-mpower8-fusion>


=item B<-mno-power8-fusion>

Generate code that keeps (does not keeps) some integer operations
adjacent so that the instructions can be fused together on power8 and
later processors.


=item B<-mpower8-vector>


=item B<-mno-power8-vector>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the vector and scalar
instructions that were added in version 2.07 of the PowerPC ISA.  Also
enable the use of built-in functions that allow more direct access to
the vector instructions.


=item B<-mquad-memory>


=item B<-mno-quad-memory>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the non-atomic quad word memory
instructions.  The B<-mquad-memory> option requires use of
64-bit mode.


=item B<-mquad-memory-atomic>


=item B<-mno-quad-memory-atomic>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the atomic quad word memory
instructions.  The B<-mquad-memory-atomic> option requires use of
64-bit mode.


=item B<-mfloat128>


=item B<-mno-float128>

Enable/disable the I<__float128> keyword for IEEE 128-bit floating point
and use either software emulation for IEEE 128-bit floating point or
hardware instructions.

The VSX instruction set (B<-mvsx>, B<-mcpu=power7>,
B<-mcpu=power8>), or B<-mcpu=power9> must be enabled to
use the IEEE 128-bit floating point support.  The IEEE 128-bit
floating point support only works on PowerPC Linux systems.

The default for B<-mfloat128> is enabled on PowerPC Linux
systems using the VSX instruction set, and disabled on other systems.

If you use the ISA 3.0 instruction set (B<-mpower9-vector> or
B<-mcpu=power9>) on a 64-bit system, the IEEE 128-bit floating
point support will also enable the generation of ISA 3.0 IEEE 128-bit
floating point instructions.  Otherwise, if you do not specify to
generate ISA 3.0 instructions or you are targeting a 32-bit big endian
system, IEEE 128-bit floating point will be done with software
emulation.


=item B<-mfloat128-hardware>


=item B<-mno-float128-hardware>

Enable/disable using ISA 3.0 hardware instructions to support the
I<__float128> data type.

The default for B<-mfloat128-hardware> is enabled on PowerPC
Linux systems using the ISA 3.0 instruction set, and disabled on other
systems.


=item B<-m32>


=item B<-m64>

Generate code for 32-bit or 64-bit environments of Darwin and SVR4
targets (including GNU/Linux).  The 32-bit environment sets int, long
and pointer to 32 bits and generates code that runs on any PowerPC
variant.  The 64-bit environment sets int to 32 bits and long and
pointer to 64 bits, and generates code for PowerPC64, as for
B<-mpowerpc64>.


=item B<-mfull-toc>


=item B<-mno-fp-in-toc>


=item B<-mno-sum-in-toc>


=item B<-mminimal-toc>

Modify generation of the TOC (Table Of Contents), which is created for
every executable file.  The B<-mfull-toc> option is selected by
default.  In that case, GCC allocates at least one TOC entry for
each unique non-automatic variable reference in your program.  GCC
also places floating-point constants in the TOC.  However, only
16,384 entries are available in the TOC.

If you receive a linker error message that saying you have overflowed
the available TOC space, you can reduce the amount of TOC space used
with the B<-mno-fp-in-toc> and B<-mno-sum-in-toc> options.
B<-mno-fp-in-toc> prevents GCC from putting floating-point
constants in the TOC and B<-mno-sum-in-toc> forces GCC to
generate code to calculate the sum of an address and a constant at
run time instead of putting that sum into the TOC.  You may specify one
or both of these options.  Each causes GCC to produce very slightly
slower and larger code at the expense of conserving TOC space.

If you still run out of space in the TOC even when you specify both of
these options, specify B<-mminimal-toc> instead.  This option causes
GCC to make only one TOC entry for every file.  When you specify this
option, GCC produces code that is slower and larger but which
uses extremely little TOC space.  You may wish to use this option
only on files that contain less frequently-executed code.


=item B<-maix64>


=item B<-maix32>

Enable 64-bit AIX ABI and calling convention: 64-bit pointers, 64-bit
C<long> type, and the infrastructure needed to support them.
Specifying B<-maix64> implies B<-mpowerpc64>,
while B<-maix32> disables the 64-bit ABI and
implies B<-mno-powerpc64>.  GCC defaults to B<-maix32>.


=item B<-mxl-compat>


=item B<-mno-xl-compat>

Produce code that conforms more closely to IBM XL compiler semantics
when using AIX-compatible ABI.  Pass floating-point arguments to
prototyped functions beyond the register save area (RSA) on the stack
in addition to argument FPRs.  Do not assume that most significant
double in 128-bit long double value is properly rounded when comparing
values and converting to double.  Use XL symbol names for long double
support routines.

The AIX calling convention was extended but not initially documented to
handle an obscure K&R C case of calling a function that takes the
address of its arguments with fewer arguments than declared.  IBM XL
compilers access floating-point arguments that do not fit in the
RSA from the stack when a subroutine is compiled without
optimization.  Because always storing floating-point arguments on the
stack is inefficient and rarely needed, this option is not enabled by
default and only is necessary when calling subroutines compiled by IBM
XL compilers without optimization.


=item B<-mpe>

Support I<IBM RS/6000 SP> I<Parallel Environment> (PE).  Link an
application written to use message passing with special startup code to
enable the application to run.  The system must have PE installed in the
standard location (F</usr/lpp/ppe.poe/>), or the F<specs> file
must be overridden with the B<-specs=> option to specify the
appropriate directory location.  The Parallel Environment does not
support threads, so the B<-mpe> option and the B<-pthread>
option are incompatible.


=item B<-malign-natural>


=item B<-malign-power>

On AIX, 32-bit Darwin, and 64-bit PowerPC GNU/Linux, the option
B<-malign-natural> overrides the ABI-defined alignment of larger
types, such as floating-point doubles, on their natural size-based boundary.
The option B<-malign-power> instructs GCC to follow the ABI-specified
alignment rules.  GCC defaults to the standard alignment defined in the ABI.

On 64-bit Darwin, natural alignment is the default, and B<-malign-power>
is not supported.


=item B<-msoft-float>


=item B<-mhard-float>

Generate code that does not use (uses) the floating-point register set.
Software floating-point emulation is provided if you use the
B<-msoft-float> option, and pass the option to GCC when linking.


=item B<-mmultiple>


=item B<-mno-multiple>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the load multiple word
instructions and the store multiple word instructions.  These
instructions are generated by default on POWER systems, and not
generated on PowerPC systems.  Do not use B<-mmultiple> on little-endian
PowerPC systems, since those instructions do not work when the
processor is in little-endian mode.  The exceptions are PPC740 and
PPC750 which permit these instructions in little-endian mode.


=item B<-mupdate>


=item B<-mno-update>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the load or store instructions
that update the base register to the address of the calculated memory
location.  These instructions are generated by default.  If you use
B<-mno-update>, there is a small window between the time that the
stack pointer is updated and the address of the previous frame is
stored, which means code that walks the stack frame across interrupts or
signals may get corrupted data.


=item B<-mavoid-indexed-addresses>


=item B<-mno-avoid-indexed-addresses>

Generate code that tries to avoid (not avoid) the use of indexed load
or store instructions. These instructions can incur a performance
penalty on Power6 processors in certain situations, such as when
stepping through large arrays that cross a 16M boundary.  This option
is enabled by default when targeting Power6 and disabled otherwise.


=item B<-mfused-madd>


=item B<-mno-fused-madd>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the floating-point multiply and
accumulate instructions.  These instructions are generated by default
if hardware floating point is used.  The machine-dependent
B<-mfused-madd> option is now mapped to the machine-independent
B<-ffp-contract=fast> option, and B<-mno-fused-madd> is
mapped to B<-ffp-contract=off>.


=item B<-mmulhw>


=item B<-mno-mulhw>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the half-word multiply and
multiply-accumulate instructions on the IBM 405, 440, 464 and 476 processors.
These instructions are generated by default when targeting those
processors.


=item B<-mdlmzb>


=item B<-mno-dlmzb>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the string-search B<dlmzb>
instruction on the IBM 405, 440, 464 and 476 processors.  This instruction is
generated by default when targeting those processors.


=item B<-mno-bit-align>


=item B<-mbit-align>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems do not (do) force structures
and unions that contain bit-fields to be aligned to the base type of the
bit-field.

For example, by default a structure containing nothing but 8
C<unsigned> bit-fields of length 1 is aligned to a 4-byte
boundary and has a size of 4 bytes.  By using B<-mno-bit-align>,
the structure is aligned to a 1-byte boundary and is 1 byte in
size.


=item B<-mno-strict-align>


=item B<-mstrict-align>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems do not (do) assume that
unaligned memory references are handled by the system.


=item B<-mrelocatable>


=item B<-mno-relocatable>

Generate code that allows (does not allow) a static executable to be
relocated to a different address at run time.  A simple embedded
PowerPC system loader should relocate the entire contents of
C<.got2> and 4-byte locations listed in the C<.fixup> section,
a table of 32-bit addresses generated by this option.  For this to
work, all objects linked together must be compiled with
B<-mrelocatable> or B<-mrelocatable-lib>.
B<-mrelocatable> code aligns the stack to an 8-byte boundary.


=item B<-mrelocatable-lib>


=item B<-mno-relocatable-lib>

Like B<-mrelocatable>, B<-mrelocatable-lib> generates a
C<.fixup> section to allow static executables to be relocated at
run time, but B<-mrelocatable-lib> does not use the smaller stack
alignment of B<-mrelocatable>.  Objects compiled with
B<-mrelocatable-lib> may be linked with objects compiled with
any combination of the B<-mrelocatable> options.


=item B<-mno-toc>


=item B<-mtoc>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems do not (do) assume that
register 2 contains a pointer to a global area pointing to the addresses
used in the program.


=item B<-mlittle>


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code for the
processor in little-endian mode.  The B<-mlittle-endian> option is
the same as B<-mlittle>.


=item B<-mbig>


=item B<-mbig-endian>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code for the
processor in big-endian mode.  The B<-mbig-endian> option is
the same as B<-mbig>.


=item B<-mdynamic-no-pic>

On Darwin and Mac OS X systems, compile code so that it is not
relocatable, but that its external references are relocatable.  The
resulting code is suitable for applications, but not shared
libraries.


=item B<-msingle-pic-base>

Treat the register used for PIC addressing as read-only, rather than
loading it in the prologue for each function.  The runtime system is
responsible for initializing this register with an appropriate value
before execution begins.


=item B<-mprioritize-restricted-insns=>I<priority>

This option controls the priority that is assigned to
dispatch-slot restricted instructions during the second scheduling
pass.  The argument I<priority> takes the value B<0>, B<1>,
or B<2> to assign no, highest, or second-highest (respectively) 
priority to dispatch-slot restricted
instructions.


=item B<-msched-costly-dep=>I<dependence_type>

This option controls which dependences are considered costly
by the target during instruction scheduling.  The argument
I<dependence_type> takes one of the following values:


=over 4


=item B<no>

No dependence is costly.


=item B<all>

All dependences are costly.


=item B<true_store_to_load>

A true dependence from store to load is costly.


=item B<store_to_load>

Any dependence from store to load is costly.


=item I<number>

Any dependence for which the latency is greater than or equal to 
I<number> is costly.

=back



=item B<-minsert-sched-nops=>I<scheme>

This option controls which NOP insertion scheme is used during
the second scheduling pass.  The argument I<scheme> takes one of the
following values:


=over 4


=item B<no>

Don't insert NOPs.


=item B<pad>

Pad with NOPs any dispatch group that has vacant issue slots,
according to the scheduler's grouping.


=item B<regroup_exact>

Insert NOPs to force costly dependent insns into
separate groups.  Insert exactly as many NOPs as needed to force an insn
to a new group, according to the estimated processor grouping.


=item I<number>

Insert NOPs to force costly dependent insns into
separate groups.  Insert I<number> NOPs to force an insn to a new group.

=back



=item B<-mcall-sysv>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code using calling
conventions that adhere to the March 1995 draft of the System V
Application Binary Interface, PowerPC processor supplement.  This is the
default unless you configured GCC using B<powerpc-*-eabiaix>.


=item B<-mcall-sysv-eabi>


=item B<-mcall-eabi>

Specify both B<-mcall-sysv> and B<-meabi> options.


=item B<-mcall-sysv-noeabi>

Specify both B<-mcall-sysv> and B<-mno-eabi> options.


=item B<-mcall-aixdesc>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code for the AIX
operating system.


=item B<-mcall-linux>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code for the
Linux-based GNU system.


=item B<-mcall-freebsd>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code for the
FreeBSD operating system.


=item B<-mcall-netbsd>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code for the
NetBSD operating system.


=item B<-mcall-openbsd>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems compile code for the
OpenBSD operating system.


=item B<-mtraceback=>I<traceback_type>

Select the type of traceback table. Valid values for I<traceback_type>
are B<full>, B<part>, and B<no>.


=item B<-maix-struct-return>

Return all structures in memory (as specified by the AIX ABI).


=item B<-msvr4-struct-return>

Return structures smaller than 8 bytes in registers (as specified by the
SVR4 ABI).


=item B<-mabi=>I<abi-type>

Extend the current ABI with a particular extension, or remove such extension.
Valid values are B<altivec>, B<no-altivec>,
B<ibmlongdouble>, B<ieeelongdouble>,
B<elfv1>, B<elfv2>.


=item B<-mabi=ibmlongdouble>

Change the current ABI to use IBM extended-precision long double.
This is not likely to work if your system defaults to using IEEE
extended-precision long double.  If you change the long double type
from IEEE extended-precision, the compiler will issue a warning unless
you use the B<-Wno-psabi> option.  Requires B<-mlong-double-128>
to be enabled.


=item B<-mabi=ieeelongdouble>

Change the current ABI to use IEEE extended-precision long double.
This is not likely to work if your system defaults to using IBM
extended-precision long double.  If you change the long double type
from IBM extended-precision, the compiler will issue a warning unless
you use the B<-Wno-psabi> option.  Requires B<-mlong-double-128>
to be enabled.


=item B<-mabi=elfv1>

Change the current ABI to use the ELFv1 ABI.
This is the default ABI for big-endian PowerPC 64-bit Linux.
Overriding the default ABI requires special system support and is
likely to fail in spectacular ways.


=item B<-mabi=elfv2>

Change the current ABI to use the ELFv2 ABI.
This is the default ABI for little-endian PowerPC 64-bit Linux.
Overriding the default ABI requires special system support and is
likely to fail in spectacular ways.


=item B<-mgnu-attribute>


=item B<-mno-gnu-attribute>

Emit .gnu_attribute assembly directives to set tag/value pairs in a
.gnu.attributes section that specify ABI variations in function
parameters or return values.


=item B<-mprototype>


=item B<-mno-prototype>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems assume that all calls to
variable argument functions are properly prototyped.  Otherwise, the
compiler must insert an instruction before every non-prototyped call to
set or clear bit 6 of the condition code register (C<CR>) to
indicate whether floating-point values are passed in the floating-point
registers in case the function takes variable arguments.  With
B<-mprototype>, only calls to prototyped variable argument functions
set or clear the bit.


=item B<-msim>

On embedded PowerPC systems, assume that the startup module is called
F<sim-crt0.o> and that the standard C libraries are F<libsim.a> and
F<libc.a>.  This is the default for B<powerpc-*-eabisim>
configurations.


=item B<-mmvme>

On embedded PowerPC systems, assume that the startup module is called
F<crt0.o> and the standard C libraries are F<libmvme.a> and
F<libc.a>.


=item B<-mads>

On embedded PowerPC systems, assume that the startup module is called
F<crt0.o> and the standard C libraries are F<libads.a> and
F<libc.a>.


=item B<-myellowknife>

On embedded PowerPC systems, assume that the startup module is called
F<crt0.o> and the standard C libraries are F<libyk.a> and
F<libc.a>.


=item B<-mvxworks>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems, specify that you are
compiling for a VxWorks system.


=item B<-memb>

On embedded PowerPC systems, set the C<PPC_EMB> bit in the ELF flags
header to indicate that B<eabi> extended relocations are used.


=item B<-meabi>


=item B<-mno-eabi>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems do (do not) adhere to the
Embedded Applications Binary Interface (EABI), which is a set of
modifications to the System V.4 specifications.  Selecting B<-meabi>
means that the stack is aligned to an 8-byte boundary, a function
C<__eabi> is called from C<main> to set up the EABI
environment, and the B<-msdata> option can use both C<r2> and
C<r13> to point to two separate small data areas.  Selecting
B<-mno-eabi> means that the stack is aligned to a 16-byte boundary,
no EABI initialization function is called from C<main>, and the
B<-msdata> option only uses C<r13> to point to a single
small data area.  The B<-meabi> option is on by default if you
configured GCC using one of the B<powerpc*-*-eabi*> options.


=item B<-msdata=eabi>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems, put small initialized
C<const> global and static data in the C<.sdata2> section, which
is pointed to by register C<r2>.  Put small initialized
non-C<const> global and static data in the C<.sdata> section,
which is pointed to by register C<r13>.  Put small uninitialized
global and static data in the C<.sbss> section, which is adjacent to
the C<.sdata> section.  The B<-msdata=eabi> option is
incompatible with the B<-mrelocatable> option.  The
B<-msdata=eabi> option also sets the B<-memb> option.


=item B<-msdata=sysv>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems, put small global and static
data in the C<.sdata> section, which is pointed to by register
C<r13>.  Put small uninitialized global and static data in the
C<.sbss> section, which is adjacent to the C<.sdata> section.
The B<-msdata=sysv> option is incompatible with the
B<-mrelocatable> option.


=item B<-msdata=default>


=item B<-msdata>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems, if B<-meabi> is used,
compile code the same as B<-msdata=eabi>, otherwise compile code the
same as B<-msdata=sysv>.


=item B<-msdata=data>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems, put small global
data in the C<.sdata> section.  Put small uninitialized global
data in the C<.sbss> section.  Do not use register C<r13>
to address small data however.  This is the default behavior unless
other B<-msdata> options are used.


=item B<-msdata=none>


=item B<-mno-sdata>

On embedded PowerPC systems, put all initialized global and static data
in the C<.data> section, and all uninitialized data in the
C<.bss> section.


=item B<-mreadonly-in-sdata>

Put read-only objects in the C<.sdata> section as well.  This is the
default.


=item B<-mblock-move-inline-limit=>I<num>

Inline all block moves (such as calls to C<memcpy> or structure
copies) less than or equal to I<num> bytes.  The minimum value for
I<num> is 32 bytes on 32-bit targets and 64 bytes on 64-bit
targets.  The default value is target-specific.


=item B<-mblock-compare-inline-limit=>I<num>

Generate non-looping inline code for all block compares (such as calls
to C<memcmp> or structure compares) less than or equal to I<num>
bytes. If I<num> is 0, all inline expansion (non-loop and loop) of
block compare is disabled. The default value is target-specific.


=item B<-mblock-compare-inline-loop-limit=>I<num>

Generate an inline expansion using loop code for all block compares that
are less than or equal to I<num> bytes, but greater than the limit
for non-loop inline block compare expansion. If the block length is not
constant, at most I<num> bytes will be compared before C<memcmp>
is called to compare the remainder of the block. The default value is
target-specific.


=item B<-mstring-compare-inline-limit=>I<num>

Compare at most I<num> string bytes with inline code.
If the difference or end of string is not found at the
end of the inline compare a call to C<strcmp> or C<strncmp> will
take care of the rest of the comparison. The default is 64 bytes.


=item B<-G> I<num>

On embedded PowerPC systems, put global and static items less than or
equal to I<num> bytes into the small data or BSS sections instead of
the normal data or BSS section.  By default, I<num> is 8.  The
B<-G> I<num> switch is also passed to the linker.
All modules should be compiled with the same B<-G> I<num> value.


=item B<-mregnames>


=item B<-mno-regnames>

On System V.4 and embedded PowerPC systems do (do not) emit register
names in the assembly language output using symbolic forms.


=item B<-mlongcall>


=item B<-mno-longcall>

By default assume that all calls are far away so that a longer and more
expensive calling sequence is required.  This is required for calls
farther than 32 megabytes (33,554,432 bytes) from the current location.
A short call is generated if the compiler knows
the call cannot be that far away.  This setting can be overridden by
the C<shortcall> function attribute, or by C<#pragma
longcall(0)>.

Some linkers are capable of detecting out-of-range calls and generating
glue code on the fly.  On these systems, long calls are unnecessary and
generate slower code.  As of this writing, the AIX linker can do this,
as can the GNU linker for PowerPC/64.  It is planned to add this feature
to the GNU linker for 32-bit PowerPC systems as well.

On PowerPC64 ELFv2 and 32-bit PowerPC systems with newer GNU linkers,
GCC can generate long calls using an inline PLT call sequence (see
B<-mpltseq>).  PowerPC with B<-mbss-plt> and PowerPC64
ELFv1 (big-endian) do not support inline PLT calls.

On Darwin/PPC systems, C<#pragma longcall> generates C<jbsr
callee, L42>, plus a I<branch island> (glue code).  The two target
addresses represent the callee and the branch island.  The
Darwin/PPC linker prefers the first address and generates a C<bl
callee> if the PPC C<bl> instruction reaches the callee directly;
otherwise, the linker generates C<bl L42> to call the branch
island.  The branch island is appended to the body of the
calling function; it computes the full 32-bit address of the callee
and jumps to it.

On Mach-O (Darwin) systems, this option directs the compiler emit to
the glue for every direct call, and the Darwin linker decides whether
to use or discard it.

In the future, GCC may ignore all longcall specifications
when the linker is known to generate glue.


=item B<-mpltseq>


=item B<-mno-pltseq>

Implement (do not implement) -fno-plt and long calls using an inline
PLT call sequence that supports lazy linking and long calls to
functions in dlopen'd shared libraries.  Inline PLT calls are only
supported on PowerPC64 ELFv2 and 32-bit PowerPC systems with newer GNU
linkers, and are enabled by default if the support is detected when
configuring GCC, and, in the case of 32-bit PowerPC, if GCC is
configured with B<--enable-secureplt>.  B<-mpltseq> code
and B<-mbss-plt> 32-bit PowerPC relocatable objects may not be
linked together.


=item B<-mtls-markers>


=item B<-mno-tls-markers>

Mark (do not mark) calls to C<__tls_get_addr> with a relocation
specifying the function argument.  The relocation allows the linker to
reliably associate function call with argument setup instructions for
TLS optimization, which in turn allows GCC to better schedule the
sequence.


=item B<-mrecip>


=item B<-mno-recip>

This option enables use of the reciprocal estimate and
reciprocal square root estimate instructions with additional
Newton-Raphson steps to increase precision instead of doing a divide or
square root and divide for floating-point arguments.  You should use
the B<-ffast-math> option when using B<-mrecip> (or at
least B<-funsafe-math-optimizations>,
B<-ffinite-math-only>, B<-freciprocal-math> and
B<-fno-trapping-math>).  Note that while the throughput of the
sequence is generally higher than the throughput of the non-reciprocal
instruction, the precision of the sequence can be decreased by up to 2
ulp (i.e. the inverse of 1.0 equals 0.99999994) for reciprocal square
roots.


=item B<-mrecip=>I<opt>

This option controls which reciprocal estimate instructions
may be used.  I<opt> is a comma-separated list of options, which may
be preceded by a C<!> to invert the option:


=over 4



=item B<all>

Enable all estimate instructions.


=item B<default> 

Enable the default instructions, equivalent to B<-mrecip>.


=item B<none> 

Disable all estimate instructions, equivalent to B<-mno-recip>.


=item B<div> 

Enable the reciprocal approximation instructions for both 
single and double precision.


=item B<divf> 

Enable the single-precision reciprocal approximation instructions.


=item B<divd> 

Enable the double-precision reciprocal approximation instructions.


=item B<rsqrt> 

Enable the reciprocal square root approximation instructions for both
single and double precision.


=item B<rsqrtf> 

Enable the single-precision reciprocal square root approximation instructions.


=item B<rsqrtd> 

Enable the double-precision reciprocal square root approximation instructions.


=back


So, for example, B<-mrecip=all,!rsqrtd> enables
all of the reciprocal estimate instructions, except for the
C<FRSQRTE>, C<XSRSQRTEDP>, and C<XVRSQRTEDP> instructions
which handle the double-precision reciprocal square root calculations.


=item B<-mrecip-precision>


=item B<-mno-recip-precision>

Assume (do not assume) that the reciprocal estimate instructions
provide higher-precision estimates than is mandated by the PowerPC
ABI.  Selecting B<-mcpu=power6>, B<-mcpu=power7> or
B<-mcpu=power8> automatically selects B<-mrecip-precision>.
The double-precision square root estimate instructions are not generated by
default on low-precision machines, since they do not provide an
estimate that converges after three steps.


=item B<-mveclibabi=>I<type>

Specifies the ABI type to use for vectorizing intrinsics using an
external library.  The only type supported at present is B<mass>,
which specifies to use IBM's Mathematical Acceleration Subsystem
(MASS) libraries for vectorizing intrinsics using external libraries.
GCC currently emits calls to C<acosd2>, C<acosf4>,
C<acoshd2>, C<acoshf4>, C<asind2>, C<asinf4>,
C<asinhd2>, C<asinhf4>, C<atan2d2>, C<atan2f4>,
C<atand2>, C<atanf4>, C<atanhd2>, C<atanhf4>,
C<cbrtd2>, C<cbrtf4>, C<cosd2>, C<cosf4>,
C<coshd2>, C<coshf4>, C<erfcd2>, C<erfcf4>,
C<erfd2>, C<erff4>, C<exp2d2>, C<exp2f4>,
C<expd2>, C<expf4>, C<expm1d2>, C<expm1f4>,
C<hypotd2>, C<hypotf4>, C<lgammad2>, C<lgammaf4>,
C<log10d2>, C<log10f4>, C<log1pd2>, C<log1pf4>,
C<log2d2>, C<log2f4>, C<logd2>, C<logf4>,
C<powd2>, C<powf4>, C<sind2>, C<sinf4>, C<sinhd2>,
C<sinhf4>, C<sqrtd2>, C<sqrtf4>, C<tand2>,
C<tanf4>, C<tanhd2>, and C<tanhf4> when generating code
for power7.  Both B<-ftree-vectorize> and
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> must also be enabled.  The MASS
libraries must be specified at link time.


=item B<-mfriz>


=item B<-mno-friz>

Generate (do not generate) the C<friz> instruction when the
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> option is used to optimize
rounding of floating-point values to 64-bit integer and back to floating
point.  The C<friz> instruction does not return the same value if
the floating-point number is too large to fit in an integer.


=item B<-mpointers-to-nested-functions>


=item B<-mno-pointers-to-nested-functions>

Generate (do not generate) code to load up the static chain register
(C<r11>) when calling through a pointer on AIX and 64-bit Linux
systems where a function pointer points to a 3-word descriptor giving
the function address, TOC value to be loaded in register C<r2>, and
static chain value to be loaded in register C<r11>.  The
B<-mpointers-to-nested-functions> is on by default.  You cannot
call through pointers to nested functions or pointers
to functions compiled in other languages that use the static chain if
you use B<-mno-pointers-to-nested-functions>.


=item B<-msave-toc-indirect>


=item B<-mno-save-toc-indirect>

Generate (do not generate) code to save the TOC value in the reserved
stack location in the function prologue if the function calls through
a pointer on AIX and 64-bit Linux systems.  If the TOC value is not
saved in the prologue, it is saved just before the call through the
pointer.  The B<-mno-save-toc-indirect> option is the default.


=item B<-mcompat-align-parm>


=item B<-mno-compat-align-parm>

Generate (do not generate) code to pass structure parameters with a
maximum alignment of 64 bits, for compatibility with older versions
of GCC.

Older versions of GCC (prior to 4.9.0) incorrectly did not align a
structure parameter on a 128-bit boundary when that structure contained
a member requiring 128-bit alignment.  This is corrected in more
recent versions of GCC.  This option may be used to generate code
that is compatible with functions compiled with older versions of
GCC.

The B<-mno-compat-align-parm> option is the default.


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard=>I<guard>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-symbol=>I<symbol>

Generate stack protection code using canary at I<guard>.  Supported
locations are B<global> for global canary or B<tls> for per-thread
canary in the TLS block (the default with GNU libc version 2.4 or later).

With the latter choice the options
B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg> and
B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset> furthermore specify
which register to use as base register for reading the canary, and from what
offset from that base register. The default for those is as specified in the
relevant ABI.  B<-mstack-protector-guard-symbol=>I<symbol> overrides
the offset with a symbol reference to a canary in the TLS block.

=back



=head3 RX Options


These command-line options are defined for RX targets:


=over 4


=item B<-m64bit-doubles>


=item B<-m32bit-doubles>

Make the C<double> data type be 64 bits (B<-m64bit-doubles>)
or 32 bits (B<-m32bit-doubles>) in size.  The default is
B<-m32bit-doubles>.  I<Note> RX floating-point hardware only
works on 32-bit values, which is why the default is
B<-m32bit-doubles>.


=item B<-fpu>


=item B<-nofpu>

Enables (B<-fpu>) or disables (B<-nofpu>) the use of RX
floating-point hardware.  The default is enabled for the RX600
series and disabled for the RX200 series.

Floating-point instructions are only generated for 32-bit floating-point 
values, however, so the FPU hardware is not used for doubles if the
B<-m64bit-doubles> option is used.

I<Note> If the B<-fpu> option is enabled then
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is also enabled automatically.
This is because the RX FPU instructions are themselves unsafe.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<name>

Selects the type of RX CPU to be targeted.  Currently three types are
supported, the generic B<RX600> and B<RX200> series hardware and
the specific B<RX610> CPU.  The default is B<RX600>.

The only difference between B<RX600> and B<RX610> is that the
B<RX610> does not support the C<MVTIPL> instruction.

The B<RX200> series does not have a hardware floating-point unit
and so B<-nofpu> is enabled by default when this type is
selected.


=item B<-mbig-endian-data>


=item B<-mlittle-endian-data>

Store data (but not code) in the big-endian format.  The default is
B<-mlittle-endian-data>, i.e. to store data in the little-endian
format.


=item B<-msmall-data-limit=>I<N>

Specifies the maximum size in bytes of global and static variables
which can be placed into the small data area.  Using the small data
area can lead to smaller and faster code, but the size of area is
limited and it is up to the programmer to ensure that the area does
not overflow.  Also when the small data area is used one of the RX's
registers (usually C<r13>) is reserved for use pointing to this
area, so it is no longer available for use by the compiler.  This
could result in slower and/or larger code if variables are pushed onto
the stack instead of being held in this register.

Note, common variables (variables that have not been initialized) and
constants are not placed into the small data area as they are assigned
to other sections in the output executable.

The default value is zero, which disables this feature.  Note, this
feature is not enabled by default with higher optimization levels
(B<-O2> etc) because of the potentially detrimental effects of
reserving a register.  It is up to the programmer to experiment and
discover whether this feature is of benefit to their program.  See the
description of the B<-mpid> option for a description of how the
actual register to hold the small data area pointer is chosen.


=item B<-msim>


=item B<-mno-sim>

Use the simulator runtime.  The default is to use the libgloss
board-specific runtime.


=item B<-mas100-syntax>


=item B<-mno-as100-syntax>

When generating assembler output use a syntax that is compatible with
Renesas's AS100 assembler.  This syntax can also be handled by the GAS
assembler, but it has some restrictions so it is not generated by default.


=item B<-mmax-constant-size=>I<N>

Specifies the maximum size, in bytes, of a constant that can be used as
an operand in a RX instruction.  Although the RX instruction set does
allow constants of up to 4 bytes in length to be used in instructions,
a longer value equates to a longer instruction.  Thus in some
circumstances it can be beneficial to restrict the size of constants
that are used in instructions.  Constants that are too big are instead
placed into a constant pool and referenced via register indirection.

The value I<N> can be between 0 and 4.  A value of 0 (the default)
or 4 means that constants of any size are allowed.


=item B<-mrelax>

Enable linker relaxation.  Linker relaxation is a process whereby the
linker attempts to reduce the size of a program by finding shorter
versions of various instructions.  Disabled by default.


=item B<-mint-register=>I<N>

Specify the number of registers to reserve for fast interrupt handler
functions.  The value I<N> can be between 0 and 4.  A value of 1
means that register C<r13> is reserved for the exclusive use
of fast interrupt handlers.  A value of 2 reserves C<r13> and
C<r12>.  A value of 3 reserves C<r13>, C<r12> and
C<r11>, and a value of 4 reserves C<r13> through C<r10>.
A value of 0, the default, does not reserve any registers.


=item B<-msave-acc-in-interrupts>

Specifies that interrupt handler functions should preserve the
accumulator register.  This is only necessary if normal code might use
the accumulator register, for example because it performs 64-bit
multiplications.  The default is to ignore the accumulator as this
makes the interrupt handlers faster.


=item B<-mpid>


=item B<-mno-pid>

Enables the generation of position independent data.  When enabled any
access to constant data is done via an offset from a base address
held in a register.  This allows the location of constant data to be
determined at run time without requiring the executable to be
relocated, which is a benefit to embedded applications with tight
memory constraints.  Data that can be modified is not affected by this
option.

Note, using this feature reserves a register, usually C<r13>, for
the constant data base address.  This can result in slower and/or
larger code, especially in complicated functions.

The actual register chosen to hold the constant data base address
depends upon whether the B<-msmall-data-limit> and/or the
B<-mint-register> command-line options are enabled.  Starting
with register C<r13> and proceeding downwards, registers are
allocated first to satisfy the requirements of B<-mint-register>,
then B<-mpid> and finally B<-msmall-data-limit>.  Thus it
is possible for the small data area register to be C<r8> if both
B<-mint-register=4> and B<-mpid> are specified on the
command line.

By default this feature is not enabled.  The default can be restored
via the B<-mno-pid> command-line option.


=item B<-mno-warn-multiple-fast-interrupts>


=item B<-mwarn-multiple-fast-interrupts>

Prevents GCC from issuing a warning message if it finds more than one
fast interrupt handler when it is compiling a file.  The default is to
issue a warning for each extra fast interrupt handler found, as the RX
only supports one such interrupt.


=item B<-mallow-string-insns>


=item B<-mno-allow-string-insns>

Enables or disables the use of the string manipulation instructions
C<SMOVF>, C<SCMPU>, C<SMOVB>, C<SMOVU>, C<SUNTIL>
C<SWHILE> and also the C<RMPA> instruction.  These
instructions may prefetch data, which is not safe to do if accessing
an I/O register.  (See section 12.2.7 of the RX62N Group User's Manual
for more information).

The default is to allow these instructions, but it is not possible for
GCC to reliably detect all circumstances where a string instruction
might be used to access an I/O register, so their use cannot be
disabled automatically.  Instead it is reliant upon the programmer to
use the B<-mno-allow-string-insns> option if their program
accesses I/O space.

When the instructions are enabled GCC defines the C preprocessor
symbol C<__RX_ALLOW_STRING_INSNS__>, otherwise it defines the
symbol C<__RX_DISALLOW_STRING_INSNS__>.


=item B<-mjsr>


=item B<-mno-jsr>

Use only (or not only) C<JSR> instructions to access functions.
This option can be used when code size exceeds the range of C<BSR>
instructions.  Note that B<-mno-jsr> does not mean to not use
C<JSR> but instead means that any type of branch may be used.

=back


I<Note:> The generic GCC command-line option B<-ffixed->I<reg>
has special significance to the RX port when used with the
C<interrupt> function attribute.  This attribute indicates a
function intended to process fast interrupts.  GCC ensures
that it only uses the registers C<r10>, C<r11>, C<r12>
and/or C<r13> and only provided that the normal use of the
corresponding registers have been restricted via the
B<-ffixed->I<reg> or B<-mint-register> command-line
options.


=head3 S/390 and zSeries Options


These are the B<-m> options defined for the S/390 and zSeries architecture.


=over 4


=item B<-mhard-float>


=item B<-msoft-float>

Use (do not use) the hardware floating-point instructions and registers
for floating-point operations.  When B<-msoft-float> is specified,
functions in F<libgcc.a> are used to perform floating-point
operations.  When B<-mhard-float> is specified, the compiler
generates IEEE floating-point instructions.  This is the default.


=item B<-mhard-dfp>


=item B<-mno-hard-dfp>

Use (do not use) the hardware decimal-floating-point instructions for
decimal-floating-point operations.  When B<-mno-hard-dfp> is
specified, functions in F<libgcc.a> are used to perform
decimal-floating-point operations.  When B<-mhard-dfp> is
specified, the compiler generates decimal-floating-point hardware
instructions.  This is the default for B<-march=z9-ec> or higher.


=item B<-mlong-double-64>


=item B<-mlong-double-128>

These switches control the size of C<long double> type. A size
of 64 bits makes the C<long double> type equivalent to the C<double>
type. This is the default.


=item B<-mbackchain>


=item B<-mno-backchain>

Store (do not store) the address of the caller's frame as backchain pointer
into the callee's stack frame.
A backchain may be needed to allow debugging using tools that do not understand
DWARF call frame information.
When B<-mno-packed-stack> is in effect, the backchain pointer is stored
at the bottom of the stack frame; when B<-mpacked-stack> is in effect,
the backchain is placed into the topmost word of the 96/160 byte register
save area.

In general, code compiled with B<-mbackchain> is call-compatible with
code compiled with B<-mmo-backchain>; however, use of the backchain
for debugging purposes usually requires that the whole binary is built with
B<-mbackchain>.  Note that the combination of B<-mbackchain>,
B<-mpacked-stack> and B<-mhard-float> is not supported.  In order
to build a linux kernel use B<-msoft-float>.

The default is to not maintain the backchain.


=item B<-mpacked-stack>


=item B<-mno-packed-stack>

Use (do not use) the packed stack layout.  When B<-mno-packed-stack> is
specified, the compiler uses the all fields of the 96/160 byte register save
area only for their default purpose; unused fields still take up stack space.
When B<-mpacked-stack> is specified, register save slots are densely
packed at the top of the register save area; unused space is reused for other
purposes, allowing for more efficient use of the available stack space.
However, when B<-mbackchain> is also in effect, the topmost word of
the save area is always used to store the backchain, and the return address
register is always saved two words below the backchain.

As long as the stack frame backchain is not used, code generated with
B<-mpacked-stack> is call-compatible with code generated with
B<-mno-packed-stack>.  Note that some non-FSF releases of GCC 2.95 for
S/390 or zSeries generated code that uses the stack frame backchain at run
time, not just for debugging purposes.  Such code is not call-compatible
with code compiled with B<-mpacked-stack>.  Also, note that the
combination of B<-mbackchain>,
B<-mpacked-stack> and B<-mhard-float> is not supported.  In order
to build a linux kernel use B<-msoft-float>.

The default is to not use the packed stack layout.


=item B<-msmall-exec>


=item B<-mno-small-exec>

Generate (or do not generate) code using the C<bras> instruction
to do subroutine calls.
This only works reliably if the total executable size does not
exceed 64k.  The default is to use the C<basr> instruction instead,
which does not have this limitation.


=item B<-m64>


=item B<-m31>

When B<-m31> is specified, generate code compliant to the
GNU/Linux for S/390 ABI.  When B<-m64> is specified, generate
code compliant to the GNU/Linux for zSeries ABI.  This allows GCC in
particular to generate 64-bit instructions.  For the B<s390>
targets, the default is B<-m31>, while the B<s390x>
targets default to B<-m64>.


=item B<-mzarch>


=item B<-mesa>

When B<-mzarch> is specified, generate code using the
instructions available on z/Architecture.
When B<-mesa> is specified, generate code using the
instructions available on ESA/390.  Note that B<-mesa> is
not possible with B<-m64>.
When generating code compliant to the GNU/Linux for S/390 ABI,
the default is B<-mesa>.  When generating code compliant
to the GNU/Linux for zSeries ABI, the default is B<-mzarch>.


=item B<-mhtm>


=item B<-mno-htm>

The B<-mhtm> option enables a set of builtins making use of
instructions available with the transactional execution facility
introduced with the IBM zEnterprise EC12 machine generation
B<S/390 System z Built-in Functions>.
B<-mhtm> is enabled by default when using B<-march=zEC12>.


=item B<-mvx>


=item B<-mno-vx>

When B<-mvx> is specified, generate code using the instructions
available with the vector extension facility introduced with the IBM
z13 machine generation.
This option changes the ABI for some vector type values with regard to
alignment and calling conventions.  In case vector type values are
being used in an ABI-relevant context a GAS B<.gnu_attribute>
command will be added to mark the resulting binary with the ABI used.
B<-mvx> is enabled by default when using B<-march=z13>.


=item B<-mzvector>


=item B<-mno-zvector>

The B<-mzvector> option enables vector language extensions and
builtins using instructions available with the vector extension
facility introduced with the IBM z13 machine generation.
This option adds support for B<vector> to be used as a keyword to
define vector type variables and arguments.  B<vector> is only
available when GNU extensions are enabled.  It will not be expanded
when requesting strict standard compliance e.g. with B<-std=c99>.
In addition to the GCC low-level builtins B<-mzvector> enables
a set of builtins added for compatibility with AltiVec-style
implementations like Power and Cell.  In order to make use of these
builtins the header file F<vecintrin.h> needs to be included.
B<-mzvector> is disabled by default.


=item B<-mmvcle>


=item B<-mno-mvcle>

Generate (or do not generate) code using the C<mvcle> instruction
to perform block moves.  When B<-mno-mvcle> is specified,
use a C<mvc> loop instead.  This is the default unless optimizing for
size.


=item B<-mdebug>


=item B<-mno-debug>

Print (or do not print) additional debug information when compiling.
The default is to not print debug information.


=item B<-march=>I<cpu-type>

Generate code that runs on I<cpu-type>, which is the name of a
system representing a certain processor type.  Possible values for
I<cpu-type> are B<z900>/B<arch5>, B<z990>/B<arch6>,
B<z9-109>, B<z9-ec>/B<arch7>, B<z10>/B<arch8>,
B<z196>/B<arch9>, B<zEC12>, B<z13>/B<arch11>,
B<z14>/B<arch12>, and B<native>.

The default is B<-march=z900>.

Specifying B<native> as cpu type can be used to select the best
architecture option for the host processor.
B<-march=native> has no effect if GCC does not recognize the
processor.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu-type>

Tune to I<cpu-type> everything applicable about the generated code,
except for the ABI and the set of available instructions.
The list of I<cpu-type> values is the same as for B<-march>.
The default is the value used for B<-march>.


=item B<-mtpf-trace>


=item B<-mno-tpf-trace>

Generate code that adds (does not add) in TPF OS specific branches to trace
routines in the operating system.  This option is off by default, even
when compiling for the TPF OS.


=item B<-mfused-madd>


=item B<-mno-fused-madd>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the floating-point multiply and
accumulate instructions.  These instructions are generated by default if
hardware floating point is used.


=item B<-mwarn-framesize=>I<framesize>

Emit a warning if the current function exceeds the given frame size.  Because
this is a compile-time check it doesn't need to be a real problem when the program
runs.  It is intended to identify functions that most probably cause
a stack overflow.  It is useful to be used in an environment with limited stack
size e.g. the linux kernel.


=item B<-mwarn-dynamicstack>

Emit a warning if the function calls C<alloca> or uses dynamically-sized
arrays.  This is generally a bad idea with a limited stack size.


=item B<-mstack-guard=>I<stack-guard>


=item B<-mstack-size=>I<stack-size>

If these options are provided the S/390 back end emits additional instructions in
the function prologue that trigger a trap if the stack size is I<stack-guard>
bytes above the I<stack-size> (remember that the stack on S/390 grows downward).
If the I<stack-guard> option is omitted the smallest power of 2 larger than
the frame size of the compiled function is chosen.
These options are intended to be used to help debugging stack overflow problems.
The additionally emitted code causes only little overhead and hence can also be
used in production-like systems without greater performance degradation.  The given
values have to be exact powers of 2 and I<stack-size> has to be greater than
I<stack-guard> without exceeding 64k.
In order to be efficient the extra code makes the assumption that the stack starts
at an address aligned to the value given by I<stack-size>.
The I<stack-guard> option can only be used in conjunction with I<stack-size>.


=item B<-mhotpatch=>I<pre-halfwords>B<,>I<post-halfwords>

If the hotpatch option is enabled, a "hot-patching" function
prologue is generated for all functions in the compilation unit.
The funtion label is prepended with the given number of two-byte
NOP instructions (I<pre-halfwords>, maximum 1000000).  After
the label, 2 * I<post-halfwords> bytes are appended, using the
largest NOP like instructions the architecture allows (maximum
1000000).

If both arguments are zero, hotpatching is disabled.

This option can be overridden for individual functions with the
C<hotpatch> attribute.

=back



=head3 Score Options


These options are defined for Score implementations:


=over 4


=item B<-meb>

Compile code for big-endian mode.  This is the default.


=item B<-mel>

Compile code for little-endian mode.


=item B<-mnhwloop>

Disable generation of C<bcnz> instructions.


=item B<-muls>

Enable generation of unaligned load and store instructions.


=item B<-mmac>

Enable the use of multiply-accumulate instructions. Disabled by default.


=item B<-mscore5>

Specify the SCORE5 as the target architecture.


=item B<-mscore5u>

Specify the SCORE5U of the target architecture.


=item B<-mscore7>

Specify the SCORE7 as the target architecture. This is the default.


=item B<-mscore7d>

Specify the SCORE7D as the target architecture.

=back



=head3 SH Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the SH implementations:


=over 4


=item B<-m1>

Generate code for the SH1.


=item B<-m2>

Generate code for the SH2.


=item B<-m2e>

Generate code for the SH2e.


=item B<-m2a-nofpu>

Generate code for the SH2a without FPU, or for a SH2a-FPU in such a way
that the floating-point unit is not used.


=item B<-m2a-single-only>

Generate code for the SH2a-FPU, in such a way that no double-precision
floating-point operations are used.


=item B<-m2a-single>

Generate code for the SH2a-FPU assuming the floating-point unit is in
single-precision mode by default.


=item B<-m2a>

Generate code for the SH2a-FPU assuming the floating-point unit is in
double-precision mode by default.


=item B<-m3>

Generate code for the SH3.


=item B<-m3e>

Generate code for the SH3e.


=item B<-m4-nofpu>

Generate code for the SH4 without a floating-point unit.


=item B<-m4-single-only>

Generate code for the SH4 with a floating-point unit that only
supports single-precision arithmetic.


=item B<-m4-single>

Generate code for the SH4 assuming the floating-point unit is in
single-precision mode by default.


=item B<-m4>
