Generate code for the SH4.


=item B<-m4-100>

Generate code for SH4-100.


=item B<-m4-100-nofpu>

Generate code for SH4-100 in such a way that the
floating-point unit is not used.


=item B<-m4-100-single>

Generate code for SH4-100 assuming the floating-point unit is in
single-precision mode by default.


=item B<-m4-100-single-only>

Generate code for SH4-100 in such a way that no double-precision
floating-point operations are used.


=item B<-m4-200>

Generate code for SH4-200.


=item B<-m4-200-nofpu>

Generate code for SH4-200 without in such a way that the
floating-point unit is not used.


=item B<-m4-200-single>

Generate code for SH4-200 assuming the floating-point unit is in
single-precision mode by default.


=item B<-m4-200-single-only>

Generate code for SH4-200 in such a way that no double-precision
floating-point operations are used.


=item B<-m4-300>

Generate code for SH4-300.


=item B<-m4-300-nofpu>

Generate code for SH4-300 without in such a way that the
floating-point unit is not used.


=item B<-m4-300-single>

Generate code for SH4-300 in such a way that no double-precision
floating-point operations are used.


=item B<-m4-300-single-only>

Generate code for SH4-300 in such a way that no double-precision
floating-point operations are used.


=item B<-m4-340>

Generate code for SH4-340 (no MMU, no FPU).


=item B<-m4-500>

Generate code for SH4-500 (no FPU).  Passes B<-isa=sh4-nofpu> to the
assembler.


=item B<-m4a-nofpu>

Generate code for the SH4al-dsp, or for a SH4a in such a way that the
floating-point unit is not used.


=item B<-m4a-single-only>

Generate code for the SH4a, in such a way that no double-precision
floating-point operations are used.


=item B<-m4a-single>

Generate code for the SH4a assuming the floating-point unit is in
single-precision mode by default.


=item B<-m4a>

Generate code for the SH4a.


=item B<-m4al>

Same as B<-m4a-nofpu>, except that it implicitly passes
B<-dsp> to the assembler.  GCC doesn't generate any DSP
instructions at the moment.


=item B<-mb>

Compile code for the processor in big-endian mode.


=item B<-ml>

Compile code for the processor in little-endian mode.


=item B<-mdalign>

Align doubles at 64-bit boundaries.  Note that this changes the calling
conventions, and thus some functions from the standard C library do
not work unless you recompile it first with B<-mdalign>.


=item B<-mrelax>

Shorten some address references at link time, when possible; uses the
linker option B<-relax>.


=item B<-mbigtable>

Use 32-bit offsets in C<switch> tables.  The default is to use
16-bit offsets.


=item B<-mbitops>

Enable the use of bit manipulation instructions on SH2A.


=item B<-mfmovd>

Enable the use of the instruction C<fmovd>.  Check B<-mdalign> for
alignment constraints.


=item B<-mrenesas>

Comply with the calling conventions defined by Renesas.


=item B<-mno-renesas>

Comply with the calling conventions defined for GCC before the Renesas
conventions were available.  This option is the default for all
targets of the SH toolchain.


=item B<-mnomacsave>

Mark the C<MAC> register as call-clobbered, even if
B<-mrenesas> is given.


=item B<-mieee>


=item B<-mno-ieee>

Control the IEEE compliance of floating-point comparisons, which affects the
handling of cases where the result of a comparison is unordered.  By default
B<-mieee> is implicitly enabled.  If B<-ffinite-math-only> is
enabled B<-mno-ieee> is implicitly set, which results in faster
floating-point greater-equal and less-equal comparisons.  The implicit settings
can be overridden by specifying either B<-mieee> or B<-mno-ieee>.


=item B<-minline-ic_invalidate>

Inline code to invalidate instruction cache entries after setting up
nested function trampolines.
This option has no effect if B<-musermode> is in effect and the selected
code generation option (e.g. B<-m4>) does not allow the use of the C<icbi>
instruction.
If the selected code generation option does not allow the use of the C<icbi>
instruction, and B<-musermode> is not in effect, the inlined code
manipulates the instruction cache address array directly with an associative
write.  This not only requires privileged mode at run time, but it also
fails if the cache line had been mapped via the TLB and has become unmapped.


=item B<-misize>

Dump instruction size and location in the assembly code.


=item B<-mpadstruct>

This option is deprecated.  It pads structures to multiple of 4 bytes,
which is incompatible with the SH ABI.


=item B<-matomic-model=>I<model>

Sets the model of atomic operations and additional parameters as a comma
separated list.  For details on the atomic built-in functions see
B<__atomic Builtins>.  The following models and parameters are supported:


=over 4



=item B<none>

Disable compiler generated atomic sequences and emit library calls for atomic
operations.  This is the default if the target is not C<sh*-*-linux*>.


=item B<soft-gusa>

Generate GNU/Linux compatible gUSA software atomic sequences for the atomic
built-in functions.  The generated atomic sequences require additional support
from the interrupt/exception handling code of the system and are only suitable
for SH3* and SH4* single-core systems.  This option is enabled by default when
the target is C<sh*-*-linux*> and SH3* or SH4*.  When the target is SH4A,
this option also partially utilizes the hardware atomic instructions
C<movli.l> and C<movco.l> to create more efficient code, unless
B<strict> is specified.  


=item B<soft-tcb>

Generate software atomic sequences that use a variable in the thread control
block.  This is a variation of the gUSA sequences which can also be used on
SH1* and SH2* targets.  The generated atomic sequences require additional
support from the interrupt/exception handling code of the system and are only
suitable for single-core systems.  When using this model, the B<gbr-offset=>
parameter has to be specified as well.


=item B<soft-imask>

Generate software atomic sequences that temporarily disable interrupts by
setting C<SR.IMASK = 1111>.  This model works only when the program runs
in privileged mode and is only suitable for single-core systems.  Additional
support from the interrupt/exception handling code of the system is not
required.  This model is enabled by default when the target is
C<sh*-*-linux*> and SH1* or SH2*.


=item B<hard-llcs>

Generate hardware atomic sequences using the C<movli.l> and C<movco.l>
instructions only.  This is only available on SH4A and is suitable for
multi-core systems.  Since the hardware instructions support only 32 bit atomic
variables access to 8 or 16 bit variables is emulated with 32 bit accesses.
Code compiled with this option is also compatible with other software
atomic model interrupt/exception handling systems if executed on an SH4A
system.  Additional support from the interrupt/exception handling code of the
system is not required for this model.


=item B<gbr-offset=>

This parameter specifies the offset in bytes of the variable in the thread
control block structure that should be used by the generated atomic sequences
when the B<soft-tcb> model has been selected.  For other models this
parameter is ignored.  The specified value must be an integer multiple of four
and in the range 0-1020.


=item B<strict>

This parameter prevents mixed usage of multiple atomic models, even if they
are compatible, and makes the compiler generate atomic sequences of the
specified model only.


=back



=item B<-mtas>

Generate the C<tas.b> opcode for C<__atomic_test_and_set>.
Notice that depending on the particular hardware and software configuration
this can degrade overall performance due to the operand cache line flushes
that are implied by the C<tas.b> instruction.  On multi-core SH4A
processors the C<tas.b> instruction must be used with caution since it
can result in data corruption for certain cache configurations.


=item B<-mprefergot>

When generating position-independent code, emit function calls using
the Global Offset Table instead of the Procedure Linkage Table.


=item B<-musermode>


=item B<-mno-usermode>

Don't allow (allow) the compiler generating privileged mode code.  Specifying
B<-musermode> also implies B<-mno-inline-ic_invalidate> if the
inlined code would not work in user mode.  B<-musermode> is the default
when the target is C<sh*-*-linux*>.  If the target is SH1* or SH2*
B<-musermode> has no effect, since there is no user mode.


=item B<-multcost=>I<number>

Set the cost to assume for a multiply insn.


=item B<-mdiv=>I<strategy>

Set the division strategy to be used for integer division operations.
I<strategy> can be one of: 


=over 4



=item B<call-div1>

Calls a library function that uses the single-step division instruction
C<div1> to perform the operation.  Division by zero calculates an
unspecified result and does not trap.  This is the default except for SH4,
SH2A and SHcompact.


=item B<call-fp>

Calls a library function that performs the operation in double precision
floating point.  Division by zero causes a floating-point exception.  This is
the default for SHcompact with FPU.  Specifying this for targets that do not
have a double precision FPU defaults to C<call-div1>.


=item B<call-table>

Calls a library function that uses a lookup table for small divisors and
the C<div1> instruction with case distinction for larger divisors.  Division
by zero calculates an unspecified result and does not trap.  This is the default
for SH4.  Specifying this for targets that do not have dynamic shift
instructions defaults to C<call-div1>.


=back


When a division strategy has not been specified the default strategy is
selected based on the current target.  For SH2A the default strategy is to
use the C<divs> and C<divu> instructions instead of library function
calls.


=item B<-maccumulate-outgoing-args>

Reserve space once for outgoing arguments in the function prologue rather
than around each call.  Generally beneficial for performance and size.  Also
needed for unwinding to avoid changing the stack frame around conditional code.


=item B<-mdivsi3_libfunc=>I<name>

Set the name of the library function used for 32-bit signed division to
I<name>.
This only affects the name used in the B<call> division strategies, and
the compiler still expects the same sets of input/output/clobbered registers as
if this option were not present.


=item B<-mfixed-range=>I<register-range>

Generate code treating the given register range as fixed registers.
A fixed register is one that the register allocator cannot use.  This is
useful when compiling kernel code.  A register range is specified as
two registers separated by a dash.  Multiple register ranges can be
specified separated by a comma.


=item B<-mbranch-cost=>I<num>

Assume I<num> to be the cost for a branch instruction.  Higher numbers
make the compiler try to generate more branch-free code if possible.  
If not specified the value is selected depending on the processor type that
is being compiled for.


=item B<-mzdcbranch>


=item B<-mno-zdcbranch>

Assume (do not assume) that zero displacement conditional branch instructions
C<bt> and C<bf> are fast.  If B<-mzdcbranch> is specified, the
compiler prefers zero displacement branch code sequences.  This is
enabled by default when generating code for SH4 and SH4A.  It can be explicitly
disabled by specifying B<-mno-zdcbranch>.


=item B<-mcbranch-force-delay-slot>

Force the usage of delay slots for conditional branches, which stuffs the delay
slot with a C<nop> if a suitable instruction cannot be found.  By default
this option is disabled.  It can be enabled to work around hardware bugs as
found in the original SH7055.


=item B<-mfused-madd>


=item B<-mno-fused-madd>

Generate code that uses (does not use) the floating-point multiply and
accumulate instructions.  These instructions are generated by default
if hardware floating point is used.  The machine-dependent
B<-mfused-madd> option is now mapped to the machine-independent
B<-ffp-contract=fast> option, and B<-mno-fused-madd> is
mapped to B<-ffp-contract=off>.


=item B<-mfsca>


=item B<-mno-fsca>

Allow or disallow the compiler to emit the C<fsca> instruction for sine
and cosine approximations.  The option B<-mfsca> must be used in
combination with B<-funsafe-math-optimizations>.  It is enabled by default
when generating code for SH4A.  Using B<-mno-fsca> disables sine and cosine
approximations even if B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is in effect.


=item B<-mfsrra>


=item B<-mno-fsrra>

Allow or disallow the compiler to emit the C<fsrra> instruction for
reciprocal square root approximations.  The option B<-mfsrra> must be used
in combination with B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> and
B<-ffinite-math-only>.  It is enabled by default when generating code for
SH4A.  Using B<-mno-fsrra> disables reciprocal square root approximations
even if B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> and B<-ffinite-math-only> are
in effect.


=item B<-mpretend-cmove>

Prefer zero-displacement conditional branches for conditional move instruction
patterns.  This can result in faster code on the SH4 processor.


=item B<-mfdpic>

Generate code using the FDPIC ABI.


=back



=head3 Solaris 2 Options


These B<-m> options are supported on Solaris 2:


=over 4


=item B<-mclear-hwcap>

B<-mclear-hwcap> tells the compiler to remove the hardware
capabilities generated by the Solaris assembler.  This is only necessary
when object files use ISA extensions not supported by the current
machine, but check at runtime whether or not to use them.


=item B<-mimpure-text>

B<-mimpure-text>, used in addition to B<-shared>, tells
the compiler to not pass B<-z text> to the linker when linking a
shared object.  Using this option, you can link position-dependent
code into a shared object.

B<-mimpure-text> suppresses the "relocations remain against
allocatable but non-writable sections" linker error message.
However, the necessary relocations trigger copy-on-write, and the
shared object is not actually shared across processes.  Instead of
using B<-mimpure-text>, you should compile all source code with
B<-fpic> or B<-fPIC>.


=back


These switches are supported in addition to the above on Solaris 2:


=over 4


=item B<-pthreads>

This is a synonym for B<-pthread>.

=back



=head3 SPARC Options


These B<-m> options are supported on the SPARC:


=over 4


=item B<-mno-app-regs>


=item B<-mapp-regs>

Specify B<-mapp-regs> to generate output using the global registers
2 through 4, which the SPARC SVR4 ABI reserves for applications.  Like the
global register 1, each global register 2 through 4 is then treated as an
allocable register that is clobbered by function calls.  This is the default.

To be fully SVR4 ABI-compliant at the cost of some performance loss,
specify B<-mno-app-regs>.  You should compile libraries and system
software with this option.


=item B<-mflat>


=item B<-mno-flat>

With B<-mflat>, the compiler does not generate save/restore instructions
and uses a "flat" or single register window model.  This model is compatible
with the regular register window model.  The local registers and the input
registers (0--5) are still treated as "call-saved" registers and are
saved on the stack as needed.

With B<-mno-flat> (the default), the compiler generates save/restore
instructions (except for leaf functions).  This is the normal operating mode.


=item B<-mfpu>


=item B<-mhard-float>

Generate output containing floating-point instructions.  This is the
default.


=item B<-mno-fpu>


=item B<-msoft-float>

Generate output containing library calls for floating point.
B<Warning:> the requisite libraries are not available for all SPARC
targets.  Normally the facilities of the machine's usual C compiler are
used, but this cannot be done directly in cross-compilation.  You must make
your own arrangements to provide suitable library functions for
cross-compilation.  The embedded targets B<sparc-*-aout> and
B<sparclite-*-*> do provide software floating-point support.

B<-msoft-float> changes the calling convention in the output file;
therefore, it is only useful if you compile I<all> of a program with
this option.  In particular, you need to compile F<libgcc.a>, the
library that comes with GCC, with B<-msoft-float> in order for
this to work.


=item B<-mhard-quad-float>

Generate output containing quad-word (long double) floating-point
instructions.


=item B<-msoft-quad-float>

Generate output containing library calls for quad-word (long double)
floating-point instructions.  The functions called are those specified
in the SPARC ABI.  This is the default.

As of this writing, there are no SPARC implementations that have hardware
support for the quad-word floating-point instructions.  They all invoke
a trap handler for one of these instructions, and then the trap handler
emulates the effect of the instruction.  Because of the trap handler overhead,
this is much slower than calling the ABI library routines.  Thus the
B<-msoft-quad-float> option is the default.


=item B<-mno-unaligned-doubles>


=item B<-munaligned-doubles>

Assume that doubles have 8-byte alignment.  This is the default.

With B<-munaligned-doubles>, GCC assumes that doubles have 8-byte
alignment only if they are contained in another type, or if they have an
absolute address.  Otherwise, it assumes they have 4-byte alignment.
Specifying this option avoids some rare compatibility problems with code
generated by other compilers.  It is not the default because it results
in a performance loss, especially for floating-point code.


=item B<-muser-mode>


=item B<-mno-user-mode>

Do not generate code that can only run in supervisor mode.  This is relevant
only for the C<casa> instruction emitted for the LEON3 processor.  This
is the default.


=item B<-mfaster-structs>


=item B<-mno-faster-structs>

With B<-mfaster-structs>, the compiler assumes that structures
should have 8-byte alignment.  This enables the use of pairs of
C<ldd> and C<std> instructions for copies in structure
assignment, in place of twice as many C<ld> and C<st> pairs.
However, the use of this changed alignment directly violates the SPARC
ABI.  Thus, it's intended only for use on targets where the developer
acknowledges that their resulting code is not directly in line with
the rules of the ABI.


=item B<-mstd-struct-return>


=item B<-mno-std-struct-return>

With B<-mstd-struct-return>, the compiler generates checking code
in functions returning structures or unions to detect size mismatches
between the two sides of function calls, as per the 32-bit ABI.

The default is B<-mno-std-struct-return>.  This option has no effect
in 64-bit mode.


=item B<-mlra>


=item B<-mno-lra>

Enable Local Register Allocation.  This is the default for SPARC since GCC 7
so B<-mno-lra> needs to be passed to get old Reload.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type>

Set the instruction set, register set, and instruction scheduling parameters
for machine type I<cpu_type>.  Supported values for I<cpu_type> are
B<v7>, B<cypress>, B<v8>, B<supersparc>, B<hypersparc>,
B<leon>, B<leon3>, B<leon3v7>, B<sparclite>, B<f930>,
B<f934>, B<sparclite86x>, B<sparclet>, B<tsc701>, B<v9>,
B<ultrasparc>, B<ultrasparc3>, B<niagara>, B<niagara2>,
B<niagara3>, B<niagara4>, B<niagara7> and B<m8>.

Native Solaris and GNU/Linux toolchains also support the value B<native>,
which selects the best architecture option for the host processor.
B<-mcpu=native> has no effect if GCC does not recognize
the processor.

Default instruction scheduling parameters are used for values that select
an architecture and not an implementation.  These are B<v7>, B<v8>,
B<sparclite>, B<sparclet>, B<v9>.

Here is a list of each supported architecture and their supported
implementations.


=over 4


=item v7

cypress, leon3v7


=item v8

supersparc, hypersparc, leon, leon3


=item sparclite

f930, f934, sparclite86x


=item sparclet

tsc701


=item v9

ultrasparc, ultrasparc3, niagara, niagara2, niagara3, niagara4,
niagara7, m8

=back


By default (unless configured otherwise), GCC generates code for the V7
variant of the SPARC architecture.  With B<-mcpu=cypress>, the compiler
additionally optimizes it for the Cypress CY7C602 chip, as used in the
SPARCStation/SPARCServer 3xx series.  This is also appropriate for the older
SPARCStation 1, 2, IPX etc.

With B<-mcpu=v8>, GCC generates code for the V8 variant of the SPARC
architecture.  The only difference from V7 code is that the compiler emits
the integer multiply and integer divide instructions which exist in SPARC-V8
but not in SPARC-V7.  With B<-mcpu=supersparc>, the compiler additionally
optimizes it for the SuperSPARC chip, as used in the SPARCStation 10, 1000 and
2000 series.

With B<-mcpu=sparclite>, GCC generates code for the SPARClite variant of
the SPARC architecture.  This adds the integer multiply, integer divide step
and scan (C<ffs>) instructions which exist in SPARClite but not in SPARC-V7.
With B<-mcpu=f930>, the compiler additionally optimizes it for the
Fujitsu MB86930 chip, which is the original SPARClite, with no FPU.  With
B<-mcpu=f934>, the compiler additionally optimizes it for the Fujitsu
MB86934 chip, which is the more recent SPARClite with FPU.

With B<-mcpu=sparclet>, GCC generates code for the SPARClet variant of
the SPARC architecture.  This adds the integer multiply, multiply/accumulate,
integer divide step and scan (C<ffs>) instructions which exist in SPARClet
but not in SPARC-V7.  With B<-mcpu=tsc701>, the compiler additionally
optimizes it for the TEMIC SPARClet chip.

With B<-mcpu=v9>, GCC generates code for the V9 variant of the SPARC
architecture.  This adds 64-bit integer and floating-point move instructions,
3 additional floating-point condition code registers and conditional move
instructions.  With B<-mcpu=ultrasparc>, the compiler additionally
optimizes it for the Sun UltraSPARC I/II/IIi chips.  With
B<-mcpu=ultrasparc3>, the compiler additionally optimizes it for the
Sun UltraSPARC III/III+/IIIi/IIIi+/IV/IV+ chips.  With
B<-mcpu=niagara>, the compiler additionally optimizes it for
Sun UltraSPARC T1 chips.  With B<-mcpu=niagara2>, the compiler
additionally optimizes it for Sun UltraSPARC T2 chips. With
B<-mcpu=niagara3>, the compiler additionally optimizes it for Sun
UltraSPARC T3 chips.  With B<-mcpu=niagara4>, the compiler
additionally optimizes it for Sun UltraSPARC T4 chips.  With
B<-mcpu=niagara7>, the compiler additionally optimizes it for
Oracle SPARC M7 chips.  With B<-mcpu=m8>, the compiler
additionally optimizes it for Oracle M8 chips.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu_type>

Set the instruction scheduling parameters for machine type
I<cpu_type>, but do not set the instruction set or register set that the
option B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type> does.

The same values for B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type> can be used for
B<-mtune=>I<cpu_type>, but the only useful values are those
that select a particular CPU implementation.  Those are
B<cypress>, B<supersparc>, B<hypersparc>, B<leon>,
B<leon3>, B<leon3v7>, B<f930>, B<f934>,
B<sparclite86x>, B<tsc701>, B<ultrasparc>,
B<ultrasparc3>, B<niagara>, B<niagara2>, B<niagara3>,
B<niagara4>, B<niagara7> and B<m8>.  With native Solaris
and GNU/Linux toolchains, B<native> can also be used.


=item B<-mv8plus>


=item B<-mno-v8plus>

With B<-mv8plus>, GCC generates code for the SPARC-V8+ ABI.  The
difference from the V8 ABI is that the global and out registers are
considered 64 bits wide.  This is enabled by default on Solaris in 32-bit
mode for all SPARC-V9 processors.


=item B<-mvis>


=item B<-mno-vis>

With B<-mvis>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of the UltraSPARC
Visual Instruction Set extensions.  The default is B<-mno-vis>.


=item B<-mvis2>


=item B<-mno-vis2>

With B<-mvis2>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of
version 2.0 of the UltraSPARC Visual Instruction Set extensions.  The
default is B<-mvis2> when targeting a cpu that supports such
instructions, such as UltraSPARC-III and later.  Setting B<-mvis2>
also sets B<-mvis>.


=item B<-mvis3>


=item B<-mno-vis3>

With B<-mvis3>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of
version 3.0 of the UltraSPARC Visual Instruction Set extensions.  The
default is B<-mvis3> when targeting a cpu that supports such
instructions, such as niagara-3 and later.  Setting B<-mvis3>
also sets B<-mvis2> and B<-mvis>.


=item B<-mvis4>


=item B<-mno-vis4>

With B<-mvis4>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of
version 4.0 of the UltraSPARC Visual Instruction Set extensions.  The
default is B<-mvis4> when targeting a cpu that supports such
instructions, such as niagara-7 and later.  Setting B<-mvis4>
also sets B<-mvis3>, B<-mvis2> and B<-mvis>.


=item B<-mvis4b>


=item B<-mno-vis4b>

With B<-mvis4b>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of
version 4.0 of the UltraSPARC Visual Instruction Set extensions, plus
the additional VIS instructions introduced in the Oracle SPARC
Architecture 2017.  The default is B<-mvis4b> when targeting a
cpu that supports such instructions, such as m8 and later.  Setting
B<-mvis4b> also sets B<-mvis4>, B<-mvis3>,
B<-mvis2> and B<-mvis>.


=item B<-mcbcond>


=item B<-mno-cbcond>

With B<-mcbcond>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of the UltraSPARC
Compare-and-Branch-on-Condition instructions.  The default is B<-mcbcond>
when targeting a CPU that supports such instructions, such as Niagara-4 and
later.


=item B<-mfmaf>


=item B<-mno-fmaf>

With B<-mfmaf>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of the UltraSPARC
Fused Multiply-Add Floating-point instructions.  The default is B<-mfmaf>
when targeting a CPU that supports such instructions, such as Niagara-3 and
later.


=item B<-mfsmuld>


=item B<-mno-fsmuld>

With B<-mfsmuld>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of the
Floating-point Multiply Single to Double (FsMULd) instruction.  The default is
B<-mfsmuld> when targeting a CPU supporting the architecture versions V8
or V9 with FPU except B<-mcpu=leon>.


=item B<-mpopc>


=item B<-mno-popc>

With B<-mpopc>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of the UltraSPARC
Population Count instruction.  The default is B<-mpopc>
when targeting a CPU that supports such an instruction, such as Niagara-2 and
later.


=item B<-msubxc>


=item B<-mno-subxc>

With B<-msubxc>, GCC generates code that takes advantage of the UltraSPARC
Subtract-Extended-with-Carry instruction.  The default is B<-msubxc>
when targeting a CPU that supports such an instruction, such as Niagara-7 and
later.


=item B<-mfix-at697f>

Enable the documented workaround for the single erratum of the Atmel AT697F
processor (which corresponds to erratum #13 of the AT697E processor).


=item B<-mfix-ut699>

Enable the documented workarounds for the floating-point errata and the data
cache nullify errata of the UT699 processor.


=item B<-mfix-ut700>

Enable the documented workaround for the back-to-back store errata of
the UT699E/UT700 processor.


=item B<-mfix-gr712rc>

Enable the documented workaround for the back-to-back store errata of
the GR712RC processor.

=back


These B<-m> options are supported in addition to the above
on SPARC-V9 processors in 64-bit environments:


=over 4


=item B<-m32>


=item B<-m64>

Generate code for a 32-bit or 64-bit environment.
The 32-bit environment sets int, long and pointer to 32 bits.
The 64-bit environment sets int to 32 bits and long and pointer
to 64 bits.


=item B<-mcmodel=>I<which>

Set the code model to one of


=over 4


=item B<medlow>

The Medium/Low code model: 64-bit addresses, programs
must be linked in the low 32 bits of memory.  Programs can be statically
or dynamically linked.


=item B<medmid>

The Medium/Middle code model: 64-bit addresses, programs
must be linked in the low 44 bits of memory, the text and data segments must
be less than 2GB in size and the data segment must be located within 2GB of
the text segment.


=item B<medany>

The Medium/Anywhere code model: 64-bit addresses, programs
may be linked anywhere in memory, the text and data segments must be less
than 2GB in size and the data segment must be located within 2GB of the
text segment.


=item B<embmedany>

The Medium/Anywhere code model for embedded systems:
64-bit addresses, the text and data segments must be less than 2GB in
size, both starting anywhere in memory (determined at link time).  The
global register %g4 points to the base of the data segment.  Programs
are statically linked and PIC is not supported.

=back



=item B<-mmemory-model=>I<mem-model>

Set the memory model in force on the processor to one of


=over 4


=item B<default>

The default memory model for the processor and operating system.


=item B<rmo>

Relaxed Memory Order


=item B<pso>

Partial Store Order


=item B<tso>

Total Store Order


=item B<sc>

Sequential Consistency

=back


These memory models are formally defined in Appendix D of the SPARC-V9
architecture manual, as set in the processor's C<PSTATE.MM> field.


=item B<-mstack-bias>


=item B<-mno-stack-bias>

With B<-mstack-bias>, GCC assumes that the stack pointer, and
frame pointer if present, are offset by -2047 which must be added back
when making stack frame references.  This is the default in 64-bit mode.
Otherwise, assume no such offset is present.

=back



=head3 SPU Options


These B<-m> options are supported on the SPU:


=over 4


=item B<-mwarn-reloc>


=item B<-merror-reloc>


The loader for SPU does not handle dynamic relocations.  By default, GCC
gives an error when it generates code that requires a dynamic
relocation.  B<-mno-error-reloc> disables the error,
B<-mwarn-reloc> generates a warning instead.


=item B<-msafe-dma>


=item B<-munsafe-dma>


Instructions that initiate or test completion of DMA must not be
reordered with respect to loads and stores of the memory that is being
accessed.
With B<-munsafe-dma> you must use the C<volatile> keyword to protect
memory accesses, but that can lead to inefficient code in places where the
memory is known to not change.  Rather than mark the memory as volatile,
you can use B<-msafe-dma> to tell the compiler to treat
the DMA instructions as potentially affecting all memory.  


=item B<-mbranch-hints>


By default, GCC generates a branch hint instruction to avoid
pipeline stalls for always-taken or probably-taken branches.  A hint
is not generated closer than 8 instructions away from its branch.
There is little reason to disable them, except for debugging purposes,
or to make an object a little bit smaller.


=item B<-msmall-mem>


=item B<-mlarge-mem>


By default, GCC generates code assuming that addresses are never larger
than 18 bits.  With B<-mlarge-mem> code is generated that assumes
a full 32-bit address.


=item B<-mstdmain>


By default, GCC links against startup code that assumes the SPU-style
main function interface (which has an unconventional parameter list).
With B<-mstdmain>, GCC links your program against startup
code that assumes a C99-style interface to C<main>, including a
local copy of C<argv> strings.


=item B<-mfixed-range=>I<register-range>

Generate code treating the given register range as fixed registers.
A fixed register is one that the register allocator cannot use.  This is
useful when compiling kernel code.  A register range is specified as
two registers separated by a dash.  Multiple register ranges can be
specified separated by a comma.


=item B<-mea32>


=item B<-mea64>

Compile code assuming that pointers to the PPU address space accessed
via the C<__ea> named address space qualifier are either 32 or 64
bits wide.  The default is 32 bits.  As this is an ABI-changing option,
all object code in an executable must be compiled with the same setting.


=item B<-maddress-space-conversion>


=item B<-mno-address-space-conversion>

Allow/disallow treating the C<__ea> address space as superset
of the generic address space.  This enables explicit type casts
between C<__ea> and generic pointer as well as implicit
conversions of generic pointers to C<__ea> pointers.  The
default is to allow address space pointer conversions.


=item B<-mcache-size=>I<cache-size>

This option controls the version of libgcc that the compiler links to an
executable and selects a software-managed cache for accessing variables
in the C<__ea> address space with a particular cache size.  Possible
options for I<cache-size> are B<8>, B<16>, B<32>, B<64>
and B<128>.  The default cache size is 64KB.


=item B<-matomic-updates>


=item B<-mno-atomic-updates>

This option controls the version of libgcc that the compiler links to an
executable and selects whether atomic updates to the software-managed
cache of PPU-side variables are used.  If you use atomic updates, changes
to a PPU variable from SPU code using the C<__ea> named address space
qualifier do not interfere with changes to other PPU variables residing
in the same cache line from PPU code.  If you do not use atomic updates,
such interference may occur; however, writing back cache lines is
more efficient.  The default behavior is to use atomic updates.


=item B<-mdual-nops>


=item B<-mdual-nops=>I<n>

By default, GCC inserts NOPs to increase dual issue when it expects
it to increase performance.  I<n> can be a value from 0 to 10.  A
smaller I<n> inserts fewer NOPs.  10 is the default, 0 is the
same as B<-mno-dual-nops>.  Disabled with B<-Os>.


=item B<-mhint-max-nops=>I<n>

Maximum number of NOPs to insert for a branch hint.  A branch hint must
be at least 8 instructions away from the branch it is affecting.  GCC
inserts up to I<n> NOPs to enforce this, otherwise it does not
generate the branch hint.


=item B<-mhint-max-distance=>I<n>

The encoding of the branch hint instruction limits the hint to be within
256 instructions of the branch it is affecting.  By default, GCC makes
sure it is within 125.


=item B<-msafe-hints>

Work around a hardware bug that causes the SPU to stall indefinitely.
By default, GCC inserts the C<hbrp> instruction to make sure
this stall won't happen.


=back



=head3 Options for System V


These additional options are available on System V Release 4 for
compatibility with other compilers on those systems:


=over 4


=item B<-G>

Create a shared object.
It is recommended that B<-symbolic> or B<-shared> be used instead.


=item B<-Qy>

Identify the versions of each tool used by the compiler, in a
C<.ident> assembler directive in the output.


=item B<-Qn>

Refrain from adding C<.ident> directives to the output file (this is
the default).


=item B<-YP,>I<dirs>

Search the directories I<dirs>, and no others, for libraries
specified with B<-l>.


=item B<-Ym,>I<dir>

Look in the directory I<dir> to find the M4 preprocessor.
The assembler uses this option.

=back



=head3 TILE-Gx Options


These B<-m> options are supported on the TILE-Gx:


=over 4


=item B<-mcmodel=small>

Generate code for the small model.  The distance for direct calls is
limited to 500M in either direction.  PC-relative addresses are 32
bits.  Absolute addresses support the full address range.


=item B<-mcmodel=large>

Generate code for the large model.  There is no limitation on call
distance, pc-relative addresses, or absolute addresses.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<name>

Selects the type of CPU to be targeted.  Currently the only supported
type is B<tilegx>.


=item B<-m32>


=item B<-m64>

Generate code for a 32-bit or 64-bit environment.  The 32-bit
environment sets int, long, and pointer to 32 bits.  The 64-bit
environment sets int to 32 bits and long and pointer to 64 bits.


=item B<-mbig-endian>


=item B<-mlittle-endian>

Generate code in big/little endian mode, respectively.

=back



=head3 TILEPro Options


These B<-m> options are supported on the TILEPro:


=over 4


=item B<-mcpu=>I<name>

Selects the type of CPU to be targeted.  Currently the only supported
type is B<tilepro>.


=item B<-m32>

Generate code for a 32-bit environment, which sets int, long, and
pointer to 32 bits.  This is the only supported behavior so the flag
is essentially ignored.

=back



=head3 V850 Options


These B<-m> options are defined for V850 implementations:


=over 4


=item B<-mlong-calls>


=item B<-mno-long-calls>

Treat all calls as being far away (near).  If calls are assumed to be
far away, the compiler always loads the function's address into a
register, and calls indirect through the pointer.


=item B<-mno-ep>


=item B<-mep>

Do not optimize (do optimize) basic blocks that use the same index
pointer 4 or more times to copy pointer into the C<ep> register, and
use the shorter C<sld> and C<sst> instructions.  The B<-mep>
option is on by default if you optimize.


=item B<-mno-prolog-function>


=item B<-mprolog-function>

Do not use (do use) external functions to save and restore registers
at the prologue and epilogue of a function.  The external functions
are slower, but use less code space if more than one function saves
the same number of registers.  The B<-mprolog-function> option
is on by default if you optimize.


=item B<-mspace>

Try to make the code as small as possible.  At present, this just turns
on the B<-mep> and B<-mprolog-function> options.


=item B<-mtda=>I<n>

Put static or global variables whose size is I<n> bytes or less into
the tiny data area that register C<ep> points to.  The tiny data
area can hold up to 256 bytes in total (128 bytes for byte references).


=item B<-msda=>I<n>

Put static or global variables whose size is I<n> bytes or less into
the small data area that register C<gp> points to.  The small data
area can hold up to 64 kilobytes.


=item B<-mzda=>I<n>

Put static or global variables whose size is I<n> bytes or less into
the first 32 kilobytes of memory.


=item B<-mv850>

Specify that the target processor is the V850.


=item B<-mv850e3v5>

Specify that the target processor is the V850E3V5.  The preprocessor
constant C<__v850e3v5__> is defined if this option is used.


=item B<-mv850e2v4>

Specify that the target processor is the V850E3V5.  This is an alias for
the B<-mv850e3v5> option.


=item B<-mv850e2v3>

Specify that the target processor is the V850E2V3.  The preprocessor
constant C<__v850e2v3__> is defined if this option is used.


=item B<-mv850e2>

Specify that the target processor is the V850E2.  The preprocessor
constant C<__v850e2__> is defined if this option is used.


=item B<-mv850e1>

Specify that the target processor is the V850E1.  The preprocessor
constants C<__v850e1__> and C<__v850e__> are defined if
this option is used.


=item B<-mv850es>

Specify that the target processor is the V850ES.  This is an alias for
the B<-mv850e1> option.


=item B<-mv850e>

Specify that the target processor is the V850E.  The preprocessor
constant C<__v850e__> is defined if this option is used.

If neither B<-mv850> nor B<-mv850e> nor B<-mv850e1>
nor B<-mv850e2> nor B<-mv850e2v3> nor B<-mv850e3v5>
are defined then a default target processor is chosen and the
relevant B<__v850*__> preprocessor constant is defined.

The preprocessor constants C<__v850> and C<__v851__> are always
defined, regardless of which processor variant is the target.


=item B<-mdisable-callt>


=item B<-mno-disable-callt>

This option suppresses generation of the C<CALLT> instruction for the
v850e, v850e1, v850e2, v850e2v3 and v850e3v5 flavors of the v850
architecture.

This option is enabled by default when the RH850 ABI is
in use (see B<-mrh850-abi>), and disabled by default when the
GCC ABI is in use.  If C<CALLT> instructions are being generated
then the C preprocessor symbol C<__V850_CALLT__> is defined.


=item B<-mrelax>


=item B<-mno-relax>

Pass on (or do not pass on) the B<-mrelax> command-line option
to the assembler.


=item B<-mlong-jumps>


=item B<-mno-long-jumps>

Disable (or re-enable) the generation of PC-relative jump instructions.


=item B<-msoft-float>


=item B<-mhard-float>

Disable (or re-enable) the generation of hardware floating point
instructions.  This option is only significant when the target
architecture is B<V850E2V3> or higher.  If hardware floating point
instructions are being generated then the C preprocessor symbol
C<__FPU_OK__> is defined, otherwise the symbol
C<__NO_FPU__> is defined.


=item B<-mloop>

Enables the use of the e3v5 LOOP instruction.  The use of this
instruction is not enabled by default when the e3v5 architecture is
selected because its use is still experimental.


=item B<-mrh850-abi>


=item B<-mghs>

Enables support for the RH850 version of the V850 ABI.  This is the
default.  With this version of the ABI the following rules apply:


=over 4


=item Z<>*

Integer sized structures and unions are returned via a memory pointer
rather than a register.


=item Z<>*

Large structures and unions (more than 8 bytes in size) are passed by
value.


=item Z<>*

Functions are aligned to 16-bit boundaries.


=item Z<>*

The B<-m8byte-align> command-line option is supported.


=item Z<>*

The B<-mdisable-callt> command-line option is enabled by
default.  The B<-mno-disable-callt> command-line option is not
supported.

=back


When this version of the ABI is enabled the C preprocessor symbol
C<__V850_RH850_ABI__> is defined.


=item B<-mgcc-abi>

Enables support for the old GCC version of the V850 ABI.  With this
version of the ABI the following rules apply:


=over 4


=item Z<>*

Integer sized structures and unions are returned in register C<r10>.


=item Z<>*

Large structures and unions (more than 8 bytes in size) are passed by
reference.


=item Z<>*

Functions are aligned to 32-bit boundaries, unless optimizing for
size.


=item Z<>*

The B<-m8byte-align> command-line option is not supported.


=item Z<>*

The B<-mdisable-callt> command-line option is supported but not
enabled by default.

=back


When this version of the ABI is enabled the C preprocessor symbol
C<__V850_GCC_ABI__> is defined.


=item B<-m8byte-align>


=item B<-mno-8byte-align>

Enables support for C<double> and C<long long> types to be
aligned on 8-byte boundaries.  The default is to restrict the
alignment of all objects to at most 4-bytes.  When
B<-m8byte-align> is in effect the C preprocessor symbol
C<__V850_8BYTE_ALIGN__> is defined.


=item B<-mbig-switch>

Generate code suitable for big switch tables.  Use this option only if
the assembler/linker complain about out of range branches within a switch
table.


=item B<-mapp-regs>

This option causes r2 and r5 to be used in the code generated by
the compiler.  This setting is the default.


=item B<-mno-app-regs>

This option causes r2 and r5 to be treated as fixed registers.


=back



=head3 VAX Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the VAX:


=over 4


=item B<-munix>

Do not output certain jump instructions (C<aobleq> and so on)
that the Unix assembler for the VAX cannot handle across long
ranges.


=item B<-mgnu>

Do output those jump instructions, on the assumption that the
GNU assembler is being used.


=item B<-mg>

Output code for G-format floating-point numbers instead of D-format.

=back



=head3 Visium Options



=over 4



=item B<-mdebug>

A program which performs file I/O and is destined to run on an MCM target
should be linked with this option.  It causes the libraries libc.a and
libdebug.a to be linked.  The program should be run on the target under
the control of the GDB remote debugging stub.


=item B<-msim>

A program which performs file I/O and is destined to run on the simulator
should be linked with option.  This causes libraries libc.a and libsim.a to
be linked.


=item B<-mfpu>


=item B<-mhard-float>

Generate code containing floating-point instructions.  This is the
default.


=item B<-mno-fpu>


=item B<-msoft-float>

Generate code containing library calls for floating-point.

B<-msoft-float> changes the calling convention in the output file;
therefore, it is only useful if you compile I<all> of a program with
this option.  In particular, you need to compile F<libgcc.a>, the
library that comes with GCC, with B<-msoft-float> in order for
this to work.


=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type>

Set the instruction set, register set, and instruction scheduling parameters
for machine type I<cpu_type>.  Supported values for I<cpu_type> are
B<mcm>, B<gr5> and B<gr6>.

B<mcm> is a synonym of B<gr5> present for backward compatibility.

By default (unless configured otherwise), GCC generates code for the GR5
variant of the Visium architecture.  

With B<-mcpu=gr6>, GCC generates code for the GR6 variant of the Visium
architecture.  The only difference from GR5 code is that the compiler will
generate block move instructions.


=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu_type>

Set the instruction scheduling parameters for machine type I<cpu_type>,
but do not set the instruction set or register set that the option
B<-mcpu=>I<cpu_type> would.


=item B<-msv-mode>

Generate code for the supervisor mode, where there are no restrictions on
the access to general registers.  This is the default.


=item B<-muser-mode>

Generate code for the user mode, where the access to some general registers
is forbidden: on the GR5, registers r24 to r31 cannot be accessed in this
mode; on the GR6, only registers r29 to r31 are affected.

=back



=head3 VMS Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the VMS implementations:


=over 4


=item B<-mvms-return-codes>

Return VMS condition codes from C<main>. The default is to return POSIX-style
condition (e.g. error) codes.


=item B<-mdebug-main=>I<prefix>

Flag the first routine whose name starts with I<prefix> as the main
routine for the debugger.


=item B<-mmalloc64>

Default to 64-bit memory allocation routines.


=item B<-mpointer-size=>I<size>

Set the default size of pointers. Possible options for I<size> are
B<32> or B<short> for 32 bit pointers, B<64> or B<long>
for 64 bit pointers, and B<no> for supporting only 32 bit pointers.
The later option disables C<pragma pointer_size>.

=back



=head3 VxWorks Options


The options in this section are defined for all VxWorks targets.
Options specific to the target hardware are listed with the other
options for that target.


=over 4


=item B<-mrtp>

GCC can generate code for both VxWorks kernels and real time processes
(RTPs).  This option switches from the former to the latter.  It also
defines the preprocessor macro C<__RTP__>.


=item B<-non-static>

Link an RTP executable against shared libraries rather than static
libraries.  The options B<-static> and B<-shared> can
also be used for RTPs; B<-static>
is the default.


=item B<-Bstatic>


=item B<-Bdynamic>

These options are passed down to the linker.  They are defined for
compatibility with Diab.


=item B<-Xbind-lazy>

Enable lazy binding of function calls.  This option is equivalent to
B<-Wl,-z,now> and is defined for compatibility with Diab.


=item B<-Xbind-now>

Disable lazy binding of function calls.  This option is the default and
is defined for compatibility with Diab.

=back



=head3 x86 Options


These B<-m> options are defined for the x86 family of computers.


=over 4



=item B<-march=>I<cpu-type>

Generate instructions for the machine type I<cpu-type>.  In contrast to
B<-mtune=>I<cpu-type>, which merely tunes the generated code 
for the specified I<cpu-type>, B<-march=>I<cpu-type> allows GCC
to generate code that may not run at all on processors other than the one
indicated.  Specifying B<-march=>I<cpu-type> implies 
B<-mtune=>I<cpu-type>.

The choices for I<cpu-type> are:


=over 4


=item B<native>

This selects the CPU to generate code for at compilation time by determining
the processor type of the compiling machine.  Using B<-march=native>
enables all instruction subsets supported by the local machine (hence
the result might not run on different machines).  Using B<-mtune=native>
produces code optimized for the local machine under the constraints
of the selected instruction set.  


=item B<x86-64>

A generic CPU with 64-bit extensions.


=item B<i386>

Original Intel i386 CPU.


=item B<i486>

Intel i486 CPU.  (No scheduling is implemented for this chip.)


=item B<i586>

(No scheduling is implemented for this chip.)


=item B<nano-2000>

VIA Nano 2xxx CPU with x86-64, MMX, SSE, SSE2, SSE3 and SSSE3
instruction set support.
(No scheduling is implemented for this chip.)


=item B<nano-3000>

VIA Nano 3xxx CPU with x86-64, MMX, SSE, SSE2, SSE3, SSSE3 and SSE4.1
instruction set support.
(No scheduling is implemented for this chip.)


=item B<nano-x2>

VIA Nano Dual Core CPU with x86-64, MMX, SSE, SSE2, SSE3, SSSE3 and SSE4.1
instruction set support.
(No scheduling is implemented for this chip.)


=item B<nano-x4>

VIA Nano Quad Core CPU with x86-64, MMX, SSE, SSE2, SSE3, SSSE3 and SSE4.1
instruction set support.
(No scheduling is implemented for this chip.)


=item B<geode>

AMD Geode embedded processor with MMX and 3DNow! instruction set support.

=back



=item B<-mtune=>I<cpu-type>

Tune to I<cpu-type> everything applicable about the generated code, except
for the ABI and the set of available instructions.  
While picking a specific I<cpu-type> schedules things appropriately
for that particular chip, the compiler does not generate any code that
cannot run on the default machine type unless you use a
B<-march=>I<cpu-type> option.
For example, if GCC is configured for i686-pc-linux-gnu
then B<-mtune=pentium4> generates code that is tuned for Pentium 4
but still runs on i686 machines.

The choices for I<cpu-type> are the same as for B<-march>.
In addition, B<-mtune> supports 2 extra choices for I<cpu-type>:


=over 4


=item B<generic>

Produce code optimized for the most common IA32/AMD64/EM64T processors.
If you know the CPU on which your code will run, then you should use
the corresponding B<-mtune> or B<-march> option instead of
B<-mtune=generic>.  But, if you do not know exactly what CPU users
of your application will have, then you should use this option.

As new processors are deployed in the marketplace, the behavior of this
option will change.  Therefore, if you upgrade to a newer version of
GCC, code generation controlled by this option will change to reflect
the processors
that are most common at the time that version of GCC is released.

There is no B<-march=generic> option because B<-march>
indicates the instruction set the compiler can use, and there is no
generic instruction set applicable to all processors.  In contrast,
B<-mtune> indicates the processor (or, in this case, collection of
processors) for which the code is optimized.


=item B<intel>

Produce code optimized for the most current Intel processors, which are
Haswell and Silvermont for this version of GCC.  If you know the CPU
on which your code will run, then you should use the corresponding
B<-mtune> or B<-march> option instead of B<-mtune=intel>.
But, if you want your application performs better on both Haswell and
Silvermont, then you should use this option.

As new Intel processors are deployed in the marketplace, the behavior of
this option will change.  Therefore, if you upgrade to a newer version of
GCC, code generation controlled by this option will change to reflect
the most current Intel processors at the time that version of GCC is
released.

There is no B<-march=intel> option because B<-march> indicates
the instruction set the compiler can use, and there is no common
instruction set applicable to all processors.  In contrast,
B<-mtune> indicates the processor (or, in this case, collection of
processors) for which the code is optimized.

=back



=item B<-mcpu=>I<cpu-type>

A deprecated synonym for B<-mtune>.


=item B<-mfpmath=>I<unit>

Generate floating-point arithmetic for selected unit I<unit>.  The choices
for I<unit> are:


=over 4


=item B<387>

Use the standard 387 floating-point coprocessor present on the majority of chips and
emulated otherwise.  Code compiled with this option runs almost everywhere.
The temporary results are computed in 80-bit precision instead of the precision
specified by the type, resulting in slightly different results compared to most
of other chips.  See B<-ffloat-store> for more detailed description.

This is the default choice for non-Darwin x86-32 targets.


=item B<sse>

Use scalar floating-point instructions present in the SSE instruction set.
This instruction set is supported by Pentium III and newer chips,
and in the AMD line
by Athlon-4, Athlon XP and Athlon MP chips.  The earlier version of the SSE
instruction set supports only single-precision arithmetic, thus the double and
extended-precision arithmetic are still done using 387.  A later version, present
only in Pentium 4 and AMD x86-64 chips, supports double-precision
arithmetic too.

For the x86-32 compiler, you must use B<-march=>I<cpu-type>, B<-msse>
or B<-msse2> switches to enable SSE extensions and make this option
effective.  For the x86-64 compiler, these extensions are enabled by default.

The resulting code should be considerably faster in the majority of cases and avoid
the numerical instability problems of 387 code, but may break some existing
code that expects temporaries to be 80 bits.

This is the default choice for the x86-64 compiler, Darwin x86-32 targets,
and the default choice for x86-32 targets with the SSE2 instruction set
when B<-ffast-math> is enabled.


=item B<sse,387>


=item B<sse+387>


=item B<both>

Attempt to utilize both instruction sets at once.  This effectively doubles the
amount of available registers, and on chips with separate execution units for
387 and SSE the execution resources too.  Use this option with care, as it is
still experimental, because the GCC register allocator does not model separate
functional units well, resulting in unstable performance.

=back



=item B<-masm=>I<dialect>

Output assembly instructions using selected I<dialect>.  Also affects
which dialect is used for basic C<asm> and
extended C<asm>. Supported choices (in dialect
order) are B<att> or B<intel>. The default is B<att>. Darwin does
not support B<intel>.


=item B<-mieee-fp>


=item B<-mno-ieee-fp>

Control whether or not the compiler uses IEEE floating-point
comparisons.  These correctly handle the case where the result of a
comparison is unordered.


=item B<-m80387>


=item B<-mhard-float>

Generate output containing 80387 instructions for floating point.


=item B<-mno-80387>


=item B<-msoft-float>

Generate output containing library calls for floating point.

B<Warning:> the requisite libraries are not part of GCC.
Normally the facilities of the machine's usual C compiler are used, but
this cannot be done directly in cross-compilation.  You must make your
own arrangements to provide suitable library functions for
cross-compilation.

On machines where a function returns floating-point results in the 80387
register stack, some floating-point opcodes may be emitted even if
B<-msoft-float> is used.


=item B<-mno-fp-ret-in-387>

Do not use the FPU registers for return values of functions.

The usual calling convention has functions return values of types
C<float> and C<double> in an FPU register, even if there
is no FPU.  The idea is that the operating system should emulate
an FPU.

The option B<-mno-fp-ret-in-387> causes such values to be returned
in ordinary CPU registers instead.


=item B<-mno-fancy-math-387>

Some 387 emulators do not support the C<sin>, C<cos> and
C<sqrt> instructions for the 387.  Specify this option to avoid
generating those instructions.
This option is overridden when B<-march>
indicates that the target CPU always has an FPU and so the
instruction does not need emulation.  These
instructions are not generated unless you also use the
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> switch.


=item B<-malign-double>


=item B<-mno-align-double>

Control whether GCC aligns C<double>, C<long double>, and
C<long long> variables on a two-word boundary or a one-word
boundary.  Aligning C<double> variables on a two-word boundary
produces code that runs somewhat faster on a Pentium at the
expense of more memory.

On x86-64, B<-malign-double> is enabled by default.

B<Warning:> if you use the B<-malign-double> switch,
structures containing the above types are aligned differently than
the published application binary interface specifications for the x86-32
and are not binary compatible with structures in code compiled
without that switch.


=item B<-m96bit-long-double>


=item B<-m128bit-long-double>

These switches control the size of C<long double> type.  The x86-32
application binary interface specifies the size to be 96 bits,
so B<-m96bit-long-double> is the default in 32-bit mode.

Modern architectures (Pentium and newer) prefer C<long double>
to be aligned to an 8- or 16-byte boundary.  In arrays or structures
conforming to the ABI, this is not possible.  So specifying
B<-m128bit-long-double> aligns C<long double>
to a 16-byte boundary by padding the C<long double> with an additional
32-bit zero.

In the x86-64 compiler, B<-m128bit-long-double> is the default choice as
its ABI specifies that C<long double> is aligned on 16-byte boundary.

Notice that neither of these options enable any extra precision over the x87
standard of 80 bits for a C<long double>.

B<Warning:> if you override the default value for your target ABI, this
changes the size of 
structures and arrays containing C<long double> variables,
as well as modifying the function calling convention for functions taking
C<long double>.  Hence they are not binary-compatible
with code compiled without that switch.


=item B<-mlong-double-64>


=item B<-mlong-double-80>


=item B<-mlong-double-128>

These switches control the size of C<long double> type. A size
of 64 bits makes the C<long double> type equivalent to the C<double>
type. This is the default for 32-bit Bionic C library.  A size
of 128 bits makes the C<long double> type equivalent to the
C<__float128> type. This is the default for 64-bit Bionic C library.

B<Warning:> if you override the default value for your target ABI, this
changes the size of
structures and arrays containing C<long double> variables,
as well as modifying the function calling convention for functions taking
C<long double>.  Hence they are not binary-compatible
with code compiled without that switch.


=item B<-malign-data=>I<type>

Control how GCC aligns variables.  Supported values for I<type> are
B<compat> uses increased alignment value compatible uses GCC 4.8
and earlier, B<abi> uses alignment value as specified by the
psABI, and B<cacheline> uses increased alignment value to match
the cache line size.  B<compat> is the default.


=item B<-mlarge-data-threshold=>I<threshold>

When B<-mcmodel=medium> is specified, data objects larger than
I<threshold> are placed in the large data section.  This value must be the
same across all objects linked into the binary, and defaults to 65535.


=item B<-mrtd>

Use a different function-calling convention, in which functions that
take a fixed number of arguments return with the C<ret I<num>>
instruction, which pops their arguments while returning.  This saves one
instruction in the caller since there is no need to pop the arguments
there.

You can specify that an individual function is called with this calling
sequence with the function attribute C<stdcall>.  You can also
override the B<-mrtd> option by using the function attribute
C<cdecl>.  

B<Warning:> this calling convention is incompatible with the one
normally used on Unix, so you cannot use it if you need to call
libraries compiled with the Unix compiler.

Also, you must provide function prototypes for all functions that
take variable numbers of arguments (including C<printf>);
otherwise incorrect code is generated for calls to those
functions.

In addition, seriously incorrect code results if you call a
function with too many arguments.  (Normally, extra arguments are
harmlessly ignored.)


=item B<-mregparm=>I<num>

Control how many registers are used to pass integer arguments.  By
default, no registers are used to pass arguments, and at most 3
registers can be used.  You can control this behavior for a specific
function by using the function attribute C<regparm>.


B<Warning:> if you use this switch, and
I<num> is nonzero, then you must build all modules with the same
value, including any libraries.  This includes the system libraries and
startup modules.


=item B<-msseregparm>

Use SSE register passing conventions for float and double arguments
and return values.  You can control this behavior for a specific
function by using the function attribute C<sseregparm>.


B<Warning:> if you use this switch then you must build all
modules with the same value, including any libraries.  This includes
the system libraries and startup modules.


=item B<-mvect8-ret-in-mem>

Return 8-byte vectors in memory instead of MMX registers.  This is the
default on Solaris@tie{}8 and 9 and VxWorks to match the ABI of the Sun
Studio compilers until version 12.  Later compiler versions (starting
with Studio 12 Update@tie{}1) follow the ABI used by other x86 targets, which
is the default on Solaris@tie{}10 and later.  I<Only> use this option if
you need to remain compatible with existing code produced by those
previous compiler versions or older versions of GCC.


=item B<-mpc32>


=item B<-mpc64>


=item B<-mpc80>


Set 80387 floating-point precision to 32, 64 or 80 bits.  When B<-mpc32>
is specified, the significands of results of floating-point operations are
rounded to 24 bits (single precision); B<-mpc64> rounds the
significands of results of floating-point operations to 53 bits (double
precision) and B<-mpc80> rounds the significands of results of
floating-point operations to 64 bits (extended double precision), which is
the default.  When this option is used, floating-point operations in higher
precisions are not available to the programmer without setting the FPU
control word explicitly.

Setting the rounding of floating-point operations to less than the default
80 bits can speed some programs by 2% or more.  Note that some mathematical
libraries assume that extended-precision (80-bit) floating-point operations
are enabled by default; routines in such libraries could suffer significant
loss of accuracy, typically through so-called "catastrophic cancellation",
when this option is used to set the precision to less than extended precision.


=item B<-mstackrealign>

Realign the stack at entry.  On the x86, the B<-mstackrealign>
option generates an alternate prologue and epilogue that realigns the
run-time stack if necessary.  This supports mixing legacy codes that keep
4-byte stack alignment with modern codes that keep 16-byte stack alignment for
SSE compatibility.  See also the attribute C<force_align_arg_pointer>,
applicable to individual functions.


=item B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary=>I<num>

Attempt to keep the stack boundary aligned to a 2 raised to I<num>
byte boundary.  If B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary> is not specified,
the default is 4 (16 bytes or 128 bits).

B<Warning:> When generating code for the x86-64 architecture with
SSE extensions disabled, B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary=3> can be
used to keep the stack boundary aligned to 8 byte boundary.  Since
x86-64 ABI require 16 byte stack alignment, this is ABI incompatible and
intended to be used in controlled environment where stack space is
important limitation.  This option leads to wrong code when functions
compiled with 16 byte stack alignment (such as functions from a standard
library) are called with misaligned stack.  In this case, SSE
instructions may lead to misaligned memory access traps.  In addition,
variable arguments are handled incorrectly for 16 byte aligned
objects (including x87 long double and __int128), leading to wrong
results.  You must build all modules with
B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary=3>, including any libraries.  This
includes the system libraries and startup modules.


=item B<-mincoming-stack-boundary=>I<num>

Assume the incoming stack is aligned to a 2 raised to I<num> byte
boundary.  If B<-mincoming-stack-boundary> is not specified,
the one specified by B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary> is used.

On Pentium and Pentium Pro, C<double> and C<long double> values
should be aligned to an 8-byte boundary (see B<-malign-double>) or
suffer significant run time performance penalties.  On Pentium III, the
Streaming SIMD Extension (SSE) data type C<__m128> may not work
properly if it is not 16-byte aligned.

To ensure proper alignment of this values on the stack, the stack boundary
must be as aligned as that required by any value stored on the stack.
Further, every function must be generated such that it keeps the stack
aligned.  Thus calling a function compiled with a higher preferred
stack boundary from a function compiled with a lower preferred stack
boundary most likely misaligns the stack.  It is recommended that
libraries that use callbacks always use the default setting.

This extra alignment does consume extra stack space, and generally
increases code size.  Code that is sensitive to stack space usage, such
as embedded systems and operating system kernels, may want to reduce the
preferred alignment to B<-mpreferred-stack-boundary=2>.
