=item B<-mcldemote>

These switches enable the use of instructions in the MMX, SSE,
SSE2, SSE3, SSSE3, SSE4, SSE4A, SSE4.1, SSE4.2, AVX, AVX2, AVX512F, AVX512PF,
AVX512ER, AVX512CD, AVX512VL, AVX512BW, AVX512DQ, AVX512IFMA, AVX512VBMI, SHA,
AES, PCLMUL, CLFLUSHOPT, CLWB, FSGSBASE, PTWRITE, RDRND, F16C, FMA, PCONFIG,
WBNOINVD, FMA4, PREFETCHW, RDPID, PREFETCHWT1, RDSEED, SGX, XOP, LWP,
3DNow!, enhanced 3DNow!, POPCNT, ABM, ADX, BMI, BMI2, LZCNT, FXSR, XSAVE,
XSAVEOPT, XSAVEC, XSAVES, RTM, HLE, TBM, MWAITX, CLZERO, PKU, AVX512VBMI2,
GFNI, VAES, WAITPKG, VPCLMULQDQ, AVX512BITALG, MOVDIRI, MOVDIR64B,
AVX512VPOPCNTDQ, AVX5124FMAPS, AVX512VNNI, AVX5124VNNIW, or CLDEMOTE
extended instruction sets.  Each has a corresponding B<-mno-> option to
disable use of these instructions.

These extensions are also available as built-in functions: see
B<x86 Built-in Functions>, for details of the functions enabled and
disabled by these switches.

To generate SSE/SSE2 instructions automatically from floating-point
code (as opposed to 387 instructions), see B<-mfpmath=sse>.

GCC depresses SSEx instructions when B<-mavx> is used. Instead, it
generates new AVX instructions or AVX equivalence for all SSEx instructions
when needed.

These options enable GCC to use these extended instructions in
generated code, even without B<-mfpmath=sse>.  Applications that
perform run-time CPU detection must compile separate files for each
supported architecture, using the appropriate flags.  In particular,
the file containing the CPU detection code should be compiled without
these options.


=item B<-mdump-tune-features>

This option instructs GCC to dump the names of the x86 performance 
tuning features and default settings. The names can be used in 
B<-mtune-ctrl=>I<feature-list>.


=item B<-mtune-ctrl=>I<feature-list>

This option is used to do fine grain control of x86 code generation features.
I<feature-list> is a comma separated list of I<feature> names. See also
B<-mdump-tune-features>. When specified, the I<feature> is turned
on if it is not preceded with B<^>, otherwise, it is turned off. 
B<-mtune-ctrl=>I<feature-list> is intended to be used by GCC
developers. Using it may lead to code paths not covered by testing and can
potentially result in compiler ICEs or runtime errors.


=item B<-mno-default>

This option instructs GCC to turn off all tunable features. See also 
B<-mtune-ctrl=>I<feature-list> and B<-mdump-tune-features>.


=item B<-mcld>

This option instructs GCC to emit a C<cld> instruction in the prologue
of functions that use string instructions.  String instructions depend on
the DF flag to select between autoincrement or autodecrement mode.  While the
ABI specifies the DF flag to be cleared on function entry, some operating
systems violate this specification by not clearing the DF flag in their
exception dispatchers.  The exception handler can be invoked with the DF flag
set, which leads to wrong direction mode when string instructions are used.
This option can be enabled by default on 32-bit x86 targets by configuring
GCC with the B<--enable-cld> configure option.  Generation of C<cld>
instructions can be suppressed with the B<-mno-cld> compiler option
in this case.


=item B<-mvzeroupper>

This option instructs GCC to emit a C<vzeroupper> instruction
before a transfer of control flow out of the function to minimize
the AVX to SSE transition penalty as well as remove unnecessary C<zeroupper>
intrinsics.


=item B<-mprefer-avx128>

This option instructs GCC to use 128-bit AVX instructions instead of
256-bit AVX instructions in the auto-vectorizer.


=item B<-mprefer-vector-width=>I<opt>

This option instructs GCC to use I<opt>-bit vector width in instructions
instead of default on the selected platform.


=over 4


=item B<none>

No extra limitations applied to GCC other than defined by the selected platform.


=item B<128>

Prefer 128-bit vector width for instructions.


=item B<256>

Prefer 256-bit vector width for instructions.


=item B<512>

Prefer 512-bit vector width for instructions.

=back



=item B<-mcx16>

This option enables GCC to generate C<CMPXCHG16B> instructions in 64-bit
code to implement compare-and-exchange operations on 16-byte aligned 128-bit
objects.  This is useful for atomic updates of data structures exceeding one
machine word in size.  The compiler uses this instruction to implement
B<__sync Builtins>.  However, for B<__atomic Builtins> operating on
128-bit integers, a library call is always used.


=item B<-msahf>

This option enables generation of C<SAHF> instructions in 64-bit code.
Early Intel Pentium 4 CPUs with Intel 64 support,
prior to the introduction of Pentium 4 G1 step in December 2005,
lacked the C<LAHF> and C<SAHF> instructions
which are supported by AMD64.
These are load and store instructions, respectively, for certain status flags.
In 64-bit mode, the C<SAHF> instruction is used to optimize C<fmod>,
C<drem>, and C<remainder> built-in functions;
see B<Other Builtins> for details.


=item B<-mmovbe>

This option enables use of the C<movbe> instruction to implement
C<__builtin_bswap32> and C<__builtin_bswap64>.


=item B<-mshstk>

The B<-mshstk> option enables shadow stack built-in functions
from x86 Control-flow Enforcement Technology (CET).


=item B<-mcrc32>

This option enables built-in functions C<__builtin_ia32_crc32qi>,
C<__builtin_ia32_crc32hi>, C<__builtin_ia32_crc32si> and
C<__builtin_ia32_crc32di> to generate the C<crc32> machine instruction.


=item B<-mrecip>

This option enables use of C<RCPSS> and C<RSQRTSS> instructions
(and their vectorized variants C<RCPPS> and C<RSQRTPS>)
with an additional Newton-Raphson step
to increase precision instead of C<DIVSS> and C<SQRTSS>
(and their vectorized
variants) for single-precision floating-point arguments.  These instructions
are generated only when B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> is enabled
together with B<-ffinite-math-only> and B<-fno-trapping-math>.
Note that while the throughput of the sequence is higher than the throughput
of the non-reciprocal instruction, the precision of the sequence can be
decreased by up to 2 ulp (i.e. the inverse of 1.0 equals 0.99999994).

Note that GCC implements C<1.0f/sqrtf(I<x>)> in terms of C<RSQRTSS>
(or C<RSQRTPS>) already with B<-ffast-math> (or the above option
combination), and doesn't need B<-mrecip>.

Also note that GCC emits the above sequence with additional Newton-Raphson step
for vectorized single-float division and vectorized C<sqrtf(I<x>)>
already with B<-ffast-math> (or the above option combination), and
doesn't need B<-mrecip>.


=item B<-mrecip=>I<opt>

This option controls which reciprocal estimate instructions
may be used.  I<opt> is a comma-separated list of options, which may
be preceded by a B<!> to invert the option:


=over 4


=item B<all>

Enable all estimate instructions.


=item B<default>

Enable the default instructions, equivalent to B<-mrecip>.


=item B<none>

Disable all estimate instructions, equivalent to B<-mno-recip>.


=item B<div>

Enable the approximation for scalar division.


=item B<vec-div>

Enable the approximation for vectorized division.


=item B<sqrt>

Enable the approximation for scalar square root.


=item B<vec-sqrt>

Enable the approximation for vectorized square root.

=back


So, for example, B<-mrecip=all,!sqrt> enables
all of the reciprocal approximations, except for square root.


=item B<-mveclibabi=>I<type>

Specifies the ABI type to use for vectorizing intrinsics using an
external library.  Supported values for I<type> are B<svml> 
for the Intel short
vector math library and B<acml> for the AMD math core library.
To use this option, both B<-ftree-vectorize> and
B<-funsafe-math-optimizations> have to be enabled, and an SVML or ACML 
ABI-compatible library must be specified at link time.

GCC currently emits calls to C<vmldExp2>,
C<vmldLn2>, C<vmldLog102>, C<vmldPow2>,
C<vmldTanh2>, C<vmldTan2>, C<vmldAtan2>, C<vmldAtanh2>,
C<vmldCbrt2>, C<vmldSinh2>, C<vmldSin2>, C<vmldAsinh2>,
C<vmldAsin2>, C<vmldCosh2>, C<vmldCos2>, C<vmldAcosh2>,
C<vmldAcos2>, C<vmlsExp4>, C<vmlsLn4>,
C<vmlsLog104>, C<vmlsPow4>, C<vmlsTanh4>, C<vmlsTan4>,
C<vmlsAtan4>, C<vmlsAtanh4>, C<vmlsCbrt4>, C<vmlsSinh4>,
C<vmlsSin4>, C<vmlsAsinh4>, C<vmlsAsin4>, C<vmlsCosh4>,
C<vmlsCos4>, C<vmlsAcosh4> and C<vmlsAcos4> for corresponding
function type when B<-mveclibabi=svml> is used, and C<__vrd2_sin>,
C<__vrd2_cos>, C<__vrd2_exp>, C<__vrd2_log>, C<__vrd2_log2>,
C<__vrd2_log10>, C<__vrs4_sinf>, C<__vrs4_cosf>,
C<__vrs4_expf>, C<__vrs4_logf>, C<__vrs4_log2f>,
C<__vrs4_log10f> and C<__vrs4_powf> for the corresponding function type
when B<-mveclibabi=acml> is used.  


=item B<-mabi=>I<name>

Generate code for the specified calling convention.  Permissible values
are B<sysv> for the ABI used on GNU/Linux and other systems, and
B<ms> for the Microsoft ABI.  The default is to use the Microsoft
ABI when targeting Microsoft Windows and the SysV ABI on all other systems.
You can control this behavior for specific functions by
using the function attributes C<ms_abi> and C<sysv_abi>.



=item B<-mforce-indirect-call>

Force all calls to functions to be indirect. This is useful
when using Intel Processor Trace where it generates more precise timing
information for function calls.


=item B<-mmanual-endbr>

Insert ENDBR instruction at function entry only via the C<cf_check>
function attribute. This is useful when used with the option
B<-fcf-protection=branch> to control ENDBR insertion at the
function entry.


=item B<-mcall-ms2sysv-xlogues>

Due to differences in 64-bit ABIs, any Microsoft ABI function that calls a
System V ABI function must consider RSI, RDI and XMM6-15 as clobbered.  By
default, the code for saving and restoring these registers is emitted inline,
resulting in fairly lengthy prologues and epilogues.  Using
B<-mcall-ms2sysv-xlogues> emits prologues and epilogues that
use stubs in the static portion of libgcc to perform these saves and restores,
thus reducing function size at the cost of a few extra instructions.


=item B<-mtls-dialect=>I<type>

Generate code to access thread-local storage using the B<gnu> or
B<gnu2> conventions.  B<gnu> is the conservative default;
B<gnu2> is more efficient, but it may add compile- and run-time
requirements that cannot be satisfied on all systems.


=item B<-mpush-args>


=item B<-mno-push-args>

Use PUSH operations to store outgoing parameters.  This method is shorter
and usually equally fast as method using SUB/MOV operations and is enabled
by default.  In some cases disabling it may improve performance because of
improved scheduling and reduced dependencies.


=item B<-maccumulate-outgoing-args>

If enabled, the maximum amount of space required for outgoing arguments is
computed in the function prologue.  This is faster on most modern CPUs
because of reduced dependencies, improved scheduling and reduced stack usage
when the preferred stack boundary is not equal to 2.  The drawback is a notable
increase in code size.  This switch implies B<-mno-push-args>.


=item B<-mthreads>

Support thread-safe exception handling on MinGW.  Programs that rely
on thread-safe exception handling must compile and link all code with the
B<-mthreads> option.  When compiling, B<-mthreads> defines
B<-D_MT>; when linking, it links in a special thread helper library
B<-lmingwthrd> which cleans up per-thread exception-handling data.


=item B<-mms-bitfields>


=item B<-mno-ms-bitfields>


Enable/disable bit-field layout compatible with the native Microsoft
Windows compiler.  

If C<packed> is used on a structure, or if bit-fields are used,
it may be that the Microsoft ABI lays out the structure differently
than the way GCC normally does.  Particularly when moving packed
data between functions compiled with GCC and the native Microsoft compiler
(either via function call or as data in a file), it may be necessary to access
either format.

This option is enabled by default for Microsoft Windows
targets.  This behavior can also be controlled locally by use of variable
or type attributes.  For more information, see B<x86 Variable Attributes>
and B<x86 Type Attributes>.

The Microsoft structure layout algorithm is fairly simple with the exception
of the bit-field packing.  
The padding and alignment of members of structures and whether a bit-field 
can straddle a storage-unit boundary are determine by these rules:


=over 4


=item 1. Structure members are stored sequentially in the order in which they are

declared: the first member has the lowest memory address and the last member
the highest.


=item 2. Every data object has an alignment requirement.  The alignment requirement

for all data except structures, unions, and arrays is either the size of the
object or the current packing size (specified with either the
C<aligned> attribute or the C<pack> pragma),
whichever is less.  For structures, unions, and arrays,
the alignment requirement is the largest alignment requirement of its members.
Every object is allocated an offset so that:

	
	offset % alignment_requirement == 0



=item 3. Adjacent bit-fields are packed into the same 1-, 2-, or 4-byte allocation

unit if the integral types are the same size and if the next bit-field fits
into the current allocation unit without crossing the boundary imposed by the
common alignment requirements of the bit-fields.

=back


MSVC interprets zero-length bit-fields in the following ways:


=over 4


=item 1. If a zero-length bit-field is inserted between two bit-fields that

are normally coalesced, the bit-fields are not coalesced.

For example:

	
	struct
	 {
	   unsigned long bf_1 : 12;
	   unsigned long : 0;
	   unsigned long bf_2 : 12;
	 } t1;


The size of C<t1> is 8 bytes with the zero-length bit-field.  If the
zero-length bit-field were removed, C<t1>'s size would be 4 bytes.


=item 2. If a zero-length bit-field is inserted after a bit-field, C<foo>, and the

alignment of the zero-length bit-field is greater than the member that follows it,
C<bar>, C<bar> is aligned as the type of the zero-length bit-field.

For example:

	
	struct
	 {
	   char foo : 4;
	   short : 0;
	   char bar;
	 } t2;
	
	struct
	 {
	   char foo : 4;
	   short : 0;
	   double bar;
	 } t3;


For C<t2>, C<bar> is placed at offset 2, rather than offset 1.
Accordingly, the size of C<t2> is 4.  For C<t3>, the zero-length
bit-field does not affect the alignment of C<bar> or, as a result, the size
of the structure.

Taking this into account, it is important to note the following:


=over 4


=item 1. If a zero-length bit-field follows a normal bit-field, the type of the

zero-length bit-field may affect the alignment of the structure as whole. For
example, C<t2> has a size of 4 bytes, since the zero-length bit-field follows a
normal bit-field, and is of type short.


=item 2. Even if a zero-length bit-field is not followed by a normal bit-field, it may

still affect the alignment of the structure:

	
	struct
	 {
	   char foo : 6;
	   long : 0;
	 } t4;


Here, C<t4> takes up 4 bytes.

=back



=item 3. Zero-length bit-fields following non-bit-field members are ignored:


	
	struct
	 {
	   char foo;
	   long : 0;
	   char bar;
	 } t5;


Here, C<t5> takes up 2 bytes.

=back




=item B<-mno-align-stringops>

Do not align the destination of inlined string operations.  This switch reduces
code size and improves performance in case the destination is already aligned,
but GCC doesn't know about it.


=item B<-minline-all-stringops>

By default GCC inlines string operations only when the destination is 
known to be aligned to least a 4-byte boundary.  
This enables more inlining and increases code
size, but may improve performance of code that depends on fast
C<memcpy>, C<strlen>,
and C<memset> for short lengths.


=item B<-minline-stringops-dynamically>

For string operations of unknown size, use run-time checks with
inline code for small blocks and a library call for large blocks.


=item B<-mstringop-strategy=>I<alg>

Override the internal decision heuristic for the particular algorithm to use
for inlining string operations.  The allowed values for I<alg> are:


=over 4


=item B<rep_byte>


=item B<rep_4byte>


=item B<rep_8byte>

Expand using i386 C<rep> prefix of the specified size.


=item B<byte_loop>


=item B<loop>


=item B<unrolled_loop>

Expand into an inline loop.


=item B<libcall>

Always use a library call.

=back



=item B<-mmemcpy-strategy=>I<strategy>

Override the internal decision heuristic to decide if C<__builtin_memcpy>
should be inlined and what inline algorithm to use when the expected size
of the copy operation is known. I<strategy> 
is a comma-separated list of I<alg>:I<max_size>:I<dest_align> triplets. 
I<alg> is specified in B<-mstringop-strategy>, I<max_size> specifies
the max byte size with which inline algorithm I<alg> is allowed.  For the last
triplet, the I<max_size> must be C<-1>. The I<max_size> of the triplets
in the list must be specified in increasing order.  The minimal byte size for 
I<alg> is C<0> for the first triplet and C<I<max_size> + 1> of the 
preceding range.


=item B<-mmemset-strategy=>I<strategy>

The option is similar to B<-mmemcpy-strategy=> except that it is to control
C<__builtin_memset> expansion.


=item B<-momit-leaf-frame-pointer>

Don't keep the frame pointer in a register for leaf functions.  This
avoids the instructions to save, set up, and restore frame pointers and
makes an extra register available in leaf functions.  The option
B<-fomit-leaf-frame-pointer> removes the frame pointer for leaf functions,
which might make debugging harder.


=item B<-mtls-direct-seg-refs>


=item B<-mno-tls-direct-seg-refs>

Controls whether TLS variables may be accessed with offsets from the
TLS segment register (C<%gs> for 32-bit, C<%fs> for 64-bit),
or whether the thread base pointer must be added.  Whether or not this
is valid depends on the operating system, and whether it maps the
segment to cover the entire TLS area.

For systems that use the GNU C Library, the default is on.


=item B<-msse2avx>


=item B<-mno-sse2avx>

Specify that the assembler should encode SSE instructions with VEX
prefix.  The option B<-mavx> turns this on by default.


=item B<-mfentry>


=item B<-mno-fentry>

If profiling is active (B<-pg>), put the profiling
counter call before the prologue.
Note: On x86 architectures the attribute C<ms_hook_prologue>
isn't possible at the moment for B<-mfentry> and B<-pg>.


=item B<-mrecord-mcount>


=item B<-mno-record-mcount>

If profiling is active (B<-pg>), generate a __mcount_loc section
that contains pointers to each profiling call. This is useful for
automatically patching and out calls.


=item B<-mnop-mcount>


=item B<-mno-nop-mcount>

If profiling is active (B<-pg>), generate the calls to
the profiling functions as NOPs. This is useful when they
should be patched in later dynamically. This is likely only
useful together with B<-mrecord-mcount>.


=item B<-minstrument-return=>I<type>

Instrument function exit in -pg -mfentry instrumented functions with
call to specified function. This only instruments true returns ending
with ret, but not sibling calls ending with jump. Valid types
are I<none> to not instrument, I<call> to generate a call to __return__,
or I<nop5> to generate a 5 byte nop.


=item B<-mrecord-return>


=item B<-mno-record-return>

Generate a __return_loc section pointing to all return instrumentation code.


=item B<-mfentry-name=>I<name>

Set name of __fentry__ symbol called at function entry for -pg -mfentry functions.


=item B<-mfentry-section=>I<name>

Set name of section to record -mrecord-mcount calls (default __mcount_loc).


=item B<-mskip-rax-setup>


=item B<-mno-skip-rax-setup>

When generating code for the x86-64 architecture with SSE extensions
disabled, B<-mskip-rax-setup> can be used to skip setting up RAX
register when there are no variable arguments passed in vector registers.

B<Warning:> Since RAX register is used to avoid unnecessarily
saving vector registers on stack when passing variable arguments, the
impacts of this option are callees may waste some stack space,
misbehave or jump to a random location.  GCC 4.4 or newer don't have
those issues, regardless the RAX register value.


=item B<-m8bit-idiv>


=item B<-mno-8bit-idiv>

On some processors, like Intel Atom, 8-bit unsigned integer divide is
much faster than 32-bit/64-bit integer divide.  This option generates a
run-time check.  If both dividend and divisor are within range of 0
to 255, 8-bit unsigned integer divide is used instead of
32-bit/64-bit integer divide.


=item B<-mavx256-split-unaligned-load>


=item B<-mavx256-split-unaligned-store>

Split 32-byte AVX unaligned load and store.


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard=>I<guard>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg>


=item B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset>

Generate stack protection code using canary at I<guard>.  Supported
locations are B<global> for global canary or B<tls> for per-thread
canary in the TLS block (the default).  This option has effect only when
B<-fstack-protector> or B<-fstack-protector-all> is specified.

With the latter choice the options
B<-mstack-protector-guard-reg=>I<reg> and
B<-mstack-protector-guard-offset=>I<offset> furthermore specify
which segment register (C<%fs> or C<%gs>) to use as base register
for reading the canary, and from what offset from that base register.
The default for those is as specified in the relevant ABI.


=item B<-mgeneral-regs-only>

Generate code that uses only the general-purpose registers.  This
prevents the compiler from using floating-point, vector, mask and bound
registers.


=item B<-mindirect-branch=>I<choice>

Convert indirect call and jump with I<choice>.  The default is
B<keep>, which keeps indirect call and jump unmodified.
B<thunk> converts indirect call and jump to call and return thunk.
B<thunk-inline> converts indirect call and jump to inlined call
and return thunk.  B<thunk-extern> converts indirect call and jump
to external call and return thunk provided in a separate object file.
You can control this behavior for a specific function by using the
function attribute C<indirect_branch>.  

Note that B<-mcmodel=large> is incompatible with
B<-mindirect-branch=thunk> and
B<-mindirect-branch=thunk-extern> since the thunk function may
not be reachable in the large code model.

Note that B<-mindirect-branch=thunk-extern> is incompatible with
B<-fcf-protection=branch> since the external thunk cannot be modified
to disable control-flow check.


=item B<-mfunction-return=>I<choice>

Convert function return with I<choice>.  The default is B<keep>,
which keeps function return unmodified.  B<thunk> converts function
return to call and return thunk.  B<thunk-inline> converts function
return to inlined call and return thunk.  B<thunk-extern> converts
function return to external call and return thunk provided in a separate
object file.  You can control this behavior for a specific function by
using the function attribute C<function_return>.


Note that B<-mcmodel=large> is incompatible with
B<-mfunction-return=thunk> and
B<-mfunction-return=thunk-extern> since the thunk function may
not be reachable in the large code model.



=item B<-mindirect-branch-register>

Force indirect call and jump via register.


=back


These B<-m> switches are supported in addition to the above
on x86-64 processors in 64-bit environments.


=over 4


=item B<-m32>


=item B<-m64>


=item B<-mx32>


=item B<-m16>


=item B<-miamcu>

Generate code for a 16-bit, 32-bit or 64-bit environment.
The B<-m32> option sets C<int>, C<long>, and pointer types
to 32 bits, and
generates code that runs on any i386 system.

The B<-m64> option sets C<int> to 32 bits and C<long> and pointer
types to 64 bits, and generates code for the x86-64 architecture.
For Darwin only the B<-m64> option also turns off the B<-fno-pic>
and B<-mdynamic-no-pic> options.

The B<-mx32> option sets C<int>, C<long>, and pointer types
to 32 bits, and
generates code for the x86-64 architecture.

The B<-m16> option is the same as B<-m32>, except for that
it outputs the C<.code16gcc> assembly directive at the beginning of
the assembly output so that the binary can run in 16-bit mode.

The B<-miamcu> option generates code which conforms to Intel MCU
psABI.  It requires the B<-m32> option to be turned on.


=item B<-mno-red-zone>

Do not use a so-called "red zone" for x86-64 code.  The red zone is mandated
by the x86-64 ABI; it is a 128-byte area beyond the location of the
stack pointer that is not modified by signal or interrupt handlers
and therefore can be used for temporary data without adjusting the stack
pointer.  The flag B<-mno-red-zone> disables this red zone.


=item B<-mcmodel=small>

Generate code for the small code model: the program and its symbols must
be linked in the lower 2 GB of the address space.  Pointers are 64 bits.
Programs can be statically or dynamically linked.  This is the default
code model.


=item B<-mcmodel=kernel>

Generate code for the kernel code model.  The kernel runs in the
negative 2 GB of the address space.
This model has to be used for Linux kernel code.


=item B<-mcmodel=medium>

Generate code for the medium model: the program is linked in the lower 2
GB of the address space.  Small symbols are also placed there.  Symbols
with sizes larger than B<-mlarge-data-threshold> are put into
large data or BSS sections and can be located above 2GB.  Programs can
be statically or dynamically linked.


=item B<-mcmodel=large>

Generate code for the large model.  This model makes no assumptions
about addresses and sizes of sections.


=item B<-maddress-mode=long>

Generate code for long address mode.  This is only supported for 64-bit
and x32 environments.  It is the default address mode for 64-bit
environments.


=item B<-maddress-mode=short>

Generate code for short address mode.  This is only supported for 32-bit
and x32 environments.  It is the default address mode for 32-bit and
x32 environments.

=back



=head3 x86 Windows Options


These additional options are available for Microsoft Windows targets:


=over 4


=item B<-mconsole>

This option
specifies that a console application is to be generated, by
instructing the linker to set the PE header subsystem type
required for console applications.
This option is available for Cygwin and MinGW targets and is
enabled by default on those targets.


=item B<-mdll>

This option is available for Cygwin and MinGW targets.  It
specifies that a DLL---a dynamic link library---is to be
generated, enabling the selection of the required runtime
startup object and entry point.


=item B<-mnop-fun-dllimport>

This option is available for Cygwin and MinGW targets.  It
specifies that the C<dllimport> attribute should be ignored.


=item B<-mthread>

This option is available for MinGW targets. It specifies
that MinGW-specific thread support is to be used.


=item B<-municode>

This option is available for MinGW-w64 targets.  It causes
the C<UNICODE> preprocessor macro to be predefined, and
chooses Unicode-capable runtime startup code.


=item B<-mwin32>

This option is available for Cygwin and MinGW targets.  It
specifies that the typical Microsoft Windows predefined macros are to
be set in the pre-processor, but does not influence the choice
of runtime library/startup code.


=item B<-mwindows>

This option is available for Cygwin and MinGW targets.  It
specifies that a GUI application is to be generated by
instructing the linker to set the PE header subsystem type
appropriately.


=item B<-fno-set-stack-executable>

This option is available for MinGW targets. It specifies that
the executable flag for the stack used by nested functions isn't
set. This is necessary for binaries running in kernel mode of
Microsoft Windows, as there the User32 API, which is used to set executable
privileges, isn't available.


=item B<-fwritable-relocated-rdata>

This option is available for MinGW and Cygwin targets.  It specifies
that relocated-data in read-only section is put into the C<.data>
section.  This is a necessary for older runtimes not supporting
modification of C<.rdata> sections for pseudo-relocation.


=item B<-mpe-aligned-commons>

This option is available for Cygwin and MinGW targets.  It
specifies that the GNU extension to the PE file format that
permits the correct alignment of COMMON variables should be
used when generating code.  It is enabled by default if
GCC detects that the target assembler found during configuration
supports the feature.

=back


See also under B<x86 Options> for standard options.


=head3 Xstormy16 Options


These options are defined for Xstormy16:


=over 4


=item B<-msim>

Choose startup files and linker script suitable for the simulator.

=back



=head3 Xtensa Options


These options are supported for Xtensa targets:


=over 4


=item B<-mconst16>


=item B<-mno-const16>

Enable or disable use of C<CONST16> instructions for loading
constant values.  The C<CONST16> instruction is currently not a
standard option from Tensilica.  When enabled, C<CONST16>
instructions are always used in place of the standard C<L32R>
instructions.  The use of C<CONST16> is enabled by default only if
the C<L32R> instruction is not available.


=item B<-mfused-madd>


=item B<-mno-fused-madd>

Enable or disable use of fused multiply/add and multiply/subtract
instructions in the floating-point option.  This has no effect if the
floating-point option is not also enabled.  Disabling fused multiply/add
and multiply/subtract instructions forces the compiler to use separate
instructions for the multiply and add/subtract operations.  This may be
desirable in some cases where strict IEEE 754-compliant results are
required: the fused multiply add/subtract instructions do not round the
intermediate result, thereby producing results with I<more> bits of
precision than specified by the IEEE standard.  Disabling fused multiply
add/subtract instructions also ensures that the program output is not
sensitive to the compiler's ability to combine multiply and add/subtract
operations.


=item B<-mserialize-volatile>


=item B<-mno-serialize-volatile>

When this option is enabled, GCC inserts C<MEMW> instructions before
C<volatile> memory references to guarantee sequential consistency.
The default is B<-mserialize-volatile>.  Use
B<-mno-serialize-volatile> to omit the C<MEMW> instructions.


=item B<-mforce-no-pic>

For targets, like GNU/Linux, where all user-mode Xtensa code must be
position-independent code (PIC), this option disables PIC for compiling
kernel code.


=item B<-mtext-section-literals>


=item B<-mno-text-section-literals>

These options control the treatment of literal pools.  The default is
B<-mno-text-section-literals>, which places literals in a separate
section in the output file.  This allows the literal pool to be placed
in a data RAM/ROM, and it also allows the linker to combine literal
pools from separate object files to remove redundant literals and
improve code size.  With B<-mtext-section-literals>, the literals
are interspersed in the text section in order to keep them as close as
possible to their references.  This may be necessary for large assembly
files.  Literals for each function are placed right before that function.


=item B<-mauto-litpools>


=item B<-mno-auto-litpools>

These options control the treatment of literal pools.  The default is
B<-mno-auto-litpools>, which places literals in a separate
section in the output file unless B<-mtext-section-literals> is
used.  With B<-mauto-litpools> the literals are interspersed in
the text section by the assembler.  Compiler does not produce explicit
C<.literal> directives and loads literals into registers with
C<MOVI> instructions instead of C<L32R> to let the assembler
do relaxation and place literals as necessary.  This option allows
assembler to create several literal pools per function and assemble
very big functions, which may not be possible with
B<-mtext-section-literals>.


=item B<-mtarget-align>


=item B<-mno-target-align>

When this option is enabled, GCC instructs the assembler to
automatically align instructions to reduce branch penalties at the
expense of some code density.  The assembler attempts to widen density
instructions to align branch targets and the instructions following call
instructions.  If there are not enough preceding safe density
instructions to align a target, no widening is performed.  The
default is B<-mtarget-align>.  These options do not affect the
treatment of auto-aligned instructions like C<LOOP>, which the
assembler always aligns, either by widening density instructions or
by inserting NOP instructions.


=item B<-mlongcalls>


=item B<-mno-longcalls>

When this option is enabled, GCC instructs the assembler to translate
direct calls to indirect calls unless it can determine that the target
of a direct call is in the range allowed by the call instruction.  This
translation typically occurs for calls to functions in other source
files.  Specifically, the assembler translates a direct C<CALL>
instruction into an C<L32R> followed by a C<CALLX> instruction.
The default is B<-mno-longcalls>.  This option should be used in
programs where the call target can potentially be out of range.  This
option is implemented in the assembler, not the compiler, so the
assembly code generated by GCC still shows direct call
instructions---look at the disassembled object code to see the actual
instructions.  Note that the assembler uses an indirect call for
every cross-file call, not just those that really are out of range.

=back



=head3 zSeries Options


These are listed under 



=head1 ENVIRONMENT

This section describes several environment variables that affect how GCC
operates.  Some of them work by specifying directories or prefixes to use
when searching for various kinds of files.  Some are used to specify other
aspects of the compilation environment.

Note that you can also specify places to search using options such as
B<-B>, B<-I> and B<-L>.  These
take precedence over places specified using environment variables, which
in turn take precedence over those specified by the configuration of GCC.



=over 4


=item B<LANG>


=item B<LC_CTYPE>


=item B<LC_MESSAGES>


=item B<LC_ALL>

These environment variables control the way that GCC uses
localization information which allows GCC to work with different
national conventions.  GCC inspects the locale categories
B<LC_CTYPE> and B<LC_MESSAGES> if it has been configured to do
so.  These locale categories can be set to any value supported by your
installation.  A typical value is B<en_GB.UTF-8> for English in the United
Kingdom encoded in UTF-8.

The B<LC_CTYPE> environment variable specifies character
classification.  GCC uses it to determine the character boundaries in
a string; this is needed for some multibyte encodings that contain quote
and escape characters that are otherwise interpreted as a string
end or escape.

The B<LC_MESSAGES> environment variable specifies the language to
use in diagnostic messages.

If the B<LC_ALL> environment variable is set, it overrides the value
of B<LC_CTYPE> and B<LC_MESSAGES>; otherwise, B<LC_CTYPE>
and B<LC_MESSAGES> default to the value of the B<LANG>
environment variable.  If none of these variables are set, GCC
defaults to traditional C English behavior.


=item B<TMPDIR>

If B<TMPDIR> is set, it specifies the directory to use for temporary
files.  GCC uses temporary files to hold the output of one stage of
compilation which is to be used as input to the next stage: for example,
the output of the preprocessor, which is the input to the compiler
proper.


=item B<GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG>

Setting B<GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG> is nearly equivalent to passing
B<-fcompare-debug> to the compiler driver.  See the documentation
of this option for more details.


=item B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX>

If B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX> is set, it specifies a prefix to use in the
names of the subprograms executed by the compiler.  No slash is added
when this prefix is combined with the name of a subprogram, but you can
specify a prefix that ends with a slash if you wish.

If B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX> is not set, GCC attempts to figure out
an appropriate prefix to use based on the pathname it is invoked with.

If GCC cannot find the subprogram using the specified prefix, it
tries looking in the usual places for the subprogram.

The default value of B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX> is
F<I<prefix>/lib/gcc/> where I<prefix> is the prefix to
the installed compiler. In many cases I<prefix> is the value
of C<prefix> when you ran the F<configure> script.

Other prefixes specified with B<-B> take precedence over this prefix.

This prefix is also used for finding files such as F<crt0.o> that are
used for linking.

In addition, the prefix is used in an unusual way in finding the
directories to search for header files.  For each of the standard
directories whose name normally begins with B</usr/local/lib/gcc>
(more precisely, with the value of B<GCC_INCLUDE_DIR>), GCC tries
replacing that beginning with the specified prefix to produce an
alternate directory name.  Thus, with B<-Bfoo/>, GCC searches
F<foo/bar> just before it searches the standard directory 
F</usr/local/lib/bar>.
If a standard directory begins with the configured
I<prefix> then the value of I<prefix> is replaced by
B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX> when looking for header files.


=item B<COMPILER_PATH>

The value of B<COMPILER_PATH> is a colon-separated list of
directories, much like B<PATH>.  GCC tries the directories thus
specified when searching for subprograms, if it cannot find the
subprograms using B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX>.


=item B<LIBRARY_PATH>

The value of B<LIBRARY_PATH> is a colon-separated list of
directories, much like B<PATH>.  When configured as a native compiler,
GCC tries the directories thus specified when searching for special
linker files, if it cannot find them using B<GCC_EXEC_PREFIX>.  Linking
using GCC also uses these directories when searching for ordinary
libraries for the B<-l> option (but directories specified with
B<-L> come first).


=item B<LANG>

This variable is used to pass locale information to the compiler.  One way in
which this information is used is to determine the character set to be used
when character literals, string literals and comments are parsed in C and C++.
When the compiler is configured to allow multibyte characters,
the following values for B<LANG> are recognized:


=over 4


=item B<C-JIS>

Recognize JIS characters.

=item B<C-SJIS>

Recognize SJIS characters.

=item B<C-EUCJP>

Recognize EUCJP characters.

=back


If B<LANG> is not defined, or if it has some other value, then the
compiler uses C<mblen> and C<mbtowc> as defined by the default locale to
recognize and translate multibyte characters.

=back


Some additional environment variables affect the behavior of the
preprocessor.





=over 4


=item B<CPATH>


=item B<C_INCLUDE_PATH>


=item B<CPLUS_INCLUDE_PATH>


=item B<OBJC_INCLUDE_PATH>

Each variable's value is a list of directories separated by a special
character, much like B<PATH>, in which to look for header files.
The special character, C<PATH_SEPARATOR>, is target-dependent and
determined at GCC build time.  For Microsoft Windows-based targets it is a
semicolon, and for almost all other targets it is a colon.

B<CPATH> specifies a list of directories to be searched as if
specified with B<-I>, but after any paths given with B<-I>
options on the command line.  This environment variable is used
regardless of which language is being preprocessed.

The remaining environment variables apply only when preprocessing the
particular language indicated.  Each specifies a list of directories
to be searched as if specified with B<-isystem>, but after any
paths given with B<-isystem> options on the command line.

In all these variables, an empty element instructs the compiler to
search its current working directory.  Empty elements can appear at the
beginning or end of a path.  For instance, if the value of
B<CPATH> is C<:/special/include>, that has the same
effect as B<S<-I. -I/special/include>>.



=item B<DEPENDENCIES_OUTPUT>

If this variable is set, its value specifies how to output
dependencies for Make based on the non-system header files processed
by the compiler.  System header files are ignored in the dependency
output.

The value of B<DEPENDENCIES_OUTPUT> can be just a file name, in
which case the Make rules are written to that file, guessing the target
name from the source file name.  Or the value can have the form
I<file>B< >I<target>, in which case the rules are written to
file I<file> using I<target> as the target name.

In other words, this environment variable is equivalent to combining
the options B<-MM> and B<-MF>,
with an optional B<-MT> switch too.


=item B<SUNPRO_DEPENDENCIES>

This variable is the same as B<DEPENDENCIES_OUTPUT> (see above),
except that system header files are not ignored, so it implies
B<-M> rather than B<-MM>.  However, the dependence on the
main input file is omitted.



=item B<SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH>

If this variable is set, its value specifies a UNIX timestamp to be
used in replacement of the current date and time in the C<__DATE__>
and C<__TIME__> macros, so that the embedded timestamps become
reproducible.

The value of B<SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH> must be a UNIX timestamp,
defined as the number of seconds (excluding leap seconds) since
01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 represented in ASCII; identical to the output of
B<@command{date +%s>} on GNU/Linux and other systems that support the
C<%s> extension in the C<date> command.

The value should be a known timestamp such as the last modification
time of the source or package and it should be set by the build
process.


=back

=head1 FOOTNOTES


=over 4

=item 1.

On some systems, B<gcc -shared>
needs to build supplementary stub code for constructors to work.  On
multi-libbed systems, B<gcc -shared> must select the correct support
libraries to link against.  Failing to supply the correct flags may lead
to subtle defects.  Supplying them in cases where they are not necessary
is innocuous.

=back
